column2: Ten more wounded at Fort Pillow, picked up a few days since from their hiding places, where they had been suffering since the battle, have been brought up to the Mound City Hospital.

The examination in the case of John W. Hunter, charged with defrauding the Government, was continued yesterday afternoon. In the absence of Judge Pierrepont, Sidney Webster, Esq., appeared for the accused, and opened the case for the defence in a few eloquent remarks, giving a statement of what he expected to prove by the witnesses for Mr. Hunter, and placed the case before the court and the public in a new light.

A force of from ten to fifteen thousand rebels marched upon Plymouth, N.C., last Sunday, and opened an impetuous attack upon its defences. Fort Gray, about one mile from the town, was vigorously bombarded, and twice attempted to be carried by the bayonet. In each instance, however, the enemy were repulsed with great slaughter, and the town is considered impregnable to their assaults.

AMBROSE W. CLARK, of New-York, (Union,) from the Committee on Printing, made a report, the design of which is to secure the continuation of the publication of the Congressional Globe by additional compensation. The report was recommitted, with instructions.
Yesterday, the fifteenth day of the Fair, was another very successful one. The buildings were crowded from morning till night, and the receipts for sales were very large.

Exaggerated rumors prevail in reference to the call of the War Department upon Gov. SEYMOUR for the State militia. These rumors grow out of intelligence received here from the War Department that State troops will be received by Gen. DIX for guard and other special duty in and around the harbor and forts of New-York, during the absence of the volunteer forces recently stationed there.

A great weight is lifted from people's minds in France: the official paper announces that MAXIMILIAN is to be invested with the title of Emperor of Mexico on Sunday next, and is to sail the day after for Vera Cruz. So that long agony is over, and you can hardly imagine what a nightmare has been dissipated by the announcement.

In the Court of Sessions, yesterday, SARAH JANE McPHERSON pleaded guilty to an attempt at grand larceny, and was sent to the Penitentiary for one year. MARY TERRY and CHARLES KREPPLES were tried for grand larceny, and acquitted. District-Attorney HUTCHINGS abandoned the prosecution in these cases for want of evidence. CATHERINE CONNOLY pleaded guilty of forgery in the fourth degree, and was remanded for sentence.

The Senate this morning reconsidered the vote of yesterday, by which the Senate bill providing to nationalize the State banks was lost. This vote prevailed, and the Assembly bill passed the Senate without amendment, and by the following vote:

Yesterday, the sixteenth day of the fair, and the first on which tickets were sold for 25 cents, was an excellent day. The buildings were kept constantly filled. Over fourteen thousand tickets were received at the door, the largest number taken on any one day since the opening of the fair, and the receipts were very satisfactory. The season tickets were not used yesterday, and the buildings in consequence, though crowded, were not jammed.

JOHN W. DOBBINS, a deserter from the United State army, was hanged at Dayton, on Friday, for the murder, on the 14th of February 1863, of a farmer named LINDENMOOD, who had wandered out of town with DOBBINS, both being intoxicated, when the latter killed him and robbed him of his money. DOBBINS was arrested soon after, and tried in the June following. The jury failed to agree; was tried in November and convicted.

We have had no direct communication from there since Monday, and so we know but little of what has occurred, and what the result of the battle. I stated in my last communication that probably Plymouth was in the hands of the enemy, and the most reliable information confirms the supposition.

FELLOW-CITIZENS: Once more time has brought the period when, by established usage, we should address you a few words before returning to our homes.

The City of New-Orleans is still the theatre of operations of great interest. In the courts, in the streets, in the shops, and all around the City, there are a thousand matters of great interest to the Government, to liberty and to humanity.
The following is the message from Gov. SEYMOUR, to which reference has already been made by telegraph:

Probably a more perplexing or more painful responsibility has never devolved upon the President than that of making good his order threatening retaliation for any violation of the laws of war upon our colored soldiers.
The following letter from the President of the Refugee Relief Committee of Ohio, has been addressed to Col. B.P. BAKER, the Ohio State Military Agent, resident in this City:

The grand military and civic ball given by the Twelfth Regiment National Guard, S.N.Y. in aid of the widows and orphans of deceased New-York soldiers, took place last evening, at the Academy of Music, and was one of the most successful and brilliant of the season.
The Navy Department has received a communication dated April 22, from Commander Fox, commanding the Potomac Flotilla, in relation to a recent expedition up the Rappahannock.
The reported death of Col. LEWIS BENEDICT is confirmed by letters from Grand Ecore, near the scene of the engagement.
We have spoken already of the great Act of Emancipation, offered by the Russian Government to Poland, as showing both the wisdom and liberal spirit of the Emperor.

We have received a copy of the introductive report of the Commissioner of Patents (D. P. HOL LOWAY.) It is an interesting and important document. It gives the following statistics of the operations of the office:

AFFAIES IN THE ARMY. The latest intelligence from the front to-day left everything quiet there. A heavy reconnoissance into the valley developed the fact that no considerable body of rebels are this side the Rapidan. The belief was general that LEE would not venture an offensive movement. A report prevailed to-day at the front that LEE was removing his heavy artillery to Richmond.
New-Mexican papers of the 16th state that Capt. ARCHER, late Quartermaster of Arizona, under Gen. WEST, recently absconded into Old Mexico.

We have made, during the past two years, an ample trial of the plan of subduing the South by fighting the Confederates with small and isolated detachments, and as it does not seem to work well, we presume there must be some flaw in it, and think it ought to be examined by the authorities. It was "inaugurated" by "Little Mac" on...

Reports from Plymouth have it that our flag still floats over our fortifications in that place, though the enemy have possession of the town and river. It is said that Gen. WESSELS retired with his force into the fortifications with fifteen days' provisions. This report appears to be believed. On the arrival of more gunboats we shall be able to reach Plymouth and ascertain the facts.
Late Little Rock dates say Mr. ALLIS, of Jefferson County, has been elected Speaker of the Arkansas Legislature.
The steamer Moonlight has arrived from Newbern, N.C.

A report, hardly credible, comes from Newbern, under date of the 23d, that Gen. WESSELS, with his force, was still holding the fortifications at Plymouth, the rebels having only gained possession of the town. Although the rumor was believed at Newbern, it is altogether improbable.

The Board of Supervisors met yesterday and transacted a large amount of business. An ordinance appropriating $800,000 (making $2,000,000 in all) for the construction and completion of the new County Court-house was adopted. The money is to be raised on a six per cent loan, upon bonds to extend twenty-one years, as authorized by a recent act of the Legislature. The Mayor sent in two veto messages, one in regard to bills...

THE RETIRING OF NAVAL OFFICERS. Mr. HALE, of New-Hampshire, (Union,) introduced a bill to amend the act to provide for the efficiency of the navy, which provides that no officer shall be retired under the age of sixty-two, and whose name shall not have been borne upon the Navy Register forty-five years after the age of sixteen. Referred to the Naval Committee.
There have been no arrivals or departures of moment.
The muster of the State Militia, yesterday, was well attended.
The Petersburgh (Va.,) Express of April 22, says:

The announcement of a trot for a purse of $100 on this track, for which there were no less than twelve entries, and in which the much-talked-of gelding, General Grant, who, it will be remembered, was most ignominiously defeated last week by Stonewall Jackson, although at starting the odds were 3 to 1 on the former, attracted a few adventurous sportsmen...

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. Mr. MARETZEK'S announcement for the coming supplemental season will be found to-day under the proper "amusement" column. It states officially what we have already announced semi-officially, namely, that the attraction will be the " Huguenots," and that the prices of admission are to be slightly raised, to meet the exigencies of the times.

NEW-YORK, Tuesday, April 26, 1864 6 P.M. The receipts of the principal kinds of Produce since our last have been 55 bbls. Ashes, 7,501 bbls. Flour, 168 bbls. and 768 bags Corn Meal, 363 bushels Corn, 4,000 bushels Barley, 2,110 bushels Oats, 700 bushels Malt, 1,053 pkgs. Provisions, and 598 bbls. Whisky.
We have received Richmond papers as late as April 19, which furnish us the following interesting extracts:

Mr. GRIMES, of Iowa, (Union,) presented petitions of the wives, daughters and sisters of soldiers of the army, setting forth that the pay of their husbands, fathers and brothers is inadequate, and praying an increase of their compensation.

The mails from Calcutta to March 10, Hong Kong March 1, and Melbourne Feb. 25, are received. The commercial news has been anticipated, and, politically, there is nothing of importance. The new Japanese Embassy to Europe, consisting of 35 persons, had arrived at Hong Kong.
In the House of Commons, on the 12th, Mr. HORSMAN gave notice of his intention to offer the following resolutions:

With what will the President electrify the country before the meeting of the next Congress, which assembles now in less than thirty days? Will it be MAXIMILIAN'S recognition? Will it be France and England combining to raise the blockade? Will it be a victory? Of all the good news that the President could communicate, a victory would most electrify his fellow-citizens and most depress the public enemy.

The Memorial Diplomatique gives a long account of the reception of the Mexican deputation at Miramar. As the Archduke always throws open his park to the public on holidays, an immense crowd collected to witness the arrival of the procession. The account says:
The Inman steamer City of Baltimore, Capt MIREHOUSE, which left Liverpool at 3 o'clock on the afternoon of the 13th, and Queenstown on the 14th of April, arrived here yesterday.

There has been no little regret evinced in regard to the manner in which the preliminary acts for the laying of the corner-stone of the Shakespeare Mounment, on last Saturday, were committed or omitted. Mr. HACKETT, who for so many, ever so many, years has made us laugh at Falstaff and love sack, had, as is understood, charge of the matter.

GENERAL ORDER No. 1. The Eleventh and Twelfth Corps having been consolidated with the Twentieth Corps, the undersigned, in compliance with the orders from department headquarters assumes command.

A special dispatch to the Gazette, from Chattanooga, says on the 23d the rebels attacked our pickets near Nickajack Gap, killing five, wounding seven and capturing nineteen. Some of our men were killed after surrendering, and several of the wounded were cruelly butchered as they lay on the field.
Arrived, bark Clutha Bell, from Glasgow, in 180 days, with coal.

Yesterday Comptroller BRENNAN obtained certified copies of the City and County Tax Laws for 1864, which he sent a messenger to Albany to get, who was obliged to make the requisite copies in the office of the Secretary of State to secure them early, and to-day they will be submitted to the Common Council, accompanied with appropriate ordinance, in conformity with the figures contained in them.

The people of the North can, we are firmly persuaded, bear with ease twice as great burdens in the shape of debt and taxation as were ever imposed on any other people of the same size, as long as these burdens are fairly and equitably imposed, as long as proper pains are taken to avoid violent changes of policy, and violent disturbances of trade and industry. We are, therefore, still far ...
The House went into Committee of the Whole on the Internal Tax Bill.

All the Ministry have been returned, except Mr. FOLEY, Postmaster-General, who was defeated by a large majority.

Speculators are once more turning their attention to the coat market, and preparing to manipulate it, so as to inflate prices, impose on consumers, and enrich themselves at the public expense. In commercial circles, and through the press, representations are being made, with suspicious industry, to the effect that though there is no lack of coal at the mines, great difficulty is experienced in ...

One occurrence connected with the massacre at Fort Pillow, has aroused a more than usually deep feeling of indignation through all the loyal States. It is related that a United States officer, coming on a flagof-truce boat to take away the wounded, after the butchery, was so far forgetful of his position and honor, as to entertain in the most cordial manner, these barbarians just red with the blood of their horrible murders.

On the 6th instant Lord ROBERT CECIL moved in the House of Commons for an "Account of guns and other munitions of war shipped from the port of Liverpool for America during the years 1861 and 1862, showing the quantity, description, value, and port of destination."

Those most unreliable of news-bearers, the deserters, are now passing to and fro, in large number, from one army to the other. The Northern papers from time to time contain the stories of those who pass hitherward from the rebel lines, and the Southern papers, in like manner, contain the information conveyed by those who decamp from our lines.

The Morning Herald states that Lord CLARENDON'S mission to Paris is for the purpose of restoring more amicable relations between England and France, and dispelling the irritation recently manifested by the Emperor.
A fleet of gunboats appeared yesterday in Rappahannock River, twelve miles below Tappahannock. A dredging apparatus was sent in advance to search for torpedoes.

Facts showing the determined energy with which the rebels are concentrating troops in Virginia continue to multiply. The President to-day received a dispatch from Gen. BUTLER stating his belief that the rebel forces were withdrawing from North Carolina and hastening to reinforce LEE.

Cairo dates to the 26th, by mail, say that the steamboats Liberty and Belle, from Memphis, have arrived, the former with 128 bales of cotton for Evansville, and the latter with a number of men, horses, mules and wagons, belonging to the Sixteenth Army Corps, for Cairo, and 270 bales of cotton for St. Louis.

We are still without full official information of the brilliant affair of Plymouth. We learn, however, upon reliable authority, that skirmishing commenced on Sunday, continued briskly Monday and Tuesday, and on Wednesday the enemy's works were carried by assault in a most gallant manner. The Yankee Commander, Brig.-Gen. WESSELS, as will be seen...
The Inquirer of this city has a letter from Norfolk which says:

Steamer Josephine Thompson, Cundiff, Baltimore, W. Daizell. Ships America, (Br.,) Mortimer, Liverpool, Samuel Thompson's Nephew, City of Kandy, (Br.,) Kewley, Liverpool, Napier, Welsford Co.; W. Frothingham, Quarley, Havre, Boyd Hincken; Confidence, Cole, New Orleans, W. A. Nelson.

Mr. CLARK, President of the Senate pro tem., submitted a letter from the Secretary of the Interior, recommending the appropriation of $1,670 to adjust a settlement of the claims of the Orchard party and First Christian party of Onelda Indians in New-York.
[Passed April 25, 1864, three-fifths being present.] The People of the State of New-York, represented in Senate and Assembly, do enact as follows:

The Italian Consul-General in this City, Signor ANFORA DE LICIGNANO, has received a letter from Capt. ISOLA, of the frigate Re Galantuomo, announcing the gratifying intelligence of the safe arrival of that vessel at Terceira, one of the Azores. Capt. ISOLA states that his veasel sustained fearful damage from the storm which prevailed shortly after her departure from this port, but fortunately not a singe life was lost.
The Navy Department has received a communication from Rear-Admiral LEE, in which he says:

Mr. SCHENCK, of Ohio, (Union,) asked leave to offer a resolution calling on the President to furnish copies of all letters, notes, telegrams and other documents referred to in the President's Message of to-day, in connection with the answer to the inquiry whether FRANCIS P. BLAIR holds any appointment or commission in the military service of the United States.
This is a forty years' loan at five per cent. per annum, interest and principal, by special act of Congress, made payable in Gold, and also by special act this loan is ex empt from taxation.
The House went into Committee of the Whole on the State of the Union on the Internal Revenue Bill.

There was a general review of the whole army to-day, and, notwithstanding the coldness of the weather, it was largely attended. The enemy are quite active in front, and stirring times are looked for by all.

The steamer America, from New-Orleans on the 19th inst., arrived here about noon yesterday. The Era of the 19th contains late news from the army of Gen. BANKS. The transport steamer Black Hawk arrived here from Grand Ecore last evening, and her officers inform us that they have participated in a very exciting adventure since they were last here.

The offer of the Governors of the Western and Northwestern States of a large number of men according to report, one hundred thousand to man the Union garrisons and forts, thus freeing for service an important force of veterans, is one of the most inspiriting events of this war.
Passed April 25, 1864, three-fifths being present. The People of the State of New-York, represented in Senate and Assembly, do enact as follows:

The annexed correspondence explains itself. The people of Kentucky will see how the interview impressed the Governor, and they have his testimony to the good feeling and the sympathy of President LINCOLN and Secretary STANTON for the citizens of this State. We commend the Governor's letter to our readers.
The mails for Europe, by the Nova Scotian, via Portland, will close Friday, at 1.30 P.M.

The Union State Convention, called for the purpose of placing in nomination an Electoral ticket, and selecting delegates at large to the National Convention, and to take such action as it may deem proper, in reference to the approaching Presidential campaign, met here to-day.

THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing, Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents.

At a few minutes before 2 o'clock P.M., yesterday, Mr. E. HAYDOCK WHITE, as Chairman, called the adjourned meeting of commercial brokers to order. Mr. CHARLES TAYLOR, Secretary, read the minutes of the previous meeting, which were unanimously adopted.
THE COMMITTEE ON CLOTHING AND MEN'S FURNISHING GOODS, acknowledge the receipt of the following contributions to the U.S. SANITARY COMMISSION:

On last evening, Hon. WM. H. SEWARD, Secre tary of State, accompanied by the Ministers of Russia, France, Prussia, Italy, Belgium, Sweden, Brazil, Peru, Chilt and Costa Rica, and several ladies, visited the fair, where a very large assemblage of citizens were in waiting to receive them.
The Panama Railroad Company steamer Salvador, Capt. RATHBUN, from the Central American ports, arrived in our bay on the 5th inst., at noon. She brings the following freight:

WINTER GARDEN. Mr. MARETZEK'S promised season cannot take place. No fault attaches to the empresario. He always keeps his word with the public, even when a ruinous pecuniary loss is involved. The trouble in this case rests with a few German chorus singers, and is not likely to end until they are weeded out of the company.

The purse of $100, best 3 in 5, to wagons, yesterday, had originally 13 entries, but the result of the last few days reduced the appearances at the score to a trio, it appearing to be foregone conclusion that from the power Stonewall Jackson had previously shown, and the easy style in which he had disposed of his competitors, that the race was his own. The advantageous change in the weather had not...

We have before us a new and supplementary circular-petition to the National Executive Committee for a postponement of the Union National Convention. It is dated on Wednesday last, a month later than the other, but adds nothing thereto of any account, save the statement that "as far as we learn, the desire is quite general that...

HUNTSVILLE, Ala., Wednesday, April 20, 1864. We have exciting reports from Decatur. A rebel force, variously estimated at from 8,000 to 10,000, with considerable artillery, has been hovering around there for several days. The Ninth Illinois Infantry (mounted) first discovered the enemy some miles out from Decatur, on the 14th, while scouting. They have had several skirmishes with the rebels, who have been ascertained to be REDDY's command...
REPORTS FROM THE FRONT. Officers from the front to-night profess to believe that active operations will not be commenced just yet.

In the Senate, yesterday, the Red River disaster came up for discussion, in connection with a joint resolution offered by Mr. HENDERSON, of Missouri, to provide for the printing of the report of the Cotton Speculation Investigating Committee, of which Gen. McDOWELL was President.

In his proclamation to the people of Illinois, Gov. YATES says: On the 21st of April, the Governors of Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, Iowa, and Wisconsin submitted to the President of the United States a proposition to furnish volunteers from their respective States for the coming campaign:

The St. Louis correspondent of the Cincinnati Gazette writes that the largest Indian expedition ever fitted out on the continent is now moving toward Idaho, having for its object the subjugation or extermination of the Sioux Indians. The entire business of organizing, equipping and completing this mammoth enterprise has been conducted under Brig-Gen. SULLY headquarters in this city.

The sub-Committee on the Conduct of the War are here investigating the Fort Pillow massacre. It is thought they will exonerate Gen. HURLBUT, as it is generally conceded the force at his command was inadequate to deal vigorously with FORREST.

To the Editor of the New-York Times; My attention has been called to a malicious attack on me, in connection with the Fourth National Bank, in the financial columns of your paper of 28th inst. I cannot stoop to discuss statements so false and scurrilous. A sufficient refutation of them will be found in the following resolutions, unanimously adopted by the shareholders of that bank at a meeting held on Thursday last:

GARIBALDI has brought Summer, or the Summer has brought GARIBALDI. The weather is lovely the first we have had; and yesterday the working classes of London received the great Italian, and handed him over to the Duke of Sutherland one of the richest nobles of Scotland. The papers will tell you this, but they will not tell how it was done. I will try to do so.

It may be remembered that some weeks since we mentioned the arrest in Washington of Maj. F.S. BOND, one of the staff of Gen. ROSECRANS, for being in that city without proper leave, and that he was ordered to report to Gen. ROSECRANS for trial by court-martial at St. Louis. The St. Louis journals of the 14th bring the report of his trial.

-Some of the PROSPECTS OF THE WHEAT CROP. Some of the Western papers have said much about the effects of a bad Winter upon the growing wheat, but after careful inquiry the Cincinnati Gazette does not anticipate a diminution to exceed one-third, and even this is probably an excessive etstimate of the damage. A reconnoisance by a cavalry force under Gen. DEVENS to Madison Court-house demonstrates the fact that the rumors regarding a rebel force having crossed the Rapidan were unture. Gen. BURNSIDE is said to have visited Gen. GRANT at his headquarters yesterday, and...

The following correspondence and extracts furnish interesting details of the Central and South American news, received by the Champion:

A visit to the naval ship-yards, in the Metrpolis, reveals the fact that unusual activity prevails in the constructing of war steamers for the Government. The following vessels are now building here, some of them having been only commenced:
The advices from Carthagena are up to the 11th of last month, and more interesting than usual.

I have to-day come in possession of a secret circular, issued at Charleston five months before the firing on Sumter. The document is genuine. It is signed by one of the wealthiest and ablest lawyers of South Carolina, and the copy which I inclose to the Tribune was addressed to one of the most prominent and influential citizens of Alabama a Harisville rebel whom Gen. LOGAN ordered south of our lines.
Before Judge Betts. COLLISION PRIVILEGED TACK JURISDICTION.

The United States vs. William T. Poynton. The prisoner in this case pleaded guilty to an indictment against him for passing an altered Treasury note. He was brought up for sentence some days since, but made an application to the Court to suspend sentence, that an application might be made to...

The Congressional Republican caucus this morning agreed to ask for the appointment of a Joint Committee of Congress to investigate charges made against Secretary CHASE by FRANK BLAIR. Senator HOWE will offer a resolution to that effect in the Senate tomorrow. This action is demanded by Mr. CHASE'S friends, who desire to give an official and effectual refutation to the slurs heaped upon him.
We find the following account of the capture of the bark Sea Bride, in the Port Louis (Mauritius) Commercial Gazettee:

GENERAL ORDSRS, No. 179. Another, and among the last of the heroes of our "Second War of Independence," is gone. Brevet Maj.-Gen. JOSEPH GILBERT TOTTEN, Chief of Engineers of the United States Army, departed this life on the 22d inst., in this city, in his seventy-sixth year.

Those who are fond of drawing instruction from historical parallels, or who seek for political guidance by examining the analogies of different States, may consult, with no little interest at the present time, a comprehensive and learned monogram, by Gen. J. WATTS DEPEYSTER, of New-York, entitled "Secession in Switzerland and in the United States Compared."

The Belgian journals publish the following curious story: A widow lady, named TILMANNE, recently died at Charleroi, and the family of the deceased were three days back assembled at her residence for the purpose of hearing the will read.
The merchants of New-York will be gratified to know that the new Health Officer has commenced his duties in a manner which commends him to their confidence.
The U.S. transport steamship St. Mary, Capt. JOHN E. BARSTOW, from Brazos Santiago April 18, via Pass Cavailo April 20, arrived last evening.

The Yazoo, from New-Orleans, April 21, the Columbia, from the same port, April 23, via Havana, and the Merrimac, from New-Orleans direct, April 24, arrived at this port yesterday afternoon. We are indebted to the officers of the respective steamers for the prompt delivery of our news packages.

The Navy Department has received a communication from Rear-Admiral BAILEY, commanding the East Gulf Blockading Squadron, giving the details of two expeditions in the vicinity of St. Andrew's Sound, Fla., under the direction of Acting Volunteer Lieut. WM. R. BROWNE.
At Duppel the Prussians had connected their intrenchments with a new parallel, and without loss. The cannonading goes on night and day.

A private letter from an officer of the gunboat Essex, in Red River, published in the Cincinnati Commercial, gives this account of an interesting series of experiments at Fort De Russey:

The report of the General Agent (JOHN F. SEYMOUR, Esq.,) of the State of New-York, for the Relief of Sick, Wounded, Furloughed and Discharged Soldiers, has just been published. It is a document of great interest and contains a vast deal of useful information. Diagrams of the principal hospitals, the Gettysburgh Cemetery, the field of Antietam, , accompany the report.

Gov. VANCE spoke here to-day before an immense audience. The whole square was crowded with ladies and gentlemen. In his speech he showed that he had been in advance of Gov. BROWN and A. H. STEPHENS in opposition to the bill to suspend habeas corpus. He read a letter which he addressed to President DAVIS, protesting against the passage of the bill. He sent letters also to the Senators and Representatives in Congress.

A raider of the Army of the Potomac writes to the Biltimora American: "I give you a brief statement of the sufferings of the raiding prisoners that were under command of Col. DAHLGREN and Lieut.-Col. COOK.
The Europa arrived at Halifax yesterday morning after a stormy passage. She brings European dates as late as the 17th ult. via Queenstown.

B.F.TAYLOR, of the Chicago Journal, writes from Chattanooga: "Chattanooga is as busy as a hive in June. Formidable fortifications that will take the vim out of shell, and into which shot will blunder as harmless as beetles by candle-light, are going up all over the land

The steamers Yazoo, Columbia and Merrimac, bringing advices from New-Orleans to April 24, arrived at this port yesterday. That part of the military news which is apparently the most important, seems to be only the echo of that already received via Cairo.

The Newbern Times, of the 27th, states that up to Wednesday the rebels had not made their appearance in that vicinity and the general impression there was that PICKETT'S Division had been recalled to Virginia. Gen.PECK has been very busy in strengthening the fortifications and clearing the decks for action. The Times contains the following late particulars of the siege and capture of Plymouth:

Morton's Gold Pens are now sold at the same prices as before the commencement of the war; this is entirely owing to the Manufacturer's improvements in machinery, his present large Retail Business and Cashin-Advance System; for, until he commenced advertising, his business was done on Credit and strictly with the Trade.

The Toronto Leader publishes the following curious document: SIR: Your disinterested and noble support of the cause of constitutional right in the Southern States, as opposed to Yankee usurpation, entitles you to the gratitude of every Southern heart; and as a very humble officer in the Confederate army I herewith tender you mine.

Much interest has been felt in the bookselling world of London on the contemplated intention of Mr. HENRY G. BOHN to retire from business. It is about thirty years since he commenced in the same locality that he still occupies in York-street, Covent Garden in the old book branch of the profession.
The capture of Plymouth, including Gen. WESSELS and his command, by the rebels, is confirmed. Nothing is known of the movements of the rebels here. It is reported they have gone to Virginia.
To-night was set apart for the purpose of "speech-making." Although a majority of the House voted for the recess, not more than twenty members were present at the "Evening Session."

GENERAL ORDERS, No. 30. Many citizens of this department have gone voluntarily into the States in rebellion against the United States some to join the rebel army, others to aid and encourage the rebellion by their presence and otherwise who have left properly in real estate, slaves, stocks of various description, and other securities for money, in this department.
The steamer Universe, Capt. WATTS, arrived yesterday from Red River. She left Alexandria on the evening of the 19th inst., and reports all quiet there at that time.
The Royal Mail steamship Europa, from Liverpool 16th, via Queenstown 17th inst., arrived here at 3 o'clock this morning.

We have already published a letter from the United States Consul at Mauritius relative to the case of the bark Sea Bride. A correspondent of the Boston Traveller gives the following additional particulars:

On Saturday last, says the Times of the 27th, solemn funeral services were held in Newbern on the remains of Capt. FLUSSER. At 12 o'clock all licensed traders closed their places of business, and united in a tribute of respect to one whose memory will ever be green in the hearts of his associates.

Some days since we published a curious story regarding a man by the name of SANFORD, alias Gill, who succeeded in marrying a young lady in Palmyra by impersonating an officer in the Army of the Potomac, with whom she had been corresponding without ever having seen him. The denouement of the case is thus related by a correspondent of the Rochester Express, who writes under date of Lyons, April 27:

On the 18th inst., private JOEL BURGESS, of the Fifth Kansas Cavalry, reached Little Rock, having escaped from Shreveport, La., where he had been held by the rebels as a prisoner of war. Mr. BURGESS is a middle-aged man, of robust stature, and evidently a man of candor and intelligence. From his statement, as given in the Little Rock Union, we gather the follwing facts:

The operatives of England are the creators of the wealth of England. Without their industry she could not pay the interest of her enormous debt, could not meet the current expenses of her Government, could not maintain her present proud position among the nations.
Capt. MARTIN, the Provost-Marshal of Abingdon, brought here this morning a man calling him self STERLING KING, who was arrested at Abingdon suspected of being a Federal spy.

An Empire of Mexico has now been, added to the States of the world. The new sovereign took his departure yesterday for the seat of his Government, and with his arrival will commence one of the most remarkable experiments in the history of our own times.

The London Observer says that it is generally, believed that Lord CLARENDON has succeeded in establishing a complete understanding between Great Britain and France, to which Russia will probably adhere.
I met Gen. DUFF GREEN, the old Washington editor and printer, whom everybody knows, or has heard tell of, at Richmond, in the Fall of 1862.
A correspondent of the Norfolk Daily Advertiser, on board the gunboat Miami, gives the following account of the operations of the rebel ram:

ARSENAL. Yesterday afternoon an experiment was made at the Bridesburgh Arsenal, under the supervision of Major T.T.S. Dispatches from the Army of the Potomac furnish the usual stories relative to the fabulous strength which LEE is massing in front of Gen. GRANT. His infantry is reported by deserters to number eighty thousand, and his cavalry twenty-two thousand, all mounted, of course, on well-fed steeds, with ten days' rations issued every week for an advance which don't take place. The opinion is universal, both in the North and in the South, that this month of May will be a month of great battles. It was almost impossible, this year, to commence operations earlier.

It has come to be recognized as a natural law of society that the sins and evils of one class are visited upon other classes. If the rich be extravagant or corrupt in morals, the poor are injured by their influence. If the poor live in unhealthy physical conditions, their diseases pass over to those who have every comfort.

The Europa arrived at Halifax yesterday morning after a stormy passage. She brings European dates as late as the 17th ult, via Queenstown. The pirate Florida had found refuge in a Spanish port, her application for a supply of coal at a Portuguese port having been refused.

Advices from Camden, Arkansas, say that Gen. STEELE'S army is there. Gen. THAYER joined Gen. STEELE at Elkin's Ferry, on the Little Missouri River, where the rebels were driven from a line of breastworks commanding the river bottom.

In the Senate, Saturday, Mr. WILSON, introduced a resolution, which was referred to the Military Committee, that any officer whose resignation of a commission was accepted, shall not be entitled to hold or exercise com mand until again appointed by the President, with consent of the Senate.
The Yazoo, from New-Orleans, April 21, the Columbia, from the same port, April 23, via Havana, and the Merrimac, from New-Orleans direct, April 24, arrived at this port yesterday afternoon.

The Emperor MAXIMILIAN arrived at Rome on the 18th. His reception was brilliant. The French military bands played as he passed through the streets.

It was suddenly announced on Monday, the 18th, that Gen. GARIBALDI was unwell, that he was unequal to the excitement through which he was passing, and that in deference to the recommendation of his medical advisers he would bring his adjourn in England to a speedy termination, quitting London en route for Caprera on the 22d April.

EXPERIENCES OF A PIANO-FORTE MANUFACTURER IN THE SOUTH. Mr. POISSON, formerly welknown as a manufacturer of piano-fortes, has returned to this City, after a residence of several years in North Carolina, and advertises tn another column his intention to resume his old business at No. 478 Broadway.

A Richmond paper of Thursday says the languor in the commercial markets shows that the town people will have to live on half rations until the country people, who have provisions to spare, shall have heard of the defeat of GEANT'S army. We may then expect supplies from all quarters, and a revival of business on a descending scale of prices.

The reported capture of the steamship Bavaria by a Danish frigate proves unfounded. She reaches Southampton on the night of the 20th. She sails for New-York this evening.

By the arrival of the steamer Belle from Memphis we have one day's later dates from Memphis, and advices from Alexandria, Red river, to the 24th of April, at which place Gen. BANKS was then, and in a good position.

Gen. GRANT, by General Order, calls the particular attention of officers to regulations requiring all official correspondence to be conducted through proper channels. Violations of the regulations will be treated hereafter as disobedience of orders and will subject the writers of such communications to arrest.
The declaration of principles on the Mexican question voted unanimously by the House of Representatives at Washington, is variously appreclated by the French press.

Mr. HALE, of New-Hampshire, (Union,) from the Committee on naval Affairs, reported a bill providing for a board of competent persons to examine the claims of contractors for side-wheel gunboats, known as "double enders," It is claimed that the contracts were made under a misapprehension that the enginees were required subsequently to be enlarged, and other changes made.

A detachment of the First Colorado Cavalry had a fight yesterday with a band of Cheyennes numbering 200, at Cedar Canon, on the South Platte. The Indians were totally routed, with a loss of 25 killed, and 35 to 40 wounded. Over 100 horses were captured. One soldier was killed and one wounded.

Mr. FARNSWORTH, of Illinois, (Union,) offered a resolution that the Secretary of the Treasury inform the House whether there is employed in the Treasury Department a Clerk or Assistant Register, by the name of GARNETT, and whether said GARNETT has no held a position in the rebel army, if he was not a prisoner in the Old Capitol, and who recommended him for the position he now holds in the Treasury Department.

The steamship Matanzas, from New-Orleans April 26, via Havana April 28, arrived at this port yesterday morning.

The House took up the bill extending to soldiers and sailors, without regard to color, the benefits of the Homestead law on rebel confiscated lands.

The obsequies of Commodore WILLIAM DAVID PORTER took place yesterday afternoon. During the moring the body lay in state at the Governor's Room, City Hall, which was thronged with persons anxious to see the features of the dead hero.

As time moves on it brings us nothing new in regard to the siegs and fall of Plymouth. What little we hear, however, confirms previous reports of the horrible loss and barbarity of the enemy. The investigation into the causes of the boiler explosion on board the United States steamer Chenango, was finally concluded Tuesday, when Coronear NORRIS delivered his charge to the jury, in which all the circumstances connected with the disaster, as drawn from the testimony, are summed up.

At the Methodist General Convention to-day the Rev. Dr. CURRY made an address, which was very feebly applauded. He spoke in favor of having colored ministers in all the conferences. He was opposed to the formation of separate conferences for colored people. They must be brought into close connection with the white population be thought.

There are 369 numbers in the thirty-ninth annual catalogue of the National Academy of Design many of them representing works of art. All things considered, the show, in point of numbers, is creditable. Artists have been exposed to many and various temptations during the past year.

Leaving Nashville and penetrating southeasterly to this point, you enter what was formerly the country of the Creeks, and find it still a comparative wilderness. As you approach the mountains, signs of civilization become rare, and you feel that the link between you and the inhabited world is growing more and more attenuated.

Lieut.-Gen. GRANT has spoken the word, and the long-anticipated "forward march" of our great armies has begun. On the first secular day of the current month, the soldiers struck their tents by the Rapidan, and probably also by the Tennessee; and, with rifle and knapsack, with the enthusiasm of volunteers and the stern spirit of veterans, advanced to the struggle with the rebellion.

The Army of the Potomac began its forward march on Monday. The crossing of the Rapidan was effected without opposition on Tuesday and Wednesday at Culpepper, Jacobs', Germanna and Ely's Fords. No rebels were seen, except a few pickets, who retired as we advanced.

The veterans of 1812, '13 and '14, old men, whose patriotism is now as strong as ever, have addressed the following letter to GOV. SEYMOUR, by him it was forwarded to Gen. DIX, and by the General it has been forwarded to the Adjutant-General of the United States Army for his consideration.
The House went into Committee of the Whole on the special order, viz., the bill on reimburse Pennsylvania for the expenses incurred in calling out troops to repel invasion.

The news from the several armies of the Union this morning will be read with intense interest. Though we have yet no announcement of actual collison, there is the utmost assurance for stating and believing that the great armies under Gens. SHERMAN, MEADE and BUTLER are all well in motion, and but a few days can elapse are we have stirring news.

Michael Walsh and others vs. John Kelly Sheriff. This was an action for the recovery of property belonging, as claimed, to the plaintiff, which had been levied upon by the defendant as Sheriff of the City and County of New-York.

We published yesterday the constitution and the address of the new society in Washington among the ladies, for the promotion of economy in the purchase of foreign imports. This is undoubtedly a movement most wise and patriotic.

PHILADELPHIA ACADEMY OF MUSIC PRODUCTION OF MR. FRY'S NEW OPERA, NOTRE DAME OF PARIS. In accordance with extensive announcement, and after an amount of preparation that has rarely been bestowed on any wort of art, Mr. FRY'S opera of "Notre Dame of Paris" was produced at the Philadelphia Academy on Wednesday evening.
This is a forty years' loan at five per cent, per annum, interest and principal, by special act of Congress, made payable in Gold, and also by special act this loan is exempt from taxation.

We have no news from Bogota, the capital of the Republic, although a few private letters reached the Isthmus from there by the British steamship Mexican, from Santa Martha last week. We have a report that the Congress of Bogota have modified, or have under consideration a law modifying, the late restrictions upon the church, which have caused so much trouble here and elsewhere in the country the past year.
WM.C. BRYANT, ESQ. Sir: I have received a printed circular to which your and other distinguished names are attached, urging the postponement of the National Convention.

There was a large attendance, yesterday afternoon, at the regular monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce. President A.A. Low presided. A communication was received from Mr. W.C. BRYANT, presenting to the chamber, on behalf of Mr. MORRIS KETCHUM, a portrait of Mr. CORDEN. The picture was accepted with a vote of thanks to Mr. KETCHUM.
We have been waiting for the verdict of the Coroner's jury in the case of the Chenango before making the inquest the subject of comment; but no verdict seems to be forthcoming.

The steamship Ocean Queen, from Aspinwall, April 26, arrived at this port yesterday. The Government of Nicaragua had concluded a contract with Capt. PRIM to build an Interoceanic Railroad. Advices from Lima state that the question between Peru and Spain had reached an alarming stage.
The draft in the First Ward yesterday, passed off quietly. Among those drawn is ALFRED GAITHER, Superintendent of the Adams' Express Company. Several other prominent citizens were also drafted.

The Red River expedition, as far an offensive campaign against the rebels is concerned, is for the present at an end. Gen BANKS and army are now falling back upon this place, the advance of the baggage trains having arrived last night. The whole army will be here in a day or two.

It can have escaped no one's memory that on the occasion of nearly every great battle since the war commenced, one of the first appeals to public feeling and sympathy has taken the shape of an urgent request for supplies of material for bandages for the wounded.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: It is proper that you should give both sides of the matter at issue between the Park Commissioners and the National Guard as the subject has been brought before the public by the action of Col. MAIDHOFF.

THE SPECULATORS AT WORK. It is all well to charge the high and rapidly increasing prices of everything to the inflation of the currency. But a great deal of this increase is due to the direct combinations of speculators, who take advantage of the public notions on this subject to keep supplies out of market until they can force prices to a very high figure.

We give below an alphabetical table of the principal amendments to the Tax Bill, made during its passage through the House of Representatives. All the amendments affecting the rates of taxation will be found there; some of those affecting the duties of officers, or the machinery of the bill, we have no deemed it important to insert, as they were not of general interest.

Look where you will over the wide field of battle, there stands prominently in the foreground one object which not all the pomps and pageantries of war, or the thousand evils which follow in its train, can more than temporarily shut from view. That object is the Negro.

The vessels-of-war now being built at Jersey City are progressing finely. There are about 400 hands constantly employed on the iron-clads Manhattan, Mahopac, and the iron double-ender, Mohongo, at the yard of the Messrs. SECOR. The Manhattan is already launched, turret up, gun carriages being lowered, and about 200 hands are busy upon her decks

WINTER GARDEN. Mr. EDWIN BOOTH will appear here to-night in his great character of "Richard the Third." The success of this gentleman during the week bas been almost without a parallel; and it has been universally remarked by press and public that he has never been seen to such advantage.

The Ike Davis is just in from Alexandria. It is useless to disguise the fact that we are meeting with reverses and disasters from every quarter. There are but three feet of water on the falls at Alexandria, and the greater part of our fleet of transports and gunboats are above.

BASE BALL NEWS. Ninth annual opening day of the Enterprise Club of Bedford, L.I. This veteran club having, through the kindness of Messrs. WEED DECKER, secured the famous Capitoline Ball Grounds for their use on their regular practice days, which will be Wednesday and Saturday afternoons of each week during the ensulting season, will commence play at 2 o'clock P.M., this day.

The Board of Councilmen met yesterday. The only business transacted was to consider and pass upon the general appropriation ordinance, which had been received from the Board of Aldermen on Wednesday. It was finally concurred in by a large vote, without amendment.

BLAIR is not, and the other that Mr. KNOX, the contestant, is entitled to a seat in the House as the Representative of the First Congressional District of Missouri.

A gunboat from the Red River brings information that finding it impossible to get the Eastport off and being attacked by the enemy while endeavoring to lighten her, Admiral PORTER ordered her to be destroyed to prevent her falling into hands of the enemy.

The news from the Armies in Virginia is of a highly interesting character. The most important part of it, however, is the announcement of Gen. BUTLER'S successful landing at City Point, Va., and the report of the occupation of Petersburgh by the rebel General BEAUREGARD, with 30,000 men.

FIVE MEN DROWNED FOUR OF THEM UNKNOWN. An unknown man, about forty years of age, five feet seven inches in height, stout built, with long, dark hair and whiskers, was found floating in the water at the foot of Thirty-fourth-street, East River, Deceased was dressed in a block coat and pants, brown vest, gray woolen stockings and laced shoes. Coroner COLLIN held an inquest on the body....The

Nearly all fair-minded persons who have investigated the subject, agree now that French socialism brought forth from its fanciful theories, one great economical fact which is of immense importance to the well-being of the working classes: the existence and the utility of "Cooperative Societies." A recent writer in the London Spectator has given a most valuable account of such of these associations as have survived the fall of Socialism, among the workingmen of Paris.

Up to the hour of going to press, we have received no news from Virginia really later than that given to the public yesterday afternoon. A battle was begun on Thursday, and probably renewed on Friday. After Gen. GRANT had crossed the Rapidan, it seems he was met by, LEE, with his whole force marching up from his defences on the Gordonsville road.

Charles C. Rittenhouse et al. vs. The Indepen dent Telegraph Company. This was an action brought to recover damages from the Independent Telegraph Company for alleged carelessness in the transmission of a dispatch producing an error, by which plaintiffs claim to have suffered loss.

Gov. CURTIN, on April 30, communicated to the Legislature, by special message, the fact that Congress as yet has made no provision for the payment of the money advanced by the banks for the pay of the troops called out for the emergency in 1853.

JUDGE STELLO DEAR SIR: Since you asked my judgment as to the course to be taken in nominating a candidate for the Presidency. I have been requested to sign a call for a convention for that purpose, to meet at Cleveland, in May next.

The demonstrations in England in honor of the tercentenary of SHAKESPEARE were in full swing. In Liverpool they had gone off with great eclat. The interdiction of the English Shakespeare banquet at Paris was withdrawn on the 22d.

As the train from Brandy Station was on the way down this morning, when about three mills this side of Bull Run, it was fired into by guerrillas concealed in the woods. A volley was returned by the guard on the train.

The Mayor, Comptroller and City Inspector met yesterday, to take action in regard to cleaning streets under the provision therefor in the tax levy. The opinion of the Corporation Counsel in regard to the construction of the clause in the tax levy relating to cleaning the streets was read, approved and ordered on file.

The New-York Ladies' Educational Union have purchased a beautiful and commodious property in Flushing, L.I., where they have permanently eatablished their institution for the protection and education of the children of our soldiers, both of the army and navy. The building will accommodate three hundred. They have now in charge one hundred and daily applicants are begging, through parents or friends, to be admitted. The ladies are anxious to...

The stated meeting of the Managers was held at the Bible House, Astor-place, on Thursday, the 5th inst., at 3 o'clock P.M., JAMES LENOX, Esq., President of the society, in the Chair, assisted by BENJAMIN L.SWAN and FRANCIS HALL, Esqs., Vice Presidents.

The Thirty-seventh Regiment N.G.S. N.Y,, were Friday afternoon mustered into the service of the United States for thirty days, by Capt. BARSTOW, United States Army. The regiment received their uniforms in the morning, and about 4 o'clock in the afternoon they formed line, and marched down Broadway to the Battery, where they embarked, on their way to Forts Richmond and Tompkins, which they are to garrison.
The Examiner of the 26th thus discourses about Miss Dr. WALKER, who is well-remembered as a notoriety-loving female M.D. in this city:

SIR: You have done me the honor to refer to me a communication to yourself from his Excellency JOHN A. ANDREW, Governor of Massachusetts, with accompanying papers, relative to the claim of Rev. SAMUEL HARRISON for pay as Chaplain of the Fifty-fourth regiment of Massachusetts Volunteers.

The statements which were received here today, and which are entitled to belief, are that Gen. LEE made a tremendous and violent attack to pierce our centre, hoping thereby to divide our forces and to secure a victory; but Gen. HITCHCOCK'S corps came to the relief, and, amid a murderous fire, formed in line of battle, and thwarted the designs of the rebels. The loss was heavy on both sides.

We learn that Gen. IMBODEN, in addition to his other duties, is now organizing the reserve forces of Virginia in the counties of Botetouri, Roanoke, Craig, Rockingham, Pendleton, Highland, Augusta, Bath, Rockbridge, Alleghany, Page, Shenandoah, Hardy, and such portions of the country lower down the Valley as can be controlled.

The steamer Hillman has arrived here with one day later advices from Memphis. The advance of Gen. STURGIS' cavalry, 700 strong, with two pieces of artillery, encountered a band of FORREST'S men,1,000 strong, near Boliver, Tenn., on the south side of the Hatchie River, on Monday last.

Wednesday, City Inspector BOOLE suggested to the Common Council, the means by which to rid the City of the pest of fat-boiling establishments. It appears that the ordinances in regard to this class of nuisances, which are treated as being dangerous to the heatlth of the City, extend only to bone-boiling in fact, covering nearly all things in the manufacturing line, that produce stench, which might engender disease, except fat-boiling.

The President pro tem, presented the resignation of Rev. BYRON SUNDERLAND, Chaplain. Mr. RAMSEY, of Michigan, (Union.) introduced a bill making an additonal grant of land to aid in constructing a railroad from St. Paul to a point between Big Stene Lake and the mouth of the Sioux Wood River. Referred to the Committee on Public Lands.
The following is a synopsis of the bi-monthly report for March and April of the Agricultural Department:

NASHVILLE, Tonn., Wednesday, May 4, 1864. The United States, Circuit and District Courts have been in session for three weeks, and during that time have transacted an immense amount of business. The decisions of the Circuit Court in cases of Southern indebtedness, have been decidedly favorable to Northern creditors, among whom are A. T. STEWART Co., and HARPER BROTHERS.
The city has been intensely excited all day with the news from the Army of the Potomac, the early publications serving to excite the public curiosity concerning the military movements.
From Gov. BUCKINGHAM'S Message to the connecticut Legislature, we make the following extracts:

We have highly important news from the Southwest. On the 25th ultimo, a wagon train, consisting of two hundred and forty wagons, was capturerd by the rebels while returning to Pine Bluff, together with the escort, under the command of Col. DRAKE, comprising the Twenty-sixth, Iowa Regiment, the Seventy seventh Ohio Regiment, and the Fortythird Indiana Regiment, with four pieces of artillery.

There is as yet no positive news as to whether or no there will be a draft in this City. Gen. HAYES has gone to Washington to consult with the authorities there on the matter, and is ex pected to return on Monday, when it is probable some official information will be given on the subject.

The General-Commanding publishes the following instructions to the men just entering the service of their country. He expects every old soldier, who has learned their value by experience, will join in impressing their importance on those who are now to share with him the honor of a soldier's life:

The movement to discourage the use of imported goods where native substitutes can be procured, is worthy of encouragement, and this subsititution can be made with much greater case and to a far greater extent than is generelly believed. Indeed, we know of many kinds of homemade goods which are usually sold as foreign, and which are fully equal in quality and finish to anything in the same line that can be imported.

A considerable sensation was produced on the streets yesterday, by rumors that a force of rebels had succeeded in reaching the Baltimore Road at New-Creek and Pledmont, and in destroying a large amount of Government and railroad property at those points. For some hours early in the day no telegraphic communication could be had with those points, and it was impossible to get at the truth of the rumors afloat.

In separating from a body of officers and men whom I have so long commanded, it would be improper and inconsistent with my feelings if I did not give some testimonial of services rendered and duties performed by this Corps. On motion of Alderman JONES to refer the Tax Law and Appropriation Ordinance to the Finance Committee, with instructions to report in half an hour.

The latest United States papers contain the very violent indignation of the Yankees over the alleged Fort Pillow "massacre." The world opposes the slaugnter of the innocent prisoners, which has been recommended, and advises Mr. LINCOLN to make on the Richmond authorities "a demand for the surrender of FORREST, or whatever officer was in immediate command of the soldiers by whom the massacre was committed."
On Tuesday night, the 3d inst., about one-half of the large fleet of transports that have been lying in the Roads for some time were ordered to Yorktown, and commenced embarking troops on Wednesday.

The special correspondent of the Rochester Democrat, with the army, has arrived in Washington with the following account of operations up to Friday morning:

The National Republican has the following: We are glad to be able to state that the result of the fighting on Thursday and Friday is all that the most sanguine friends of the Government can desire. The dawn of day on Saturday exhibited no evidence of the presence of the enemy. Gen. GRANT with great promptness took advantage of the fact and ordered a forward movement.

Although the Brazil Steamship Aid Bill passed the Post-office Committee in the Senate on Thursday, there is an apparent hesitancy, natural enough perhaps, to take decisive action on the measure at once. The reasons attributed to the opponents of the measure for delaying action are, we think, of doubtful validity.
We have no official reports from the front, but the Medical Director has notified the Surgeon-General that our wounded were being sent to Washington, and will number from six to eight thousand.

The news from Louisiana continues to get worse and worse. Gen. BANKS has given up all thoughts of a forward movement, and seems to be just now occupied mainly in devising means to get back to the Mississippi. He has lost one-third of his army, twenty or thirty guns, perhaps twice as much baggage as the force which defeated him has had in...

It is often remarked that the best measure of the real meaning of events is to be found in the stock market. The state of the Government funds, for instance, after the announcement of a victory, is a far truer indication of the public judgment than the official bulletins or the articles of journalists. To a certain degree this is true.

The latest news from the army received here is up to seven o'clock yesterday evening, at which time GRANT fully maintained his position. The fighting on Thursday and Friday was very severe, with skirmishing only on Saturday. LEE'S first onset was made upon our left, but failing he then fell upon our centre and finally upon our right, where the hardest contest took place.

Major-Gen. John A. Dix, New-York: We are yet without any official dispatches from the Army of the Potomac, except those referred to this morning from the Medical Director and Chief Quartermaster, and nothing additional has been received by the department from any other source. It is believed that no fighting took place yesterday.

Lieut.-Gen. Grant, Commanding Armies of the United States, Washington, D.C.: We have seized Wilson's Wharf Landing. A brigade of WILD'S Colored troops are there. At Fort Powhatan Landing two regiments of the same brigade have landed. At City Point HINKS' Division, with the remaining troops and battery, have landed. The remainder of both the Eighteenth and Tenth Army Corps are being landed at Bermuda Hundreds, above the Appomattox.

On Friday night last, our pickets on the creek that runs through the marsh on the western side of Morris Island, succeeded in capturing two boats containing sixteen rebels, who had come down from Charleston on a scouting expedition. The capture was made by a party of the Fitty-fourth Massachusetts (colored) Regiment; Capt. HENESSEY, of the Fifty-second Pennsylvania, acting as officer of the picket line at the time.

A verdict was rendered in our Court of Common Pleas, on Saturday, which establishes, so far as that court is concerned, a principle of marked importance in regard to the liability of Telegraph Companies for the accuracy of their dispatches. It seems that a firm telegraphed to their agents here to sell 500 shares of Southern Michigan stock at the Morning Board, and buy 500 Hudson in the afternoon.

The time has come for the campaign to begin. It is just a year since the sturdy boys "of ours" (the Twenty-first New-Jersey) and the other regiments assigned, flung away their knapsacks, and, with one hurried thought of home, and years compressed in a moment, rushed on through shot and shell till we stood on the impossible heights of Fredericksburgh. The first look around on Marye's Hill showed us the shaft of an imposing monument.

Many of the tonic preparations which are now giving universal satisfaction to the public were donoted [to the fair] in large quantities; prominent in the list was a generous invoice of Golden Bittters, from the manufacturers, GEORGE C. HUBBEL Co., of Hudson, N.Y., and whose warehouse is in the Amercan Express Building, No. 55 Hudson-street, in this City.

The great and salient fact in the intelligence from Virginia this morning, is the confirmation of yesterday's announcement that LEE had retreated from before Lieut.Gen. GRANT. His fight commenced on Friday night, immediately after the drubbing...

The work of landing the troops, stores, horses and artillery, went on last night with uncommon dispatch, considering that the necessary wharves had first to be constructed. The shallow water near the banks of the James River at this point, does not admit of the very close approach of the transports, and pontoon bridges and other temporary landing-places had to be made.

Mr. SUMNER has introduced a bill into the Senate, which, owing to the general absorption of the public attention in the great events which are taking place in the field, will probably not attract much notice, but it nevertheless attempts to deal with a matter which is of more importance, we venture to say, to the stability of this Government, than any other one thing except the extinction of the rebellion.

I was in error in my last night's letter in saying that the Petersburgh and Richmond Railroad had been tapped by Gen. HECKMAN at its junction with the City Point branch. The information was brought to me, and I unfortunately used it without stopping...
The Democrat of this morning publishes the following: The expedition of Gen. STEELE towards Shreveport has ended with his return, under rather exciting circumstances, to Little Rock.

Though comparatively an off day, and out of the programme, there was a goodly attendance at the Fashion yesterday, to witness the match for $500, half forfeit, mile heats, best three in five, to wagons, between the two Harlem horses the gray gelding Sam and the bay gelding Billy both celebrated on the road, and both having numerous partisans.

The news this morning fully confirms all that was promised yesterday. Gen. GRANT'S victory brightens and looms up in importance as time brings us fuller particulars. The official dispatches from Gens. GRANT and MEADE announce that LEE began his retreat on Friday night, and on Saturday morning he was promptly pursued by our army.

Lieut. JACKSON, First Michigan Cavalry, of Gen. GRANT'S Staff, arrived here this afternoon, with dispatches for the Secretary of War. He left headquarters Sunday, with a small escort, and reached Rappahannock Station the same night. The news he brings confirms the previous reports of the final success of our arms. On Thursday the enemy attempted their old game of massing their forces to break our lines,...

During the month of April the Fourth Auditor of the Treasury settled 3,299 claims for prize money, amounting to $506,933,76. Awards have recently been made in the cases off the Weehawken, Cimmerone and Nahant. First-class firemen receive $353, seamen $320, landsmen $213 and cooks $427.

The schooner Eliza Sheddon, bound for NewYork, has just arrived here from Newbern, and reports that the enemy made a demonstration on Newborn yesterday, cutting off the railroad communication between that place and Beaufort, and making his appearance on the south side of the Neuse River,

Gen. WADSWORTH'S death excites feelings of intense regret everywhere. There has been no instance in this war of a more high-toned surrender of comfort, fortune and life itself to principle, than that afforded in his career.

There is nothing particularly new from the front to-day. The weather has been so insufferably hot that neither the rebels nor ourselves have been in anxious mood to fight.

The Army of the Potomac has had a portion of a day to recuperate. Gen. BURNSIDE on Monday began the attack on the left with great fury, and with an encouraging degree of success. He had a fight the day before, in which, to use his own words, he "whipped old LONGSTREET."
To Maj.-Gen Dix: Dispatches have been received this evening from Lieut.-Gen. GRANT dated at 1 o'clock yesterday.

Brig.-Gen. HAYS returned from Washington yesterday, and ordered a postponement of the draft in this City and in the Second District of Brooklyn. The following is the circular addressed by Gen. HAYS to the various Provost-Marshals:

The United States Sanitary Commission sent, this morning, to Aquia Creek a steamboat, which had been previously chartered and loaded with some seventy or eighty tons of hospital stores; also, a barge loaded with wagons and horses for transporting these supplies to Fredericksburgh or elsewhere.

Information has been received to-night that the rebel ram in Albemarie Sound has been attacked and sunk by the United States steamer Sassacus.
The jury in the case of the boiler explosion on the U.S. steamer Chenango, have at length come to an agreement the majority deciding upon one verdict and the minority upon another.

Accounts from the Army of the Potomac concur that there was heavy fighting yesterday, and that at about 5 o'clock in the afternoon an attack was made upon the rebel batteries. It is stated that after the assault was continued for some time, and it was found that the rebel batteries could not be carried without probably a great sacrifice of life, the effort was for the time abandoned.

The Inman steamship City of Manchester, with Liverpool dates to the 27th ult., and Queenstown to the 28th, arrived here yesterday. The London Shipping Gazette states that the two new rebel steamers, Shanghai and San Francisco, have been launched at Nantes. No mystery, it is...

The Army of the Potomac has had a portion of a day to recuperate. Our army could not be in a more cheerful condition. All the men are sanguine of success, and they count the days when they shall in triumph enter the rebel capital.

The grand army movements in the East have absorbed every other excitement during the past week. With all our confidence in Gen. GRANT, the former experiences of the Army of the Potomac causes us to "bate our breath" as the news of its advance is flashed to us over the wires.

The latest news received here from Gen GRANT'S army relates to the operations of Monday and yesterday. The fight on Monday evening was very severe, inflicting a loss on our side of over two thousand men killed and wounded. It was brought on by HANCOCK, who, in his effort to take Spottsylvania Court-house, accomplished the crossing of the River Po under cover of a tremendous artillery fire, and established himself on the south bank.

Dispatches from the Army of the Potomac have just reached here, bearing dates to 5 o'clock P.M., of yesterday. Both armies at that time held their positions at Spottsylvania Court-house, without any material change.

Gen. LEE is determined to hold Richmond; Lieut.-Gen. GRANT is determined to take it. LEE defends the approaches to it with great vigor; GRANT overcomes obstacles and steadily advances upon it by his indomitable perseverance. It is a week to-day since

Gov. SEYMOUR has telegraphed Adjt.-Gen. SPRAGUE, at Washington, to receive the remains of Gen. WADSWORTH, on behalf of New-York State, and make all necessary arrangements for transporting the body home.

Gen. ROBINSON suffers much from his wound, which is in the knee. His division was in the advance on the Spottsylvania road, from Todd's Tavern, with Gen. PHIL. SHERIDAN'S cavalry, and had driven the rebels about six miles, carrying two positions they had endeavored to hold on to.
The Commissioners of Health, held an adjourned meeting yesterday, the President (Mayor GUNTHER,) in the Chair.

Provisions, and 730 bbls, Whiskey.
The House resumed the consideration of the Senate's amendments to the Consular and Diplomatic Appropriation Bill.

The important race for the "Two Thousand Guineas Stakes" at Newmarket resulted in the victory of Lord GLASGOW'S horse Gen. Peel, Mr. TEN BROECK'S horse Paris running second. The winner was immediately made first favorite in the betting for the Derby.

We cannot too highly commend the system of transmitting military news to the country, inaugurated by Secretary STANTON since the opening of the present campaign. These War Office dispatches have embraced the latest authentic intelligence received by the Government from the Army of the Potomac, and from the cooperating army on the James, as well as from the army of Gen. SHERMAN, in Georgia, and its cooperating columns.
It is reported that last night our headquarters were two miles in advance of Spotisylvania Courthouse.

Dispatches from the Army of the Potomac speak of Gen. WRIGHT, who succeeds the late Gen. SEDGWICK, as an able soldier, and who will not fall to secure the confidence of those over whom he is placed.

Dispatches have been received from Gens. GRANT and MEADE giving an account of operations up till dark on Monday. At that time our army was closely pressing LEE'S retreating columns, Every inch of ground was stubbornly contested by the rebels. We have captured many prisoners. The loss on both sides is very heavy.

The intelligence from Gen. GRANT'S army in Virginia is up to Tuesday evening at 5 o'clock, at which time he was steadily forcing LEE back, and driving him out of one strong position after another. SIR: I had the honor to inform you, in my communication No. 106, of the sinking of the Eastport while proceeding down to Alexandria, caused by the explosion of a torpedo under her bottom, and near her bow. On hearing this bad news I proceeded at once to the vessel, and found her sunk to the gundeck, the water over it on one side.

News received to-day continues to be of a most satisfactory character.

Dispatches from General Grant have been received by this Department down to seven o'clock this morning. There had been no engagement for the last two days.
In six distinct bulletins, admirable for their brevity and distinctness, the Secretary of War sums up the whole of the news from the armies East and West, which had reached the Depart-...

We surrender a large space this morning to a Secession speech in the English House of Lords from the Earl of Derby, and to a sensible and conclusive reply from Lord JOHN RUSSELL. Both are of marked interest and importance. They will produce, on both sides...

The storm has burst! Those who like the crash of battle and the flow of blood will have enough of it. The armies are now all commanded by Western Generals, and whether they be good or bad, their onset will be terrible.

Our official advices from the Army of the Potomac are to yesterday morning. There had been no renewal of the great struggle. LEE'S army was still near its last battle-field, apparently awaiting for another onset.

The receipts of the principal kinds of Produce since our last have been 55 bbls. Ashes, 20,923 bbls. Flour, 67 bbls. and 816 bags Corn Meal, 158,168 bushels Wheat, 26,927 bushels Oats, 6,500 bushels Malt, 4,514 pkgs. Provisions, and 1,433 bbls. Whisky.

Frequent absence from Paris, together with an impression that the absorbing interest of your great war must render you comparatively indifferent to European news, induced me to discontinue a series of letters which (without a signature) had the honor of contributing to the New-York TIMES some two or three years ago. The war has now lasted so long that the description...

Major-Gen. Dix, New-York: We have dispatches from Gen. GRANT to 8 o'clock this morning. He states that offensive operations have been necessarily suspended until the roads become passable; that the army is in the best of spirits, and feels the fullest confidence in success. The two armies are now concentrated on the main road from Fredericksburgh to Richmond.
The latest news from Gen. BUTLER, represents him as laying regular siege to Fort Darling, and that his Chief Engineer Gen. GILLMORE, was confident of soon having possession of the fortification.

Both Boards of the Common Council were in session yesterday. The Aldermen referred to the Committee on Markets a lengthy but important communication from the City Inspector, renewing and urging his proposition to banish slaughterhouses from the City, and erect abattoirs in the suburbs, and the draft of an ordinance from the same officer, to prohibit the keeping of offal by butchers longer than one day, was laid over.
At daylight Gen. BURNHAM'S Brigade charged upon the enemy's outer works at Proctor's Creek and carried the entire line, section by section.

We publish this morning the important intelligence from our Panama correspondent, that on the 14th of April Admiral PINZON, commanding the Spanish fleet on the coast of Peru, and DON EUSADIO SALAZAR, Her Catholic Majesty's Special Commissioner to Peru, formally and without any warning, took possession of the Chincha Guano Islands, and raised the Catholic flag in the name of the Queen.

The prisoners taken by the Spaniards whom they kept on board of their vessels as hostages have been put at liberty; this is owing to the energetic note directed by our Minister of foreign affairs to Admiral PIKZON, in which he showed that the custom of keeping hostages only belonged to the times of barbarism.

I observe that some of the Eastern papers are still discussing the subject of FORREST'S recent raid into Western Kentucky, and censuring the Commandant of the Union forces in the District of Cairo--Gen. BRAYMAN. I notice likewise that it has been under discussion in the Senate, and one of the grave members...

The screw corvette Georgia is moored in a snug little bight at the Vittoria Wharf, on the south side of the Great Float, at Birkenbead, about a mile from Woodside Ferry. The best mode of access for visitors from Liverpool is to go by one of the dock omnibusses which have recently commenced running from the ferry, for they pass within a couple of hundred yards of the vessel.

The anniversary of the Christian Commission was held on Sunday evening in the Academy of Music, which was crowded to its utmost capacity. W.E. DODGE, Esq., opened the meeting by proposing the well-known hymn.
The steamer Thomas Collier, has arrived from Newbern, with Chief Quartermaster WEBSTER, on board, who reports all quiet there.

On the afternoon of the 11th instant, Commander PARKER, of the Potomac flotilla, received information that a party of rebels were engaged in placing torpedoes in the Rappahannock and Piankatank Rivers, to blow up our boats.

By the Inman steamer City of London and the Cunard steamer Hecla, which arrived here yesterday, we have European news to the 5th inst., and by the Hibernian at Father Point, dates to the 6th. The rebel privateer Georgia is at Liverpool...

In response to a call, issued by the ladies of the Executive Committee of the Metropolitan Fair, a very large meeting was held yesterday afternoon at Cooper Union for the purpose of calling the attention of women to the injury inflcted upon the country in this crisis by the extravagant purchase of imported luxuries, and to suggest the propriety of abstaining...
We published a few days ago the call of a small body of radicals for a convention at Cleveland, to "counsel together concerning the approaching Presidential election." A supplementary...
