ELPHINSTONE asked the Under Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether her Majesty's Government had expressed any opinion on the circumstances of Mr. SEWARD having presented a document of Lord LYONS on the 22d of December last, which, on the 19th of March, he "felt bound" to tell him he had "just discovered" to be "a forgery;" and, whether...
The Inman steamer City of London, Capt. PETRIE, which left Liverpool at 4 P.M. on the 4th, and Queenstown on the 5th, arrived here yesterday.

A late arrival from Belle Plain says that the Surgeon of the Sixty-sixth New-York, who was a prisoner, was paroled by LEE, and allowed to disinter the body of Gen. WADSWORTH, which had been interred in a coffin made by breaking up a door. He was then passed by LEE, with the remains, over the rebel line into ours.

The steamship Ariel, Capt. WILSON, from Aspin wall, May 8, arrived at port yesterday morning, having been detained off Sandy Hook since 8 o'clock Sunday evening. The following is her treasure list from Aspinwall.

We take from the London Times, of April 30, the following report of the highly important debate regarding the seizure of the rams in the Mersey which transpired in the House of Lords on the preceding evening:

In my last I gave the readers of the TIMES a short history of the Talambo affair, and stated that matters had assumed such a threatening aspect, so far as the action of Senor MAZARREDO Y. SALAZAR, the Spanish agent, was concerned, that fears were entertained at Lima that the Spanish fleet would be ordered up from Chili to make reprisals on Peruvian property or territory. The court-room was crowded this morning, as it was understood that the District-Attorney would move on the trial of Solomon Kohnstamm for frauds on the Government. The panel of petit jurors was called over, and such of them as had excuses to make were heard.

I am writing to-night at the Half-Way House, a fast decaying, old-fashioned tavern, (only ten and a half miles from the rebel Capital,) which, in bygone times, before turnpikes were superseded by railways, was a famous hostelry for travelers between Petersburgh and Richmond.

I have just returned from the scene of Gen. HANCOCK's brilliant victory of yesterday morning. At the point at which his assault was made, the rebel breastworks formed an angle or salient, and his men advanced silently and, without firing a shot, entered...

The rebels up to yesterday occupied their line of entrenchments immediately around and this side of Spottsylvania Court-house. Both armies lay on their arms on Sunday night, expecting an attack. The rebel works bear all appearance of having been but recently thrown up. A few hours' sunshine will remove all impediment to the resumption of active hostilities. LEE'S position is described as being a very strong one in itself, but it can be flanked with.

Mr. HAWES, of New-York, (Union,) from the Judiciary Committee, reported a bill to authorize the Secretary of the Treasury to stipulate for the release from attachment or other process property claimed by the United States, with the following amendments:

The Republican Union State Convention met here to-day. The attendance was large, and every county in the State was represented. Hon. G.W. GRANDY was chosen President, and Mr. SWAN, Secretary. The following nominations for State officers were read:
A dispatch has been received at the Headquarters of the Army here, dated yesterday morning, from Gen. SHERMAN.
To the Editor of the New-York Times: I take the liberty of sending to you for publication in your journal, the following:

Slavery died by over-doing itself. AntiSlavery, if left to some of its friends, would perish in the same manner. Slavery was not content with its own sure constitutional ground, but crusaded on needless and false issues.

Surgeon W.J. McDERMOTT, of the Sixty-sixth Regiment New-York Volunteers, who arrived in this City yesterday from Fredericksburgh, gives some interesting particulars concerning the recovery of Gen. WADSWORTH'S body, and the removal of a large number of our wounded from the rebel lines, after the first great battle in the Wilderness.
We have no official intelligence of any military operations since my last dispatch. The Richmond papers of Saturday state that Gen. STEELE had sur
Four military posts in the Northwest, by general order of the War Department, have been named in honor of Gens. WADSWORTH, HAYS, STEVENSON and RICH, slain in the recent battles in Virginia.

Comptroller BRENNAN yesterday opened proposals from forty-five different individuals and firms, embodying eighty-six bids for a new issue of "Central Park Improvement Fund stock," to bear 6 per cent. interest, and to be payable in 1876. The sum to be issued is $300,000. The bids for it aggregated $1,702,300.

The news of the situation in Virginia does not disclose any remarkably new features. Gen. GRANT has been receiving and disposing of large reinforcements, and on Friday evening last there seems to have been a very material change in the position of the two armies.
The bark Richard Irvin, arrived at this port from Cape Town, Cape of Good Hope, March 27, reports that the pirate Alabama left that port on the 25th of March. Her destination was unknown.
Dispatches from Gen. BUTLER, just received, report the success of his expedition under Gen. KAUTZ to cut the Danville Road and destroy the iron bridge across the Appomattox.
The United States Steam transport Fulton, WOTTON, Commander, from Port Royal, S.C., May 14, 1864, to Major S. VAN VLIET, Quartermaster, arrived at this port yesterday.

As the son was going down, one Sunday evening, three years since, the Seventy-ninth New-York (Highland) Regiment, clad in the ancient and picturesque costume of the Scottish Highlanders, passed down Broadway amid the plaudits and farewells of a loyal multitude.
The Board met, pursuant to adjournment, in their Chamber, number sixteen City Hall. Present--James Hayes, Esquite, President, in the chair, and the following members:

The royal mail steamship Persia, Capt. Lorr, which sailed from Liverpool at 10 o'otook on the morning of the 7th, and from Queenstown on the evening of the 8th inst., arrived here yesterday afternoon.
New-Orleans dates of the 11th are received. Gens. HERRON, BENTON and HAMILTON, and a large number of officers, both American and Mexican, had arrived.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The gratitude and admiration of theatrical people move in mysterious ways. Several prominent actors give to-night a testimonial enteriainment to Mr. DAN BRYANT, a gentleman who receives a testimonial benefit every night ...
The Tribune, in an editorial notice of Mr. RAYMOND'S History of President Lincoln's Administration, says:

The Senate Finance Committee is working from four to six hours daily on the Tax Bill. It will probably not be ready to report before Monday. Commissioner LEWIS was before them to-day for several hours. It is understood that they have decided to increase the tax on whisky. Also, that they have decided to adhere to their former action, and not tax stock on hand.

By the publication of the following atrocious forgery a the World and Journal of Commerce, yesterday morning, great excitment was created among our citizens until the feat that it was utterly false, concoctd by enemies of the Union and of the Administration, became patent.

Mr. CALDWELL said the intention of asking Parliament to grant the interest on the money required to complete the railway from Halifax to Quebec had not been abandoned, and was still under consideration.
The following dispatches from Gen. LEE and the late J.E.B. STUART are published in Richmond papers of the 12th inst., under the head of " Gratifying Intelligence:"

We have important advices from our special correspondent at headquarters of the Army of the Potomac, dated 5 o'clock yesterday morning, at which time the battle was being renewed, skirmishing having just commenced.

Yesterday morning, at about 3 o'clock, a boy left in the business office of the TIMES three pages of thin paper, upon which was written what purported to be a proclamation, signed by President LINCOLN, and countersigned ...

The demand for Money at the Bank of England continued large, even at the advanced rate of 9 per cent. The charge was as high as 10 per cent in exceptional cases. In the open market, great caution was displayed, but there was no panic and no symptoms of discredit.

On Saturday, a very feeble, and under almost all its aspects, a most ridiculous attempt was made to celebrate the birthday of our great poet, by what was called in the handbills a "Working Men's Shakespeare Jubilee and Great National Festival."

The Democratic State Convention, to appoint delegates to Chicago, assembled to-day. Hon. J. K. WURTENDYKE was elected temporary Chairman, and one Secretary from each Congressional District appointed. A committee of one from each county was ...

Mr. CYRUS W. FIELD returns home in the Persia. He left everything in England in the most encouraging condition for the laying of the Atlantic cable next year. The company had obtained the entire amount of capital necessary to manufacture and lay down the cable.

Major CUTTING, of Gen. AUGER'S Staff, arrived here this morning with the body of Gen. WADSWIRTH. He was shot by a rebel sharpshooter who was concealed in a tree, the ball striking him on the top of the head and coming out back of the neck. Gen.

The House passed the Senate bill, amendatory of the act authorizing Nevada to form a State Government. It changes the time for submitting the Constitution to the vote of the people to the first Wednesday in September.

The hardest fighting of the campaign on the south side of the James River occurred yesterday. In the early morning, under cover of a fog so dense as to limit vision to the distance of a few yards, the enemy fell upon the right of our line of battle with the force of an avalanche, completely crushing it backward, and turning our flank, as two days before we had turned theirs.

The trial of Salomon Kohnstamm was resumed yesterday morning. Shortly before the opening of the court, Hon. William M. Evarts, who arrived home from Europe on Wednesday, appeared and took his seat as one of the counsel for the accused. The crowd in the court-room was very dense, and exceedingly German.

The skirmishing which began yesterday morning at daybreak settled into a heavy engagement, lasting through the forenoon, and culminating in another brilliant charge by HANCOCK on our right, when he drove the enemy a short distance, and carried their first line of intrenchments.

Mr. HARDING, of Oregon, (Union,) from the Committee on Public Lands, reported back the bill to amend the Act of Sept. 27, 1850, in relation to donation to settlers upon public lands in California, and it was passed.

Mr. J.B. PUMEY, who has for some time past resided in the City of New-York, in the character of Consul-General of the Republic of Liberia, presented his credentials, yesterday, and was received by the Secretary of State as Charge d'Affaires of that Republic near this Government.

A battle was fought at this point on the afternoon of the 8th last., the primary object of which was to engage the attention of the enemy immedi? ately around Dalton, while McPHERSON was penetrating the mountain at Snake Gap, some six or seven miles further south, and gaining a position in the enemy's rear. The plan was successful, and McPHERSON passed through the defile without opposition. We are here immediately abreast of Dalton,...

Rumors continue rife that SIGEL is to be superseded for his conduct in the recent engagement in the Valley of Virginia. It is believed that the force opposing him only numbered about four thousand, and some express doubts as to whether BRECKINRIDGE was there at all. CROOKS was in the rear of the rebel force, and there are no apprehensions of their making any effort to pursue their advantage over SIGEL.

The Copperhead journals have at last found how to extract some comfort from GRANT's success. They are discovering that this success is just the thing to defeat the renomination of President LINCOLN! They feel quite certain that the Baltimore Convention, in view of these victories, will adjourn until September, and then select a more available candidate.

All is quiet with our army to-day. The object of the demonstration on Fort Darling was merely to draw off and entertain as many of Gen. LEE's troops as possible, and also to attract the attention of all the rebel forces in and about Richmond to enable Gen. KAUTZ to destroy the communications south of Richmond.
The Trial of Salomon Kohnstamm for alleged frauds upon the Government, was resumed yesterday morning.
Gen. SHERMAN is in possession of Kingston, Rome, Casaville, and the line of the Etowah.

The steamship Peruvian, from Liverpool, at 3 P.M. of the 12th, and Londonderry, l3th inst., for Quebec, was intercepted at Port au Basque, at 7 o'clock this evening, and the following summary of her news obtained.

It is officially announced by the State Department that citizens of the United States holding commissions, and recognized as Consuls of foreign Powers, are not by law exempt from military service, if drafted.
The Board met, pursuant to adjournment, in their Chamber, number sixteen City Hall. Present--James Hayes, Esquire, President, in the chair, and the following members:
WAR DEPARTMENT, WASHINGTON, May 20, 1864--6:30 P.M. This afternoon we have dispatches dated at 8 o'clock this morning from Gen. GRANT.
From a sprightly little sheet, called the Hammond Gazette, published at Point Lookout, Md., the general rendezvous for rebel prisoners of war, we extract the following items of intelligence:
Mr. HALE, of New-Hampshire, (Union,) presented a petition from JOHN ERICSSON, builder of the two monitors Dictator and Puritan, praying for relief, which was granted.
A singular series of operations has just been completed, and the rebel army has retreated from the works around Resaca.

By a European mail which recently arrived, we have a full report of the debate on the Tuscaloosa in the House of Commons, on the resolution condemning the Government for the instructions issued to the Colonial Governor at the Cape, with regard to the detention of the vessel.
The primary aim of this new edition, as stated by the editor himself, was to disclose all the evidence known to exist to designate the respective contributions of its authors.
A special dispatch from Washington to the Bulletin says that the Star states:
Nashville just now is in a fever of excitement at the brief and unsatisfying, but thrilling dispatches, which the wires are conveying to us from our armies in Virginia.

The report of the Election Committee, that Gen. BLAIR had not been legally elected to the House would have been called up before this, but for the position taken by his friends that notice must be given him. It is understood that they claim that he is still a member of the house notwithstanding his military position.
About 5 o'clock this evening, the rebels made a dash on our extreme right, held by WARREN, but were driven back after half an hour's fighting.

A note of the Moniteur on the relations between the United States and Mexico has put to rest all the apprehensions which the House resolution had given rise to. The note is so strong in form as to give to the reader the impression that the American Government had apologized, rather than explained, on the subject of the Congressional vote.

The Opinion Nationale of Paris, in its issue of April 30, devotes four columns of its editorial page to the reproduction of documents that offer fresh and most conclusive proof in reference to the vessels-ofwar in progress of construction at Bordeaux and Nantes on rebel account.

Dispatches from the Army of the Potomac, dated last night, say that a chaplain came in, yesterday, from the hospital of the Second Corps on the Wilderness battle-field, and reported that our 400 wounded belonging to that corps are still in hospital there, and that they were entirely out of provisions and medical supplies.

The news from Gen. GRANT is up to 8 o'clock yesterday morning, at which time Gen. GRANT dated a dispatch to Secretary STANTON, announcing the failure of an attempt of the enemy to turn our right flank, they being severely repulsed by Gen. TYLER'S division, just from Washington. Yesterday there was no fighting, and up to latest accounts no change in the position. Gen. GRANT had received 25,000 veteran reinforcements.
The following is a brief summary of the news taken out by the Glasgow, which left Liverpool on the 11th:
The Evening Bulletin, of this city, has the following:

Honors to the Remains of Gen. Wadsworth. The remains of Brig.-Gen. WADEWORTH, which have been lying in state in the Governor's Room of the City Hall since Thursday evening, were yesterday afternoon, under escort of the Seventh Regiment and a detachment of the Third United States Infantry, conveyed to the foot of Chambers-street, whence they were taken to the Erie Railroad depot, to be transported to his family residence near Geneseo.

The Evening Post invokes the constitutional principle of the freedom of the press in behalf of the suspended Journal of Commerce and the World. This is not reasonable. Indeed, it seems to us little less than mockery --much like pleading the freedom of trade for the receiver of stolen goods, or the inviolability of your house for the assassin who shoots from your window.

The Tribune repeats its conviction that Gen. McCLELLAN never had any understanding with Gen. BUCKNER by which the substantial neutrality of the State of Kentucky was recognized and respected, as is stated by Mr. RAYMOND in his History of President Lincoln's Administration. It is of opinion that the letter of Gen. BUCKNER to Gov. MAGOFFIN, asserting that there was such an understanding, and purporting to give its substance, was essentially false.

The Morning Post has a special telegram from Heligstand, 10th, which says that in the naval engagement there were 170 killed and wounded on the German side, while the Danes had 53 wounded, only one killed, and their ships unimpaired. The German squadron was at Cuxhaven. The Danes had left for Norway.
The draft for McCracken County, Ky., was made yesterday. Five hundred and forty-two names were drawn, and among them are many merchants and business men of this city.

Extensive Destruction of Railroads, Depots, Bridges and Commissary Stores--The Expedition Goes Within Sight of the Rebel Capital, and Returns in Safety. Several days since a cavalry expedition, composed of the Third New-York, First District of Columbia, Eleventh and Fifth Pennaylvania Cavalry Regiments, with a section of the Eighth New-York Battery, started from here under command of Gen. KAUTZ. From an officer who accompanied the expedition we have received some important details.
In the Massachusetts Republican State Convention, which was held in Boston on Thursday last, Mr. ROBERTS offered the following resolution:

To Major-Gen. Dix: Dispatches from Gen. SHERMAN state that our forces found in Rome a great deal of provisions and seven fine Iron works and machine shops. We have secured two good bridges and an excellent ford across the Etowah. The care are now arriving at Kingston with stores, and two days would be given to replenish and fit up.

SIR: I have received a circular letter addressed to the National Executive Committee of the Union and Republican parties, signed by a number of distinguished gentlemen, and to which I am requested to add my name, urging the postponement of the National Convention which has been called to meet at Baltimore on the 7th of June next.

The battle of Elkin's Ford, on the Little Missouri River, took place on the 3d and 4th days of April. On the Union side all of the Second Brigade, Third Division, (Gen. SLOCUM'S,) except the Seventyseventh Ohio, and two companies First Iowa Cavalry, were engaged. On that of the rebels, two brigedes of MARMADUKE'S division.
Advices from the country regarding the grow ing crops are unfavorable. In the State at large the yield of thousands of acres of grain are now being cut for hay.

On the 8th the rebels sent down a flag of truce conveying a matter of $600 in greenbacks to the crew of the recaptured Bombshell. We learned from the officers that the Captain of the ram was wounded and that as soon as the ram was repaired a little they would give us another trial.

We have just received intelligence that an armistice has been concluded between the Danes and the Allies. The nature of its conditions is not mentioned we are not told whether the blockade of the German ports is to be raised, or whether Jutland is to be evacuated, but if the main fact is correct, the betligerents have removed one great stumbling-block out of the way of the diplomats.

The arrest of Marshal MURRAY under an indictment presented by the Grand Jury of the County, charging him with the offence of kidnapping, continues to excite the community. The facts as far as known are that the indictment was found on Thursday afternoon, having as is stated been previously paseed by the Grand Jury for want of evidence. What can be done? It is sad to notice the gibes and ridicule cast upon the recent effort of some of our earnest, reflecting, not "strong-minded" women, to check the inexcusable waste and extravagance of the day in the present unhappy state of our country. The meeting of Monday, whether with reference to its arrangements, or to the utility of holding it at all, may be a subject open to discussion.

Gen. BUTLER'S army is now taking needed rest within its strongly-intrenched position on the peninsula formed by the windings of the James and Appomattox Rivers, known as Bermuda Hundred. The troops have earned repose. Eleven of the fourteen days which have passed since they surprised all Secessia by their landing here, have witnessed active fighting.

The stillness of an unusually quiet day was suddenly disturbed, about 6 P.M., by the opening of a sharp musketry fire within less than two miles of the right of the army headquarters, and pretty well toward the rear.

The Newmarket First Spring Meeting. The advent of the first Spring meeting at the great English racing metropolis and headquarters of the English Jockey, Club is always regarded wit deep interest by the sporting gentlemen of England, and those who in other lands desire to be enlightened on racing topics. There are cogent reasons for this.

The more one reflects on the circumstances attending the outrage perpetrated upon Peru by the agents of Spain, the more reason is there to regard the proceeding, not as an unauthorized act of reprisal on the part of the Spanish Admiral and M. SALAZAR, but as part of a deliberate plan of invasion and subjugation.
The United States steamer Massachusetts, Lieut, WELSH, has arrived here from the South Atlantic Squadron via Hampton Roads. She left Charleston on the evening of the 17th inst.
Steamships Crusader, (Br.,) Gutnrie, Kingston, Jam., Booth Co.; Chesapeake, Willetts, Portland, H.B. Cromwell Co.

We have just passed through the second engagement with that ugly little ram, the Roanoke. Yesterday afternoon, at 2 o'clock, the rain, consorted by the steamer Cotton Planter and the Bombshell, which last they sunk at the attack on Plymouth, and afterwards raised, made its appearance at the mouth of the river. We retreated slowly and they followed, Capt. FRENCH sent the Massasoit ahead to inform the remainder of the fleet.

Mr. LANE, of Kansas, (Union,) presented the credentials of WM. M. FISHBACK, elected Senator from Arkansas by the General Assembly of that State on the 5th of May, 1864, to fill the unexpired term of Mr. SEBASTIAN.

To-day Brig.-Gen. KAUTZ again entered City Point on his return from another still more daring and successful raid within tha enemy's lines than he made a few days ago, an account of which you have already published.

Dated in the saddle, near Grand Ecore, Apri1 15, a letter to the Houston (Texas) Telegraph gives an interesting account of the late battle on Red River. After a great deal of verbiage and bombast, the writer says:

The excitement here on war matters is deep and prevailing. In ordinary times a movement like SHERMAN'S would command general interest and attention. But it is entirely overshadowed by the grander movements in the East. People no longer sneer at the Army of the Potomac. It has nobly vindicated itself, and stands before the world purged of the obloquy cast upon it, in consequence of its misfortunes under untortunate leaders.

A Paris letter writer says: "The world to Paris is gone mad after the Japanese. This embassy, regardless of the 'happy dispatch' which may await them on their return, are enjoying themselves in the most reckless manner.

Three hundred wounded men were sent from the McClelian Hospital, to-day, to Philadelphia. The weather is as yet very favorable for the patients in hospital, and most of them are doing well.

THE DACOTAH CONTESTED CASE. Mr. DAWES, of Massachusetts, (Union,) from the Committee on Elections, made a report that WILLIAM JAYNE is not, and that JOHN S. TODD is entitled to a seat as delegate from Dacotah. The subject was laid over the future consideration.

The Mayor, Comptroller, and City Inspector advertise for proposals, to be opened at noon on Thursday, June 2, for contracting to clean the streets for a term of five years, in accordance with the requirements of the City Tax Law for 1864. The amount of surety required for the fulfillment of the agreement is $500,000. All the information desirable to parties wishing to compete for the contract is also advertised.
The Copperhead press, true to their instincts, have done their best to make party capital from the arrest of ARGUELLES in this City, and his deportation to Cuba to take his trial as a slave-trader.

By the bark Urania, Capt. E. COOPER, which arrived at this port yesterday morning, we have files of papers from the Cape of Good Hope Colony to April 7. The bark Falcon, J. TAYLOR, from Boston, arrived at Port Elizabeth, March 31.

From the several armies this morning, we have hardly any news whatever. From Gen.GRANT there are no advices, either official or otherwise. We have private information that on Monday his army was not far from Hanover Junction, near the South Anna River, and that a battle was expected that day.

While England and France are expending their resources upon a variety of iron-clad vessels, and are producing such ships as the Solferino, which is officially reported to have gone fourteen knots an hour at sea, fully armed and equipped for service, the United States is building only one class of vessels, familiarly known as "Monitors," excepting only the Ironsides, which seems to be the best iron-clad at Charleston, and the Dunderberg, not yet launched.

The Union Convention now assembling does not promise to be as largely attended as are the nomination conventions of the party. Tne delegates had not arrived yet in such numbers as to warrant the holding of the usual clique caucuses this evening, so the canvassing and preliminary arrangements that are generally done over night, go over until nine o'clock to-morrow morning. The attendance of distinguished "old liners" is sparse.

OLYMPIC THEATRE. If Mr. WATTS PHILLIPS' new drama of "Paul's Return" does not deal absolutely with new material, it possesses the merit, at all events, of using old material in a thoroughly workmanlike manner. The workmanship, in fact, is sometimes too apparent, and particularly so in the matter of construction.

A rebel working party yesterday showed themselves in front of our works, and began to use their spades and axes. One of our batteries opened a deliberate fire upon the impudent fellows, and a few shots scattered them. Beyond this slight episode, nothing has occurred since the midnight assault of the enemy on Saturday, demanding on either side the burning of gunpowder.

THE TREASURY INVESTIGATIONS. The evidence before the Treasury Investigation Committee is, in some cases, of the most conflicting nature. A leading railroad man and another prominent citizen of New-York, swear positively to an attempt on the part of a certain Bank Note Company to bribe Mr. CLARK to abandon the effort to print Government notes and bonds in the Department.
The thirty-fifth anniversary of the Brooklyn Sunday-schools was celebrated Tuesday, with exercises at the different churches, processions and feasting.

In the House of Lords on the 12th instant Earl ELLENBOROUGH called attention to certain cases, which he described as well authenticated, of kidnapping of foreigners in New-York for service in the Federal army. He also asked if steps had been taken to obtain the release of those already entrapped.

A MEMORIAL FROM THE BANK OF NEW-ORLEANS. Mr. JOHNSON, of Maryland, (Union,) presented the memorial of the Bank of New-Orleans, praying to be released from the tax on a certain portion of its circulation, issued in payment of deposits made with them of Confederate bonds.
ANDREW LAYPOLE, alias ISADORE LEOPOLD, a noted guerrilla, who was captured in the month of April, 1863, was hanged yesterday morning, about 5 o'clock, at Fort McHenry.

Memorandum of cash disbursements of the United States Sanitary Commission for fifteen days, May 6 to May 20, inclusive, for the succor of the national forces in Virginia.

The latest intelligence from Gen. GRANT is up to one o'clock on Tuesday afternoon, at which time his headquarters were at Mount Carmel Church, and he says in his dispatch to Secretary STANTON that although his troops are much fatigued, he "will reach the South Anna by nightfall." This is very remarkable as well as important progress.

The steamship Asia, from Liverpool at 2 o'clock on the afternoon of the 14th, via Queenstown on the 15th instant, arrived at this port at 12 o'clock last (Tuesday) night. Her dates are two days later than those already received.

In the London Discount market the demand for money is moderate, and rather easier terms are accepted. First-class bills are at 8 8 per cent discount. The funds are firmer under favorable returns from the Bank of England, and more pacific advices from the Continent. The West India mail steamer brings $1,120,000 in gold. TRADE REPORT.

In our recent exposition of the almost universal failure of civilian Commanders in this war, we reserved judgment upon MajorGen. SIGEL and Major-Gen. BUTLER, preferring to await the issues of the important enterprises in which they were then engaged. The results have now been developed. They are of a character to round off completely a demonstration that all of our Commanders, without a regular military education, are incapable.

The New-Orleans Era of the 17th has the following interesting particulars of the late successful withdrawal of our army and gunboats from Alexandria : On the 12th inst. the gunboats Lexinglon and Mound City passed below both falls, where they were ordered to remain till they should be joined by the rest of the gunboats and transports.
VIA FORT MONROE, Tuesday, May 24--2 P.M. An arrival from the James River reports every thing quiet. There has been no fighting or skirmishing since Saturday night, the 21st.

A State Committee of War Democrats met at the St. Charles Hotel to-day, and effected an organization by electing Hon. GEORGE A. BRANDRETH, of Westchester, Chairman, and H.C. PAGE, of NewYork, Secretary.

The subject of the powers of the board was again discussed, the City Inspector having expressed the opinion that they had no right, nor anybody, except the Board of Health, to destroy property. The board were divided in opinion upon this point. The Corporation Counsel was not present.

[Per Steamship Eagle.] The newspapers of the Capital of Mexico give the particulars of dreadful atrocities said to have been committed by the partisans of JUAREZ at an estate called Malpaso, in the Department (as it is now called) of Zacatecas, which, if true, cannot be too severely condemned.

The stea mer Argo arrived this morning with 380 wounded on board. They left Fredericksburgh last night at 8:30 o'clock, and were on the river during the tremendous thunderstorm, which did much to alleviate the sufferings of the men. About 3,000 wounded were yet in Fredericksburgh, but are being moved away.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Although not a matter of any particular importance to the public, will you allow me to correct two errors of fact in one of your editorials headed "West Point Soldiership Vindicated," in the TIMES of the 16th, and to add a few suggestions to your own able remarks.

The Conference met again in London on the 12th inst. The Daily News says that the Conference approached the question of the political future of the Duchies. The discussion which took place, however, did scarcely more than make evident the immense divergence of the views of the several Powers, and the difficulties which would attend the arrangement of acceptable terms of peace. After sitting three hours the Conference adjourned till the 10th day of May.

We conversed a day or two since with a gentleman who is connected with the Refugee Commission of Louisville, Ky., from whom we learned that this organization is in pressing need of assistance in the prosecution of its labors.

The spokesmen of the Imperial Government in the French Legislative body, do not even attempt to conceal the fact that Mexico is hereafter to be regarded as a permanent appanage or dependency of France. During the debate on the budget on the 10th inst., this view of the situation was brought out with a directness and force which is really instructive.

The battle near Drury's Bluff was imperfectly appreciated in Richmond till yesterday. It was, during the time it lasted, one of the most terrific combats that has been known. Confederate valor never had a more splendid illustration. The nerve of SMITH of BUTLER'S large army was concentrated on the hills, behind heavy fortifications, which they had strengthened with all the appliances of unlimited labor and inexhaustible ingenuity.

The Democratic Union State Convention met at 10 o'clock, at the Court-house. Hon. JAMES GUTHRIE was made President, and THOMAS S. WALLACE Secretary. Four delegates at large, and two from each Congressional District were appointed to represent Kentucky in the Chicago Convention.
Eighteen hundred and sixty-five, as will be known to very many if not all the readers of the TIMES, is what is called a "Jubilee Year" with the religious societies.

To Major-Gen. Dix: The latest date from Gen. GRANT'S headquarters, received by this Department, is dated at Mount Connel Church, 1 P.M. yesterday. The dispatch says everything is going well. WARREN has four hundred prisoners, HANCOCK some three hundred, and WRIGHT has picked up some.

I decline to be a victim, most emphatically refuse to become a sufferer. Nevertheless I have spent three days under the supervision of MARTIN BURKE, whose stern discipline and unflinching obedience to orders has often been attested by the veteran hero of Mexico in these words : "I'll order you shot, and MARTIN BURKE shall do it."

Ex-Gov. PRICE vs. GEN. KEYES.--This is an interesting action, brought by Ex-Gov. PRICE, of this State, before the Supreme Court in New-York, to recover $165,000, for the sale of certain property owned by him in San Francisco, California, in fraud of his rights.

Gen. SMITH, on Sunday night sent out a hundred men to reconnoitre the position of the enemy on our extreme left. The reconnoitering party penetrated the enemy's lines a short distance, but were turned back at Bakehouse Creek, which is about two miles from our defences.

Hadley and Thomas Parsons; Eighth District, William Bristol and Edward Hazzard.
The Union State Convention, assembled here to-day, was large and harmonious. All the counties in the State, except two, were represented.

GENERAL, ORDER, No. 27. By an order of the President of the United States, I am relieved from the command of this department. Major-Gen. HUNTER, United States Votunteers, is my successor. In leaving the troops under my immediate command, I feel it my duty to give my most sincere thanks to, the officers and men who have assisted me so faithfully during the last campaign.

The long anticipated trot in which this year's champion of the trotting turf. Mr. WASHBURNE, of Illinois, (Union,) from the Committee on Commerce, reported a bill, which was passed, authorizing the Secretary of the Treasury to sell the Marine Hospital and grounds at Chicago, and with the proceeds of such sale purchase a more healthy and retired location.
We publish this morning, upon our supplementary leaf, a letter from the interior of Texas, depicting with great vividness the Confederate system of imposition.

In the existing plethora of literacy matter, when it is almost impossible to keep up with the current of publication on any given subject in America, England, France and Germany much less to carry investigations backward into times past any book about books that furnishes the student with the results of reading and inquiry on a special branch of research is sure of a favorable reception.

The loyal people of Florida, to the number of several hundred voters, met a few days since pursuant to a call for that purpose, in convention at Jacksonville, and nominated delegates to the Baltimore Convention. C.L. ROBINSON, Esq., of Jacksonville, was chosen President, and J.C. SNOWBALL as Secretary.

In the Senate, yesterday, a memorial was received from the New-York Chamber, of Commerce, in favor of establiabing a Navy-yard at New-London, Conn. Three thousand extra copies of the National Bank Bill were ordered printed. A bill to incorporate the Potomac Ferry Company was introduced and referred to the Committee on the District of Columbia.

The day could hardly have been more pleasant, or the wind more favorable, for the Fifteenth Annual Regatta of the New-York Yacht Club, which took place yesterday. At an early hour the pier at the foot of Twentieth-street, North River, was thronged by people anxiously awaiting the arrival of the steamers which were to accompany the yachts "down the river."

The tin-clads Marmora, Juliet, and Prairie Bird, recently engaged the rebel batteries at Gaines' Landing, and succeeded in driving them away. The Prairie Bird was struck thirty times, and the Marmine Brigade boat Delta bad her donkey engine shot overboard, and the engineer killed.

This demonstration of public sentiment in regard to the war, the services of the Union armies and the gratitude due to Gen. GRANT, officers and men, will take place at the southern terminator of Union-square, at 6 o'clock.

It is now generally acknowledged in England that Mr. GLADSTONE'S late speech on the extension of the franchise, indicates pretty clearly his political future. It marks him out, beyond question, for the leadership of the Liberal party which, it is acknowledged, will step into power after the Tories have had one more turn in office.

There is no official news from Gen. GRANT late than his dispatch of Wednesday morning, published yesterday. The steamer Keyport, which left White House on Wednesday at noon, and arrived at Washington yesterday, reports that very heavy cannonading was heard when she left, and rumors had come from the front that a severe battle was in progress.

FLOUR in moderately fair demand. WHEAT firm and moderately active; sales of No. 1 Milwaukee Spring at $1.47; Amber Michigan, $1.65; Red Winter, $1.60; Green Bay Club, $1.47. CORN firm; a good inquiry; sales 3,000 bushels No. 2, to arrive, delivered free, at $1.35.
In 1851, in Zanesville, O., one JOHN W. SOALES, butcher, was arrested and lodged in jail on a charge of larceny, the larceny alleged consisting in an unlawful appropriation of certain pigs.

Lord A. Cecil, Rifle Brigade; Baron Jansmond, Canada; Alderman Dakin and party, of the Grand Trunk Railway; Capt. Cook, steamer Australasian; Lieuts, Berthwell and S.G. Redoret, of H.B.M.'s Rifles; Count of Colbert and M. Salomi, of Paris, and Count J. of Colbert, French Legation, are at the Brevoort House.

The steamer Pauline Carroll, from New-Orleans 27th ult., has arrived. The news is unimportant. The officers report that when some distance from the city, they noticed a large light, supposed to be at New-Orleans.
Mr. MORGAN, of New-York, (Union,) presented a memorial from the New-York Chamber of Commerce in favor of the bill establishing a navy yard at New-London, Conn.

THE LAWRENCE MASSACRE. Our readers will doubtless remember the accounts we gave at the time of the horrible atrocities committed by QUANTRELL and his bloody band on the defenceless and unsuspecting inhabitants of Lawrence, on the morning of the 21st of last August.
FUNERAL OF A CLERGYMAN. The funeral of Rev. FREDERICK S. WILEY took place from St. Ann's Church, yesterday. The deceased was formerly assistant pastor of this congregation.

The heated term has been fairly inaugurated here in this part of the West Indies, and thermometer at 88 and 92 in shade, is a fair average, and those who are able to leave are beginning to pack up for a trip to the United States or Europe.

Mr. HENRY WINTER DAVIS has been instructed by the House Committee on Foreign Affairs to report a resolution reaffirming the MONROE doctrine, and maintaining the right of Congress to indicate the policy which the Government should pursue, especially in view of an attempt of foreign Powers to substitute monarchical for republican government on any part of this continent.

A convention of the unconditional Union men of Tennessee was held at Nashville, May 30, to appoint delegates to the Baltimore Convention. M. M. BRIEN, of Davidson, and DAVID T. PATTERSON, of Greene, were named delegates for the State at large, and the following resolutions were adopted among others:

Present John T. Henry, Esq., President, Aldermen Fox, McCool, Shannon, Chipp, McKnight, Ryers, Jeremiah, Hardy, Masterson, Ottiwell, Long. On motion, the minutes of the last meeting were dispensed with.

Sergant SLATER, of the Eigth Precinct, accompanied by Roundsman CROLIUS, and Officers Egan, Miller, Fenton, Adams, Traver and Spurbeck, were yesterday commissioned to search certain houses in Mercer-street, for deserters.

A visit to the iron-clad shipyards in the neighborhood of New-York, in which the last batch of light-dratt vessels are building, shows that the Naubuc, Modoc and Cohoes would be ready for launching within five or six weeks.

Gen. CLEBURNE'S division engaged the Fourth Army Corps, under HOWARD, about 1 o'olock this morning, and, after a desperate contest, signally repulsed the enemy, with a loss of between 5,000 and 7,000. We captured between 150 and 200 prisoners, exclusive of wounded, and immense quantities of arms and accoutrements.
Mr. VAN WINKLE, of Western Virginia, (Union,) called up the bill to prevent the counterfeiting of the coin of the United States, and it was passed.

The Constitution came in very promptly to time day before yesterday evening, and landed all of her passengers in good order and condition, and among them our old friend, the Indian chief IRATABA.

The steamer Keyport arrived this afternoon having left the White House at noon yesterday. Parties who came up on her state that heavy cannonading was heard there when they left, indicating that an engagement was in progress.

The Union State Convention was held in Springfield last week. The telegraph has already apprised you of its general results. It was one of the largest delegated conventions ever held in the West there being about seven hundred delegates present, representing one hundred and one counties Ford, a new county, being the only one absent. The deliberations and actions of the convention were characterized by great harmony, and the results cheerfully acquiesced ...

GRANT has definitely declined battle at Hanover Junction. Perhaps we should say that his army has saved him from the trouble of declining it. It is certain that both armies are once more moving. Two stories have lately prevailed of the direction in which GRANT is going. One account represented a large body of Yankees at Negro Foot, in the upper part of Hanover, but it has not been confirmed and is unlikely.

The World has, for several months, kept its readers excited and hopeful, by a succession of announcements from a Southern correspondent, that large "columns" of Confederate troops were preparing for an invasion of the North on a grand scale. One "column" was to cross the Potomac into Pennsylvania, and another was to cross the Ohio into Ohio, and both were to lay waste and destroy in every direction.

If you have the candor and boldness to publish what conflicts with the opinions of yourself and most of your readers, you will by giving this article a place is your journal, greatly oblige one who feels bound by ties of blood and long residence, to the unfortunate country most interested in the matter.

The Spaniah steamer Barcelona arrived at this port on the 26th instant from Vera Cruz, bringing news from Mexico City up to the 16th and from Vera Cruz up to the 2lst.
While I am writing a slight skirmish appears to be going on near our right, sharp musketry firing being heard from that direction.

Advices from the front are that the enemy have recrossed the North Anna, and are again on the move in the direction, it is supposed, of our right. The enemy are said to have made an effort this morning to burn the bridge over the North Anna, on the telegraph road, but were foiled. There was some skirmishing this this morning, and also some between 10 and 12 o'clock last night.

Our latest intelligence from New-Zealand is of considerable importance. The capture, by Gen. CAMERON, of the native strongholds on the Waipa has broken the backbone of Maorian power, if it has not quite crushed the revolt.

The Boston Advertiser of Friday says: "That unexpected orders, caused probably by the increasing complication of affairs among the European Powers, were received on Thursday by Admiral LISSOFSKY, directing him to return to Cronstadt immediately with his fleet. He will probably sail from Boston direct on Thursday or Friday of this week. Capt. KRAEMER sailed for New-York on Friday with the Peresveit."

The steamer Alice Dean, from Memphis for Cincinnati, has passed up with 600 bales of cotton. The steamer Hillmann is reported to have been fired into at Island No. 25, while on the way to Memphis. The result has not been learned.

To Major-Gen. Dix: Dispatches from Gen. GRANT'S headquarters, dated 3 o'clock yesterday, have just been received. No operations took place on Thursday. Yesterday, at 4:30 o'clock A.M., Gen. GRANT made an assault on the enemy's lines, of which he makes the following report:

The army here, or such portions of it as have returned, are at present in a state of quiescence, although it is evident that they will not long remain so, and that some movement of importance is already in contemplation. Of this army, under Gen. CANBY, you will, of course, get up-river news far more rapid and reliable, from your correspondents on the spot, than we can hope to send you hence.

The latest news from Gen. GRANT is up to three o'clock on Friday. In a dispatch dated at that time he gives the particulars of an assault made upon the enemy's lines on Friday morning, at 4:30 o'clock. The enemy were driven within their intrenchments at all points, and though the advantage gained was not decisive, yet our troops held all the ground they had gained. About three hundred prisoners were taken, mostly from...

It may not be uninteresting to the public in the present juncture of affairs to have an army view of political matters, as discussed in the camp the and field by our citizen soldiery, at the quadrennial period approaches for the selection of the President of the nation.

We have two official dispatches concerning the operations of Friday last. At dawn on that day, GRANT assaulted the enemy's lines, drove them within their intrenchments at all points, but gained no decisive advantage.

A rebel Major came into Gen. BUTLER'S lines at Bermuda Hundreds yesterday, who says that the federal forces are at Secessionville, and threatening Charleston. The commander has telegraphed the rebel anthorities for reinforcements, saying unless he receives them immediately Charleston is lost.

No heavy firing took place yesterday. Skirmishing at different points was brisk during the afternoon, and BURNSIDE withdrawing from the right, the enemy followed up and made a demonstration to turn WARREN'S right, but were compelled to give it up, as our position was too strong.

The House yesterday passed the Tariff Bill, after making numerous minor amendments. There was a decided disposition manifested to hurry it through. Many members wishing to go to Baltimore to-mor- row, but little business will be transacted in the House till after the convention, which is absorbing all interest now.

On the 16th instant, the Secretary of the Treasury will open bids for Seventy-five Millions of Six Per Cent. Bonds of 1881 Coupon or Registered, the money to be paid by the successful bidders, one-third on the 20th, onethird on the 25th, and the balance on the 30th inst.

The latest intelligence from Gen. GRANT comes down to 8:30 o'clock on Saturday night, and furnishes a consecutive narrative up to that time of the main events of the struggle from the hour of his previous report (3 o'clock on Friday.)

A dispatch from Gen. GRANT'S headquarters, lated 8:30 o'clock last night has been received. It states that about 7 P.M. yesterday, (Friday, 3d of June.) the enemy suddenly attacked SMITH'S brigade, GIBBONS' division. The battle lasted with great fury for half an hour. The attack was unwaveringly repulsed. SMITH'S losses were inconsiderable.

Dispatches received by Gen. EWING from Col. ROGERS, commanding at Cape Girardeau, state that the enemy is unusually active just now in that portion of the State.

THEY ARE CRUSHED BENEATH A FALLING SMOKESTACK, A most distressing accident occurred on Saturday afternoon on board the schooner Maria, lying alongside the revenue cutter Kankakee, at the foot of Horatio-street, North River.

The British steamship Talca arrived at Panama from Valparaiso and intermediate ports, on the evening of the 20th, bringing very interesting news from the South Coast. In the Senate, Saturday, the House bill to provide for the payment of the Second Regiment, Third Brigade, Ohio Volunteer Militia, for the time they were actually in the service, without regard to irregularity in the muster, was passed.

The steamer Missouri, from New-Orleans 30th, has arrived. She was fired into at Columbia by a baiteey. Sixty shots were fired at her, eight of which struck. One shell exploded in the nursery cabin, wounding a lady in the foot. No other person was wounded.
A squadron of six men-of-war had left France for Tunis.

The Board of Aldermen met yesterday. A resolution providing for a celebration of the ensuing 6th of July, with an appropriation in blank, was introduced and laid over. The Comptroller reported a balance of $1,950,932 49 in the city Treasury on last Saturday. The Board concurred to give a stand of colors to the Ninety-third Regiment, N.Y.S.N.G. Beyond this the proceedings were uninteresting. The Board adjourned to 12 M. on next Monday.

The steamship China, Capt. ANDERSON, from Liverpool on the 28th, via Queenstown on the 29th of May, arrived here at 5 o'clock yesterday (Sunday) evening. She has 30 passengers for this port and 58 for Boston.

Of course FREMONT accepts. He laid the plot on purpose to accept. His griefs would run to seed if he did not accept. His "whole charge of ancients, corporals, lieutenants, gentlemen of companies, discarded unjust serving men, revolted tapsters," would all go to the dogs if he didn't accept. It is plainly enough now but an ill venture; yet, being in so far, there was no alternative but to stand to it.

The steamer Bermuda has arrived from the West Blockading Squadron. She brings nineteen officers and thirty-six discharged and disabled men. Spoke United States ship Hartford, on a cruise. By the arrival of the China at Halifax yesterday, we received the telegraphic result of the English Derby race at Epsom, which was published in our third edition.

By the arrival of the steamer Arthur we have Vicksburgh; advices to the evening of the 1st. The Arthur was fired into at Columbia, Ark., by a battery of nine guns 6 and 12-pounders. Seventeen shots took effect, raking her fore and aft. She was also riddled with musket-balls two miles below the battery. Two men were killed and one severely wounded.

The battle of Friday last was a much more serious affair, both in its original conception, its actual character, and its final consequences, than we had been led to believe from the brief dispatches heretofore given to the public.
A meeting of the Ohio delegation was held tonight, and was addressed by Govs. DENNISON and TOD, who strongly urged the renomination of President LINCOLN.

GRANT'S army crossed the Pamunky on Saturday and snowed itself on our front on Sunday evening, at which time our men, after restin in bivouac during Saturday night, formed in line of battle with our left resting near Atlee's Station, and our right extending to and across the Mechaniesville pike, about eight or nine miles out from Richmond.

It is semi-officially announced that Secretary WELLES will, next week, leave the National Capital on his annual tour of the different navy-yards. He will first visit New-York, then Philadelphia, Boston, Portsmouth, N.H., and perhaps New-London, which is pretty generally believed to be the site for the new navy-yard.
Since my dispatch of 9 o'clock A.M., I have gathered some additional particulars of the contest this morning.

The news from the front hes been meagre for the last two days. Nothing but skirmishing has occurred except the usual nightly attack for the purpose of feeling our lines and learning whether any change of position is being made.

The Bankrupt Bill will be put on its passage tomorrow, if the attendance of members is not too slim.

The National Union Convention assembled this morning in the Front-street Theatre. The building is tastefully decorated and fitted up for the occasion. The galleries are festooned with flags and the interior stage is thrown open. This was done by the City Council of Balitmore.

The Central Sanitary Fair opened this afternoon. Previous to the exercises, an accident occurred, causing a temporary excitement. The platform in the rear of the speakers' stand, erected for the chorus, broke down. Mayor HENRY announced that the unfortunate accident that had just occurred was attended with but small injury to limb.

Fourteen bodies of the passengers on board the ill-fated steamer Berkshire, have thus far been found. Two of these were taken from the wreck yesterday. One of them has been recognized as the body of Mrs. NILES, of Spencertown, Columbia County, and mother of Miss NILES, who was also lost.

The Masonic Convention closed at a late hour last night. The main business transacted yesterday was the appointment of subordinate off cers and committees who are to sit during recess. Five thousand dollars was appropriated toward the Masonic Hall and Asylum Fund. The session just closed has been characterized by perfect harmony, and was largely attended throughout.

VALLANDIGHAM arrived at Dayton at 5:30 o'clock this afternoon, and proceeded immediately to his residence. There was no demonstration. In the House of Commons, May 30, Mr. CARDWELL stated that an application had been made by a Mr. COLLINS, the Concessionnaire of the Russo-American Telegraph, to carry a portion of it through British Columbia. The answer of Government stated the terms on which permission would be granted.
A Union mass meeting was held at Nashville on Friday night last, at which Gov. JOHNSON was the principal speaker. We find the following report in the Nashville Times:

The people crowded Cooper Institute to overflowing last evening, to ratify the nomination of LINCOLN and JOHNSON. The enthusiasm was intense, the indications unmistakable. All parties were represented, and the opening of the campaign brought with it the glad assurance of suc- cess. The mention of President LINCOLN'S name was at all times greeted with the wildest ap- plause, and JOHNSON, of Tennessee, well shared the honors.

Considerable bodies of the missing infantry of Gen. STURGIS' expedition are constantly coming in, and our loss will probably be cut down to less than 1,000, all told. By to-night the casualties will be pretty accurately reported.

By the arrival of the Eagle, from Havana, at this port yesterday, we are furnished with further details--chiefly unimportant--of the reception of MAXMILIAN at Vera Cruz, and his progress towared his future Capital.

A mass meeting of the Early Closing Associations was held last evening at Union-square, having for its object the abridgement of hours of labor. Not less than fifteen thousand people were present, and the utmost enthusiasm prevailed throughout the entire proceedings.
Mr. WASHBURNE, of Illinois, (Union,) introduced a bill for the better protection of the lives of passengers on boats propelled in whole or in part by steam. Referred to the Committee on Commerce.
The Board of Councilmen failed of a quorum yesterday, and adjourned to 2 o'clock P.M. on Monday.

On the 1st inst. Gen. WASHBURNE sent out, by order of Maj. Gen. McPHERSON, commanding the Army and Department of the Tennessee, a force consisting of about 3,000 cavalry and 5,000 infantry, with some 12 pieces of artillery, the whole under command of Brig.-Gen. STURGIS, who was sent down for the purpose of taking command of the expedition.

The Eighteenth Army Corps, (Gen. SMITH,) detached from the Army of the Potomac, embarked at White House, on the Pamunky, on Monday noon, and rejoined Gen. BUTLER'S command last evening, landing at Point of Rocks, on the Appomattox River.
The Army of the Potomac is again on the move. That it was about to retire from the position in front of Cold Harbor has been evident for some days to the most superficial observer.

The remains of BANKS' army is on the west side of the river, near Port Hudson. There is constant skirmishing between them and our forces in the rear.

England is not what you may call a warm country. The ponds have been frozen this present June. Potatoes in Yorkshire are frozen to the ground. Coal fires are among the comforts of life. The peaches grow in hot-houses. There are some ripe ones now in Covent Garden market, large and handsome, but frightful as to price, and not much, I suspect, as to flavor.

The movement was managed so skillfully that it is believed the enemy had no knowledge of what was going on until too late to take advantage of it; at all events, he did ...
The steamer John A. Warner, from Bermuda Leading, arrived here to-day.

The steamer City Albany, which left the White House on the 15th, arrived here at 10:30 this forenoon, having on board a number of horses and some beef cattle which had been captured by our men. White House has been abandoned, and all Government property removed.

One of Gen. GRANT'S couriers who arrived here this morning from Bermuda Hundred, with dispatches for the Government, says that when he left there on yesterday morning, (Wednesday, the 15th,) fighting was going on in the vicinity of Petersburgh.
Hon. HANNIBAL HAMLIN made a speech at a ratification meeting in Bangor, Maine, on Saturday evening last, of which we find the following report In the Whig:
"The House concurred in the Senate substitute for the mining clause--72 against 31.

There is no official dispatch from Washington this morning concerning army operations. The latest intelligence is from our special correspondents up to Wednesday morning, at which time the Army of the Potomac was all on the south side of the James.

The two armies are so close together that nowhere on the advance lines of either side can a man expose any portion of his person without running the risk of being shot at; and so accustomed have the men become to shooting at heads that the number of casualties each day is much larger than might be supposed.

Mr. O.C. TRACY, the western agent of the Children's Aid Society, has just returned from his journey to provide homes for the East Tennessee orphans. We condense some facts from his most interesting report.

The French authorities take an active part in the preparations for the reception of the sovereign, and the Master of the Ceremonies had already named the Mexican Generals who were to escort their Majesties on their entrance into their capital.

THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all millitary movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents.
It is now quite doubtful whether the National Democratic Convention called to meet at Chicago on the 4th of July will be postponed. The question will be decided on or before Monday next.

As generally expected the President arrived at Baltimore shortly after 11 o'clock this morning. Crowds gathered around the train in hopes of eliciting a speech, with which, however, they were not gratified. At Witmington the people turned out en masse, but the President made no speech there.

Early yesterday morning heavy canonading was heard along the right of our lines, and soon the report came to the city that the enemy were moving off. Later information stated that he had thrown a portion of his forces across to this side of the Chickahominy, and was moving in the direction of Malvern Hill, which position he is reported to have occupied.

Mr. MORGAN, of New York, (Union,) presented petitions in favor of the passage of the House bill for securing homesteads to soldiers and sailors of the United States service on the abandoned and forfeited lands in the South.
The Army of the Potomac took up its line of march for the Chickahominy at 3 o'clock Sunday afternoon.
The position of affairs in front has been unchanged for the last two days, with occasional slight skirmishing and firing on working parties.

Amid the absorbing interest in the progress of the war the public have hardly had leisure to notice a great and beneficent work of peace that has been going on in our City. The "Citizens' Association," it will be remembered, was founded by some of our most eminent citizens, during the past year, for the purpose of securing a pure, efficient and economical City Government.
Yesterday morning at 4 o'clock, the Eighteenth Army Corps, under the command of Gen. W.F. SMITH, left City Point and marched into Petersburgh.

The Speaker caused to be read to the House a communication from the Secretary of War, detailing recent events in connection with the capture of Petersburgh, and in which it is stated the hardest fighting was done by the colored troops.
The following information in regard to the late expedition of Gen. STURGIS is gathered mostly from officers accompanying the expedition, and is mainly correct.

Hon. AARON H. CRAGIN, who to-day has been elected to the high office of a United States Senator, is forty-three years of age and a native of the town of Weston, Windsor county, Vermont. His education, after leaving the common school, was obtained at the academics in Chester and Manchester, Vermont, and Lebanon, New-Hampshire.

There was a terrible explosion to-day at 12 o'clock in the laboratory of the United States Arsenal in this city, by which seventeen working girls lost their lives and several more were badly injured. The building in which the explosion took place is a one-story brick, divided off into four rooms, and runs east and west.
The Gazette's Lexington dispatch says that Gen. BURBRIDGE has issued an order forbidding the circulation of the Cincinnati Enquirer within the limits of his district.

The clear and succinct dispatches of the Secretary of War have made the country acquainted with the outline facts of the last great move of Gen. GRANT the transfer of the Army of the Potomac from the Chickahominy to the James River.

A Rebel Steamer Sunk. The United States steam transport Fulton, Capt. NORTON, from Port Royal June l5, arrived at a very early hour this morning. We are indebted to Purser McMANUS for the prompt delivery of our news packages.

The numerous representatives which the TIMES has had in the army since the commencement of the war, have all borne themselves with distinguished bravery. One of them at least, JESSE JOHN SON, of the One Hundred and Forty-sixth New-York Volunteers, formerly an employe in the composingroom, has been killed, and several have been severely wounded.

About 2 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in the rear of the second floor of the large six-story building Nos. 7 and 9 Mott-street, near Chatham owned, and occupied principally, by Messrs. POMEROY SCHENCK, feather-bed manufacturers. Owing to the highly combustible nature of the contents, the flames spread with great rapidity, and the entire structure was soon destroyed.

The amended Postal Law, which went into effect last July, prescribes (section 24) "that book manuscripts and corrected proofs, passing between authors and publishers, may pass at the rates of printed matter." The intent of this provision is clear: It is that all manuscripts, intended for publication, and containing no private communication, shall pass through the mails at printed rates. The object of the law is evident:

Yesterday the Democrats of the Third Congressional District held a convention at Hamilton, Butler County, for the purpose of electing delegates to the Chicago Convention. Quite unexpectedly to most of them, C.L. VALLANDIGHAM appeared in their midst, not by permission, but in defiance of the Government.
Mr. WILSON, from the Conference 'Committee on the disagreeing votes on the bill to equalize in pay of the soldiers of the army of the United States' made a report which was agreed to.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: There are occasions which gladden or sadden a whole community, when every countenance wears the cheerful impress of the general joy, or is darkened by the shadow of the general grief. No unimportant event can produce such results.

The rebel Col. CHENOWITH, accompanied by CHARLTON MORGAN and a number of JOHN MORGAN'S staff, came into Lexington yesterday with Gen. HOBSON, under a flag of truce, with the design of arranging with Gen. BURBRIDGE for an exchange of prisoners captured in the recent rebel raid. Gen. BURBRIDGE refused to recognize the flag, arrested the three rebels, and ordered Gen. HOBSON to the command of his division.

The army is again in motion. Yesterday afternoon transports commenced taking the Second Corps from Wilcox's and Swynard's Wharves, two and a half miles from here, across the James River, to Windmill Point.
Capt. BRANDT, of the Hamburg bark Hermann Molly, from the city, arrived last night, bringing advices to May 31.

Nothing of an exciting character occurred yesterday, our troops and trains being engaged in crossing all day.
A dispatch dated Headquarters Army of the Potomac, says: The army is now crossing the James River at two places, one from Wilcox's Wharf to Windmill Point, and the other about two miles below.

Operations have been commenced in earnest south of the James. The entire army under Gen. GRANT has made a safe and speedy crossing, in compact order, and at a point almost within sight of what must be the scene at last of a stupendous and decisive struggle.

The Chickahominy has been safely crossed. GRIFFIN'S Division of the Fifth Corps, preceded by a brigade of cavalry, advanced from Providence Church to Long Bridge on Sunday night. After a brief skirmish our advance guard drove off the few rebel pickets guarding this place.
It is one of the highest evidences of civilization when a community can carry on the beneficent works of peace at the same time it sustains a tremendous war.

The Cleveland Convention and its results do not create any sensations here, nor indeed, scarcely attract any attention. The delegates self-constitut ed comprise about the entire party, and are, for the most part, their own only constituency. It is not believed here that FREMONT will consent to have his name paraded before the country as the candidate of such an incongruous and motley assemblage as gathered at Cleveland.

The news from Gen. GRANT continues to be of a very cheering character. On Thursday the Second and Ninth Corps got up in position to support the Eighteenth, and succeeded in capturing another line of intrenchments, farther south than the lines held by SMITH. Each corps took several redoubts, and the Ninth captured four guns and four hundred and fifty prisoners.

Gen. GRANT, in the new campaign against Richmond from the South, will undoubtedly make use of a new and powerful weapon the gunboats, or, in other words, a strong floating battery, covering his flank. We believe this war is the first in history in which gunboats have been used in connection with a land force.

MYSTERIOUS DOINGS.--The citizens, soldiers, emigrants and others who frequent the Battery, have been entertained, of late, with a series of performances which cast those of HELLER or the DAVENPORTS quite in the shade. There seems, indeed, to be a sort of magical atmosphere hanging over the City just now, from which all kinds of strange doings are eliminated from time to time.

Mr. HARLAN, of Iowa, (Union,) reported the Northern Pacific Railroad Bill, with amendments, one of which provides that not more than ten sections of land per mile shall be granted for that part of the line east of the western boundary of Minnesota, until the whole line is finished and in running order, and that no railroad already constructed, in whole or part, shall receive the benefit of the act.

The operations of the old fighting Eighteenth Corps (Gen. W.F. SMITH) to-day have been very successful. The strong outer line of the defences of Petersburgh has been carried, with a heavy loss to the enemy in guns and prisoners, and from these works at daybreak to-morrow our troops now expect to sally forth over a clear field and enter what Virginians call "the Cockade City."

To Major Gen. Dix: This evening a dispatch from City Point, dated at 9 o'clock this morning, reached the Department. It reports that our forces advanced yesterday to within about a mile in front of Petersburgh, where they found the enemy occupying a new line of intrenchments, which after successive assaults we failed to carry, but hold and have intrenched our advanced position.

FLOUR, demand good and market unchanged. Sales, 1,200 bbls., at $8@$8.25 for No. 1 Spring; $8.50 for Red Winter; $9@$9.25 for White, and $9.75 @$10 for double extra. WHEAT in good milling and shipping demand, but the continued scarcity of Spring and Red Winter restricts transactions; sales 7,000 bushels White Canada, at $1.90; 6,700 bushels do., and 11,000 bushels No. 2 Chicago Spring, the latter to arrive, on private terms.

An official dispatch received at the War Office from City Point, dated Sunday morning, brings the intelligence that our army has advanced to within a mile of Petersburgh, where they found the enemy strongly entrenched. Several assaults were made but were unsuccessful. Our troops have however strongly intrenched their advanced position.

Gen. FORREST'S victory is greater than at first supposed. Our loss is 150 killed and 459 wounded. The enemy's loss is 1,000 killed and 3,000 captured. The balance is scattered through the woods, and are still being pursued, having traveled 58 miles in 31 hours. The entire army is destroyed.

After an early ride in from the front this morning, to mail the hastily-written letter which I sent off respecting yesterday's splendid operations of the Eighteenth Corps, I called at Gen. BUTLER"S headquarters. Here I found everybody in an unusual...
In all 21 pieces of artillery have been captured from the enemy in our assaults upon the works at Petereburgh, beside a large number of prisoners.

The steamship North American, from Liverpool on the 9th, Via Londonderry on the 10th inst., passed this point at 2 o'clock yesterday (Sunday) morning, en route to Quebec. The dates are five days later.
PATRICK KENNEDY died yesterday at Bellevue Hospital from the effects of injuries received on Sunday last. The facts of the case, so far as they can be as-...

To Major-Gen. Dix: No operations to-day on the James River have been reported to the Department. Unofficial statements represent our loss to have been severe in the assaults on the enemy's works on Saturday, but no official list of the casualties have been received.

We have read with great satisfaction the accounts of the excellent behavior of the colored troops in our armies during the recent battles. They come from perfectly reliable and disinterested sources, and leave no doubt, that in all the essential qualities of good soldiers they are fully up to the requirements of the service.
The Copperhead managers, after a good deal of blinking and boggling, have finally concluded to take the bull by the horns. They have settled not to postpone their convention.

Since the successful passage of the James River, and the advance on Petersburgh, many people have begun once more to fix a day on which Richmond is to be in our possession. The more sanguine spirits have, as might have been expected, fixed upon the Fourth of July, while others refuse to defer the realization of their hopes for more than one week more at the outside.
The House resumed the consideration of the bill to amend the Pacific Railroad Act.

Early yesterday morning a rumor was reported of the capture of Lexington, Va., by the enemy under Gens, CROOK and AVERILL. As the same rumor had once before gone round, not much credit was given it, but it being afterward confirmed by official intelligence, the question was at last settled. The enemy's forces were reported to be about 16,000 strong, and consisted mainly of cavalry, with a dozen pieces of artillery.

Mr. SCHENOK, of Ohio,(Union,) from the Com- mittee on Military Affairs, made an adverse report which was laid on the table, on the petition of certain citizens who have been confined in rebel prisons, asking that they be allowed the same pay and rations as soldiers of the United States army.

Mr. HALE, of New-Hampshire, (Union,) reported without amendment the House joint resolution authorizing the Secretary of the Navy to amend the contract with JOHN ERICSSON for the construction of the two floating batteries, Dictator and Puritan.

In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. HALE reported, without amendment, the House joint resolution authorizing the Secretary of the Navy to amend the contract with JOHN ERICSSON for the construction of the two floating batteries, Dictator and Puritan. The bill was also roported to secure homesteads for soilders and sailors on forfeited rebel estates.

The latest news from Gen. GRANT is up to Monday evening. There were no operations of any moment on that day. Our lines in front of Peters- burgh still press the enemy so closely that its evacuation is looked upon as a possibility. Gen. LONG- STREET'S corps of the rebel army, occupies the intrenchments in front of Gen. BUTLER'S com- ...

A movement has been already commenced among some of the wealthier citizens of NewYork for the supply of men for the army, and in advance of the draft. And it is understood that many will subscribe who are exempt, either on account of age or for physical disability. It is highly desirable, for social as well as political reasons, that this should be kept up and carried on.

THE TWELFTH WARD HOMICIDE THE PERPETRATOR UNKNOWN, An inquest was held yesterday by Coroner RANNEY, at Bellevue Hospital, on the body of PATRICK KENNEDY, who died from the effects of injuries received on Sunday morning last, at the corner of Third-avenue and One Hundred and Eighteenth-street. The testimony in the case all tended to corroborate the statements already published, with one exception.
The mails per the steamship China, for LiverPool via Halifax will close at 8 o'clock to-morrow (Wednesday) morning, but she will not sail until about 11 o'clock.

The convention of Black Republicans in Baltimore have renominated for President of their country ABRAHAM LINCOLN, the Illinois rail-splitter, and for Vice-President, ANDREW JOHNSON, known in the West as the Tennessee tailor, one of the meanest of that craft; whether they shall ever be elected or not, depends upon the Confederate army altogether.

[We have received the following facts relative to Atlanta and the surrounding country, from a very intelligent Northern gentleman, who has lately made his escape from that place. How he succeeded in getting through the rebel lines it would be manifestly impolitic to state, and the same reasons apply to the suppression of his name. His statements may be implicitly relied upon, and we give them as he has furnished them to us. EDS.]

The thoroughly unsectional character of the Union party is strikingly evinced in the ardent satisfaction with which the nomination of ANDREW JOHNSON for the Vice-Presidency is hailed by the party throughout the North. We have yet to hear of the slightest murmur.
The National Union Committee, H.J. RAY- MOND, Chairman, met at noon at the Astor House yesterday, for transaction of preliminary business. The proceedings were private.

At early dawn on Monday morning JOHN MORGAN'S advance guard came into town and soon the entire remnant of his badly-whipped and dispirited force arrived. They numbered about seven hundred men, and officers and men frankly conceded they had been handsomely thrashed at Cynthiana. MORGAN himself resembled a school-boy who had been whipped and was going home to tell his mother.
The Persia's machinery is reported to have been slightly damaged; she came into Queenstown using one engine only.

Comptroller BRENNAN has opened subscription books for the $2,000,000 loan authorized by the ordnance of the Board of Supervisors to provide for the procurement of volunteers for the armies of the Union, as part and parcel of the quota of this County under the anticipated call of the President for more men.

The steamship Africa, from Liverpool on the 11th inst., via Queenstown on the 12th inst., arrived at Halifax yesterday afternoon. She brings two days later news from Europe. The news from Gen. GRANT'S army is up to 4 o'clock yesterday. There was no fighting during the day, but Secretary STANTON says important movements were in progress, which, at the time of writing, were not proper for publication.
The following are the minutes of the proceedings had at a meeting of the Union Defence Committee. May 21, to do honor to the memory of the late Gen. WADSWORTH:
