The United States steam transport John Farren, Capt. SMALLMAN, has arrived here from Beaufort, N.C., which place she left on the morning of the 15th inst. The Captain reports having on his way taken off fourteen of the crew of the gunboat Lavender, which ran on Cape Lookout Shoals on the night of the 11th inst.

The Manchester market is firmer but quiet. BREADSTUFFS WAKEFIELD, NASH , and BIGLAND. ATHYA Co. report: Flour flat. Wheat dull and 1d.@ 2d. lower: Red Western, 7s. 9d, @8s. 5d.; Red Southern, 8s. 3d @8s. 6d.; White Western 8s. 6d @9s. 3d. Corn No sales, but market easier; Mixed.27s. 9d @28s.
Dispatches from City Point at half past four o'clock this morning report no fighting to-day. Movements are in progress which are not now proper for publication.

The steamship Africa, Capt. STONE, from Liverpool at noon on the 11th, via Queenstown on the 12th inst., arriied here at 1 o'clock this afternoon. Her dates are two days later than those already received.

The association reassembled yesterday morning, at 10 o'clock, in the Pilgrim Baptist Church. The audience was larger than on the previous day, and the proceedings of much importance and interest to the denomination. After the preliminary religious exercises, the reports of the committees were read and adopted.
The conference was in session three hours and a half on the 9th instant. The armistice has been extended a fortnight and will terminate on the 26th of June.
Our lines now extend from the Appomattox River past Petersburgh, and some distance beyond on the line of the river.

In the House of Lords, on the 9th inst., the Marquis of Clanricarde moved for the papers relative to the proceedings at Washington upon the subject of imigration; also, for the papers respecting the enlistment of Irish emigrants at Portland and Boston in March last, and also those respecting the enlistment of Canadian subjects in the Federal army.
The NEW-YORK WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office, in wrappers, ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS.

In the Senate yesterday, a petition was received from a colored citizen of Washington for relief to purchase his daughter, who he claims to have purchased when a slave. He states that the Emancipation Commissioners refused to allow the claim, on the ground that a slave could not acquire slave property.

In this court yesterday DAVID RYAN was con- victed of highway robbery, upon the complaint of JOHN JORDAN, whom he robbed in Fourth-avenue. near the Cooper Institute, on the 21st of May last. He was sentenced to ten years in the State Prison.

The Produce Exchange Company adopted a series of resolutions highly eulogistic of the charactor of the late Mr. JOHN B. WRIGHT, the first President of the Company, and expressive of the earnest sympathy of his old business associates for his afflicted family. On invitation of the Trustees of the New-York Commercial Association, extended to the members through Mr. E. HAYDOCK WHITE, numbers of the produce merchants attended the funeral of Mr. WRIGHT, in Brooklyn, yesterday.

THE SITUATION IN ITS GENERAL ASPECTS. Regarded in its most general relations, the present situation of the armies operating against Richmond, presents an aspect identical with that which has already thrice met us?in front of Spottsylvania Court-house, before the lines of the South Anna, and on the Chickahominy.

The Thirty-third Annual Commencement of the University of New-York took place yesterday, in Niblo's Theatre. The large and brilliant audience was, as usual on similar occasions, composed principally of ladies, who provided themselves with beautiful and costly bouquets, with which they rewarded the oratorical efforts of the graduates. The orchestra was occupied by Helmsmuller's Band and the musical selections were of the most charming and varied order.

Coroner WILDEY was yesterday called upon to hold an inquest on the body of a little girl named MARY GERRITY, aged three years and three months, who, according to the verdict of the jury, rendered after a careful and thorough investigation of all the facts in the case, "came to her death by exhaustion from injuries received at the hands of DORA CLINTON. The National steamship Company's steamship Pennsylvania, with European dates to the 8th, and the Hansa, with dates to the 9th inst., arrived here yesterday. The main features of the news they bring have been anticipated. But we find some additional items of interest.
Among the bills passed this morning relating to the District of Columbia, was one authorizing a new street in Washington City, to be called Colfaxstreet.

The steamer Von Phul, from New-Orleans 17th, has arrived here. Her news is unimportant. The French man-of-war Tishal, Com. DEMMERCAULT, had arrived and anchored opposite the city. She relieves the Amphion, which has left.
The Sanitary Fair was crowded to excess this evening, among the attractions being the visit of the Knights Templars, of Washington.

The Denver City Commonwealth publishes the following letter, written by RICHARD COBDEN, M.P., in reply to resolutions adopted by the Union League of that city:

At the present time, when the cotton culture of the world is seeking an entirely new develop ment, and science is testing the capacities of various soils in every quarter of the globe, it may be of interest and importance to the public at large to examine one very striking source of supply which seems destined to immense productiveness. We refer to Egypt, where the famous Jumel cotton is making such rapid strides.
The House passed the bill amendatory of the Pacific Railroad Act by a vote of 37. It removes some of the restrictions in the original statute, with a view to facilitate the construction of the road.

There is no later news from Gen. GRANT this morning. Further details of the movement and fights on Wednesday are given, from which it seems that the rebels observed our columns in motion, and moved out a corps under HILL to see what it meant, by which they happened to get in between the Second and Sixth Corps, as much to their surprise as ours.

Let no one suppose that he who fills faithfully and earnestly the position of Superintendent of Freedmen has a labor which is without care or anxiety. It is an easy matter so to direct them that they shall be comparatively peaceable, and exercise sufficient industry to supply the wants of the physical man, and in some cases to lay aside funds which constitute a foundation for future wealth.
Mr. MOREILL, of Maine, (Union) presented a memorial of the Rev. Dr. SUNDERLAND and others against running cars on Sunday.

The case of WILLIAM PARKER SNOW against CHARLES FRANCIS HALL, tried a few days since in the Marine Court, and at that time noted in this paper, was now decided in favor of the defendant, Dr. HALL, with $10 costs.

Fresh troops from the North are constantly arriving along the line of communication from Nashville to Chattanooga, and relieving the veteran forces from guard and garrison duty, that they may enter upon more active duty at the front. Some of the new regiments are hundred days men, and some are regularly enlisted, and, between the two, there will soon be a force amply sufficient to relieve every veteran regiment from duty to the rear.

The people of Canada are avowedly a rather excitable population; when once their sympathies are reached they will do a great deal more than perhaps the outside world would credit them with. Thus, when the subject of volunteering was first broached, then turned a deaf ear--dubbing the aspirants for bubble reputation," feather-bed soldiers," and with other titles quite as disheartening as they were unenviable, and to a certain extent uncalled for.

Another letter from the Army of the Potomac, dated near Petersburgh, June 23--8 P.M., says: We have had plenty of skirmishing all day. The sharpshooters on both sides are continually exchanging shots, and frequently pick off men who are perhaps a thousand yards distant.

The American people are credulous. Give them a fact plain, probable and undisputed, and they readily credit it. Give them a false hood positively stated, and they believe it with almost equal readiness, even though it bear evidence of falsity upon its face. And to such an extent does this popular credulity exist that a well-started and well-circulated falsehood stands little, if any, chance of ever being successfully contradicted.

The United States steamer Highland Light arrived here from City Point at 11 o'clock, which place she left at 10 o'clock yesterday morning.

Councilman Hagerty moved to suspend the rules for the purpose of taking from the table the veto message of His Honor the Mayor, of resolution that the Street Commissioner be directed to furnish each of the Police Justices of this City with a suitable badge, baton and staff of office, to be similar to those furnished to the members of the Common Council.

The House took up the resolution offered by Mr. INGERSOLL, of Illinois, (Union,) declaring as their opinion that all permits heretofore issued by the Treasury Department, allowing persons to trade with in the limits of any State heretofore or now in rebellion, should at once be revoked and no more issued.

The $2,000,000 loan recently authorize by the Board of Supervisors for bounties, it not being taken at rapidly at was anticipated, still a sufficient sum has been subscribed to warrant the belief that the amount will remain open for proposals but a short time. The steamship Bavaria, from Southampton 15th inst., was boarded off Cape Race at 2 P.M. Sunday, 26th inst. Her advices are two days later.

The House took up and concurred in the Senate's amendment to the bill authorizing the Secretary of the Treasury to release and discharge from liability the Irish Union Fair, recently held at Chicago, for having sold goods, lottery tickets, , without stamps.
The mail steamer Highland Light, from Bermuda Hundred, reports that there was a heavy musketry skirmish Saturday evening in front of Petersburgh.

As yet the County Volunteer Committee have not recommended operations in the business of recruiting. Of the $2,000,000 loan asked, as yet, $271,- 000 only has been subscribed, and, it is believed, the committee will not recommence work until $500,000 at least is subscribed.

On Saturday last, June 25, at 12 o'clock M., a fire broke out in the Pavilion, at Rockaway, completely consuming that far-famed hotel, with most of the furniture, and extending to and destroying several other buildings, viz.: WM. CLEARY'S Beach House and stables; Mr. BAINBRIDGE'S cottage, adjoining the Pavilion; Mrs. BULL'S stables and the extenslye bares belonging to the Pavilion.

Memphis papers say, on the morning of the 22d inst., a detachment of Gen. MAGRUDER'S command, 600 strong, attacked two companies of the Twelfth Iowa Infantry, stationed near the mouth of the White River.
Mr. HARLAN, of Iowa. (Union,) called up the bill for the extension of time for the location of land warrants, and it passed.
The Navy Department has decided on the course to be pursued in regard to the fleet of lightdraft iron-clad war steamers, whose failure has recently been brought to the notice of the public.

The United States steamer Newborn recently brought to this port thirty-one prisoners, captured on board the prize steamer Thistle, in the attempt to violate the blockade of Wilmington.

A morning cotemporary gives place to an insinuation against the Investigating Committee of the Board of Education, which can only be characterized as cowardly. The board is praised for its commendable alacrity in ferreting out the iniquities practiced in the Fourth Ward school.

Edward B.Wesley vs. The Mayor, c.----This action was brought to recover for rent of a portion of the premises No.39 Park-row, formerly occupied by the Street Commissioner, from May 1, 1863, to August 1 of the same year--the plaintiff claiming that the defendants had held over after the expiraton of the lease.

Our correspondent has enjoyed the best opportunities of studying the spirit of the army, both officers and privates, and his accounts can be relied upon, as both impartial and trustworthy.

Official advices from Gen. GRANT, up to Monday, May 27, at 3:30 P.M., are received. No new operations are reported. Our guns in front of Petersburgh are firing upon the bridge over the Appomattox, at a distance of 2,000 yards.

The Joint Special Committee of the Common Council, appointed to make arrangements for celebrating the coming Fourth of July, met and organized yesterday. Alderman MASTERSON was elected Chairman, and E. W. TAYLOR was appointed Secretary. Sub-committees on fireworks, stands, printing and music wore appointed, and then the committee adjourned to meet at the call of the Chairman.

The Senate Committee on Foreign Affairs had a protracted discussion to-day over the Arguelles case Secretary SEWARD has sent to the committee a very elaborate report upon the subject, in which she action of the Government in handing ARGUELLES over to the Spanish authorities is not only sustained, but fully justified. The committee adjourned without coming to any decision in the matter. It will undoubtedly go over untill next session.

To most of them it was a great luxury, and it is doubtful whether anything could be given them which would be more acceptable.

We are glad to find that the observations we made the other day with reference to the inexpediency of attempting, at this moment to mediate between the belligerents in America are entirely in ac cordance with the opinion expressed by Lord BROUGHAM in the House of Lords on Thursday.

AMBROSE W. CLARK, of New-York, (Union,) from the Committee on Printing, reported a resolution that 3,500 copies of the Report of the New-York Custom-house affairs be printed; also, a resolution that 20,000 copies of the Internal Revenue Act be printed for the use of members. The resolutions were passed.

In the charge of the First Division, Second Corps, on the works of Petersburgh, on the 16th and 17th inst., the Fifty-seventh Regiment New-York State Volunteers, under command of Maj. W. A. KIRK, were in advance.

A statistical report upon the foreign and domestic commerce of the United States, was transmitted to the Senate by the Secretary of the Treasury, on Saturday, and referred to the Committee on Printing.
The meeting of the London Conference, appointed for the 15th, had been postponed till the 16th of June, and upon that day it was further posponed to June 18.

Presentation week, the most delightful of college anniversaries, is just passed. It is always a great occasion to the students; and the unexampled series of benefactions which the college has lately received, amounting in round numbers to about half a million of dollars, seems to have awakened anew among old graduates the heartiness and spirit of the past.

The funds were dull, but without any material fluctuations. The Bank of England on the 16th inst. reduced its rate of discount from 7 to 6 cent. Arrangements are progressing for the amalgamation of the British and American Exchange Bank (in the shares of which such singular transactions have taken place) with the London and Colonial Bank.

In the Senate yesterday, the bill for the relief of the officers of the Indian Regiments was passed. The bill amendatory of the laws concerning commercial intercoorse between the loval and insurrectionary States, was brought up amended and passed. The pending motion to reconsider the vote by which the bill to prevent military interfence with the elections was passed, was taken up and reflected.

The notorious rebel cruiser Alabama arrived at Cherboarg, France, on the 11th of June, and was admitted to free pratique. She landed 40 prisoners---- the crews of the ship Tycoon, Capt. AYRES, from New-York, bound to San Francisco, destroyed by the Alabama; and of the ship Rockingham, previously reported destroyed.
The Senate passed the House bill for the relief of the officers of the Fourth and Fifth Indian Regiments, who were commissioned by the War Departmeat, but not mustered into the service.

Since I last addressed the readers of the NEW-YORK TIMES I have passed over two thousand miles of this beautiful country. I have stood in the Central Park of New-York, on the Highlands of the Hudson, on the shores of the Lakes, on the banks of the beautiful Ohio, and in the fertile vales of the Miamis.
The steamer Highland Light arrived here at 6 o'olock, from City Point.

About 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon a company of recruits from Goshen, in charge of a provostguard of eleven men, were passing through Morrisstreet, near Washington, on their way to Pier No.1, where they were to take the boat for Amboy, one of the recruits threw off his knapsack and attempted to make his escape by running down the street at full speed.

An important meeting was held yesterday noon, in the Chamber of the Board of Aldermen. The Commissioners of the Board of Health, the Quarantine Commissioners, Commissioners of Emigration, and the Senators from New-York, Kings and Richmond Counties were present Mayor GUNTHER presiding.

The Union State Contention met in this city to day for the nomination of a candidate for Governor and two Presidential Electors at large. The meeting was fully attended and harmonious in its proceedings.
The mails for Europe by the North American, via Quebec, will close on Thursday at 1:30 P. M.
Veto Message of his Honor the Mayor, of resolution to have certain streets in the upper part of the City declared open according to law.

It is well known that the system of statistical inquiry on the sanitary condition of the camps, pursued by the Sanitary Commission, has produced most valuable results, not merely affecting the present condition of our armies, but that of all future armies. The dry facts obtained are worth thousands of lives to the nation.
The schooner Cowpertkwait, which was seized on James River by the Government, leaves here this afternoon for Washington, to be delivered to the United States Marshal.

The steamer Keyport arrived here this morning from City Point, bringing up the army mails and the Third Excelsior New-York Regiment, 112 men, Lieut.-Col. JOHN LEONARD commanding; whose term of service has expired.
The French mail steamship Washington, A. DUCHESNE commanding, from Havre, consigned to GEORGE MACKENZIE, arrived at this port yesterday.
A prominent officer of the Christian Commission sends the following note to the editor of the American:

The undersigned, passengers on the first trip of the steamer Washington, have great pleasure in returning to Capt. DUCHESNE and officers their sincere thanks for the uniform courtesy with which they have been treated during their very pleasant passage between Havre and New-York. Rarely have they had opportunity to record a greater display of liberality, efficiency and decorum than has distinguished every officer and servant of the General Transatlantic Company.

The Chamber of Commerce and Board of Supervisors have reached no conclusion in the Camanche matter.
The one hundred and tenth Commencement of Columbia College took place yesterday morning, at the Academy of Music, which was crowded by a brilliant and fashionable audience.

The Senate Committee on Foreign Affairs to-day decided to postpone the Arguelles case until next December. The committee, after a full investigation of all the facts, deemed it inexpedient to take any action that will embarrass the Government.

An important meeting of the Board of Commissinners of Health, Commissioners of Quarantine, Commissioners of Emigration, and the Senators from New-York, Kings and Richmond Counties, was held at the City Hall, yesterday, to provide some place at which to land and detain well passengers from infected vessels.

Gov. O.P. Morton, Indianapolis, Ind.: DEAR SIR: I return you my most grateful thanks for your prompt assistance during MORGAN'S recent raid. The timely arrival of the Forty-third Regiment Indiana Volunteers gave us entire relief against all apprehensions of danger. Although the citizens had repulsed the rebels, yet the large numbers still infesting this section at the time of their arrival, kept us upon constant vigil, and serious apprehension of another assault.

Early next month Utah will boast another daily paper, The literary periodical productions of the Territory will then be two daily newspapers, each at ten dollars per annum; one religious weekly at six dollars, and one agricultural semi-monthly at two dollars. The Daily Union Vedette is the organ of the military, the miners, and the "Gentiles" generally.

The news is waited for with anxiety, indeed, but also with great confidence. The defeat of Gen. LEE and the surrender of Richmond, would be heavy blows to the general feeling of England.

The commencement exercises of the 117th Anniversary of the College of New-Jersey closed at Princeton, June 29.

The time of tho Sixty-seventh New York Volunteers better known as the First Long Island Regiment having expired, they left for home yesterday. This regiment was one of the first of the three years' regiments mustered into the service, and has participated in nearly every battle of the war.

We regret to see a disposition in some quarters to magnify the losses of Gen. GRANT. ISAAC BRAYTON, the efficient Superintendent of the Soldiers' Home in Nashville, the statement of the operations for the month of May of this important agency for the relief and comfort of our soldiers. The Soldiers' Home is connected with and sustained by the United States Sanitary Commission. WILSON and KAUTZ, from which it appears that after accomplishing a work of destruction never equaled in its thoroughness, our forces met with a serious disaster on their return home, and that, too, within a short distance of our own lines.

I take the liberty to forward to you a couple of pamphlets containing a project of "An act to provide for the organizing, arming and disciplining of the militia" of the United States, it is for a national act, under the constitutional power. The preface will commend itself to you.

HEARING IN THE McCROW MURDER CASE. A hearing was had before Justice DODGE on Friday, in relation to the murder of HUGH McCROW, the facts of which case have been previously reported. CHARLES VAN SAUN (not VAN ZAUN, as before stated,) is charged with the homicide upon the evidence of MICHAEL BRADY.

No importance attaches to the convention here of "the Democracy of Kentucky," yesterday, except as showing the split in the opposition. The Journal styles it "the convention called a month or two ago by several citizens of Kentucky." This Wickliffe-Harney Convention acted in a spirit of antagonism to the Guthrie-Prentice Convention of the 25th of May.

Between 1 and 2 o'clock this morning an alarm of fire was sounded in the city, but when responded to by the fire department the scene of the conflagration was ascertained to be too far distant from the city to render the services of the firemen of any avail. The alarm was occasioned by the burning of the "Seneca Flouring Mills," at Seneca Hill, about four miles south of the city.

There are, no doubt, many who take a deep interest in the great work progressing so favorably in this department, under the auspices of Gen. BANKS and others. Having occasion to visit this city on business lately, my attention was attracted by reading an order from Gen. BANKS, promulgating a system of education for the freedmen of his department.
The Select Committee, composed of Senators HALE, DOOLITTLE and BUCKALAW, appointed early in the session to investigate the subject of naval supplies, reported Friday.

Our cousins over the water used to be particularly fond of abusing Americans for their too sanguine predictions touching the duration of the Southern rebellion, but it seems as if the "Britishers" themselves had no more of the prophetic gift than the Yankees, since not one of their anticipations as to the speedy close of the petty and wretched Maorian war has been realized.
The following important correspondence appears in the Memphis Argus:

The statement that Col. WATKENS lost fifty killed and as many wounded, published in yesterday's paper, was an exaggeration. We are happy to make the correction. Tha Federal loss was only four killed and ten wounded, while the rebel lose was three hundred killed and wounded, instead of one hundred and seventy-five, as at first reported.

The Petersburgh papers of yesterday (23d) bring us news of the operations of the armies about that city, and the particulars of the flanking of HANCOCK'S corps, which was announced yesterday by telegraph. We condense the news in the following summary:

The Fourth of July this year brings no such remarkable series of victories as did the corresponding date of last year, which was glorified at once by Gettysburgh and Vicks- burgh the one saving the National Capital and the other securing the permanent triumph of our arms in the great Valley of the Mississippi.

BY the arrival here yesterday of the steamship Matanzas, Capt. LEISGANG, from New-Orleans on the 26th , via Havana on the 28th we have late and interesting news from Mexico. We are indebted to Mr. CARO, the Purser for favors.

These raids of our cavalry in Virginia have now a military significance, a practical purpose, and an immediate effect that did not appertain to many of our raids of other days. Formerly they were frequently almost purposeless, or, if they had a purpose, it was neither definite nor military.
For the past two weeks reports have accumulated which confirm all that has been previously stated with reference to the intended invasion of Missouri this Summer by the rebel General PRICE.

In the Senate on Saturday a report from the Conference Committee on the Guerrilla Bill was concurred in. A report from the Conference Com- mittee on the Enrollment Bill, agreeing essen- tially to the House bill, was concurred in.

The latest news from WILSON'S cavalry expe- dition is exceedingly satisfactory, and puts altogether a new complexion upon the reports which reached us on Saturday night. First of all, Gen. WILSON has rejoined the main army around Petersburgh, having got within the Union lines on Friday night.

The Commercial has a special dispatch from Sherman's headquarters, dated June 27, which states that an unsuccessful assault was made on the posi- tions of the rebels at Kenesaw Mountain on the morning of that day at 8 o'clock.

It is well for us to understand clearly that we are to be taxed; that we are not at peace, but at war; that a great war involves vast expenditure, and that this expenditure can be met only by taxation in one shape or another.

To Maj.-Gen, Dix: The following telegram, dated to-day at Marietta, Ga., was received this evening from Gen. SHERMAN, giving the successfurl result of the flanking operations in progress for some days back: "The movement on our right caused the enemy to evacuate.

By the arrival of the steamship Matanzas we have later Mexican news, giving some details of MAXIMILIAN'S progress toward the Capital, and the specially enthusiastic welcome accorded to him by the Indian population. SENTA ANNA is at St. Thomas preparing to enter upon his new duties as one of the Grand Marshals of the new Empire.

If the operations of the army in the field are of exceeding interest, so also are our financial affairs. We find importations of foreign luxuries still going on, in spite of a very high tariff, and gold rising in spite of a reduction in the currency.

At a meeting of the clerical and lay members of the Episcopal Diocesan Convention of New-Jersey, held immediately after the adjournment of said Convention in the city of Newark, May 26, 1864, Rev. R. M. ABERCROMBIE, Rector of St. Paul's Church, Rah- way, submitted a preamble and series of resolutions concerning the relations of the clergy to the military service, which were unanimously adopted.

On the morning of the 3d inst. at 1 A.M., between Barnegat and Absecomb Lights, the steamship Lo- cust Point, HOFFMAN, hence 2nd inst. for New-Orleans, came in collision with the steamer Matanzas, Capt. J.RISGANG, from New-Orleans for New-York, causing the Locust Point to sink in 7 minutes, in 14 fathoms water.

Gen. HUNTER, with the whole of his command, has arrived safely at this point without the loss to the army of a single pound of Government property, during a long and arduous march of 500 miles over almost impassable mountain roads, and with scarcely any feed for his command.
Rumors have been circulating here all day than a large rebel force, under the command of Gen. EWELL, had attacked the Federal troops at Martins burgh, and compelled the evacuation of that place.

When a new party comes before the public, the conservative elements of the community are naturally stirred up to know what the effects of its movements will be on the permanent interests of the country.

The steamship Fulton, from Hilton Head, on the 30th, arrived here yesterday. We are indebted to Mr. McMANUS, the Purser, for favors. Last week the town of Secessionville on the south side of James Island was vigorously shelled by our batteries on the lower end of Morris Island, and the upper end of Folly Island. The enemy did not reply with the earnestness which was expected. The shelling produced no important results.

The London Conference has practically come to an inglorious end. It sat for some time on Wednesday, the 22nd of June, to hear the last propositions of Austria and Prussia, propositions which are described as being of a nature little less than insulting.

The Volunteer Committee did not get to work yesterday, but have everything in readiness to begin to-day. The subscriptions to the new Bounty Fund loan have been increased to over $415,000. In addition to subscriptions of moneyed corporations heretofore named, the Harmony Fire Insurance Company are recorded for $10,000, and the Bull's Head Bank for $5,000.
The position of affairs has undergone no change since the meeting of the Conference on the 18th. The result of the sitting on the 22d, was awaited with much interest.

This time we have a bit of exciting war news to send you from this side of the water. The sinking of the Alabama by the Kearsarge, off the port of Cherbourg, occupies, for the moment, the thoughts and the conversation of everybody, for it is rare that so many circumstances combine to give interest to any one event.
Both Houses of Congress adjourned sine die at 12:30 o'clock this afternoon.

SHELBY, he sent forward the One Hundred and Thirty-eighth Illinois, the Ninth Iowa, the Third Missouri and the Third Regular Cavalry, under the command of Gen. CARR.

The eighty-eighth Anniversary of our National Independence was celebrated in this City with less military and civic display than is usually witnessed on the Fourth of July. The absence of such glorious news as that which electrified the nation last year at this time, served to dampen in some degree that unbounded popular enthusiasm which has always hailed the recurrence of the National holiday.
The Board of Supervisors have ordered to be printed an ordinance appropriating $60,000 for the contractors of the Camanche.

NIBLO'S GARDEN. The reproduction of the "Duke's Motto" at this house on Monday attracted a very large audience. Mr. WHEATLEY resumed his character of Henri de Lagardere, and was charmingly supported by Miss ROSE EYTINGE and by Miss MARY WELLS, Mrs. SKERRETT, Mr. NUNAN, and other members of the company. The piece will be withdrawn after a few nights, to make room for Miss LUCILLE WESTERN, who is engaged here.
United States vs. Isaac Henderson. The examination in this case was proceeded with to-day at 11 o'clock, in the Grand Jury room.

By the City of Baltimore, the general details of whose news we give elsewhere, we have the highly important and gratifying intelligence that on Sunday, June 19, the rebel pirate Alabama was engaged off Cherbourg by the United States steamer Kearsarge, which sunk her after an engagement lasting an hour and a half.
The Inman steamer City of Baltimore, from Liverpool June 23, arrived at this port yesterday morning.

Late private advises from Port Hudson show that the rebels are somewhat active in that vicinity, but avoid that well-fortified place. They have endeavored to establish themselves on the banks of the Mississippi River at Tunica Bend and at Fort Adams.

"DUPLEX ELLIPTIC PICNIC." Probably the largest picnic excursion, ever arranged exclusively for the employes of a single manufacturing establishment in New-York, left the City on Saturday for MEYER'S Grove, Staten Island. It was the fourth annual excursion of a similar character which has been arranged by the Messrs. WESTS BRADLEY, the man- ufacturers of the "Duplex Elliptic" hoop skirts.

The Dano-German Conference yesterday accomplished nothing. The proposition for arbitration was rejected. The conference is regarded as a failure, but will meet again on the 25th, for the completion of merely formal business.

The fire at Saratoga on Monday destroyed all the buildings on Broadway south of Union Hall to the Clarendon Hotel. West of these the buildings are small wooden structures, except the Water Cure, in which the fire originated, and which was destroyed. The total loss is $60,000. None of the large hotels were in the least injured.

RANSOM and EARLY, and driven from his posi- ...
The Asia reached Liverpool at 2 o'clock on the afternoon of the 19th, and the Kedar on the morning of the 20th June.
The Senate met at 9 o'clock. The bill from the House assessing a special tax on incomes was taken up, as in Committee of the Whole, and then reported to the Senate.

The National Anniversary was duly celebrated in this city, by the boys especially, who kept up a continual din with fire-crackers and pistols from Sunday evening till late on Monday night.

Oakey Hall, District-Attorney, Attorney-General John Cochrane and Judge Parker, of Albany; for the defence, E. Delafield Smith, United States DistrictAttorney, and Hon. Edwards Pierrepont.

In the English Parliament, on the 23d, inquiries were made of Ministers as to the proceedings of the conference; but Earl RUSSELL, and Lord PALMERSTON gave no information beyond the fact that the last sitting of the conference would take place on the 25th, and that on the 27th they would present to Parliament all documents relating to the conference, and make a statement on the subject.

In the House of Commons on the 23d, Sir JOHN HAY asked if the attention of the Government had been called to the action between the Kearsarge and the Alabama. He also inquired whether, in view of the experience gained by that action, Government would continue building, ships which could neither light nor swing.

The Supervisors' Recruiting Committee failed to commence operations yesterday, but will positively do so to-day at least, they officially announce in an advertisement this morning that they are now ready to enlist volunteers and pay them each the County bounty of $300. The American Exchange Bank have added a subscription of $50,000 to the Bounty Fund Loan, making the total amount subscribed $465,200.

The sales of COTTON for the week have been 45,000 bales, including 3,000 bales to speculators and 11,000 bales to exporters. The market has been irregular, with a decline of 1-11d.; but American descriptions have generally remained steady. We see that Hon. SCHUYLER COLFAX has been unanimously renominated by the Union men of his district in Indiana. This will be the seventh time he has been a candidate. His constituents have good warrant for this marked and stedfast confidence in him. Few men in the public service have achieved higher success or more thoroughly earned distinction and public confidence than he.
The steamship Asia, Capt. MOODIE, from Liverpool, noon June 25, and Queenstown 26th, arrived at this port at 2:30 this morning. She has on board 26 Halifax and 63 Boston passengers.

There is no interesting news from the Army of the Potomac. Our special correspondent gives a readable description of the manner in which the Fourth of July was observed. Salutes were fired morning, noon and night, from double-shotted guns, right into the teeth of the enemy, who made no reply. We have private information to the effect that such results will soon be attained by Gen. GRANT as will greatly gratify all loyal hearts.
The officers and seamen of the Alabama, captured by the Kearsarge, had been liberated on parole at Cherbourg.
The NEW-YORK WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office, in wrappers, ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS.

Save a national salute, at high noon, which was made peculiar and emphatic by the use of shotted guns trained upon rebel defences, Independence Day came and went with few outward signs to mark it from many others which, have been distributed during the last two weeks through the calendar of the Union armies on the south side of the James River. But the fires of patriotism burned not less...

Upward of three hundred rebel prisoners arrived in the steamer Gladiator, from Little Rock, yesterday, in charge of a battalion of MERRITT'S horse veterans, on furlough. They left for Rock Island last night.

The steamship Peruvian, from Londonderry yesterday for Quebec, returned there this morning with her screw broken. The Nova Scotian will leave Liverpool on the 27th to take on board her passengers, mails, etc., and convey them to their destina- tion.
The steamship Kangaroo, from New-York, arrived at Queenstown to-day.

One of the favorite methods of the English press at this time, when they wish to touch the "raw spot" of American feeling, is to speak of our financial course in this war, as something insane and unheard of.
The match between these two celebrated trotting mares, which had considerably exercised their several partisans in sporting circles, came off at the Union Course yesterday (Thursday) afternoon.
The Special correspondent of the Atlanta Register, writing from Gen. JOHNSTON'S army, June 24, says:

A dispatch over the inland line, from the operator at Chambersburgh, announcing that he was packing up his instruments to leave, the rebels having entered the town, created some excitement here this evening; but at the present writing (eleven o'clock) our forces not only hold Chambersburgh, but Greencastle also. The rebels, however, hold Hagerstown, and have advanced as far as Heidelburgh, near the State line. There is great alarm, however.
The Independent of this week contains another letter from Mr. WENDELL PHILLIPS. He says, by way of introduction:

There is no general celebration here to-day, but every one observes the anniversary as he sees fit. There is a military demonstration at Camp Douglas, to which the public have been invited, and numerous picnics, steamboat and railroad excursions, The great Democratic show being postponed, we are even without that attraction.
The Steamers Empress and Leviathan, from New-Orleans on the 38th ultimo, and the City of Alton, from Memphis yesterday, have arrived here, but they bring no news.

The attempt on the part of Gen. SMITH to carry one of the enemy's salients in his front on Thursday night, resulted in more casualties than was at first believed. Not less than 150 men were wounded, principally by shells, and, with scarcely an exception, the injuries were of a most terrible character.

The Star says: We have information direct from Hagerstown, to the effect that on Tuesday afternoon at 3 o'clock, a rebel squad, consisting of fifteen cavalry men, commanded by Lieut. SHARER, formerly of Martinsburgh, Va., entered that place. This force appeared to be a reconnoitering party, and they had only been in the town a few moments when a detachment of our Regular Cavalry, from Carlile, Penn., commanded by Lieut. MCLEAN, dashed into the place.

PASSING COUNTERFEIT BILLS. Detectives CORWIN and FROST arrested two men, yesterday, named JAMES FERRIS and MARK LEVY, on the charge of passing counterfeit $2 bills, purporting to be issues of the Bank of Saratoga Springs. Some $10 of spurious bills was found upon their persons. The accused were taken before Justice PERRY and committed for examination.
The annual commencement of Hamilton Colege, Clinton, N.Y., will be held Thursday, July 21.

We were the witness yesterday of an interesting scientific experiment, the practical results of which were of the most satisfactory nature. This was nothing less than the blowing up of a bar which had formed near one of the upper wharves, and which interferred with the landing of vessels.

The steamship Nova Scotian, from Liverpool, Monday noon, 27th ult., passed this point to-day, enroute to Quebec, with the passengers and cargo transferred from the Peruvian, which steamer had returned to repair damages.

There is a pause to-day in the firing of artillery; the rebel shells have ceased to burst about and among us; only an occasional bullet from the rifle of some irrepressible rebel skirmisher whistles over our heads; and in this lull one may attempt the use of pen and ink.

The recent meeting of the sovereigns of Austria, Russia and Prussia, at Kissingen, is viewed by Western Europe with suspicion, despite the assurance of its being a mere social reunion. The meeting of the rulers of these identical States at Verona, in 1822, had, it was avowed, no more political significance than the present one, and yet it led to the formation of a great coalition, and to the overthrow of constitutionalism in Spain.

I sent you despatches yesterday, giving the status of affairs at 7 P.M., and it appearing that the great raid had reached its culmination, or had assumed a new phase, having different objects and sending the raiders to other sections of the country, it may be as well to take a general view of it to this date.

The indications are growing more and more plain of a protracted, wearing struggle between the Union and the rebels, in which the strongest will and the longest purse are to gain the final victory. We have always taken the ground that the war was not to be closed by a coup de main, but would be a trial of endurance and pluck.

Fire was discovered in the attic of the "old forging shop" at the United States Armory in this city about 8 o'clock Saturday evening, the point where it was noticed being about forty feet from the chimney at the west end of the shop. As soon as it was known to the workmen in the second story of the shop some of them rushed up stairs and empiled...

A letter from Annandale, Va., six or eight miles west of Alexandria, says a scout of 150 men from the Second Massachusetts and Thirteenth New-York Cavalry, under command of Major FORBES, went up in the vicinity of Aldie, where they met MOSBY with a large force and a piece of artillery and riflemen.
sylvania Union State Committee, has issued an address to the people of the State, from which we make the following extracts:

This is my first opportunity of addressing you from this land of rocks and minerals. We had a very pleasant passage here of just one month to a day. There is but little news from Maryland to-night excepting that relating to the movements of our own forces, which, of course, it would be impossible to divulge.

It is noteworthy that in a parliamentary debate on the question of emigration from Ireland to the United States, which must have occupied four or five hours of the time of the House of Commons, not one of the speakers seems to have spoken from any authentic knowledge of the condition of the emigrent after his arrival here. Such a debate took place in the House of Commons on the 21st ult.

It is ascertained from parties who arrived in the mail-boat to-day from City Point, that on Thursday the rebels brought a battery to bear upon a working party of ours, who were engaged in throwing up earthworks nearer to Petersburgh, and for a while a sharp cannonading took place, our men having also brought up a battery to oppose that of the rebels, and that the latter was soon silenced.

SANDFORD took place yesterday, for the purpose of deciding what regiments should be sent out under the call.

A reliable dispatch received here estimates the the strength of the enemy at 40,000, most of which force is now in Maryland.

OAKEY HALL, with Attorney-General JNO. COCHRANE, appeared for the State; for the defendants, Judge PIERREPONT and W.M. EVARTS, Esq.

The rebels who were proceeding toward Washington at such rapid speed are becoming alarmed at the advance of HUNTER, and are retracing their steps. My informant could not state whether they were moving back toward Frederick or in this direction. It is rumored here to-night that the vandals have destroyed some of the bridges on the Northern Central Railroad. The city is deserted of strangers.

What is the real magnitude and meaning of this new rebel invasion of Maryland? Just a week ago to-day the news of an advance movement of a large rebel force up the Shenandoah Valley astonished the incredulous country.
The rebel cavalry burned the residence of Gov. BRADFORD this morning. It is only four miles out from this city, on the Charles-street road.

The Conference has ended. It has failed. There is a formal meeting to-day to exchange protocols and say good-bye, but the quarreling is over. The armistice is not extended, so that to-morrow the absurd fight begins again. The Danes blockade the German ports. The German proceed to take Alsen. The English newspapers threaten to send a fleet to the Baltic. RUSSELL and PALMERSTON do not say that.

The year's study at West Point is finished, the Board of Visitors come and gone, Gen. McCLELLAN made his speech, (a very good one,) and the Professors are taking their siesta after their labors. It is a suitable time to say something of West Point which has not heretofore been said. I have read most of the reports of the Boards of Visitors Visitors who are generally incompetent for such a duty.

The Governor will issue an order to all the military of the state to hold themselves in readiness for service, and a proclamation urging the citizens to volunteer into the National Guard.

Between 1 and 2 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out on board the steamer John Potter, owned by the Camden and Amboy Railroad Company, and at the time lying at Pier No. 1 North River. She was heavily laden with merchandise of various kinds, having just arrived at her dock, and owing to the highly inflamable nature of some of the articles on board, the flames spread with great rapidity through the vessel.

The enemy made a simultaneous attack on our right, when our batteries, ably assisted by those on Kenesaw Mountain, Commanded by Col. STOW FRENCH'S Chief of Artillery, opened a most galling fire upon them. Their loss is not yet ascertained, but it is thought to be very heavy. Forty ambulances are now in sight carrying off their wounded.

Firing at long range is the peculiar office of a rifle gun. "A quarter of a mile," even three-quarters of a mile, cannot be called long range. Why Capt. SEMMES thought fit to throw away the greatest advantage he possessed over Capt. WINSLOW, is a mystery. We would have noticed the fact before this, but there were no proofs to hand that the Alabama really had a rifle gun on board.

No collision of any moment has taken place between our forces and the enemy in Maryland since the affair of Saturday last on the Monocacy. But the rebels have, for the last two days, been dashing freely and furiously around Maryland approaching to within half a dozen miles of Baltimore, and an equal distance of Washington destroying railroad bridges, capturing railroad trains,...
The Philadelphia, Baltimore and Wilmington Railroad still remained intact this morning.
A Cape May dispatch states that the officers and crews of five vessels recently destroyed off the Caps have been landed there, and have been forwarded to Philadelphia.

Yesterday and to-day have been the most exciting of the days of wild tumul so frequently witnessed during the progress of the war, in this city. The excitement and uproar rivailed the ever memorable 19th of April, in intensity, and only differed from that shameful day in the politics of the demonstration, and the class of persons who thronged our streets with arms in their hands.

The steamer Etna, from Liverpool June 29, via Queenstown June 30, arrived here yesterday with one day's later news, but there is nothing in her advices. A meeting of the opposition members of the House of Commons had been held, at which was submitted a resolution of censure of the Government for its course on the Denmark war question.

The Inman steamer Etna, Capt. McGUIGAN, which left Liverpool at 3 P.M. on the 20th, and Queenstown on the 30th of June, arrived here yesterday. Her news is one day later than that brought by the Germania.

Mr. Secretary FESSENDEN was, yesterday morning, introduced to a number of the National Bankers, of this City, who waited upon him at the Treasury Office. He subsequently had a lengthy conference with the Associated City Banks, the results of which were left to be determined at an adjourned meeting this morning.
We cannot help hoping that, if anything will ever serve to open the eyes of the public to the defects of our militia system, it will be the events now taking place in Maryland and Pennsylvania.

The news from Maryland this morning is meagre and indefinite. At 1 o'clock yesterday the rebels made their appearance on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, at Bladensburgh and Beltsville, seven and twelve miles respectively from Washington, and interrupted telegraphic communication, since which time there have been neither dispatches nor trains.

The Times' City article says the Discount market remains without any symptoms of pressure. The English funds are stagnant, and seem likely to be free from, material fluctuation for some time little anxiety being now felt with regard to politics. The general feeling of the country has confirmed the course marked out by the Government on Monday night.

I was looking over the census account of "Vocations" in the United States, and was greatly struck by a wonderful revelation in those plain, dry figures, of what some call "progress," and others "civilization," but what I call the evolution of Christianity in facts.

OLYMPIC THEATRE, AUBER'S opera of "Fra Diavola" was revived here on Monday evening, and attracted a good and fashionable audience. It has evidently been put on the stage in great haste, and without that regard to preparatory rehearsal, which the light but delicate music of the French composer demanded.

Whatever reason there may be to alter any opinion heretofore expressed as to the scope of the so-called invasion, there can be none whatever as to the needlessness of the alarms which have been rung at every village station where a rebel scout has made his appearance.

Hon. C. Godfrey Gunther, Mayor of the City of NewYork: SIR: Although I cannot concur in your definition of Patriotism, I fully agree with you in the neceesity of retaining an organized and disciplined military force in our City, sufficiently strong to suppress any attempt of the lawless and evil-disposed members of our community to renew the scenes of arson and plunder which disgraced our City last Summer, during the absence of the City regiments.

I have just arrived in this city, bringing with me the Baltimore press dispatches. to 4 P.M. yesterday. The excitement was very great at news of the burning of Gunpowder Bridge, and at the interruption of the telegraph.

The American Club the leading one or our City organizations for Summer encampment in the country gave a grand entertainment on Monday evening, at their club-house and grounds at Green- wich, Conn., on the occasion of opening the same for the season of 1864. The guests were very numerous, upward of 2,000 visitors being present, of whom a large share were ladies.

The excitement occasioned by the President's call for militia is gradually subsiding, owing to the fact that the different organizations have been perfected and the bustle incident to the sudden calling of men into the field is over. Our soldiers are now quietly holding themselves in readiness for any emergency.

The majority of Presidents and Superintendents of the leading railroads in the United States met at the St. Nicholas Hotel yesterday, in general convention, which will last for two or three days. Several matters of importance respecting the running of trains, regulations of freights, , will be placed before the members of the convention.

COTTON Sales to-day 12,000 bales, including 6,000 to speculators and exporters. The market is firmer, but unchanged, for most descriptions, but American is advancing.

FATAL ACCIDENT. A man named HUGH McCAFFREY, employed in EISLER'S Foundry, at Red Hook Point, fell from a boiler yesterday and was killed. His family reside at the corner of Van Brunt and Dykeman streets. The Coroner was notified.

The Wheeling Intelligencer of Monday says: Gen SULLIVAN'S advance reached Martinsburgh yesterday, entered the place and took many prisoners. SULLIVAN commands the advance of Gen. HUNTER'S forces. We may thus know that our troops are vigorously pushing on after the enemy. They will doubtless be in contact with the rebels before many hours, perhaps to-day.

Gen. COUCH is at Philadelphia. The excite ment here is rapidly dying out. The stores are still closed, and recruiting is progressing slowly. A steady stream of Union refugees, with teams and droves of horses, , is passing through this city, returning home.

Before Justices Leonard, Clerke and Sutharland. John Owen and George G. Bellows vs. Jane F. Cowley and S.B. Cowley, her Husband. This action was brought to recover for services rendered by the plaintiffs as attorneys and counsellors for the benefit, as alleged, of the wife's separate estate.

The Cunard steamship Australasian, from Liverpool on the 2d and Queenstown on the 3d of July, arrived here yesterday. A seaman's boarding-house keeper in Liverpool had been brought before the Police Court, on a warrant from the Treasury, charging him with obtaining seamen for the rebel cruisers Georgia and Rappahannock.
The NEW-YORK WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office, in wrappers, ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS.

A DINNER TO CAPT. WINSLOW BY MR. DAYTON. Mr. DAYTON, the American Minister at Paris, had been giving a grand dinner to Capt. WINSLOW, of the Kearsarge, and all his officers who could be spared from duty.
The Royal Mail steamship Australasian, which left Liverpool at 8:30 on the morning of the 2d, and Queenstown on the 3d of July, arrived here yesterday afternoon.

It was rumored here yesterday that JOE JOHNSTON has gone to Richmond, but nothing positively is known with regard to the matter.

Major-Gen. FRANKLIN, arrived safely in this city about 3 o'clock this morning, as was anticipated from the information received yesterday, and is now at Barnum's Hotel, resting from his fatigue and exposure.
No intelligence has been received from the fleet of gunboats that left yesterday in search of the privateer that destroyed the bark Greenwood.

We greatly regret to see a disposition in some quarters of the Union party to keep up old bickerings. Even were there any principle involved in them, they would be inexcusable, since the party, through its accredited representatives, has settled all its essential principles at Baltimore.

A train came through from Baltimore this morning, leaving at 9 A.M. With the exception of five mud-cars, which the rebels burnt at Beltsville, and cutting the telegraph wire, no damage has been done; not a single rail has been removed from its place.

The news from Mexico which we publish this morning presents no feature of greater political interest than the reported disbanding, by Gen. DOBLADO, of the Juarist force under his command, the simultaneous desertion of the colors of the Republic by Gen. URAGA, along with his force, and the submission of both Generals to the newly-founded dynasty.

STATED SESSION THURSDAY, July 14, 1864. Present John T. Henry, Esq., President in the Chair, Aldermen Jones, McMahon, McCool, Shannon, Chipp, McKnight, Jeremiah, Hardy, Kelly, Masterson, Farley, Long.

By the steamship Liberty, which arrived here from Havana, at a late hour on Wednesday night, we have Mexican news to the 2d inst. and Havana dates to the 9th. It is said Gen. URAGA, with his whole army, has given in his adhesion to MAXMILIAN, and that this example has been followed by Gen. DOBLADO.

The rebel raid, which was looked upon as being too insignificant to require serious attention, has exceeded all others in magnificent daring. Judging from the results so far, it is a greater achievement than HUNTER'S. They are at the very doors of two cities, fortified as strongly, perhaps, as engineering skill could devise, destroying property in the outskirts with perfect impunity, regardless, apparently, of any force we can send against them.

The latest news from the rebels in Maryland, is that they will probably escape across the Poto- mac in the vicinity of Edwards' Ferry, without serious loss our forces evidently not being strong enough, or not being concentrated soon enough to attack the enemy with assurance of success.

"Hostilities around Washington and Baltimore have ceased," says one of this morning's dispatches from Washington. "The great rebel raid is over," says another. "The main force of the rebels is now (Thursday) in full retreat, trying to save their booty," it is further added.

There are three species of Copperheads. Those who, like ALEXANDER LONG, are for abolishing the war and recognizing the independence of the Confederacy outright. This is one of the most beautiful and valuable books that we have seen for a long time. The paper, binding and typography are unexceptionable. The maps and plans are admirably executed, and, while absolutely essential to military men, will be found exceedingly useful to other readers.

A train with about eight hundred and fifty rebel prisoners, on their way to the camp at Elmira, collided with the Pennsylvania Coal Company's train between here and Shohola, this afternoon, killing and wounding a large number reported at over one hundred.

A correspondent writes from Guaymas, Mexico, June 29, that official information has been received there of a conspiracy to seize one or more of the steamers on the coast for privateers, and that a party had been sent from Secessia for that purpose. The persons indicated are said to be at Guaymas, where steps have been taken to check them.

This evening's Telegraph has the following dispatch from Baltimore: "All is quiet here to-day. No armed rebels are heard of in the State. The pass system is now abolished here for all travelers and citizens.

Catharine Johnston vs. James W. Johnston. in 1849, or about that year, the defendant, who was then a married man, contracted marriage with the plaintiff. Thereupon the first wife made complaint and procured the conviction of the defendant for bigamy, and he was sentenced to imprisonment at Sing Sing for three years.

The most destructive fire that has occurred in Brooklyn for many years took place yesterday afternoon in the warehouses of Messrs. SOHENOK RUTHERFORD, on the dock at the foot of Joralemostreet and although the value of property destroyed was great, it is fortunate that there was no loss of life, or, as far ascertained, no person very seriously injured.

The Nashville Union, of the 13th, says: We have further particulars relating to the crossing of the Chattahoochee, which are highly interesting. The rebels, on Sunday, finding SHERMAN had effected a lodgment south of the river, burned the railroad and turnpike bridges, together with three pontoons.

The latest news from Maryland brings no intelligence of any further fighting. The rebels are said to be across the Potomac, and pursued by our forces, but the latter statement needs confirmation. The reports from various portions of Maryland which were visited by the enemy, all agree as to the ravages which the rebels committed. Horses, cattle, hogs and sheep were swept clean, and much personal robbery and thieving was also indulged in.

Speculations continue to be made as to the number of rebels recently menacing this city, but there are no data by which to determine this question. From conversations with farmers from Montgomery County to-night, it appears that the fields for some miles were filled with the enemy, and that those who made the demonstration on our immediate front were only the advance of their army.

WHOLESALE ROBBERY BY A FEMALE--$2,500 WORTH OF GOODS RECOVERED.--A woman who gave her name as MARIA FISCHER, was taken into custody yesterday by Officers FIELD and WALLING, of the Fifth Precinct, by orders of Capt. PETTY. MARIA was found at Union Hill, New-Jersey, with three large and well stored trunks in her possession.

The excitement among our State militia occasioned by the call of the Government for their services, has almost entirely subsided. It is thought the orders calling many of our regiments into the field will be countermanded, and that but few if any of them not now on route for Washington will leave the City.
The steamship Caledonia, from Glasgow on the 5th inst., arrived off this point en route to New-York of 5 o'clock this (Friday) morning. Her dates are three days later than those already received.
The Vicksburgh Herald of the 12th instant, says in regard to our late expedition to Jackson, that our forces moved from Black River on the morning of the 3d instant, in command of Gen. DENNIS.
Late last evening HOOD'S corps attacked the enemy, taking two lines of his intrenchments and capturing twelve pieces of artillery.

Information has been received here direct from Loudon Valley to the effect that the rebel force, on its retreat from Maryland and Washington, is moving down that valley toward Gordonsville.

CONY has information that the suspicious steamer Fung Suey, which sailed from St. John on Wednesday last, purporting to be bound for China, put into the port of Cutler, in this State, on Thursday night. DEAR BART: I heard some time ago of the action of the Baltimore Convention in the nomination of Mr. LINCOLN and Mr. JOHNSON. I think this army is almost unanimous in favor of Mr. LINCOLN'S election; and Governor JOHNSON's nomination will do good to the cause.

A CARMAN HANGS HIMSELF. JAMES TAMNEY, a carman, residing at No. 158 Washington-street, committed suicide yesterday afternoon by hanging himself by the neck from the top of a door on the second story of the premises, by means of a leather strap.

It is difficult for an Englishman who desires to pierce the American blockade to decide which of the available routes offers the greatest facilities and attractions. My own experience during the present year would seem to prove that, as regards time there is little choice between land and water.

Yesterday afternoon, as the hour approached at which the House of Commons was to assemble, an extraordinary amount of excitement prevailed in the immediate neighborhood of the House, indicative of the interest taken out of doors in the impending debate, and reminding one of the gatherings in that quarter during the party struggle which preceded the passing of the Reform Bill.

We saw a gentleman yesterday morning direct from Mathews county, who states that there have been no raiders in that region for some time, and that the people are now enjoying a temporary state of quietude. With the exception of burnt mills, empty smoke-houses and corn-cribs, pillaged barns and hog-pens minus hogs, the face of the country is wearing its usual appearance.

Yesterday, at 2 o'clock, the eighty-eighth anniversary of American Independence, a number of Americans entertained at breakfast, in St. James' Hall, Capt. Wheeler and Engineer Cushman, of the Kearsarge. Internal Revenue Commissioner LEWIS left Washington yesterday morning to be absent ten days. During his absence Mr. Deputy-Commissioner ROLLINS will discharge the duties of this important office.

This was a libel filed to recover damages for loss and injury to some retorts and tiles shipped on board the brig at Antwerp, to be brought to this port. The libelants alleged that the loss was occasioned by insufficient care in the stowage and carriage of the goods.

The July receipts at the office of Internal Revenue up to the 16th were $9,830,000. The Commissioner of Internal Revenue has decided that appraisers' levies of execution upon real estate do not require revenue stamps as conveyances. Disbursing officers will retain 5 per cent, income duty on Government salaries instead of 3 cent, as heretofore at pay-days on and after the close of July.

THE PUBLIC DEBT. According to official statement for the week ending, July 12, just published, the total public debt on that day was $1,795,033,569.34 against $1,792,867,040.51 on 5th inst. The outstanding amounts, with the interest due respectively thereon, are given below: Debt bearing interest in coin, $864,109,819.62; interest, $52,113,311.67. Debt bearing interest in lawful money, $400,330,010.21; interest, $21,639,192.81. Debt on which interest has ceased, $370,170.09. Debt bearing no interest, $530,223,569.37. Total, $1,795,033,569.34; interest, $73,752,554.48.

TRADE REPORT. In the Manchester market prices are still advancing.

On this day four years ago we quoted cotton in our commercial columns at 10 @10 3/8 cents per pound. To-day our quotation is $1.64 per pound, which after reducing the currency to a gold standard makes the present price of raw cotton in New-York as near as may be seven times its price on the 20th of July, 1860.

The date of my letter is suggestive. It reminds me most vividly of the excitement and exhilaration in which I participated on the 15th of June just four weeks ago to-night when those marvelously strong works in front of Petersburgh were wrenched from the rebels, and seized by the Union army with a determined and unrelenting grip, which must in time strangle the rebellion, or, at least, make the evacuation of Richmond a necessity.

Government is in receipt this morning of glorious news from SHERMAN. It is not news of battle, but something better.

The steamship Northern Light arrived at this port yesterday evening from Aspinwall, bringing advices from that port to the 10th inst. On the 17th, in lat. 34 , long. 74 , she was chased by a suspicious-looking schooner-rigged propeller, probably a rebel privateer, but showed her a light pair of heels and escaped. Her news is unimportant.

COTTON Sales to-day 20,000 bales. Yesterday's sales were also 20,000 bales; the market, is excited, and prices are of a penny higher; inclosed in the sales today were 10,000 to speculators and exporters.

In common with many portions of our country we are suffering from a severe drought, having had no rain of any amount since the 10th of June. As a consequence, crops of all kinds are parched, and must be a small yield.

The progress of the war has vastly simplified its operation. Instead of being waged in detail at a multitude of points along border lines and coast lines, with intervals of hundreds, and even thousands of miles, it now is made to bear almost exclusively upon two positions Richmond and Atlanta the one recognized to be the key to the northeastern, the other to the southwestern, portion of the "Confederacy."

If the Provost-Marshal-General is not now put in possession of regular weekly, or semi-weekly returns of the number of new recruits reported at the offices of his various deputies, he ought to order these returns.

Another name is added to the list of hero martyrs who have fallen in the service of their country. Col. WILLIAM SACKETT, of the Ninth New-York Cavalry, (son of Hon. W.A. SACKETT,) was mortally wounded in the engagement, under Gen. SHERIDAN, at Pavillion Station, Va., and died on the 14th ult. As he was left behind, the sad intelligence of his decease has but just been received.

Forty-three Opposition members of Congress have united in an Address to the people, to show that to use their own words "there is good reason for changing the Administration and policy of this General Government."
I am indebted to one of Gen. WASHBURNE'S staff officers for the following highly important intelligence:

The latest official information from Gen. SHERMAN, is that his army crossed the Chattahoochee in several different places north of the railroad bridge. The movement was made with such celerity as to take the enemy by surprise, and therefore the resistance to his advance was feeble on the part of the rebel cavalry.

Private letters from Lexington say that from three to nine hundred bushwhackers are in Ray County. Some Federal troops had a fight with them on Sunday, near Richmond, in which six or eight of our men were reported killed.
Steamships Kedar, (Br.,) Muir, Liverpool, E. Cunard; Potomac, Sherwood, Portland, H.B. Cromwell Co.; Roanoke, Drew, Havana, Ludlam Heineken.

We would respectfully recommend to those citizens of Hagerstown, Frederick, Greencastle and Chambersburgh, who are annually plundered by rebel raids, the following instructive occurrence: Gen. WILSON recently led a corps of some six thousand cavalry on one of his destructive expeditions.
The following important dispatch from Niagara Falls to the Rochester Democrat, was telegraphed to a private party in this City, last evening. We do not vouch for its accuracy.

SIR: Called to the high and important dignity of Chief of Finance, fearful in its responsibility, with a depleted treasury, in the midst of a sanguinary civil war, the Government in want of funds, things generally out of joint, the land covered all over with enemies, the money centres filled with financial traitors, cunning artifice and fraud resorted to by the enemy, yet fear not, be of good cheer, the people are with you.

U.S. gunboat Tahoma, D.B. Harmony commanding, Washington, D.C., 3ds. French corvette Phlegiton, Maudet, Alexandria 48 hours. 20th inst., 10 A.M., saw a sohr. on fire; ran to her, but they wanted no assistance, a small tug having taken off the crew. She was hay laden and bound S.; would be totally lost.
The following paragraph from the Richmond Examiner of July 16, shows that the rebels have not yet restored the Danville Road, which was so thoroughly destroyed by Gen. WILSON:
A terrible disaster occurred at the Blockley Almshouse this morning, caused by the walls of the Female Lunatic Asylum being undermined by workmen.
The United States steam-transport Fulton, J. A. WOTTON commander, from Port Royal, S.C., July 17, having in tow the steam-transport America, disabled, arrived yesterday morning.

The "peace negotiations " which have attracted public attention for a few days past, are further elucidated this morning by the publication of the correspondence between Messrs. HORACE GREELEY and SANDERS, CLAY and HOLCOMBE, the rebel emissaries at Niagara Falls.

The magnanimous Confederate army having raised the siege of Washington, leaving some of their martyred heroes buried near its confines, all kinds of vehicles have been in great demand the past three days, conveying strangers and the inhabitants to the scene of the recent conflict.

I never before so fully realized the depths to which men fainted with the heresy of secession could descend; never before did I so fully realize that the leaders of the men in arms against the Government had so much cause for the contemptuous manner they have ever manifested toward everything emanating from Union sources. "H.J.W.," our correspondent at Gen. BUTLER'S headquarters, forwards us Richmond papers of Monday last, July 18, from which we extract as follows:

On Sunday night, as Capt. MOSES, with fortyseven men of the Second Colorado, was scouting near Fredericksburgh, Clay County, Mo., they came upon 300 bushwhackers. The advance of the rebels were dressed in Federal uniform, and correctly replied to the challenge of our men, but their whole force immediately afterward charged upon our troops, and a bloody little fight ensued.

The Board of Councilmen again failed of a quorum yesterday, and were adjourned by the Clerk to next Monday, at 2 P.M. The Common Council have done little or nothing for a month past, and dullness pervades the City departments.

The troops under Gen. HATCH, which landed on John's Island the 1st inst., brought the expedition in that section to a successful close last Saturday having on that day been attacked twice by the enemy, repulsing him each time with a severe lose. On Friday night Gen. HATCH'S main position was about five miles southwest of Legareville.

Advices from Chillicothe state that THORNTON was twenty miles south of there this morning, where he told his men he was going to Howard County; but it is believed that he will try and cross the Missouri River and get South.

The Courier of the 12th has the following: "Nothing of special importance occurred Monday. The bombardment of Fort Sumter continues without intermission day and night from Gregg and Wagner. From 8 A.M. to 6 P.M., Monday, 127 shots were fired at the fort. Twenty-seven shots have been fired at the city since the last report.

A telegram of last night from Albany lets us know that Gov. SEYMOUR will not appoint State agents to recruit negroes in the Southern States, as he does not believe this to be wise or practicable; but if cities or counties choose to pay bounties and appoint agents for recruiting such soldiers, they can do so, and the State authority will give them such facilities as the act of Congress directs.
Nothing of importance has transpired in the department since the date of my dispatches sent by the Carolina three days ago.
Maj.-Gen. Dix yesterday directed United States District-Attorney A.G. KEASBEY, of Newark, N.J., to arrest and prosecute the editor and proprietor of the Newark Evening Journal.
Sandwich Islands advices of June 25 say that a majority of the members elected to the Constitutional Convention are opposed to any changes in the mode of Government already proposed.

The most encouraging piece of news which has reached us with regard to SHERMAN'S position in Georgia, is that Gen. BRAGG has gone to Atlanta to exercise a personal supervision over the movements of the rebel army.

I do not know that I went into ecstacies, but I certainly felt a great deal of sober pleasure and devout thankfulness on awakening this morning to hear the heavy pattering of rain upon my tent-roof.

Eighty-one rebel prisoners have been brought here from Sandy Hook, Md. They state that they were in charge of one of the plunder trains, and were overtaken near Snicker's Gap by a portion of the pursuing force under Gen. CROOK. A fight immediately followed; but the train guard, finding it impossible to save the train, destroyed it by fire, and retreated, leaving the teamsters and others at the mercy of our forces.
The mails by the Europa reached this City yesterday morning, from Boston. They furnish us the following interesting details of news:

Our harbor is again ornamented by an iron-clad frigate of the Italian navy. The new and splendid two-decker Re de Luizi de Portogallo, sister ship to the Re d'Italia, has been turned over to the representatives of King VICTOR EMANUEL by Mr. WILLIAM H. WEBB, who built her.

The will of J.G. Boyle, now admitted to probate, makes, the following charitable bequests: To the Roman Catholic Orphan Asylum of this City, $500; to the Society of St. Vincent de Paul of St. Joseph's Church, $250; to the same Society of St. James' Church, $250. The will of Mary Louise Bleecker, also admitted, leaves $300 to the Orphan Home and Asylum of the Protestant Episcopal Church of this City.

The immense reinforcements which will be secured to the National armies by the last Proclamation of the President, of course have a most important military bearing. They will make these armies irresistibly superior to any force which the "Confederates" can possibly bring against them. If LEE'S and JOHNSTON'S armies have not been able to prevent GRANT...
Official information from Gen. SHERMAN represents everything to be progressing in a manner highly satisfactory.
Yesterday was a day of more than usual activity at the front.

The business of recruiting in this City exhibits a gratifying increase of activity. The average number of volunteers received daily at the recruiting headquarters now averages over one hundred, exclusive of representative substitutes and substitutes furnished in advance of the draft. If the earnest efforts of Supervisor BLUNT are properly seconded by the citizens of New-York, the city may be spared the inconvenience of another draft.

We can vouch for the entire reliability of the facts and figures which follow, and they effectually settle the question of the strength of the rebel force:

Hon. Andrew Johnson: DEAR SIR: The undersigned have great pleasure in performing the duty assigned to them of informing you of your unanimous nomination for the office of Vice-President of the United States, by the National Union Convention, which closed its sittings in this city yesterday.

The Federal war steamer Kearsarge arrived in Dover Roads on Wednesday evening. From three to five hundred prisoners have passed through Rockingham from Maryland, captured principally during the first of the invasion by our forces. They are principally Ohlans, and nearly all were one hundred day men.

Richmond journals of the 20th inst, announce that JOE JOHNSTON has been relieved of his command in Georgia by Maj. Gen. J.B. HOOD. Army officers who knew HOOD at West Point think that the Confederacy has not bettered itself by this change. HOOD is a Kentuckian by birth, and graduated from the Military Academy in 1852 not by any means at the head of his class.

Last evening Prof. BROWN delivered in the College Church a discourse commemorative of the lamented Prof. JOHN NEWTON PUTNAM, who, it will be recollected, died last October on board the Alpha, between Halifax and Boston.

The underwriters' agents are availing of the present fine weather to raise as much as posible of the wreck as it now lies on Daunt's Rock. A large float or barge has been procured from the ship-building yard of ROBINSON Co., and is furnished with a crane of some power for the work of lifting.

The prospect of there being no draft in this City in September, is exceedingly encouraging. The business of recruiting, which is progressing satisfactorily, will be very considerably increased when the new offices are open. The building on the Battery is completed, and will be taken possession of by Supervisor BLUNT to-morrow.

Official dispatches of another battle before Atlanta, fought on Friday, were received by the authorities last night. At the time of sending the dispatch the contest was still going on, but the results, so far as developed, were favorable. A position had been gained from which SHERMAN was able to bring his siege guns to bear on the city. Extensive fires were raging within its limits as though the rebels were burning stores,

Memphis papers of the 22d say that Gen. SMITH'S command was moving into Memphis.
