A letter from the Army of the Potomac, dated yesterday, says. Nothing of peculiar interest has occurred in the past two days. The skirmishing in BURNSIDE'S front Friday afternoon was quite lively, but without injury to our men. This is the only part of the line where it may be said the firing is almost unceasing, scarcely five minutes elapsing in the day or night, without hearing musketry yr artillery.

The English Opera Company at the Olympic Theatre announce that this will be the last week of their performances there. They have given, so far, three operas--all of them old and threadbare; still, the attendance has been highly respectable, both in numbers and character.

The Boston Transcript gives the following statistics of the Harvard Senior Class: In 1860 the admissions to the class of 1864 were 112. Subsequently the class numbered 144, but is now 96. The Boston Journal publishes the following extracts from a private letter written by Lieut.-Commander THORNTON, of the Kearsarge:

Mr. JACOB HORNBROOK, who returned a day or two ago from a visit to the army in the Valley at and near Martinsburgh, brings with him the following manuscript general orders issued by the rebel Gen. RANSOM to the officers and soldiers of his command when they commenced their recent raid into Maryland. They were captured or picked up by some of our boys:

I notice in the money article of your paper of Saturday last, a notice copied from a Boston paper, in relation to real estate in this City. The statements in the article are so far from the truth as to call for a denial through the same medium. Instead of everybody wishing to sell real estate, the fact is quite the reverse.

At an early hour yesterday morning, a bold and deliberate attempt was made to burn the large tenement house situated at No. 341 Water-street. From the investigations that have been made, we learn that JOHN JACKSON, who occupied rooms on the third floor of the premises, is the guilty person.

The Board of Councilmen met yesterday. Their session was short, and the business transacted was chiefly routine. The Mayor sent in two communications. One vetoed a resolution to permit the placing of a sign on the lamp-post on the corner of Broadway and Ann street, on the ground that the streets, being held for public uses, should not be given up to private individuals.

The Pirate Alabama has at length met with a better fate than she deserved destruction in honorable combat with an equal adversary. Hitherto, with a single exception, she has been known only by her victories over the unarmed and defenceless.

Dispatches to the Government represent that a great battle was fought in Atlanta on Friday, resulting in a horrible slaughter and a complete repulse of the enemy at every point.

We understand that Mr. CISCO, on account of continued ill-health, persists in resigning his position as Assistant Treasurer, and that the President has invited MOSES TAYLOR to accept the office. No appointment could possibly be made which would reflect more credit upon the Government and at the same time give more confidence and gratification to the financial public than this.

Further regulations and instructions in regard to the special income tax, imposed under the joint resolution of Congress, approved July 4, will be issued by Commissioner LEWIS, upon his return to his seat. As the law stands now, there is an apparent conflict between it, as it finally passedjthe House, and the supplementary resolution referred to, which it would be well for all parties concerned to have cleared up.

Everything in camp is very dull at present, and the great object of all is, if possible, to keep cool. One of our boys returned from the front yesterday, and he says that the heat we suffer is nothing in comparison.

Atlanta is now the centre of great interest. All eyes are turned there in daily expectation of hearing of a great battle between the two armies that are close upon each other. All remains quiet there yet. The latest Atlanta date we have the Appeal says, editorially:

The steamer James White, from New-Orleans on the 18th inst., has arrived here. She reports that the steamer B.M. Runyon, from Natches, struck a snag off Griffiths' Landing, fifteen miles below Greenville, Miss., on the 21st inst., and sank to the hurricane roof in about five minutes. She had near 600 people on board, including 440 of the Tenth Missouri Cavalry, 50 refugees, some furloughed soldiers, and quite a number of cabin passengers.

The interdiction of all news about the operations in the vicinity of Harper'a Ferry, by the orders of Gens. HUNTER and WALLACE, leaves us with rather a limited amount of intelligence from that region this morning. Several reports have com to hand, none of which throw any positive light upon the enemy's movements. Harper's Ferry is still held by Gen. HUNTER, and it is reported that Martinsburgh, has been reoccupied by our forces.

Correspondence of the New-York Times. I stated in my last letter that the Freshman Class would probably be large. The Summer examination is now concluded, and we can form an approximate estimate of the size of the class. One hundred and seven presented themselves for admission, of whom eight were rejected. Of the ninetynine who remain, many will be obliged to be examined again on special branches, in which they showed ...
The NEW-YORK WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office, in wrappers, ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS.
From a cavalry officer who actively participated we learn the following particulars concerning Gen. A.J. SMITH'S expedition against the rebel FORREST:

Gen. SANDFORD, who went to Washington some days since, to consult with the War Department, relative to the exemption of the 100 days' men from the draft, returned last evening, and goes this morning to Albany to consult with the Governor. It is stated that he succeeded in obtaining from the War Department a declaration that the 100 days' men, who will be in service at the time of the draft, will be exempt.
We have but little telegraphic news from the reported new rebel raid into Maryland, for the reason that it is peremptorily withheld by the military authorities.

The guerrillas have burned the railroad property at Shelbina and Lakeman, on the Hannibal and St. Joseph's Railroad. Yesterday they destroyed all the block-houses and water-tanks, and the bridge at Salt River, robbed the citizens promiscuously, and plundered the stores of friend and foe alike. The band numbered eighty.

The New-York case was discussed fully in the State Central Committee during the morning session to-day. It was finally moved and decided unanimously that the whole question should be left to the determination of the next State Convention. It was virtually decided that the State Convention should be held on the 7th of September. LEO.

It was reported yesterday that there was alarming sickness among the vessels at quarantine, yellow fever in the worst form existing. Dr. SWINBURNE, Health Officer, states that the report much exaggerates the facts.
Information received from an officer at the front says, in two battles in front of Atlanta, we have destroyed the better portion of the enemy's best two corps.

Comptroller BRENNAN yesterday opened proposals from twenty-eight different parties, inclosing forty-three bids, which aggregated but $758,000, for a loan of $1,000,000, on 6 per cent. bonds, to run over twenty years, to redeem the temporary loan to pay riot damages, made last summer, and which, with interest, is to be paid on next Monday. The result of the opening was surprising, although not wholly unexpected.
Nothing positive is known in regard to the number or disposition of our own or the enemy's forces on the upper Potomac, except that we still occupy Harper's Ferry and the adjoining heights.

Major L.W. KELLY, late Mayor of Natchez, has just arrived from the front, which place he left Monday night. He reports of the Friday's fight in front of the Fifteenth, Sixteenth and Seventeenth Corps, that our men buried three thousand two hundred and twenty-one.

All egress from the city is to-day suspended, or regulated by passes. Guards are stationed all around. Negroes are digging rifle-pits. Blood and other horses of rebel sympathizers and Unionists are being impressed, and certificates of indebtedness given. Their impressment began at daybreak. Droves of them are passing my window now, to mount the gallant Ninth Pennsylvania.

Before the Draft Proclamation, the Copperheads abused President LINCOLN for not daring to risk his prospects by calling for more soldiers. Now they abuse him for calling for so large a number as half a million. His silence was denounced as pusillanimity. His proclamation is denounced as audacity.

Go into the smallest German hamlet, and you will find the inhabitants combined into one or more societies or clubs, each of which has in view some pleasant social object. You will find the drinking club a quiet, orderly, sober organization, generally composed ...
A correspondent of the St. Paul Press details the progress of Gen. SULLY'S expedition; its arrival at Swan Lake, and junction with Col. THOMAS' force is reported. The correspondent says:

The usual quiet has been broken by heavy and long-continued firing this morning in front of Gen. FOSTER'S department on the James River. The firing commenced about daylight, and continued about three hours with heavy artillery, interspersed with volleys of musketry. The result had not been ascertained at this place up to the time of the closing of the mail.

Those who may have feared that the hastening crisis in Europe, the imminence of a collision between Germany and France, and the revival of the revolutionary spirit throughout Central and Southern Europe, would lessen our consequence abroad, can turn with a certain degree of self-complacency and satisfaction to the latest files of European news.

The shelling and picket firing between the Ninth Corps and the enemy, yesterday, was more brisk than usual, and was kept up all day. During the afternoon a shell from one of our guns struck a caisson of the enemy's, which exploded with a loud noise.

The rebels have not yet shown the slightest sign of pushing incursions across the Potomac, and in consequence the population of Lower Maryland is quieting down. The Union citizens of Frederick, who had designed taking flight, and who had sent away their plate, , have now made up their minds to remain.

To the Reserve Militia of Georgia: A late correspondence with the President of the Confederate States satisfies my mind that Georgia is to be left to her own resources to supply the reinforcements to Gen. JOHNSTON'S army, which are indispensable to the protection of Atlanta, and to prevent the State being overrun by the overwhelming numbers now under command of the Federal General upon our soil.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: To that large number of our citizens who are just now revolving the question how to turn their Summer vacation to the best account, let me recommend a trip up the coast of New-England in a sailing vessel.

I notified you a few days ago that the Copperhead State candidates had proposed to the Union State candidates to join in an application to the authorities at Washington for permission to our soldiers in the field to return home to vote next Fall, and that the proposition would be more than gladly accepted, with the addition that the soldiers shall vote ...
The following circular to banks, trust companies, savings institutions, and insurance companies, concerning dividends and undivided profits, has been issued by Commissioner LEWIS:

The Democrat publishes a long account of the conspiracy for the erection of a Northwestern Confederacy, reported a few days since. The organization engaged in this conspiracy to known as the "Order of American Knights," and its real object is to embarrass the Government in the conduct of the war, and to overthrow the Government, if necessary for the supremacy of the Order.
Crops in this State, and particularly in this county and neighboring counties, are large. Corn never looked better, and wheat is very full and heavy.

We publish to-day a frantic appeal from the Governor of Georgia to the people of that State. It was promulgated twenty days ago about the time when our army crossed the Chattahoochee, and when it had become evident that we would speedily advance upon Atlanta.

"A friend who is in official communication with both sides in the American civil war, and who has almost unequaled opportunities for coming to a sound conclusion, speaks of the difficulties of the South as far greater than are allowed to appear on the surface." So writes the London correspondent of the Manchester Guardian, a paper whose sympathies have always been ardent for the rebellion.
A gentleman from Baltimore reports that such was the ignorance there concerning military movements, that it was unknown whether Gen. WRIGHT or Gen. HUNTER was in command of our forces.

Admiral PORTER has just returned home on a brief furlough, and the ladies of Perth Amboy improved the opportunity to give him a public reception. Col. WISEWELL, Military Governor, has appointed Maj. R.M. LITTLER Assistant Provost-Marshal of the Military District of Washington, with headquarters at Georgetown, Maj. LITTLER formerly led the Second Iowa Infantry in the Army of Tennessee, and shares in all its glories and successes.

The Board of Aldermen met yesterday, by special call, but scarcely more than a quorum of the members were present, so that the Family Aid Ordinance, No. 10, which will soon be needed to raise money for the Relief Fund, could not be passed. The Mexican population in the southern counties of this State are beginning to take sides for and against the usurpation of MAXIMILIAN. The great majority of them support JUAREZ, and express regret that the United States did not since extend its protection over the Republic of Mexico.
On the 12th instant the rebels tore up the track of the railroad between Duvall's Bluff and Little Rock, causing an engine to run off the track, killing the fireman, and wounding several others.

Mr. FESSENDEN well says that, "to lay heavy burdens on a great and patriotic people in such a manner as to be equal, and to occasion the least amount of suffering and annoyance, requires time and caution and vast labor."

This excellent, jolly and ancient organization, dating back to 1796, had a grand time yesterday afternoon at Striker's Bay. The grove at the back of the hotel was set apart for the benefit of the members of the club and their guests. A rope extending from tree to tree inclosed the entire grove and kept off all intruders. At the entrance a banner was suspended, bearing the motto of the club.

Information has been received at the War Department announcing that on Thursday a very considerable engagement occurred on the north bank of the James River, between a large force of the enemy and a portion of Gen. BUTLER'S army, in which the rebels were defeated with severe lose, including the capture of four pieces of artillery. I have been able to learn no further particulars.

The latest authentic intelligence is that Gen. KELLY now occupies Martinsburgh, that there has been no heavy fighting within the last three or four days, and that there is no information that the rebels have recrossed into Maryland.
The latest official dispatches from Gen. SHERMAN'S army state that he is steadily drawing his lines closer around Atlanta.

Some excitement has been created here during the past week by the report of a revolution at Penonenie, a vi11age distant about seventy-five miles hence, and a body of soldiers has been sent to quell it. The disturbance is purely a political one, got up for election purposes by the present Vice-President of the State against the actual President, both being candidates for the next election.

We shall require a great deal more evidence than we have yet seen to become convinced that the Order of "American Knights" is such a formidable body of traitors as some of our Western cotemporaries represent. That there are thousands of men in nearly every loyal State who would readily join any secret organization calculated to bring the war to a close, is certain.

The Convocation of the University of the State of New-York, under the direction of the Regents, has been in session in the Representatives' Chamber, at the capitol, yesterday and to-day. The colleges and many of the academies of the State are represented here by their professors and teachers. Educational subjects have been discussed, and papers of a good deal of interest to educators, and some of them of general interest, have been read.

Here your correspondent pauses a while under the shadow of old Greylock. Only for a day, however. By the way, the Natural Bridge at North Adams, the mighty railroad tunnel (they "calculate" eight years of hard work will be required to finish it) and old Greylock are prominent among American curiosities. But my object is to speak of other things.

No people on earth have came together more suddenly, or illustrated more clearly the improvement of the social condition by colonization, than those of the United States. Europe has forced forth her people to colonize America, and for the same reason which moved the Goths and Huns to better their condition. In fact, scarcely any people would leave their homes to find new ones, but for the strongest of motives.

The Chicago Times gives the following account of the lake tunnel: The work was commenced on the 17th of March,and since then the progress made in the construction of the tunnel has been such notwithstanding the tremendous difficulties which have had to be overcome as to astonish all who have watched the operations. The weather has been decidedly cooler during the past-week, the range of the thermometer having been 55 to 65 , during the nights, and 68 to 80 during the daytime. Letters have been received from Dr. W. HUGH PIERSON, of Orange, New-Jersey, who was a surgeon on board the Water Witch at the time of her capture by the rebels. He was taken to Savannah, and having offered his services was detailed to attend upon the Federal prisoners at that place. The letter was written three days after his capture, and sent North by a flag of truce.

Capt. W.L. WEST, of the schooner Margaret Y. Davis, and Capt. WINSLOW, of the bark Golconda, whose vessels were burned by the pirate Florida, were brought to this port yesterday by the steamer Gov. Dispatches from the TIMES' special army correspondent, herewith transmitted, bring before the imagination the opening of a grand battle drama, which began with early dawn of Saturday. Unlike customary skirmishing, with which the first sallies of battle begin, the combat of Saturday opens midst explosion of mines and the rude clamor of a hundred pieces of artillery.

BURNSIDE'S corps, was fired by the application of a lucifer match, and instantly a vast volume of dirt was thrown very high into the air, and a gap formed through which our troops rushed and carried the first line of rebel works.

The first meeting over the new race-course commences to-morrow (Tuesday.) The course is admirably arranged, and, thanks to a genial rain, in fine condition for racing purposes. The liberal charactor of the numerous stakes and purses each day of the five to which the season extends, has attracted all the best racing stock from all parts of the Union.

Washington is to-day full of rumors of the result of Saturday's battle, but they have no other authority than the imagination of their inventors. The steamer bringing the Government and press dispatches left City Point at 10 A. M. of Saturday, and subsequent to that hour there is nothing of a reliable nature.

Information from Gen. SHERMAN'S army represents affairs to be in the highest degree satisfactory. Our movements for the past day or so have met with no opposition from the enemy, but they crouch behind their fortifications, thus evidently showing they are afraid of the artillery of Gen. SHERMAN.
New Orleans papers of the 23d inst. have been received. They contain no news.

The mailboat Charlotte Vanderbilt arrived here yesterday from City Point. She brings no definite news of the further operations of the Second Corps since the fighting at Malvern Hill, but it was reported at City Point that our forces were moving on successfully, and had advanced some distance up river above the point of the late fighting.

The pirouettings of the rebel brigands north of the Potomac assume their proper and insignificant magnitude this morning alongside of the great operations which Gen. GRANT has inaugurated before Petersburgh. He has, in a two-fold sense, sprung a mine upon the rebels.

After two of the severest conflicts of the campaign, Gen. SHERMAN has pushed his lines from the Chattahoochee River to within two miles of Atlanta, at whose gates he is now loudly knocking. On the 18th all the army had crossed to the south side of the river. On the 20th Gen. McPHERSON cut the railroad at Decatur, between Atlanta and Augusta. All communications by railroad from Atlanta are now severed, except the Macon route.

Gen. McCAUSLAND was in command of the rebel troops when they burned Chambersburgh. After he had taken formal possession of the town he made proclamation demanding $100,000 in gold.

That Niagara tom-foolery ended, let it be the last of the like. It is not pleasant to think of the sorry figure we have been making. The good nature of Mr. GREELEY and the open nature of the President are all very well in their place; but that place ought to be strictly within the bounds of the national dignity.
When Gen. AVERILL, reached Chambersburgh the flames had obtained such a headway as to render it impossible for his men to stay them. The word "onward" ran along his line.

The valuable article in your Daily of Wednesday, 20th, on "Cotton, the Supply and the Demand," presents most clearly and no doubt justly the dependence of the world on America for this staple. But is our dependence on the now rebel States? How far can the want be supplied from the territory now in our hands? And with what success can cotton be raised by free labor?

The last steamer from Europe brought several expensive luxuries to MAX MARETZEK, in the shape of contracts for the coming season. We are glad to hear that our empresario's arrangements are now completed. He of all the New-York managers, is the first in the field.

Coroner RANNEY held an inquest yesterday on the body of MICHAEL CRANE, at the Sixteenth Precinct in Tenth-avenue, near Twenty-sixth-street. The testimony in the case showed about the same state of facts as published in the TIMES of yesterday.

A case is pending before the "Confederate States District Court," at Richmond, which presents to the world a new and startling history of the means by which the military despotism of the Confederacy prolongs its reign, and defies alike the criticism or the resentment of foreign Powers.

DEATH BY FALLING OUT OF A WINDOW. Coroner NORRIS held an inquest on JOHN T. MATHEWS, who died of injuries sustained by falling from a window of the house of PATRICK CARNEY, corner of Atlantic and Flatbush avenues, on the night of the 26th ult. MATHEWS had secured a substitute and took him to CARNEY'S house for safe keeping till morning.
The attempt on the lines of Petereburgh on Saturday did not result in a success. It was an effort whose success or failure must occur at once, and must at once be apparent.
The mortal remains of Maj.-Gen. JAMES BIRDSEYE McPHERSON were committed to their last restingplace at Clyde, Sandusky County, at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

In the matter of the application of R.D. OGDEN, alias Richard Wesley, for a writ of habeas corpus, seeking to be discharged from Camp Lee, Mr. P.H. AYLETT, in behalf of the War Department, delivered an argument against the discharge of Mr. OGDEN of more than four hours' length.

In this City, recruiting, for the past few days has been remarkably dull. The new barracks on the Battery, which were expected to do a very lively business have done little or nothing, and Supervisor BLUNT and his assistants have been rendered almost desperate for want of something to do.

Great disgust is expressed by the authorities at the highly colored dispatches published in the extras of yesterday morning, regarding the engagement of Saturday before Petersburgh. It is felt that such reports do infinite damage to the Union cause, as the reaction of despondency is always proportionate to the undue hopes excited.

As you have already learned, by telegraph, the grand tableaux of the present operations in Pennsylvania has been performed, and the beautiful little town of Chambersburgh is in ashes. Like the burning and devastation of dwellings in Maryland during the late raid into that State, the vandalism of burning some three hundred houses was performed under written orders from Gen. LUBAL EARLY.
A correspondent of the Baltimore American, writing from the blockading squadron off Mobile, July 10, says:

After the explosion at an early hour this morning, everything betokened a brilliant victory, but soon after matters assumed a different aspect, part of the attacking force having given way, thus exposing the balance to an enfilading fire from both artillery, and infantry.

Rev. JOHN G. FEE reports some 5,000 colored soldiers at Camp Nelson, the gallant Gen. S.S. FRY commanding. Among them are the One Hundred and Fourteenth and the One Hundred and Sixteenth Colored Regiments, under Cols. T.D. SEDGWICK and W.W. WOODWARD, and two companies of heavy artlilery, all organized, uniformed, and so well drilled that they are complimented by the correspondents of even Anti-Administration papers, as moving with the precision of veterans.

From Petersburgh our news is not of the success anticipated. After the explosion, at an early hour on Saturday morning, everything betokened a brilliant victory; but by the failure of the colored troops to carry out their part of the programme, affairs began to wear a different aspect.

Passengers by the coach last night, from Topeka, brings the startling intelligence, of the capture of Fort Larned by a band of Plain Indians, numbering some three or four thousand warriors, composed of Camanches, Kiowas, Cheyennes, Araphoes and Sioux.

THE WEATHER. Yesterday was another of those fearfully hot days which severally try the temper of even the best-natured people. Gentlemen of 200 lbs. and over were looked upon by their fellowmortals as objects of pity. Vapor baths were indulged in by many at the cheap price of five and six cents, the difference being in the choice of stage or car.

Latest advices from Atlanta by train and telegraph are to yesterday evening. We learn by the train which left at nightfall that the enemy attacked our left, extending from the city toward the Chattahoochee, yesterday, and were repulsed and driven about a mile. Late last evening orders were received by telegraph to send cars and bring the wounded to the rear.

His information is confirmatory of the main part of the news respecting the repulses published yesterday afternoon. Our loss is represented by him to be much smaller than the published statement.

An election was held throughout the State, today, on three amendments to the State Constitution, the first being in favor of soldiers voting. A comparatively small vote was polled, and it is believed, from the returns thus far received in this city, that all the amendments have been carried. But few returns have yet been received from the interior, but they indicate the same result.

Its revival at any time is sure to attract a fair degree of attention, and what is better, to merit it. Yesterday, at about the hour when Sabbath bells were ringing and good people preparing for worship, our citizens were astonished by the apparition of a regiment, the like of which certainly never marched through the streets of any Christian city.

It was the custom of the Parsees, we believe, when they met discomfiture in war, to offer up a common supplication for forgiveness, to the Sun; as their faith led them to conclude that any reverse they sustained bore an immediate and direct relation to some special iniquity they had committed. Our Christian Fasts, we suppose, imply no such literal interpretation of the inscrutable purposes of Heaven.

In the House of Lords, July 18, Lord BROUGHAM presented a petition from Jamaica, on the subject of the slave trade in Cuba. He said Spain had violated her treaty engagements, and he regretted to state that Slavery had of late years been extended in the island of Cuba.
Henry Hernton plead guilty to petit larceny and was sent to the House of Detention.
Mining interests begin to rally slightly. Leading stocks on 'Change have advanced. Gould and Curry, 1,110@1,135.

The exercises of Commencement week opened, as usual, on Sunday, with the baccalaureate sermon, by President HOPKINS. The text was Joshua, 24,15: "Choose ye this day whom ye will serve." Those who have ever seen or heard Dr. HOPKINS must know that he would only utter words of advice to young men that would insure their success and honor if they were heeded. His patriotism is intense.

Major Gen. HOOKER passed through this city this morning on route to Washington.

Gen. STONEMAN'S raid along the Macon Rail road met with a great success in cutting the rebel line of communication, and thus completely isolating Atlanta. But I regret the necessity to add that one division of cavalry, while returning, met with a serious disaster. The Macon Railroad was torn up for eighteen miles, the rails twisted, the ties, tanks, bridges and depots burned, and the road rendered useless for months to come.

The subscriptions to the new seven-thirty loan during the past six days amount to $6,565,950, or an average of nearly $1,100,000 daily. This amount has been subscribed mainly in large commercial cities. The West is yet to hear from.

Tho Actors' Protective Union held its third meeting at the Cooper Institute, yesterday afternoon, at 3 o'clock. Mr. DAVIDGE took the chair, and desired to say that this movement was not a strike of the actors, but simply action for the mutual protection of both actors and managers.

The expedition which Gen. PALMER recently sent from here to the Chowan River, in command of Lieut. WARD, of his Staff, has returned with 103 bales of cotton and a large amount of tobacco, captured from the enemy, from which the Treasury Department will realize over $100,000.

The steamer George Leary sailed yesterday afternoon for Philadelphia, Boston and New-York, with two hundred colored women and children, under the care of the Superintendent of Negro Affairs in this Department. Vouchers, conditional on proof of loyalty, are given, to the doubtful, but none at all to some avowed Secessionists or known rebel sympathizers.

Steamship Liberty, Wilson, Havana 4 ds., with passengers, specie, cotton, sugar and tobacco to Bargous Co. The steamer "Denbergh" arrived in Havana on the morning of the 30th ult, from Mobile the 26th, with 470 bales of cotton.
Nothing of interest has taken place for the past two days, and very little picket firing is being indulged in on the lines at present.
New-Orleans dates of the 29th have been received.
Fast day was observed by the suspension of all public business and with religious services.

We understand that the Commander BERTINATTI, who for several years past has, with great acceptability, represented the Government of Italy in this country successively as Charge d'Affaires and Minister Resident, has been raised to the rank of Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary, and that his presentation in that quality took place on Saturday last.

Dennis Riley plead guilty to manslaughter in the fourth degree, and was sentenced to be confined in the City Prison for 30 days. His Honor said that there were certain circumstances in this case which could not be made public, but which had induced him to award so light a sentence.
There is great activity in military circles here in carrying out the new movements.

The Pacific Steamship Navigation Company's steamer Peru arrived from the South Pacific on the 19th, with dates from Valparaiso to the 2d, and Callao to the 13th inst. She brought a large cargo of bark, wool, cotton, hides, india-rubber, copper, tin, indigo, coffee, flour, cocoa, and general merchandise.

Advices from Nashville say that Gen. McCOOK, who was supposed to have been captured near Newman, has come in with a hundred and twenty of his men. Five-hundred had previously arrived at Marietta, as already reported.

Dates from Bogota, the capital, are to the 10th instant. The Government of the new President, Senor MURILLO, had been completely organized, and all the Foreign Ministers appointed. Senor ANIBAL MOSQUERA, son of the General, is appointed to England, and Senor FELIPE ZAPOTA Minister to Washington.

The desperate character of the struggle for recognition which has marked the efforts of the rebel sympathizers in England during the past month, forms a strange comment on the boasted invincibility of their military organization.

The pitiless pelting of the long-desired rainstorm on Wednesday which was so welcome to the country at large put a decided stopper on all attempts at racing, and a postponement until to-day was the inevitable consequence.

The experimental character of the operations carried on by the Construction Department of the British Admiralty since the commencement of the armor-plated era, had a significant and varied illustration in a late discussion in the British House of Commons.

Advices from the front report all quiet since the late battle. The extremely hot weather (the thermometer averaging 100 degrees in the shade) for the past week precludes anything like active movements.

GENERAL ORDERS, No. 31: 1. All able-bodied males, between the ages of eighteen and forty-five, within the lines of occupation in the Departments of Arkansas and the Gulf, and the districts east of the Mississippi River, will immediately be enrolled for service in the militia. Neutral foreigners, not being subject to compulsory military service, will be enrolled as a separate class, to be employed whenever necessary, as a local police, or constabulary force.

The month of July, it seems, went out with two military mishaps one, a cavalry affair in Georgia, the other the more serious repulse before Petersburgh. What is done being now past recall, all we care to know of it is its effect on the grand campaign, though presently inquiry must be made as to who is in fault.
Dispatches received here at an early hour this morning state that the rebels were then crossing the river at Hancock, and that they had driven Gen. AVERILL'S pickets into Cumberland.

The aspect of the Spanish question had not changed since the previous mail. Peru was waiting the decision of the Cabinet at Madrid upon the Chincha Islands seizure, but was actively strengthening her coast and naval defences.

There is nothing of particular importance from this Republic. The Secretary of State, after greatly exasperating the Deputies by his neglect, on two or three calls, to present the correspondence on the Peruvian question with Spain to Congress, has signified his intention to communicate it.

From Gen. SHERMAN'S army we have the intelligence that Gen. STONEMAN, on the 26th ult., sent a large force of cavalry, under command of Gen. McCOOK, to destroy the Macon and Western Railroad. They destroyed some 18 miles of the road, and then started to capture a rebel train of 500 wagons, going from Atlanta to Macon or Columbus.

The stated meeting of the managers was held at the Bible House, Astor-place, on Thursday, the 4th inst., at 3:30 o'clock P.M., WILLIAM B. CROSBY, Esq., Vice-President, in the Chair, assisted by BENJ. L. SWAN, Esq., Vice-President.

A special dispatch from Washington to the Post, says, that an order has been issued directing that there shall be no more drafting under previous calls for troops. All deficits now outstanding shall be carried over to the draft to take place in September.

The drouth which has pervaded the country has been seriously felt in New-England; but the damage to what may be called the staples of this section has not been so great as the exaggerated accounts from particularly exposed localities would have the country to suppose.
The marriage of Maj. H. M. PORTER, Assistant Provost-Marshal of New-Orleans, to Miss NINA FREMONT, was solemnized last night at Christ Church, in the presence of a large and distinguished assembly.

The Panama Railroad Company's steamship Guatemala, from San Jose de Guatemala and intermediate ports, arrived at Panama on the 20th inst. In answer to a letter of inquiry from the Fourth Auditor of the Treasury, in regard to payment of bounties provided by section 4, of act of July 1, Mr. Comptroller BRODHEAD has issued the following instructions:

Tailors, boot and shoe makers, and others who manufacture partly to order and custom work, and partly for general sale, must pay five per cent., the same as other manufacturers under section 93." Commission houses, selling goods on consignment, are not to be regarded as local agents of the manufacturer or producer of said goods.

The steamship Saxonia, from Southampton 26th ult., passed this point at 10 o'clock to-day, en route to New-York.

Nearly two weeks have elapsed since we crossed the Chattahoochee. The passage of the stream was effected at midnight. The half full moon rode grandly across the heavens in the midst of cumuli of white clouds.

The news of the exchange of prisoners at Charleston, which is related in our correspondence from Hilton Head this morning, is an agreeable relief from the stereotyped report of a bombardment which brings results no more appreciable to-day than they were fifteen months ago.
All is quiet along the lines this morning. The enemy shelled the city for half an hour last evening.

The appalling murder committed with at least temporary impunity on a line of metropolitan railway by which thousands travel to and from the city every day, has very naturally raised the question as to how the traveling public, including not only ninetenths of the metropolis, but a large proportion of the whole community, may be best protected in future from exposure to such fearful risks.

Very little business is doing here at present. The news of SHERMAN's progress, and of the consequent decline of gold in New-York, has unsettled the markets. Quotations are nominal, without material change.

Until within two weeks, affairs in Florida have been very quiet. By order of Maj.-Gen. FOSTER, some recent raids made by Gen. BIRNEY have served to invest the district with something of that interest which attached to it at the time Gen. SEYMOUR was in command.

A German Confederacy, embracing Denmark, seems to be among the strange possibilities at this time, in the political future of Europe! The exhilarating announcement "Atlanta is ours" has not yet been given to the country. The people are confidently awaiting the tidings, and the general expectation is not likely to wait long in being fulfilled.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: There may be and often is noting so disastrous to a country as a change of an Administration at the crisis of a war, or in fact at any other crisis. To learn such a fact by experience involves the chance of a fatal catastrophe, for history is fertile in examples of the fearful effect of such madness.

Business of an important nature calling me from the front to this city, alone accounts for the date and place of this letter. I arrived here on Saturday, 30th ult., after a very tiresome ride on, one of those modes of conveyance known as a military railroad a mode of transportation excessively exhausting to feeble constitutions, and a horrible ordeal to men of a small amount of patience.

Having had of late occasion to travel over a greater part of the States of Pennsylvania, Jersey, Delaware and Maryland, along the New-Jersey Central, Delaware and Wilmington, Pennsylvania Northern, Central and the great lines of the Pennsylvania Central and Baltimore and Ohio Railroads, I have enjoyed many opportunities of gaining interesting information regarding the crops in the various States enumerated.

Local military matters for the past few days have been very dull. Recruiting progresses but slowly, still it seems to be steadily increasing. The new barracks at the Battery are doing well, though not quite as well as was expected. A number of aliens are enlisted daily, and, to the credit of the managers at the Barracks be it said, the men are protected in their rights, and they are not allowed to be swindled.

Not the least important of the advantages offered for residence by our Atlantic cities, is their proximity to the most charming natural retreats, to which we can easily escape during the intervals of business, and where we can replenish our fountains of vitality, exhausted by the feverish drain of over-effort.

The steamship Hibernian, from Liverpool on the afternoon of the 28th, via Londonderry on the 29th of July, passed Father Point at 6:30 o'clock this morning, en route to Quebec. Her dates are two days later than those already received.

To the Supporters of the Government: We have read without surprise, but not without indignation, the proclamation of the President of the 18th of July, 1864. The supporters of the Administration are responsible to the country for its conduct, and it is their right and duty to check the encroachments of the Executive on the authority of Congress, and to require it to confine itself to its proper sphere.

There is a peculiar appropriateness in the address of the Geneva people which we publish this morning. It is the voice of Republican Europe formally expressed as to the intent and aim of the struggle in which we are engaged. It is the utterance of that voice from the seat of free thought in modern Europe.

JOHNSON, who subsequently escaped, and his whole staff, with their headquarters, colors, all the rebel artillery and trains, and a large quantity of small arms. Gen. McCAUSLAND himself barely escaped by flying into the mountains.

The Editors' and Publishers' Convention for the State of Maine met at Portland this morning, Hon. NELSON DINGLEY, Jr., of the Lewiston Journal preciding. A constitution was adopted for a permanent organization.

The demonstration in favor of making Gen. McCLELLAN the candidate of the Chicago Convention took place last evening at Union-square. It was one of the largest political meetings ever held in the City of New-York, there being fully 30,000 persons in attendance. It was characterized with the greatest enthusiasm throughout. The speeches, however, were of the most common-place character, and the speakers generally without reputation.
Gen. SMITH'S expedition is well out. Its destination is unknown.

With the recurrence of every Summer, the arrival of strangers in Boston, interested in its old history, renews the regret that the monuments of the past disappear so rapidly, and that even the natural contour of the land is so changed that WINTHROP, and PEPPERELL, and HANCOOK might well be excused if they should not recognize the scenes of their earthly life.

The decision of Acting Commissioner ROLLINS, that seven-thirty Treasury notes are liable to taxation, applies only to banks that hold them as a part of their capital stock. The first section of the last loan act expressly exempts all United States Treasury notes as well as bonds from State and municipal taxation.

A most remarkable stroke of lightning occurred in the Camp Fuller Brigade, near Rosville, Ga., July 14, 1864, killing and wounding about fifteen soldiers, and killing and shocking severely several teams, a description of which may be interesting to your readers.

Last Wednesday two considerable bodies of picked cavalry started simultaneoulsy on a raid on the enemy's communications one under Gen. STONEMAN, passing around the left of our army near Stone Mountain; the other, under Gen. ED. McCOOK, around our right. The presumed object of the raid was the thorough destruction of the Macon Railroad, which is essential to the enemy's hold upon Atlanta.

A few days ago three cavalry expeditions were planned and put into operation as follows: Gen. STONEMAN, with a large force, started upon an important expedition, which, if successful, will electrify the whole country. Men, women and children, from Maine to California, will join in the glorious acclaim the nation will rejoice and suffering humanity throughout the world will be eclipsed with joy.

We have nearly done laughing at and wondering over the great scare of Washington and Baltimore, which accompanied the third invasion of Maryland, and are waiting, like the sailor at the show, for what is to come next. Europe is so dull, that we look to America for our semi-weekly excitement, as the manufactories used to look for their cotton.

The subscriptions to the 7-30 loan to-day amount to $471,200. The total amount thus far received is $11,272,450. Parties transmitting 7-30 bonds for conversion will do well to bear in mind the fact that some little time must necessarily be required to attend to their orders. The acknowledgment of the receipt of their packages is all the department can do the first day of their receipt.

The enemy has not yet evacuated Atlanta, though some such movement has been looked upon as probable, for the last ten days. Our army has shifted from the east and north of Atlanta to the west, the extreme left covering the city on the north, while the extreme right now is southwest of the city, running parallel with the Atlanta and Macon Railroad, and near enough, were the country favorable, to command it with artillery.

Six refugees and twenty-one deserters from the rebel army arrived here to-day from City Point. The former left Richmond by stealth on Thursday night and came into our lines. They tell a long story, representing that on Saturday last four trains of twenty cars each arrived in Richmond, bringing a body of troops from Petersburg, said to be a division, and they left immediately on the Central road, to reinforce Gen. EARLY.

A party of refugees and deserters, not the most trustworthy sources of information, arrived yesterday at Washington, and report that heavy reinforcements have been sent to Gen. EARLY from Richmond. They also bring a report of a serious state of disaffection, amounting almost to mutiny, among portions of the rebel troops, who are said to be restrained with difficulty from deserting and returning home. It would be pleasant to believe these stories.

WASHINGTON, Tuesday, Aug. 17. The operations of the force on the north bank of the James River continue to develop in the most suspicious manner. The manoeuvres of Monday resulted in turning the rebel fortifications; and, yesterday morning, when our forces advanced, they found that the enemy had fallen back during the night, and had thrown up defences in a position naturally stronger than the one they had been driven from.

A Meeting of the Actors' Protective Union was held yesterday afternoon at Cooper Institute, Mr. WILLIAM DAVIDGE presiding. The theatres were nearly all represented. Rev. Dr. HUBBARD WINSLOW, the author and clergyman, whose death we have lately announced, was born in Vermont near the commencement of this century, and came by direct line of descent from the Mayflower WINSLOWS.
