You may expect to hear shortly of the offensive being taken again in this department. Before this reaches you, GORDON GRANGER will be thundering at the gates of Mobile. I understand that our base of operations is to be Pascagoula. I presume that the importance of a demonstration upon this City of Mobile at this time is fully appreciated by Gen. CANBY, and that it is being pushed forward with all dispatch.

Before I had fairly completed my letter of yesterday, orders arrived at the headquarters of the Nineteenth Corps, for that body to move to Winchester and garrison the town. The troops were to get into motion at eleven o'clock, and matters at headquarters speedily became hurried and exciting ...

An old man, named FREDERICK NEWTON, residing in Madison-st., near Franklin-av., Brooklyn, was beaten so seriously by his son RICHARD NEWTON, on Saturday night, that he died from the effects of his wounds at the City Hospital yesterday afternoon. There were a number of conflicting stories in regard to the melancholy affair, and it was almost impossible to obtain a correct account yesterday.

The visit of the pirate Tllahassee to our coast has reawakened an interest in the subject of our harbor defences. The Connecticut shore of Long Island Sound is probably the most wealthy and most thickly-populated of any equal length of coast in the country, excepting, of course, the vicinities of Boston and New-York, and yet it is entirely undefended, except at New-London, and any dashing cruiser could play havoc among its harbors, and put ...

Late advices from Mexico indicate that the empire of MAXIMILIAN I, is a fait accompli. Already the leading men of the Mexican people are becoming attached to the new dynasty. ALMISES had consented to assume the portfolio of the State Department, and Gen. DODLADO has perfectly acquiesced in the recent changes. This peaceful solution of the question, though perhaps unexpected so quickly, cannot, however, be regarded with surprise, for the ...
The steamship Peruvian, from Liverpool on the afternoon of the 11th via Londonderry 12th, passed this point at 5 o'clock this afternoon.
The Commercial has a special dispatch from Nashville, which states as follows:

Chicago has been highly honored. The first National Convention of the Spiritualists commenced its session in this city on Tuesday last, and is still in operation. Five or six hunhundred delegates are present from all parts of the country, about one-half of whom are women.
The Cunard screw steamer Kedar, which left Liverpool at 2 P.M. on the 9th and Queenstown on the 10th August, arrived here yesterday.
The Emperor had arrived at St. Cloud from Vichy.

Brig.-Gen. WILLIAM A. HAMMOND, Surgeon-General of the United States, was tried by a court-martial continued by order of the President at Washington on the 15th of January, 1864, consisting of Major-Gen. R. J. Ogiesby, United States Volunteers, President; Brig.-Gen. W.S. Harney, U.S.A.; Brig.-Gen. W.S. Ketchum, Brig.-Gen. G.S. Greene, Brig.-Gen. W. W. Morris, Colonel United States Artillery, Brig.Gen. A.P. Howe, Brig.-Gen. J.P. Slough, Brig.Gen. H.E. Paine, Brig.-Gen. J.C. Starkweather, with Maj. John M. Bingham as Judge-Advocate.

By far the most important and far-reaching success achieved by the Army of the Potomac since it assumed its present position on the Appomattox, is that set forth in the three dispatches from City Point, incorporated by Secretary STANTON in his bulletin.

Hon. CLEMENT C. CLAY, one of the Confederate gentlemen recently at Niagara Falls, declared in a letter to Mr. GREELEY that he and his associates were not empowered by the rebel Government to negotiate for peace. As nobody but that crazy-headed busy-body JEWETT had ever intimated that they were, Mr. CLAY'S assertion on this point must be deemed conclusive.

If there be one thing more than another which tends to plunge the public into doubt and despondency, it is the exaggerated accounts of the military prospects which come from Washington. Not that we have any fault to find with anybody's honest endeavors to set the best side of our affairs before the people, and to encourage them to look at it, if not constantly, at least as often as the other side.
Senator WILSON publishes a note denying all the reports to the effect that he is mixed up with any proposition for an armistice with the rebels. He says:

The following is the correspondence between Gov. SEYMOUR and the gentlemen composing the recent meeting at the Mayor's office, to which allusion has previously been made in these columns. We have not, we are free to confess, been in possession of a copy of the correspondence "for several days;" on the contrary, we never saw it before this morning, though we were aware that letters had passed between the gentlemen named and His Excellency.

Many of your readers are doubtless desirous of information as to the main features of the campaign what were the principal objects aimed at, and what causes led to their failure. I will try and furnish that want. If any one will take the map of the Upper Potomac in hand, he will perceive that Harper's Ferry, Martinsburgh, and Winchester, form the three angles of a triangle.
CARY D. STRONG, CO. D, Fourth Ohio Volunteer Cavalry, writes as follows from the headquarters of Chief of Cavalry, in the field, Department of the Cumberland:

Gen SHERIDAN changed his position in order the better to watch the passes of the mountains. The great number of points which he is compelled by orders to cover, imposes upon him a more conservative military policy than he would otherwise adopt. The rebel force at Martinsburgh is but an inconsiderable raiding party, and will not interfere with Gen. SHERIDAN'S programme of operations, which will be something more than defensive.
To Major-Gen. John A. Dix: The operations of Gen. GRANT'S forces are detailed in the following official dispatches received by this department:

From City Point we have intelligence that the Fifth Army Corps had a severe fight with the enemy yesterday, on the Weldon Railroad, but succeeded in routing the rebels, and finally advanced and occupied a position on the line of the Petersburg and Weldon Railroad, and at last accounts we still held the position.

The installation of the Right Rev. JOHN MCCLOSKEY, late Bishop of Albany, as Archbishop of the Metropolitan See of New-York, took place yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral, on Mottstreet. It was attended with imposing ceremonies, and exceeded, in the grandeur of the pageant, any similar occasion in the United States.

The German papers publish the preliminaries of peace between Denmark and Germany, of which the following are the most important points: The King of Denmark relinquishes his rights over Schleswig-Holstein and Lauenburg in favor of the Emperor of Austria and the King of Prussia, and agrees to recognize all arrangements made by the two latter Sovereigns with respect to the Duchies.

COTTON The market yesterday continued dull, not with standing a large attendance of the trade. The sales were about 5,000 bales, including 1,000 for speculation and export. Prices generally were unchanged. To-day the business is also about 5,000 at the same rates.

Archbishop McCLOSKEY will be installed in his new office next Sunday. Before his departure from Albany he was entertained by his clergy, at the residence of the Very Rev. J.J. CONROY. Some seventy were present on the occasion. Father JOHN MCMENOMY, in a few brief and eloquent words, explained the desire all had to meet the Bishop once more.

The latest intelligence from the Army of the Potomac represents the situation as materially unchanged since the successful attempt to gain possession of the Weldon Railroad. The Fifth Army Corps still maintain their position on the railroad, every effort of the enemy to dislodge them proving unsuccessful. Last Friday was very quiet in front of Petersburgh, scarcely a gun being fired during the entire day. On the North side of
The sales of Cotton for the four days add up 21,000 bales. Prices at the opening showed a down ward tendency, but the market closed firmer. The sales to speculators and exporters were 5,000 bales.

The political news to-day is unimportant. Lord PALMERSTON has made a speech, expressing hopes of an early peace in America. He thought, however, the-interposition of England at present would be worse than useless.
Yesterday was the quietest day we have had in front of Petersburgh for a month, scarcely a shot being heard the entire day.
This war, like all wars has abounded with personal disgraces, but it would be hard to name one more painful or scandalous than that now fastened upon Surgeon-General HAMMOND.
The following note from GEORGE W. LANE, Superintendent of the Branch Mint, to Senator JAS. H. LANE, expresses the general feeling here:

To the Honorable the Common Council: GENTLEMEN: It becomes my painful duty to announce to the members of the Common Council the death of Hon. ISAAC L. VARIAN, at his late residence at Peekskill, on the 10th inst.
The Memphis Bulletin says: Boats from below are obliged to pass Gaines' Landing by night, with all their lights put out.
The Raleigh (N.C.) Confederate says that Gen. S.D. LEE recently arrived at Atlanta from Mississippi with a large number of reinforcements, and participated in the late battle.

The steamship Roanoke, from Havana, Aug. 18, arrived at this port last evening. Our Havana files and correspondence per this arrival contain nothing of especial importance. The latest news from Mexico represents MAXIMILIAN as still engaged in his work of conciliation, but with only moderate succass. A leader now and then comes over to him, but the soldiers remain opposed to the reign of the monarch.

The Copperhead wing of our "Constitutional Unionists" seems now practically identical with our "Peace Democrats," and well represented by GARRET DAVIS and Lieut.-Gov. JACOB. Neither can say too much against the Administration, and both call the President a tyrant deserving the fate of CHARLES the First. Mr. JACOB predicts 80,000 majority in Kentucky for McCLELLAN, though he might not get even a fourth of that, if any at all.

On the night of the 9th inst., a blockade-runner, while attempting to either pass out of, or enter into Charleston Harbor, ran aground on Sullivan's Island beach, near the old pier opposite Fort Moultrie, when she was discovered at daylight the next morning by the gunners at Battery Chatfield.
The Bermudian, of Aug. 16, publishes an interesting correspondence between Gov. BURLEY and the Euke of Newcastle, relative to the question of blockade-running. It opens thus:
I am obliged to the writer of "Accurate Observer" for some information I had not before, but not enough to be convinced that the monitors will be fit for sea service.

An advertisement appears requesting the Alumni of Yale College, in this City, to meet "to devise and adopt a method of mutual insurance against the draft." Et tu, Brute! Educated men, too, plotting evasion and desertion. The Republic calls upon her sons to defend her.

The extraordinary military resources developed in the United States by the present war, the immense strength as a nation which has been put forth, have produced such a revolution abroad in the minds of the governing classes as was not at first anticipated. The Government people in...

The following deaths of New-York soldiers are reported today: T. Pratt, Eighty-third Infantry; Jobson Holt, K. One Hundred and Fifty-third Infantry; George Fields, L, Ninth Artillery; George W. Bradley, F. Sixth Infantry; John Scott, F. Sixtyninth Infantry; John T. Kennedy, G. One Hundred and Fifty-fifth Infantry.

Some four months ago, we published a speech, delivered to the Bahama Legislature by Mr. C.J. BAYLEY, who happens to be Governor of the islands for the time being. Possibly many of our readers have forgotten that in that speech Mr. BAYLEY ...

Later intelligence from the front represents our losses in the fight at the Weldon Railroad as heavier than heretofore reported. It appears that the attack was a surprise to our forces, many of them being in their shelter-tents at the time, to escape the heavy rain that was falling.
From Southern journals the latest Richmond papers of Aug. 19 we make the following extracts:

The following communications were laid before the Board of Councilmen yesterday. That body unanimously adopted the drafted ordinance accompaying Mr. BLUNT'S letter, and it probably will soon be concurred in by the Board of Aldermen:

FORT RTLY, Kansas, Sunday, Aug. 14, 1864. As I anticipated when I wrote my last, the Indian difficulties grow more serious and threatening. Though at presest the damage is confined to the most advanced ranches and scattered western settlers, yet the savages are evidently growing emboldened by their success.

It is said in naval circles that Chief-Engineer STIMERS, of this station, is selected to undertake an important mission by the Navy Department. What that mission is we cannot state at present; but the light-draft or tin-clad monitor Tunxis, of Philadelphia, which is to sail very soon, will be placed at his disposal.

The anxiety of the rebels for an exchange of prisoners at this time takes a singularly contradictory way of manifesting itself. At Charleston, as will be seen by our correspondent's letter from the Department of the South, ...
Our losses at the fight at the Weldon Railroad, on Friday afternoon, were greater than heretofore reported.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The counsels of your "Veteran Observer," in the TIMES of the 15th inst., on the subject of "Public virtue," are worthy of serious consideration by every patriot in these times of trial, through which our nation is now passing.
The brig Rosetta, from Pictou for Boston, put in here yesterday.

In the Washington dispatch of the 11th inst. to the TIMES, the thermometer is represented as standing there on that day at 96 degrees in the shade and 120 degrees in the sun. We may congratulate ourselves that "the lines have fallen to us" for the summer in a pleasanter place than that.
The United States transport Arago, HENRY A. GADSDEN, Commanding, from Port Royal, S.C., 5 P. M., Thursday, Aug. 18, also arrived yesterday.
The Nashville Times contains a report that Gen. WHEELER'S rebel forces have crossed the river above Chattanooga, though there is a report that he has gone to East Tennessee.

WALLACK'S THEATRE. Miss. OLIVE LOGAN made her first appearance at this establishment last evening in a new drama called "Eveleen." The place is strongly sensational, and in that point of view, is better written, and contains more felicitous language than we expect or find in similar productions. Miss. LOGAN comes of a recognized dramatic family, and her infuitions give promise of a brilliant career.
Some days ago Gov. MORTON received a letter from the East, stating that a large quantity of arms were being shipped to disloyal parties in Indiana.
The steamer E.B. Sunder, from New-Orleans Aug. 14, arrived at this port yesterday.

The Cunard mail steamer China, Capt. ANDERSON, which left Liverpool at 3 o'clock on the afternoon of the 13th and Queenstown on the 14th August, arrived here yesterday morning, having made the run from the latter port in less than nine days.
The Federal steamer Pontoosuc arrived at North Sydney this morning. She saw no signs of the Tallahassee.
The following notes of the movements of the blockade-runners are given in the shipnews column of the Bermudian, as late as Aug. 10.
Four exchanged prisoners arrived here on Monday from Hilton Head by the Arago, bringing a memorial to the President, setting forth the condition of the Union prisoners in Georgia, as follows:
The mail steamer Vanderbilt arrived here at 4:30 o'clock this afternoon from City Point.
Steamships Northern Light, Seabury, Aspinwall, D. B. Allen; Persia, (Br.,) Lott, Liverpool, E. Cunard. Steamers Artisan, Kirk, Baltimore; Anthracite, Jones, Philadelphia.

There were two battles of considerable magnitude on Sunday last one on the Weldon Railroad and the other on the Upper Potomac, near Charlestown. In both instances the rebels were the attacking party. On the railroad, where the rebel assault upon Gen. WARREN was made, with two divisions, they were repulsed with heavy loss.

By the arrival, yesterday, of the Cunard steamer China we have dates from Liverpool to the 13th and from Queenstown to the 14th inst. American news was anxiously awaited in England, where intelligence of GRANT'S renewed activity before Richmond had been received.

The Board of Supervisors met yesterday. Supervisor PURDY introduced a preamole and resolutions, which were adopted, setting forth that Supervisor BLUNT has gleaned information from the naval enlistment depots, of naval enlistments to the number of over 24,000, which shall be claimed upon the quota of the City, and directing the Volunteer Committee to act in conjunction with Gov. SEYMOUR and his associate Commis- ...

Reports from reliable men in every county in the State, whose attention has been especially directed to inquiries concerning the State of the crops and the prospects of the harvest, enable us to state with a good degree of confidence, that the agricultural products of Maine this year will be abundant; in re- ...

The last of Poland for this generation probably, as I wrote in my last, has been strangled on the glacis of Warsaw. I see no use in writing the names of the five leaders selected by the Russian military authorities for death, while their followers, by tens of thousands, have been transported to Siberia.

An attack was made by the enemy early this morning, about 8 o'clock, on the right of our advanced line of cavalry pickets in front of Summit Point, which resulted in our having to abandon that position. A simultaneous attack was made on our left near Berryville, but this latter only proved a feint, and did not amount to much.
At Londonderry on the 12th August there was the usual celebration of the siege of that place. There was some fighting in the evening, and one or two persons were reported seriously injured.
We are requested to give publicity to the following order just received by Brig.-Gen. LANSING:
Letters from the City of Mexico bring the text of an Imperial decree appointing, in case of the Emperor's death, the Empress CHARLOTTE Regent of the Empire.
The steamer Ida Hande, with New-Orleans dates of the 16th inst., has arrived here. She had 200 bales of cotton for Memphis.

The funds on the 12th were steady. Consols remained at 89 1/8@ for money. The demand for discount had become quite moderate, and the supply was considerable. The best paper was done as low as 7 @7 7/8cent, with the bank rate at 8.
The mails for Europe by the Persia will close at 9:30 A.M. to-day.

The news of the occupation of the Weldon Railroad has already been sent you by another correspondent. The Fifth Corps moved out in that direction about 4 o'clock A.M. on the 18th inst., and struck the railroad about noon at a point about five or possibly six miles from Petersburgh. The several divisions of the corps followed each other on the march in their regu- ...
The Board met in their Chamber, No. 16, City Hall, pursuant to the following call:
On Aug. 6, King CHRISTIAN opened the Rigsdag. The following is his address:
The Board of Supervisors met yesterday afternoon, Supervisor BLUNT occupying the chair in the absence of the President.
On the 13th inst., in front of Atlanta, the Fifteenth Corps charged on the rebel works.

THE POLITICAL FIELD. The Democratic atmosphere of Washington, being made up of breezes from other sections of the United States beside New-York, does not appear to be so thoroughly McClellanized as it is in that City. Knowing ones, who have been thoroughly sitting the situation all over the country, say that the North- ...

A delegation, consisting of four Union prisoners just released from Andersonville, Ga., will have an early interview with the President, for the purpose of presenting the case of the thirty-five thousand Union soldiers now penned up at that place as prisoners of war.
The undersigned has read in the Sunday Morning Chronicle, of this City, the remarks of JudgeAdvocate-General HOLT on the proceedings of the Court-martial in his case.

The army now occupy the Heights near, and on a line with Halltown, following the first of the three ranges of hills comprising the Heights of Bolivar. Our line is an exceedingly strong one, and it is to be hoped that the enemy will attack us in our present position.
The land forces under Gen. GRANGER are within 300 yards of Fort Morgan, and a general assault is expected in a few days. The fleet is fully prepared, including the ram Tennessee.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Prodvce since our last have been: 18 bbls. Ashes, 7,201 bbls. Flour, 210 bags Corn Meal, 71 bushels Rye, 21,783 bushels Oats, 523 pkgs. Provisions, and 227 bbls. Whisky.
The following was received at the Navy Department this morning:

The Government has at last undertaken to watch over the interests of British emigrants on their landing in America. The following circular, which was on Saturday last issued by order of the Government, will explain itself: "Information for emigrants to the United States: On arrival at New-...

The steamer Courier, owned by the Memphis and St. Louis Packet Company, was burned to the water's edge at 9 o'clock this evening, while transferring her cargo of naval stores to the dispatch boat Volunteer at Mound City. The fire was caused by the ignition of a barrel of naptha which was being hoisted into the hold falling and bursting and scattering its contents all around.
The following intelligence is published in the American this morning, the substance of which the censor would not permit to be transmitted over the wires last night:

It is right that the journals of Capt. SEMMES and his lieutenants should be published, but the wise reader will not expect too much from them. In point of fact, the public already know nearly all that these journals have to tell, and they are useful, less for the information which they have to convey than for authenticating, summarizing and methodizing ...

Mr. FLOWERS, the sitting magistrate at the Bow-street Police Court, was occupied during a considerable portion of Tuesday afternoon in the investigation of a case which excited a great deal of interest in the theatrical profession. A summons for assault had been issued at the instance of Mrs. BRISTOWE, box book-keeper at the Adelphi Theatre, against Mr. HENRY BATEMAN, the father of the young lady whose successful performances at that theatre ...

The morning papers publish lengthy extracts from DODD'S correspondence, captured at Indianapolis. The manuscript copy of DODD'S address to the Grand Council is among the papers, in which it appears a Grand Convention, to be held July 1, two days before the Democratic National Convention, was to have been held.
Political news in Paris is exceedingly scarce, the public attention being chiefly engrossed in the preparations for the Imperial fete and the forthcoming visit of the King of Spain.

The National Intelligencer persists in maintaining that President LINCOLN stands pledged, not only by the letter "to whom it may concern," but also by his Emancipation Proclamation, not to receive or consider any proposition for peace with the rebels which does not embrace the abandonment of Slavery as well as the restoration of the Union.

On Saturday last a man calling himself GEORGE A. MASON arrived here from Lexington, Kentucky. In the evening he made himself noticeable at a room on Sixth-street the Free and Easy, we believe by heaping all the abuse his tongue was capable of upon our Government, the Administration, and the soldiers in the field.

Just at this time I feel to my heart's core that our country; God's best gift to these latter days, is in great need. She needs almost everything from the hands and the hearts of her citizens, and if I mistake not, just at this time there is a disposition to withdraw from her support. What are men thinking about? or rather, ...

The belligerent forces in the valley keep active. On Sunday a considerable engagement oc curred two miles cast of Charlestown, on the Summit Point road. The attack was made by the enemy, and the Sixth Corps bore the brunt of the engagement, sustaining the chief loss, which was 370 in killed, wounded and missing.

There is nothing new in the spirit in which the London press approaches the question of maintaining an imperial military force in the neighboring provinces. And the lecture ad dressed to the Canadian people by the leading English journal, which we publish in another column, will not be likely to alarm any large section of the province. As a specimen of drivel, it can probably bear comparison with ...

The situation of affairs in the middle military division is unchanged. Slight skirmishing occurred early this morning on Gen. SHERIDAN'S left, and continued to break out at intervals all forenoon. Our forces now hold Shepherdstown. Advices from AVERILL state that the enemy have not yet attempted the passage of the river. No signs of EARLY'S forces are yet manifest at any of the upper fords.

Subscriptions to the new 7 30 loan, reported to day, amount to $480,200. Total to date, $22,430,500. To 10-40 loan, $232,950. Total to date, $77,370,850. Within the past few days an increased demand has arisen for the 10-40 bonds, and subscriptions are coming in quite freely.
The valuable documents found among the pri vate papers belonging to the Lodge of the Sons of Liberty, contain a complete roll of members of the order in this city.
On last Saturday afternoon Gov. MORTON re ceived a letter from an Eastern city, which was as follows, except some names which we omit for pru- dential reasons:

Maj.-Gen. CURTIS arrived here to-day to straighten up the Indian affairs. The Overland Stage Company have removed all the agents, stock, and coaches to this post for protection. There are no white inhabitants between here and Denver. All have fled to the forts for protection. The road around Denver is reported as swarming with hostile Indians.
The following correspondence will interest all who feel an interest in the welfare of our prisoners in the South:

By the arrival of the United States transport steamer Haze, from North Carolina, we rearn that the new pirate steamer Coquette, which is one of the number now in wilmington receiving her armament, is considered the most formidable of them all. She will be the first to leave that port, if she is not al- ready out.

The main body of this army is situated in the same position as when I last wrote you. They hold their works in front of the enemy, waiting patiently for whatever may come. If Gen. HOOD desires to charge their works, they deem it a favorable opportunity of diminishing the number of their enemy without much hazard to ...
A dispatch dated Lick Creek, East Tennessee, from Gen. GILLETT to Gov. JOHNSON, says:

The political campaign now in progress in the State of Indiana is one of the most remark- able that has taken place for many years in the West, and is exciting great attention and in terest, not only throughout that State, but in the adjoining States of Illinois and Ohio. The two candidates for the office of ...

The death of Mr. ROBSON, the lessee of the Olym pic Theatre, London, is announced by the China. The melancholy event took place on Thursday, night, (Aug. 11,) at 12 o'clock. This popular come- dian (says the Men of the Time) was born at Margate, in the year 1821, and was apprenticed at an early age to a copper-plate engraver in the metropolis.

The enemy early yesterday morning disappeared from the front of the Fifth and Ninth Corps on the Weldon Railroad, and the belief is that the attempt to regain possession of this important line of communication has been abandoned, and that the enemy are fortifying their right flank to resist an attack in this direction from our forces. They may, however, be preparing to make a dash on our lines in some other direction.

"Coming events cast their shadows before them," consequently we have the forerunners of the great National Democratic Convention, which is to come off in this city on the 29th, already in our midst. The attaches of such gatherings are here in considerable numbers, and, as a matter of precau tion, our police force has been increased, and every man has a more vigilant watch upon his pocket and of his door fastenings o'nights.
Memphis was attacked, at 4 o'clock this morning, by the rebel Gen. FORREST, with three brigades of cavalry, about three thousand strong.

The President stands firm against every so- licitation to postpone the draft. To the pro crastinators who have asked it, that they may fill their quota by volunteers, his reply is, that for this end, his proclamation gave ample time, and that the army is not to be punished if that time has been wasted.
S.L. TILLEY, Provincial Secretary, received the Congressional excursionists of Fredericton on the 22d, and on the evening of that day gave them an entertainment.

It would be wise not to be in haste to look for too much from the uncredited naval en listments, as affording promise of relief from the draft. It is doubtless true that a large body of naval recruits enlisted in New-York have not been credited to the City, and it may be equally true that were the uncredited num bers assigned to the districts from which they ...

Elsewhere we print a communication, from a source entitling its statements to credit, setting forth the embarrassments and annoy ances in the way of putting recruits in the naval service, as the system is now managed.
The European mails by the Peruvian, covering dates to Aug. 11, reached this City yesterday. They have been fully anticipated.

The news from Gen. GRANT'S army in front of Petersburgh is to the effect that he still main tains his firm hold upon the Weldon Railroad, and that on Tuesday the rebels were discovered to have withdrawn from Gen. WARREN'S front. Our forces have advanced on the Weldon Railroad to within two miles of Petersburgh without opposition. The rebels have retired within their earthworks, and no longer dispute the possession of the Weldon line.

In our yesterday's issue we had occasion to notice the arrival of the Swedish steamer Ernest Merck, from Stockholm, with 478 passengers. Certain facts have since come to our knowledge which clearly prove the complicity of the Federal Government in an attempt to kidnap a considerable number of these emigrants, as its agents have already kidnapped thousands of others in order to recruit the armies of the model republic.
I have just gleaned the following interesting facts from a gentleman who just arrived from Shawneetown:

On the 27th ult., in accordance with the royal decree of the 6th ult., the Government here granted permission for the importation of the Cochin Chinese, with the condition that one-fourth of each cargo consist of females.

Comptroller BRENNAN opened proposals for a county loan, yesterday, of $946,700, to extend to 1880 and 1881, at 6 per cent., for the redemption, on Sept. 1, of the "Soldiers' Substitute Relief Fund Bonds," issued in August of 1863, the new bonds to be entitled "Soldiers' Substitute and ...

One of our readers has clipped from Tuesday's TIMES, and inclosed to us, an article which we copied from a Georgia paper, making preposterous statements about the capture of Gen. STONEMAN'S troops, and accusing the gallant General of cowardice; and he indignantly asks us, "Why do you continually copy such things from rebel papers without comment? Many a person reads them and supposes they are true, because the TIMES gives no denial of them."
The following is taken from the Memphis Bulletin:
The American has Richmond papers of the 19th inst.

The Public expectation was raised so high by the early successes of GRANT and SHERMAN, that, in the minds of many, there is an evident feeling of disappointment that the campaign is not now ended. Is that reasonable? Is a campaign, which involves on both sides the movement of a million of men and thousands of miles ...
Our forces still maintain their position on the Weldon Railroad, a large portion of which has been effectually destroyed. No engagement, up to latest advices, had taken place since Sunday.

No engagement has taken place since Sunday As was stated in yesterday's dispatch, the enemy have fallen back to their lines, two miles from Petersburgh, where they are seen busily erecting strong works, similar to those we first encountered on our arrival here.

As published in the TIMES of yesterday, the packet ship Victoria, Capt. CHAMPION, from London in thirty-eight days, arrived at Quarantine about 9:30 o'clock on Wednesday evening, having on board FRANZ MULLER, the young German, who is charged with having, about two months since, murdered Mr. BRIGGS, a London bank clerk, a few miles out of that metropolis, while the two were riding together in a railway carriage.
The Mexican question, so far as the position of the State debt is concerned, remains unchanged.

SIR: The application in behalf of the persons engaged in the manufacture of clothing for the Quartermaster's Department, in Philadelphia, has received the attention of this department, and direction has been given to increase the wages of those in the employment of the Government twenty per cent.

It has been said that the wolf when learning to read could make nothing out of the letters but lamb, whatever other words they might form. Copperheads have a similar inaptitude. Whatever the military situation, they can never make anything of it but failure. It would seem as if failure were their very meat and drink, and as if their whole heart were constantly set upon it.

A gentleman has arrived in this city from Georgia, who came by way of Atlanta, with permission of Gen. SHERMAN, and who represents that State Government. He desires to learn upon what basis the United States Government will treat with the State of Georgia for readmission into the Union. This action of the Georgia authorities is had without reference to the balance of the Southern Confederacy.

The United States steam transport Mississippi Capt. KENNEDY, arrived at this port, this morning, from New-Orleans 18th inst., and the Bar 19th. She brings a number of passengers, and 175 sick and wounded soldiers, consigned to the United States Assistant Quartermaster.

Negro recruiting bands, with music and flying colors, are said to be quite successful in Shelby and other slave counties. This accords with Adjt.-Gen. THOMAS' published order June 13, that "as early as possible Kentucky colored troops will be used and distributed by Gen. CHETLAIN (now Gen. BURBRIDGE) for recruiting purposes."

The court-room was crowded to excess yesterday morning by curious people anxious to catch a glimpse of Muller, the man who perpetrated so horrible a murder in such a remarkable place as a public railway car. Prisoner looked, as he has all through the affair since his arrest, perfectly stupified and idiotic.

No material change is reported in the military situatlon around Petersburgh. On the right a severe cannonade is kept up in front of the Eighteenth Corps. On the left the line has been extended about six or seven miles, and our forces now hold the Weldon Railroad to Ream's Station. It is surmised that the rebel lines has been contracted on our left front.

One hundred and twenty-five guerrillas entered this place this morning and compelled a negro blacksmith to look after their horses. Shortly afterward they commenced breaking in the doors of the Courthouse, when the same number of Home Guards and a company of the Henry Rifles fired upon them, killing four, including the negro blacksmith, and wounding four. The guerrillas were then driven out of the town without any loss on our side.

BEAVERS, about the 22d of February last, came into our lines at Vienna and gave himself up as a deserter from MOSBY'S force.

FRED. K. HOLMAN, citizen, with two soldiers, whose names we did not learn, executed a bold feat. They were standing on Beal-street armed, when six rebels dashed up. They were ordered to halt and surrender. The rebels fired with no effect. HOLMAN and his companions, who had not fired, leveled their muskets and again ordered them to surrender, which they did. They had no opportunity to reload.

THE CASE OF DR. HAMMOND. Yesterday the District Attorney entered a suit in the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia against WM. A. HAMMOND, late Surgeon-General United States Army, to recover $450,000, the amount it is alleged the Government has been defrauded of by his purchase of blankets from W.A. STEPHENS and of supplies from JOHN WYETH BROTHER, $50,000 being the amount in the first case and $400,000 in the second.

Early yesterday morning, rumors came thick and fast of the battle on the Weldon Road, on Thursday. Some had it that the enemy had been driven from the road in utter rout, and many thousand prisoners captured. Others had it that the number of prisoners was as high as 7,600, and the number of cannon captured was put as high as 20.

The naval supply-ship Brandywine, lying at Norfolk, took fire last night, and is consumed, with all the stores on board. The loss is exceedingly heavy. The books and money are saved.

A very complete Union victory was achieved by Gen. GILLEM, commanding a portion of the Union forces in East Tennessee, at Greenville, on the morning of the 4th. The camp of the notorious guerrilla and raider JOHN MORGAN was surprised, MORGAN himself killed, his Staff and one piece of artillery captured, and his force entirely dispersed, with a loss of from fifty to one hundred in killed alone. This is the end of MORGAN.

Late yesterday afternoon a sharp engagement took place between Gen. CROOK'S command and a heavy force of the enemy, at a point to the left of, and about a mile beyond Berryville, resulting in the rebels being repeatedly and handsomely repulsed. The battle commenced at 4 P.M., by the enemy furiously attacking our lines. They succeeded at first in driving in our picket-line and gaining possession...

By direction of Gov. SEYMOUR flags were displayed from all the public buildings, and one hundred guns were fired at noon to-day, in honor of the occupation of Atlanta by Gen. SHERMAN'S forces, and the victories of Admiral FARRAGUT in the harbor of Mobile.

This morning, a large number of convalescents and detached service men arrived at Harper's Ferry, and are now being distributed to their respective commands. Brown University commemorates its one hundredth anniversary to-day. There is a large gathering of the alumni and friends of the College. President BARNAS SEARS this morning delivered a long and elaborate historical address in the First Baptist Meeting-house.

SHERMAN's design to withdraw his advance columns, and give his army rest in Atlanta, and reestablish himself securely there and restore his railway communications, broken by WHEELER and FORREST, before making further advances.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The expose in your paper of last Monday, showing the enormous destruction of life going on in the prison camp at Andersonville, Ga., must smite the public mind with remorse for the wrong which has been done to our suffering soldiers, so long left in the hands of cruel and relentless enemies, whose barbarity exceeds that of Algerine corsairs or Bedoun robbers.

Three thousand rebel cavalry, under WILLIAMS and ROBERTSON, with three pieces of artillery, were near Murfreesboro on Saturday morning. They were attacked by Gen. MILROY, and brisk fighting continued all day. On Sunday the rebels retreated toward Triune, followed by MILROY'S forces, which made several attacks during Sunday.

We are entering upon a Presidential campaign of unequaled importance. To our own judgment and that of great numbers of our citizens, the success of the Chicago platform and the Democratic nominee, would involve ultimately the acknowledgment of the independence of the rebel Confederacy, the permanence of Slavery on this continent, and the destruction of our national unity and imperial power.

The opposition steamboat Washoe exploded her boiler in Sacramento River last night. Her upper works were shattered and stern blown off. One hundred and fifty passengers were killed and wounded. Fifty persons are dead or will soon die. The boat was running at a high rate of speed. The engineer said before he died that the cause of the explosion was rotten iron in the boiler.

The Union State Convention at Syracuse, yesterday, nominated Hon. REUBEN E. FENTON for Governor of the State of New-York. He received 247 votes, to 69 for Mr. TREMAIN, and 35 for Gen. Dix. Mr. FENTON has had a long experience in public life having served as a Representative in the Thirty-third, Thirty-fifth and Thirty-sixth Congresses, and being also a member of the present (or Thirty-seventh) Congress, where he achieved distinction both for his general ability...

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The question has often been asked of late, "who the present King of Spain is." If it is the Queen's (of Spain) husband, why is he called King? Such was not the case with Prince ALBERT. By answering the above you will confer a great favor on CORRESPONDENTS.

The response of the Chicago nominee has been awaited with a good deal of interest. The nine days' grace he had taken had shown the extreme unpopularity of the platform on which he was nominated. Would he repudiate that platform and yet keep the nomination? Such an inconsistency would disgust everybody. Would he renounce the nomination? Nobody who knew what he had been so long in training for, believed that.

The Richmond Ex aminer, of Tuesday last, says : "The prospects of the Confederacy were never brighter than at this moment, it she deserves success and is resolved to win it; never so gloomy if, tired of the struggle and unworthy of independence, her resolution and zeal fail at the eleventh hour." The Examiner adds that "in all probability the next sixty days will in fact decide the contest."

The recent widely extended and severe drouth has given rise to serious apprehensions of a failure in the Fall crops. The great loss sustained by the corn crop last year from destructive frosts, and the injury to the wheat crop by freezing out during last Winter, estimated at 30 per cent., presented just grounds for alarm, should the Fall crops of corn and potatoes be cut short by the prevailing drouth.

There is a duty before earnest and loyal citizens even more urgent than that which awaits them at the ballot-box. The Union forces are moving with steady and unfaltering step from victory to victory. It is for those anxious hearts at home that these remarks are penned.

This neat and brilliant little establishment was reopened for the season Thursday evening, and was graced with an audience numerically strong, and of a quality that gave abundant evidence of the fact that Mr. HELLER'S Salle is regarded as a permanent and acceptable institution.

It is an ingenious trick of a shrewd business man, to begin his elequent dollar-a-line advertisement in a New-York journal, with "Don't read this!" in big letters, displayed and spaced. He knows that from the fall of Adam the human race has been predisposed to perversity and prying into forbidden things.

Gen. A.J. SMITH'S last expedition into Northern Mississippi and probably it will for a long time be the last into that quarter has terminated by the arrival of the force at Memphis. It has resulted less favorably than the previous expedition into Mississippi, which culminated in the brilliant victories at Tupelo and Town Creek, but only because we could not, by diligent search, find any rebel army on which to operate.

Richmond papers to the 6th inst., inclusive, are received. They still utter gloomy comments over the fall of Atlanta. THE SANITARY INQUIRY. The Citizens' Association have inaugurated a system of sanitary inspection and inquiry which cannot but result to the benefit of the City. Every section of every ward is visited and inspected, their condition ascertained, all classes of disease taken cognizance of, and their cause sought out; dwellings are inspected, and specially are tenement-houses and overcrowded vicinities.

Coroner RANNEY yesterday afternoon concluded the investigation in the case of ELLEN MEEHAN, the woman who died from injuries received by reason of the explosion of what is popularly known as a calcium light, at Union-square on the evening of the 8th inst., at the McCLELLAN ratification meeting. A sister of the deceased, named MARGARET MEEHAN, was also dangerously injured at the time.

Introducer quickly enlightened him he was talking to a Lincolnite.

At an early hour of yesterday morning, the Turners from this City, with their guests, repaired to Turner Hall, where the business meetings are held, for the purpose of organizing. A large number of ladies, both from this City and abroad, who had come out, despite of the driving rain-storm, were in attendance, and occupied seats in the galleries.

Atlanta is ours. The thunder of cannon from the capitol and from Fort Nagley at 4 o'clock P.M. of Saturday confirmed intelligence reaching the City on Friday evening somewhat suspiciously via Cumberland Gap and Knoxville. Though the news afforded the liveliest joy to every Union heart here, it came upon us with very little of the startling element, occasioning indeed surprise only in a moderate degree.

Dispatches dated Pulaski, Sept. 9, to Major R. H. POLK, A.A.G., state that Gen. ROUSSEAU concentrated all the forces of Gens. STEDMAN and GRANGER and his own at Athens, Ala., and moved toward the Tennessee. Gen. MILROY has returned to Tullahoma.

"A slight improvement is manifest," as the market reporter says, for which small favor we are truly thankful. Things is again "workin'." Mining stocks, that had gone so low that a "deep-sea lead" couldn't reach them, are again coming slowly to the surface.

The racing world of New-York and its surroundings, anywhere within hailing distance, is on the qui vive for the inauguration of the Fall Meeting at Paterson, N.J., which takes place to-morrow, (Tuesday.)

Gen. McCLELLAN's letter of acceptance is essentially a dishonest document, intended to obtain votes on false pretences. The main question at issue before the people of these United States at the coming election is not whether peace is desirable.

The Academy of Music reopens for a brief series of operatic performances, to-night, under the direction of Mr. LEONARD GROVER, of Philadelphia. The announcement will be found in another column, and we direct attention to it as a fine specimen of what may be called the evasive style of composition.

There is no greater proof of the utter corruption of politics in this country than the simple fact that the demagogues should be able to force upon the people a party strife in this crisis of the country. Why should we have a party controversy? For what earthly purpose?

Surgeon RICHARD S. SATTERLEE, Medical Purveyor United States Army, who ranked as Major, has received the successive brevets of LieutenantColonel, Colonel, and finally Brigadier-General, the latter dating from Sept. 2. The gratifying honors are bestowed, as is officially stated, "for diligent care and attention in procuring proper army supplies, as Medical Purveyor, and for economy and fidelity in the disbursement of large sums of money."

I send you an extract from a letter just received from that distinguished patriot in reference to the pending issues:

Beside the enjoyment, long denied me, of spending a cool and pleasant Summer and Autumn in a Northern State, I have had the grateful task imposed upon me of engaging in the political campaign. For the last three weeks the State has been literally in a blaze of excitement. Meetings have been held everywhere, in every county, village and hamlet. The Union men have been much more active than the Democrats.

The batteries on the right and centre of our lines kept up quite a lively fire to-day at intervals. The noise made by the cars, as they passed toward the front, attracted the attention of the enemy, and they endeavored to interrupt the operations of the road, but without success.

Last evening the rooms of the Central Union Lincoln and Johnson Campaign Club, corner Twentythird-street and Broadway, were crowded with a patriotic and enthusiastic audience, who had assembled to indorse the Union nominations.

FORTRESS MONROE, Sunday, Sept. 11. About 200 able-bodied contrabands from North Carolina arrived at Fortress Monroe to-day. They have enlisted for service in the army.
On Tuesday of last week the Vermont election for State officers and Congressmen took place, and the returns showed an aggregate increase of 5,000 Union majority over last year.

ENGINES FOR GUNBOATS. The whole force at the extensive machine shops in the Navy-yard, heretofore at work upon large guns are now exclusively employed upon engines for gunboats a very fine double engine being now in hand.
A large portion of the recent loan will be appropriated to the pay of the army.

Three valuable blockade-runners have just been caught. The British steamer Elsie, which was captured on the 5th by the gunboats Quaker City and Keystone State, arrived here yesterday, on her way to Boston. She had on board 320 bales of cotton. On the 9th inst. the prize steamer Georgia arrived at Beaufort, N.C., and would also proceed to Boston. She was cotten-laden.

Firing has been kept up all day on the centre and right. The rebels seem to have got their temper excited by that surprise of last night, and appear determined to annoy our pickets as much as they can. It was the Twentieth Indiana and Ninety-ninth Pennsylvania Cavalry that made the charge and took the rebel line of pickets.

The St. Helena Guardian says: It is reported that the Slave trade has been carried on very briskly for some time past by means of steamers of such a class that our cruisers have no chance of catching them. One steamer of 900 tons has got away three times, each time well laden with negroes. The barracoons are full.

The prize steamer Elsie, (British flag,) in charge of RICHARD WILKINSON, Prize Master, from Beaufort, N.C., on the 9th inst., arrived yesterday. She is bound to Boston, and after obtaining a Hell Gate pilot, proceeded. She was captured by the gunboats Quaker City and Keystone State on 5th inst., in lat. 33 10', lon. 77 02', from Wilmington N.C., for Nassau, with a cargo of 320 bales of cotton.

In one of the most important reforms of the present day the improvement of the homes of laboring people New-York is very far behind some of the cities of the Old World. In London and Paris especially, movements in behalf of comfortable dwellings for working people have been in progress for years, and have been attended with marked success.

Mr. VALLANDIGHAM, in his speech at Dayton, giving his account of the Chicago Convention, said: "That convention has met every expectation of mine. The promises have all been realized." It seems the martyr was a little too fast. He finds that the promises have not all been realized; and on seeing McCLELLAN'S letter of acceptance, he discards him on the instant.

The Union-loving citizens of Kings County assembled in large numbers, last evening, in and around the Academy of Music, Brooklyn, at the call of the General Committee, to ratify the National and State nominations. Not all the rain that fell could damp the ardor of the people, although interferring in some degree with arrangements outside, and causing a denser throng within the building.

We ought to have the whole number of men called for by the President in the shortest possible time. Prompt action in filling our armies will have more effect upon the enemy than a victory over them. They profers to believe, and made their men believe, there is such a party North in favor of recognizing Southern independence, that the draft cannot be enforced. Let them be undeceived.
The steamer Luminary, from New-Orleans 7th, has arrived. She was fined $2,500 by Gen. DANA at Vicksburgh for landing at other than military ports on her previous trip.
Richmond papers of Monday contain the following items:
OPINION OF THE CHICAGO PEACE ORGAN. The Chicago Times has committed itself irre trievably to the support of Gen. McCLELLAN. In its issue of Saturday it says:

Picket and artillery firing has been kept up very briskly since Saturday, the ire of the rebels not seeming to have cooled off yet at being surprised and losing so many prisoners. The result is that some five or six of our men are brought into the hospitals, the majority badly wounded, and some few have died.

From the armies in the field there is nothing of special importance. Since the rebels were so completely surprised on Saturday last, they have kept up a constant picket firing, as if apprehensive that something of a like nature might occur again. The Richmond journals gravely announce that GRANT is receiving heavy reinforcements, and sending them to his left, which portion of his line, they say, he is slowly but steadily extending.

The Journal has special correspondence from Atlanta up to the 10th inst. It contains a congratulatory order from Gen. SHERMAN, recounting his victory and an agreement between Gens. SHERMAN and HOOD for a ten days' truce at Rough and Ready, on the Macon Railroad, and the country around it, inclosed by a circle of two miles radius, from Sept. 12, to enable the people of Atlanta to remove to points South.

The Republican State Convention met here today. Nearly sixteen hundred delegates were present. Gov. ANDREW and the rest of the State ticket were renominated by acclamation, with the exception of Attorney-General FOSTER, who declined, and CHESTER J. REED, of Taunton, was nominated in his stead.

A disturbance took place yesterday afternoon in Norfolk between some sailors and the colored guard doing duty on Main-street. Two sailors and one of the guard were shot. One of the sailors died, and the other lost a leg. The guard will die.

Admiral FARRAGUT is not disposed to rest upon his oars. Although the main channel near the head of the bay, across Dog River bar, is still blockaded by a sunken rebel ironclad, four vessels of the Union fleet have run over, or through, the obstructions, and are now anchored within three miles, or easy shelling distance of the City. The vessels that have made this advance are the Winnebago, (double-turreted monitor,) the Metacomet, ...

STETSON, were cleared, and the wine had been discussed, when the President, Judge DERRICKSON, of Pennsylvania, rose and introduced GEORGE DE CAMP, Esq., of Erie.

JOHN VAN BUREN

We have dates from Bogota, the capital, to the 20th ult. The whole Republic is in a state of complete peace. The administration of President MURILLO gives such general satisfaction that even the most ultra Conservaties have but little to say against it.

A decision recently made in the United States Circuit Court in this District, in relation to the Income Tax, will be of interest to all persons who hold stock in Express Companies. It has been claimed that the dividends received upon stock in such companies were exempted from the Income Tax. A suit was brought against a collector to test the question, and the court has decided that the dividends are subject to the tax.

The Legislative Assembly met in this city on the 1st inst., and offer scrutinizing the votes cast for President in the late election, declared Gen. SANTACOLOMA unconditionally elected for the coming period. For some days previous to the meeting of the Assembly, a great deal of excitement existed, and it was generally believed that a revolution was inevitable; but with the announcement of the relection of SANTACOLOMA all fears of an uprising have entirely disappeared.

The British mail steamship Bogota, from Valparalso and intermediate ports, arrived at Panama on the 4th inst. She brings dates from Valparalso and Santiago de Chill to Aug. 16, Bolivia to the 20th, and from Lima and Callao to the 27th August. The Bogota brings $372,000 in specie and a cargo of wool, cotton, bark, , principally for England. For New-York she has 77 bales cacao, 83 bales wool, 31 bales goatskins and 61 hides.

The intelligence from the Army of the Potomac is rather meagre. On Wednesday, our batteries at the front opened heavily on the enemy, in reply to an annoying fire from their batteries on our left. The firing continued nearly all day.

The Richmond Examiner, judging by the looks of the thing, seems to have stopped its press last Saturday to insert the following terrible paragraph in its issue of that day: "It is reported that there is little doubt that Grant is receiving reinforcements, and that he is conveying them to his left. Where they come from, or what the object of collecting them on our right can be, is a mere conjecture."

We remarked in Wednesday's issue on the gross misrepresentation made by Mayor GUNTHER, in his recent letter upon the new Emigrant Act. The economical and political utterances which he there makes are, however, even more unfounded. We are informed that immigration will add to the number of those 50,000 operatives in this City who are already "suffering under the oppression of capital."

Intelligence from the front is, that our batteries opened on the enemy on Wednesday, and there has been heavy firing all day to silence the fire of the rebels, who for some days have been annoying our lines, particularly on the left.

During the past four days I have enjoyed opportunities of conversing with a large number of influential gentlemen, residing in this and the adjoining counties of Cayuga and Seneca. You will naturally infer that my first inquiries were in reference to the political complexion of this section.

In fifty years we have made no material progress in militia organization. Constant failure is presumptive evidence of wrong methods. The temper of our people is more mercurial than that of our Canadian neighbors or of the English people. But while we have been repeating our failures in militia organization, they have heen quite successful. Their methods have been radically different from ours, and to this single fact, doubtless, their success is attributable.

There has been comparative quiet in our city since the adjournment of the Democratic Convention; but the Union men are active, and the campaign is being carried forward with much spirit. As between the war candidate and the peace platform, the more intelligent of the party are in a quandary.

Yesterday was one of unusual bustle for the Fifth Corps. Nothing is so monotonous as the daily camp routine of the soldier's life. We can imagine with what eagerness and curiosity they were assembled around a large platform, overshadowed by a square-shaped music stand. The entire corps was under arme, making an imposing display with brightly-burnished weapons and well-brushed clothes. To every man in the rank and file the occasion was one of peculiar interest.
To-day the Emperor passed in review on the Champ de Mars the Imperial Guard, the First Army Corps, the National Guard, and the pupils of the Military School of St. Cyr.

Under no form of government is disobedience of the law attended with such fatal results as under the republican form. For, if the people, who are the fountain of power in a republic, will not respect the laws, the enactment of which they have themselves sanctioned, what hope can there be for the commonwealth?

Passengers by the mail boat to-day report that on Friday a large number of rebel cavalry made a raid on our reserve cattle herd, opposite Harrison's Landing, and succeeded in cutting off the entire number, about twenty-five hundred head. The guard taking care of these cattle was the l3th Pennsylvania cavalry--about 200 men--and, of course, could not make much resistance against such a heavy body of the enemy.

For many years we have not had so complete a calm in the political world as at the present moment. The Emperor is absent at the Champ of Chalons with the Prince HUMBERT of Italy, the politicians are off at their country places, and the calm that pervades France appears to reign equally all over Europe.
PSALM 98, 1. O, sing unto the Lord a new song, for He hath done marvelous things: His right hand and His holy arm hath gotten him the victory.

The rebel cavalry dash upon a cattle corral near Harrison's, Landing on the James River, appears to have been entirely successful. Gen. GREGGS' cavalry were immediately sent out in hot pursuit; but, although it was rumored that the entire herd had been recaptured, it was generally believed that the raiders had too long a start to be overtaken, and that the rumor was without foundation.

Yesterday was quite a busy day, and considerable interest was created by the result of the reconnoissances sent out by Gen. SHERIDAN. The colonies of Australia were the first in our time to organize and foster a system of emigration by means of public subsidies. Their enterprise has been amply rewarded. In 1850 the entire population of New South Wales and Victoria was but 237,000.

Sugar closes with much dullness; prices are 1 per cent, under those of last Friday. There are few buyers, and 47c is taken for low lump. Coffee demand moderate and sales again a little lower. Tea business limited and prices in favor of purchasers. Rice dull, but no decided fall in value. Saltpetre offering at rather lower rates, Tallow slow of sale; P.Y.C. 42@42 1/3 on the spot.

Yesterday this army and its Generals, suffered considerable disappointment on account of an anticipated attack by the enemy on our lines not coming off, as expected, and it was a great pity that the ample preparations made by the Nineteenth Army Corps for the proper reception of the enemy did not have their full fruition, for no doubt the results of the day would have been numbered among the successes of the campaign.

The demand for discount at the Bank on the 9th inst, was extremely heavy, owing to an exceptional pressure occasioned by the large amount of India bills payable on Sept. 10. Ordinary Banks and discount brokers manifested great caution, but there was no difficulty in negotiating sound commercial bills at the existing rates, with exceptional transactions at a fraction lower.

The price of Gold fell 3 [per] cent. additional on the Shenandoah victory yesterday, the speculation closing weak. Two women who have been confined in the Old Capitol Prison upon the charge of repeatedly aiding soldiers to desert by furnishing them with citizens' clothing have been sent to the female prison at Fitchburgh, Mass.

The opening of Fall fashions has been signalized by a larger display of novelties this season than we remember to have seen for several years. Bonnets have undergone a total revolution; extraordinary innovations have been introduced into garments for outside wear, while in dress and ornamental fabrics, many quite new and elegant designs and combinations have made their appearance for the first time in this country.

BODY RECOVERED The body of a colored boy, named JAMES FRANKLIN, was picked up in the Atlantic Dock Basin yesterday. He was identified by his mother as one of the victims of the boiler explosion on the tug-boat B.B. Sanders, some day last week. His face had been blown off and his bowels torn out. His mother identified him by a ring on one of his fingers.

Yesterday, between the hours of 10 and 3, the remains of Brig.-Gen. RUSSELL, who was killed in the recent great battle in the Shenandoah Valley, lay in state in the City Hall. Great numbers of citizens, and many well-known army officers, called to pay a last tribute of respect to the departed hero. Since the arrival of the remains in this City, the Eighth Regiment has been on duty, acting as guard of honor.

The draft in this county passed off yesterday in quiet and good humor. From 13,032 cards, 1,562 were drawn one-half to make up deficiencies arising from excemptions and vacancies among the other half first drawn.

The train captured at Cabin's Creek, Kansas, on Monday last, consisted of 200 wagons instead of 100, as previously reported. Several ambulances and sutler's wagons, and about 50 wagons were also lost. Their total value was estimated at $1,000,000. McDONALD and FULLER, of Leavenworth, were heavy losers. In the trenches, on fatigue, skirmish or vidette line, is now the order of the day. My time for keeping you posted in a private's daily experience is limited enough, and I write this on my knee, whilst relieved on fatigue one hour on, and one hour off.

The testimony given in the case is somewhat different from the previous version of the affair.

Yesterday the Erie County Convention met and nominated for Congress SAMUEL J. HOLLEY, a staunch, liberty-loving man, who is for the Union "day and night, in heat and cold, in sunshine and in storm." A son of MYRON HOLLEY, he inherited his strong prejudices against any system which does not entirely harmonize with the declaration that "all men are created free and equal."

Gen. SHERIDAN was six miles South of Newmarket on Saturday evening, or about ninetysix miles South-west of Harper's Ferry. His men probably had ten hours rest at Woodstock. Certainly not more. What rations were served out to them, we apprehend, must have been carried in their knapsacks. It is barely probable the supply train could have come up with them before they left Woodstock.

General HAMPTON'S late foray upon the larder of GRANT was a very useful, as well as a very brilliant, affair. Some time since we published a notice of the arrest of Mr. John Bellamy, of this City, upon a charge of arsan. We publish below a letter from the Judge who issued the warrant, which shows that the charge was without foundation.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The sale of tickets for the forthcoming season of Italian opera commences here to-day. Mr. MARETZEK'S card will be found in another column. It says all that need be said. This much we may add; that the rehearsal yesterday gave abundant promise of a tremendous success for all the artists to whom Mr. MARETZEK refers with such simple candor and honesty.

Gov. DENNISON, the new Postmaster-General, will enter formally upon his duties on Friday, the 30th inst. The correspondence between the President and Judge BLAIR, upon the subject of his resignation, was published at the express request of the letter.
Quiet still prevails in front of Petersburgh, broken only by the usual picket firing and occasional artillery duel, the effect of which is to consume a large quantity of powder on both sides.

It is a good sign of success that the friends of the Union are almost everywhere putting in nomination for office, young, active, efficient men, who have the zeal, endurance, devotion and patriotism of youth. Especially is this the case in the nominations for Congress.

The County Convention summoned under the auspices of the Union General Committee, met at Hope Chapel last night. A temporary organization was effected, by the appointment of Col. RUSH C. HAWKINS as Chairman, J. SOLIS RITTERBAND and JAMES L. HASTIE, Secretaries.

During the month just passed there have appeared from time to time, many items about the Confederate eruiser Tallahassee, and extracts from the Northern papers regarding the doings of the pirate Tallahassee have been extensively copied. Perhaps the main facts have thus been made public, but only one side of the story has been told, and that, with all the exaggeration and falsehood of particular instances.

FORREST has, no doubt, crossed the Tennessee River again with considerable force, for the purpose of doing more thoroughly what WHEELER a few weeks ago attempted and failed. The public will not be surprised at this renewal of an attempt upon our communications with Atlanta, as the newspapers weeks ago announced that the hero of Fort Pillow was collecting a large body of cavalry in Mississippi.

CIRCULAR No. 90. The quota of the County of New-York on all calls of the President for volunteers having been filled, the A.A. Provost-MarshalGeneral directs the Provost-Marshals of the Fourth to the Ninth Districts inclusive, to muster into the United States service, until further orders, recruits and substitutes, to be accredited to any district in the State of New-York which such recruits or substitutes may select.

When all the facts of this case are taken into consideration, it would seem that attempts to murder in this City are (pecuniarily) matters of very small importance.
There is no news of importance from the Army of the Potomac. There are, however, very strong intimations that we may receive very stirring news from that quarter very soon.

WALLACK'S THEATRE. LOVEL'S five-act comedy of "Look Before You Leap" was revived here on Wednesday evening with very marked and well-deserved success. Although not free from the usual stiltedness of the school to which it belongs, it is nevertheless a fresh and interesting work. The characters are nicely drawn, the dialogue is well distributed.

Gen. GRANT began yesterday morning a new movement against Richmond. He telegraphs to Secretary STANTON at 10:45 A.M., Thursday, that Gen. ORD'S corps, the Eighteenth, advanced in the morning and carried the very strong fortifications and long line of intrenchments below Chapin's Farm, some fifteen pieces of artillery, and from two to three hundred prisoners. Gen. ORD was wounded, though not dangerously.

A meeting of the War Democratic State Committee of the State of New-York was held at the Astor House on Tuesday, Sept. 27, 1864, Hon. GEORGE A. BRANDRETH, Chairman; Hons. T.R. WESTBROOK and R.H. TYLER, Vice Chairmen; H.C. PAGE, Secretary.

The blue haze which I recently described as resting upon the landscape, has cleared away. There was a sort of despondent tone in the atmosphere, which found its analogy in the tone of the public mind. I could account for neither. I saw nothing in nature which should make that haze, and I saw nothing in our public situation ...

The Common Council, the great majority of which, of course, are for the Chicago nominee, felt the necessity, after the late victories, of doing something to clear him of the odious associations of the platform he stands upon.

The nineteenth century will be handed down by history as one in which science has made greater progress than any other. Discovery upon discovery has changed almost our entire system of living so much so that could our forefathers return to earth they would fully realize that a generation, inventive and progressive, had sprung up in the place of the one to which they belonged. Among them all, medicine has not been behind-hand.

The Richmond Enquirer consoles itself for the defeat of EARLY in the Shenandoah by recalling the fact that STONEWALL JACKSON marched down the Valley and was driven back; that he again advanced and was obliged to retreat; that SIGEL marched up and was defeated, and that HUNTER, after gaining a complete victory over JONES, and after having penetrated to the defences of Lynchburgh, was also compelled to retrace his steps.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The sale of tickets for the opening night on Monday next goes on in spite of the bad weather with unprecedented velocity. Yesterday there were but four seats left in the sections reserved for the Fourteenth-street customers. Mr. MARETZEK'S down-town reserves are pressed in...
Gen. EWING, after blowing up the magazine, evacuated Pilot Knob, brought away his entire command, and will reach Harrison Station, on the Southwest Branch Railroad, to-night.

Of the sudden, rapid, bold and remarkable series of movements around Richmond, inaugurated by Gen. GRANT on Thursday morning, we know just enough to leave us in considerable bewilderment. To the dashing and unexpected movement on the north bank of the James, were yesterday added two other movements of equal or greater magnitude....

To Major-Gen. Dix: A dispatch from Gen. GRANT, dated at 3:30 o'clock this afternoon at City Point, states that WARREN attacked and carried the enemy's line to-day on their extreme right, capturing a number of prisoners. He immediately prepared to follow up his success.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Three or four weeks ago, there were four hundred and fifty soldiers, Maine men, remnants of regiments, and many among them wounded, going home on furlough by the Fall River line. The Government gave them their passage, but no rations. The few passengers, who learned that these men were supperless, promptly did what they could toward supplying them, and the very walters stripped the tables...

We had the pleasure yesterday of meeting a gentleman who has been a resident of Little Rock, Ark., for the past seven months, and who left that city Saturday last, on his way to his old home in Lincoln, Illinois. This gentleman represents the season as having been extremely unhealthy in the region of Little Rock, and far more so than has for some years been known by the people living there.

Bapt. HILL gives a detailed account of the defense of Pilot Knob, but it does not differ materially from the report already telegraphed. At one time the rebels were so near the fort that they got on the drawbridge, but they were driven back with great slaughter and forced to retreat.

The St. Louis Union of the 28th says dispatches received at Headquarters from North Missouri report that our troops had a fight with TODD'S and THRAILKILL'S guerrillas on Sunday, the 25th, in which thirteen of the rebels were killed, including two captains, one of them named BISSELL, of Platte County.

The United States mail steamship Suwo Nada arrived at this port from New-Orleans yesterday morning, with advices to the 24th. Among her passengers was Maj.-Gen. BANKS, who, for nearly three years, has been in command of the Department of the Gulf.

Gen. LOW has issued a proclamation calling on the citizens to enlist for a new regiment of infantry and to fill the recent requisition to fill old regiments. Recruiting is going on briskly. The State offers a bounty of $160 in gold for new recruits, and $300 for veterans, and tender $5 per month extra pay.
THE OHIO ELECTION. Advices from Ohio clearly indicate that at the coming election the Union party will carry that State by 75,000 majority.
The political campaign opened most auspiciously with us last evening, at which time a large audience congregated at our Academy Hall, to hear an address from Hon. C.M. DEPEW, of Albany.

The United States hospital steamer George Leary arrived here this afternoon, with 200 sick and 60 wounded soldiers from the Tenth Army Corps Hospital.

Mobile is at our mercy. It is for us to say when it shall fall and how. While the eager, expectant North are waiting to hear that the Federal flag has been hoisted over the doomed city, FAREAGUT is scattering his brave fleet in every direction. The land forces are now engaged in another expedition where, we know not. Our monitors, the Chickasaw and Winnebago, are above, within shelling distance of the city.

Passengers from City Point report that early on Wednesday night the Tenth Corps, under Gen. ORD, began to move from their old position to Jones' Neck, on the James River, where a pontoon bridge had been thrown across the river, and immediately began to cross. By 12 o'clock the advance guard succeeded in effecting the crossing in safety, and before daylight the whole corps was over.

The steamship Saxonia, from Southampton, on the 21st inst., passed Cape Race at eight o'clock this evening en route to New-York. She was boarded by the news-yacht of the Associated Press, and a summary of her news obtained, which is three days later.

JOHN H. MORGAN was the eldest of five brothers, all of whom have been in the rebel service, and was born in Lexington, Ky. He was a handsome man, six feet one inch in heighth, and built comparatively. His temperament was sanguine-biliousnervous. His eyes, nose, mouth and teeth were all adornments. His complexion was florid and his hair auburn.

This noble and gallant officer fell at Chapin's farm, on the 29th inst. It is simple truth to say that a braver and more conscientious soldier never lived. Not bred a professional military man, yet entering into military service with all the enthusiasm of a national soldier, combined with that high sense of duty which he felt as a patriotic citizen, and which placed him foremost in every place of danger.

The final struggle for the possession of Virginia is now near. This war draws to a close. If Richmond is held by the youth till the 1st of November it will be ours for evermore, for the North will never throw another large army into the abyss where so many lie; the war will conclude, beyond a doubt, with the independence of the Southern States.

Sergt-Maj. HASTINGS returned home on Monday night, having been unsuccessful in arresting any of the Lake Erie pirates of whom he was in search. He traced them from this city to St. Catherines, where they stopped for a day, each one at a different hotel, and thence proceeded to London. The trial of DODD, now going on before a courtmartial in this city, will develop one of the most infernal conspiracies which has ever disgraced mankind. Whether regarded as to its design to overthrow this Government or in respect to the atrocious measures which the conspirators intended to employ, it stands with few, if any, parallels.

As the human mind developes, it becomes more and more all-embracing in its desire to advance those arts and sciences which contribute to pleasure, when the recipient is in abounding health, or relieve, when overtaken by disease.

The price of Gold fell to 189 cent, on Saturday. The Railway Stocks were very much depressed. The Government Stocks were a fraction easier, while Treasury Certificates were firm. The Secretary of the Treasury proposes to award $40,000,000 of new 5-20 Bonds to the highest bidders, on the 14th October, receiving 25 cent, of the awards in Treasury Certificates.

The steamship Peruvian, from Liverpool at 2:30 P.M. on the 22d of September, via Londonderry on the 23d, arrived off this point at 2:30 O'clock this afternoon. Her dates are two days later than those already received.

Mr. BLAIR entered upon the discharge of the duties of his office March 4, 1861. At that time several of the Southern States had already seceded, although the mall was still being carried in those States at the expense of the Government.
The Board met, pursuant to adjournment, in their Chamber. Number sixteen City Hall.
