U.S. revenue cutter Varuna, Jones, Philadelphia, via Long Island Sound. Was blown off in the late N.W. gale: split sails,

THE FIRE IN FRONT-STREET.--The insurances on the Front-street fire could not be fully ascertained yesterday, owing to a number of the proprietors being out of town. It is estimated that Mr. GOODWIN'S loss on stock will be about $4,500, said to be covered by insurance; and that the damage to the building. Nos. 228 and 230 Front-street, will be about $20,000. Messrs. DICKERSON, REED CO., Nos. 243 and 245 ...
SIR: Yours of the 7th ult., relative to the liability of banks to taxation, under several provisions of the Excise Law, has been received and considered.
The TIMES special correspondent at Gen. BUTLER'S headquarters transmits to this office the following account of operations on the north side of the James:

The United States hospital steamer George Leary, arrived from Deep Bottom this afternoon, reports fighting in progress, yesterday, on the north side of the James. Also, heavy firing on the south side of Petersburgh, which continued at a late hour last evening. No important results are yet reported, but the indications are very favorable.

Union League Hall was filled last evening, on the occasion of Gen. JOHN COCHRANE, of New-York, delivering an address in favor of the election of LINCOLN and JOHNSON. The distinguished gentleman was introduced by Gen. SIMON CAMERON, Chairman of the Union State Committee, who gave a brief account of a successful tour that he had just made through several counties in Western Pennsylvania.

On Saturday evening a number of War Democrats of this City, opposed to the Chicago platform and its candidates, met at the Bancroft House, Broadway and Twentieth-street. On motion, Hon. PETER COOPER was called to the Chair, and H.W. JENNINGS was appointed Secretary. The object of the meeting was stated to be for conference and consultation among Democrats opposed to the Chicago candidates, and the platform, and general harmony and enthusiasm prevailed.
Memphis papers of the 30th ult., contain nothing important.

It having been determined by Gen. MEADE to make an attack on the enemy's right flank southwest of Petersburgh, the troops selected for that purpose were massed near the Weldon Railroad this morning. These consisted of the First and Second Divisions and a brigade of the Third Division of the Fifth Corps, with the Second and Third Divisions of the Ninth Corps, while Gen. CRAWFORD with his command held the works on the flank.
The steamer Belle has arrived here with Memphis papers of the 30th of September, which contain Duvall's Bluff dates of the 22d.
The Board met, pursuant to adjournment, in their Chamber, No. Sixteen City Hall.

The inauguration of Rev. F.A.P. BARNARD, D.D., L.L.D., as President of Columbia College, took place yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the institution. The proceedings were of a very interesting character, and were witnessed by a large concourse of distinguished gentlemen, including many of the Alumni of the college.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC OPENING OF THE SEASON. A brilliant audience attended the opening performance here last evening, and extended to Mr. MARETZEK'S new artists the welcome wnice is seldom withheld from new comers. The opera was "Travatore," selected by the prima donna for her debut. It answered its purpose thoroughly, and placed Mile. COROSSI ZUCCHI in an enviable light before the public.

One of the largest meetings ever held in Chester County took place in the town of West Chester, on Saturday morning. The town was filled with people, men and women, coming from every township, and showing by their enthusiasm and the many displays of flowers, wreaths, banners and flags, their devotion to the cause.

Transactions in most descriptions of produce and merchandise were on a restricted scale yesterday. The very unfavorable news a from Chicago tended decidedly to depress prices of breadstuffs, which were generally lower, with a light business. Provisions were unsettled, during the day, but closed heavily. Cotton, whisky, oils, tallow and groceries were quiet and declining. Freights were dull.

The steamship Saxonia, from Southampton on the 21st September, arrived at this port to-day. The steamship Peruvian, with advises to the 23d, arrived off Father Point yesterday afternoon. A brief summary of the news by the Saxonia has already been published, but we find the following additional items of interest.

A dispatch from Gen. SHERIDAN, dated at Harrisonburgh. Oct. 1, 9:30 P.M., has been received by the War Department. He says he has been to Staunton and Waynesborough with the cavalry; destroyed the iron bridge on South River at Waynesborough, throwing it into the river; also the bridge near Christiana Creek, and the railroad from Staunton to Waynesborough. SHERIDAN is also preparing for a renewed onset against EARLY'S forces.

The National Union League Hall was again crowded this evening with intelligent ladies and gentlemen on the occasion of an address, of nearly two hours' length, by DAVID DOUGHERTY, Esq. The meeting was exceedingly enthusiastic.

We arrived here about 3 o'clock yesterday after noon, and found the enemy under Gen. VAUGHN strongly entrenched on both sides of the river. After heavy cannonading and skirmishing all the afternoon and until noon to-day, the enemy were driven out of his forts, and fled towards Zollicoffer.
This Court was opened for the October Term yesterday morning, and the following gentlemen sworn in as Grand Jurymen:

Secretary STANTON says, in his bulletin published this morning, that no dispatches have been received for three days from Gen. SHERMAN and press dispatches. from that army have latterly almost entirely stopped. It has been surmised that this silence is ominous, and that active operations in Georgia are again about to be resumed. On this topic the Louisville Journal, of Friday last, remarks:

FORREST, with his whole force, appeared before Huntsville, this morning, and demanded its surrender. The Commanding Officer, Col. G.M.L. JOHNSON, of the Twelfth Indiana Cavalry, refused to comply. There has probably been heavy fighting there, to-day, but no fears are entertained of its capture.

SATURDAY, Oct. 1. Purse of $100, with inside stake of $20 each; mile heats, best three in five, in harness.

On Saturday, Gen. BUFORD, with a part of FORREST'S command, including all his artillery, attacked Athens, Ala., shelling the place for two hours, and demanded its surrender from the Commandant, Col. WADE, of the Seventy-third Indiana, who refused. BUFORD soon after retired.
The Royal mail steamer China, which left Livurpool at 2 o'clock on the afternoon of the 24th, and Queenstown on the 25th of September, arrived here at 1 o'clock this morning.
The Stock market continued to be influenced by the feeling of distrust which prevailed in commercial circles. Consols were weak and drooping, closing on the 23d at 88@88 for money.

The latest reliable accounts state that PRICE is moving on Rolla in three columns, the right under SHELBY and MARMADUKE, the centre under himself, and the left under COOPER, the latter being mainly composed of half-breed Indians.
WEDNESDAY, OCT. 5 MATCH OF $500. Mile heats; best 3 in 5 in harness.

The sensation here, in Italy, at Rome, in all the Catholic States, is intense. No European question has the privilege of exciting people's passions to the same extent at this one, and ... no one dreamed even that negotiations were going on for its settlement. The transport Josephine, from Brazos Santiago, brings the intelligence that the French, who marched from Bagdad upon Matamoras, were met by CORTINAS and badly whipped. The rebels appeared on the Texas side of the Rio Grande, and covered the retreat of the French.
The War Department yesterday had received nothing later from either Gen. SHERMAN or Gen. SHERIDAN than has already been published.

There have been no active operations on either side to-day nothing but a few spirts of loud-mouthed artillery, and an angry dash of picket-firing. I don't attribute the lull to a feeling of respect for the Christian Sabbath, but rather to the fact that neither side is ready, as yet, for aggression. On our part, there is no disposition to turn back, and an evident intention to keep every inch that we gain.
On the 20th instant the French steamer Santiago arrived from the La Plata River with dates from Buenos Ayres to the 13th and from Montevideo to the 15th.

English and French papers alike declare the nomination of Gen. McCLELLANS at Chicago the most important event that has occurred since the beginning of the war. This view of its importance rests solely upon the idea that it is a peace nomination, and that the election of McCLELLAN, which to looked upon as almost certain, will be attended with a speedy restoration of peace. The Union resolutions are looked upon as a mere pretence.

George Opdyke vs. Manton Marble, Elon Comstock, John Doe, Richard Roe, and John Stiles. This was an action for a libel in the newspaper called The World, and the plaintiff being able to discover only two of the editors and proprietors, viz.: Manton Marble and Elon Comstock, and believing that there were other parties concerned, issued summons against them by fictitious names.

The train which left Hannibal, yesterday morning far the West, run off the track 17 miles from Palmyra, and was soon afterward visited by a band of 10 guerrilias, who searches the train for soldiers, seized the express safe, containing about $20,000, took three revolvers from the passengers, and then compelled one of the employee to fire the cars.

Neptune, S., 9 guns, The U.S. gunboat Neptune, Commander J.P. SANDFORD, will sail on Wednesday morning from the Philadelphia Navy-Yard for the headquarters of the East Gulf Blockading Squadron at Key West. She will take, as passengers, Acting Rear Admiral C.K. STRIBLING, his secretary, clerks, a barge's crew and servants. Admiral STRIB LING will command to East Gulf Blockading Squadron.
THE NEW-YORK WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office, in wrappers, ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- DONIZETTI'S Opera of "Lucrezia Borgia" was given here last evening to a brilliant house. The work is too well known to need particular criticism. It served the purpose on this occasion of Introducing the new prima donnaMadame ZUCCHI in a great dramatic part, and one in which she has already won considerable reputation in Italy. Her conception of the role is eminently Italian, and her rendering of the music thoroughly good.

The Chilian bark Tabon, from Valparaiso, has arrived. Exchanged signals Aug. 20, lat, 25 04, long, 31 10, with an American bark steering southeast, showing a white flag with "S.R." in the centre, and another blue flag with "1448" in the centre. A steamer which left Monte Cristi, in St. Domingo, on the 24th of September, brings intelligence which fully confirms all that I said in my last letter as to the probable conclusion of the war. Letters from many reliable persons assert with confidence that the conferences held at Guarico had been highly satisfactory to the Spanish authorities, since it was affirmed confidently that the Government of the insurgents had submitted unconditionally.

The Academy of Music, Brooklyn, last evening was crowded with one of those audiences such as only the announcement of a Union meeting can call forth in the City of Churches. An excellent band was in attendance.

Produce and Merchandise were generally quiet and depressed on Saturday. Flour fell off 15c. @25c. bbl.; Wheat, 3c.@5c.; Corn, 4c @6c.; Oats, 2c., bushel; New Mess Pork, 25c. bbl., with a light business. Cotton was heavy and drooping, as were also Groceries, Hides, Leather, Oils, Wool, Tallow and Tobacco. Freights were quite dull, with 440 vessels of all classes in port.

THE LATE MURDER OF A POLICEMAN.?Coroner NORRIS held an inquest yesterday upon the body of the late CHARLES CURRAN, a member of the Forty Second Precinct Police, who died at the Brooklyn City Hospital on the morning of the 5th inst., of injuries caused by a pistol shot, fired by a man named THEODORE YATES. The officers had the prisoner in custody at the time he was shot.

THE BOMBARDMENT OF CHARLESTON. Charleston papers of the 29th of September say that the bombardment of the city since our last has been unusually severe, the enemy firing from three guns in rapid and constant succession. During the twenty-four hours, ending at 6 o'clock on Wednesday evening, eighty-eight shots were reported fired at the city. A number of casualties occurred, but mostly from flying bricks and splinters.

Elections occur to-morrow in PENNSYLVANIA, OHIO and INDIANA. They are watched with intense interest by men of all parties throughout the country. In themselves the results in these States are of comparatively little consequence; but the indications which those results will afford of the probable issue of the Presidential contest in November are of the utmost interest and importance.

The NATIONAL UNION EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE will publish immediately a series of Documents in said of the Union cause for the Presidential Canvass. They are not intended to supersede or take the place of documents issued by the Congressional Committee at Washington, or by any other Union organizations, but rather to supply a want which has been brought to their notice by correspondence from different sections of the country.

To-day will be generally observed by our Jewish fellow-citizens as a rigid fast-day and period of strict religions observance. It is known as Your Kippur Day of Atonement. Every Israelite in every part of the world, who believes in the law of Moses and the doctrine of a future world, keeps the day as a strict fast-day. From sunset yesterday till sunset to-day no food or drink is indulged in.

FROM TENNESSEE. Advices from Tennessee show that Gen. THOMAS is taking the most energetic measures to secure the capture of FORREST and his command. The Tennessee River has been rising for some days, and now has twelve feet of water, so that it is hoped the marauders will be hived.

The great States of PENNSYLVANIA, OHIO and INDIANA, yesterday, gave their popular verdict in favor of the Union, the prosecution of the war against rebellion to its successful conclusion, and in favor of the present administration of the Government.

The election returns last evening occupied the telegraph to the exclusion of all other news; and the only intelligence from our armies is that received during the afternoon. From the West we learn that the rebel demonstrations in Jefferson City on the 7th, was merely to occupy while the main body of the enemy crossed the Osage river.

PHILADELPHIA, Tuesday, Oct. 11 Midnight, Philadelphia is in a blaze of glory. Union City and County ticket elected by eight thousand majority. RANDALL, Dem., elected to Congress in the First District; O'NPIL, KELLEY, MYERS and THAYER in the Second, Third, Fourth and Fifth Districts, elected by increased majorities.

The Elections yesterday in Pennsylvania, Ohio and Indiana, resulted in glorious triumphs for the Union cause. In Pennsylvania the majority will be fully equal to that of last year, to which will be added the soldiers' vote, bringing it up to thirty-five thousand at least. We also gain five members of Congress, making the delegation stand 17 Union to 7 Copperheads. In Ohio the majority on the home vote is estimated at 40,000.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The repetition of " Il Trovatore" on Monday night, was witnessed by a good audience, and the performance was generally excellent. If it lacked the auditorial enthusiasm of the first night it deserved it more.
The Lynchburgh papers bring us some particulars of the fight at Saltville.

Nothing of any immediate importance or interest has occurred in the Army of the Potomac since the close of the recent operations on our left. The army is quietly resting upon its laurels, and completing the projected lines of offensive and defensive works. The new levies are being drilled, and everything that tends to the improvement and comfort of the troops is being attended to.

Intelligence has been received at headquarters that PRICE'S army went from California to Booneville, Cooper County, yesterday, and SHELBY sent 2,000 cavalry across the Missouri River at that point. Gen. FISK has gone to Lexington to take command there.

The Republican Convention in the Fourth District to-day nominated SAMUEL HOOPER for reelection to Congress, and J.M.S. WILLIAMS, of Cambridge, for presidential elector.

An arrival from Newbern brings the following Capt. J.W. DENNEY, the popular Provost-Marshal of Newbern, arrived here yesterday in the Dudley Duck, in charge of his regiment, the Twenty-fifth Massachusetts, whose term of service has expired. The regiment lay at quarantine five days, there having been two cases of yellow fever on board since her departure from Morehead City. Four new cases developed on her passage, who are now on the hospital ship.

DEMOCRATIC COUNTY CONVENTION. The delegates to the Democratic Convention for Hudson County met at Hudson City, yesterday afternoon, for the purpose of nominating candidates for County. Clerk, Sheriff, Surrogate, and three Coroners. Mr. CHARLES E. NEWHAM was chosen Chairman and FREDERICK BOHNSTEDT Secretary. The following-named gentlemen were nominated: For Sheriff Bernard McAnally. For Country Clerk George W. Cassedy. For Surrogate James O'Neil. For Coroners Dennis Farrell, Martin Hanley and George S. Avery.

In the execution of a task so formidable and complex as that which the Lieutenant-General has undertaken, much time is necessarily consumed.

From returns received up to this hour, the editors of FORNEY'S Press claim a Union majority of 3,000 to 5,000, although they say it is possible later returns may reduce it; but, from the appearance of the soldiers' vote, a gain of three Republicans in the Congressional delegation is considered probable.

We wish very much that the Copperhead leaders would intersperse their abuse of "Old Abe," and their elaborate defences of slavery, with a little more elucidation of the famous proposition of the Chicago Convention that after four years trial, "the experiment of war has proved a failure." This most interesting topic, the most interesting of all those on which the platform touched, has been almost entirely neglected ever since the Convention adjourned.
The elections in Pennsylvania, Ohio and Indiana, though but preliminary to the struggle in November, have put several great points beyond all further doubt.

SALARIES OF SCHOOL TEACHERS. The Brooklyn Board of Education resolved at their last meeting to increase the salaries of female teachers of the public schools to the extent of $5 per month, in addition to present salaries, for the months of October, November and December, 1864, and for January. February, March, April, May, June and July, 1865. An attempt was made to increase the salaries of male teachers of the public schools, but failed.

Six months and a day from his appointment as the successor of Lieut.-Gen. GRANT in command of the Grand Division of the Mississippi, Gen. SHERMAN sat down to indite his review of that remarkable campaign, which began at Chattanooga on the 27th day of April, and ended at Atlanta on the night of the 1st of September.

The demise of Chief-Justice TANEY comes almost like some strange visitation. For one full generation he has occupied the highest judicial position in the United States, and it almost seems identified with his name. The disturbance of old associations is all the greater, because it happens at the very height of the civil conflict which is linked indissolubly with the most important act of his judicial life.

ROGER BROOK TANEY, Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States, died in Washington, at 11 o'clock Wednesday night, in the seventy-eighth year of his age. This distinguished American jurist was born in Calvert County, Maryland, March 17, 1777.

The excellent letter from Gen. DIX which we published on Monday, contains some admirable remarks on the effect upon our polical condition, evoked by the practice in which all public parties have indulged, for the last forty years, of considering nothing but " availability " in the choice of candidates for the Presidency. Gen. DIX ascribes, and with great reason, most of the toils which now beset us to this most unfortunate tendency.

Nashville enjoyed, on Tuesday evening last, the novel spectacle, for this region, of a torchlight procession. It was a pleasant sequel to the reoen illumination, and to the voices of cannon several times repeated within a month, halting the victories of SHERMAN, FARRAGUT and SHERIDAN. The object of the procession was partly political and wholly Union, and, therefore, closely connected with the other jubilant manifestations.

GRANT immediately upon the close of the State Fair, where, by a largely preponderating vote it was decided that it should be given to the Lieutenant-General instead of McCLELLAN. Judge HOLT has published in the Washington Chronicle a report, eight columns in length, in relation to the secret associations and conspiracy against the Government in the Western and Northwestern States. The actual number of persons in these secret lodges he supposes is 500,000, which is the number VALLANDIGHAM stated it to be.

The ocean iron-clad Dictator having been completed at the yard of Messrs. DELAMATER, at the foot of Thirteenth-street, North River, was towed by two tugs to the navy-yard yesterday morning, to be put in commission. She has already got the heavier stores on board, and what may be added in the way of supplies can be done immediately.
Two heavy shocks of an earthquake were felt in the lower part of the State last night, and another this morning, frightening the people out of their houses, but doing no damage.

The steamer Mollie Able, from New Orleans 9th, has arrived.

An expedition into West Florida, under command of Brigadier General ASBOTH, reached Mariana on the afternoon of the 27th of September, capturing that place after a stubborn resistance of several hours. The resuit is the capture of eighty-one prisoners of war, amongst them a Brigadier General and a Colonel, ninety-five stand of arms, large quantities of quartermaster's and commissary stores, over two hundred fine horses and mules, and four hundrod head of cattle.

Persistent and continuous picket firing has been kept up all yesterday and last night, accompanied by considerable cannonading, along the line of the Second Corps, in front of Petersburgh. The firing has been almost entirely in the vicinity of "Fort Hell," near Gen. HANOOCK'S headquarters. Nothing of great moment or importance has resulted from it, however. The batteries and pickets in front of the Fifth and Ninth Corps have been unusually silent.
On the third the money market manifested decided improvement, Gold continued to flour lergely into the Bank of England, inducing the belief that the financial pressure was over.
What comes from ALEXANDER H. STEPHENS always commands peculiar attention in the North, for he is believed to possess the clearest mind and frankest heart in the Confederacy.

About 2,000 rebels, with two pieces of artil lery, under J.H. THOMPSON, attacked Sedalia at 2 o'clock yesterday, and drove the militia out of the place. A few of the militia in the fort resisted the attack, but finally surrendered, and were paroled or shot.
The steamships Yazoo, which left New-Orleans on the 6th, and the Creole, which sailed on the 9th, arrived at this port yesterday.

The Union men of Vermont are pushing the Presidential campaign with commendable energy and vigor. While it is felt that this State is always safe, the importance attached to the emphasis with which it speaks at the polls was never before so fully realized as now. The result of the recent State election is felt in the Union ranks here, not less, certainly, than elsewhere.

JEREMIAH CLEMENS, late Senator from Alabama, has written a letter, under date of October, from this city, to a friend at Huntsville, Alabama, in which he invites the return of his State to the Union under separate State action. The steamer City of Alton, from Memphis, passed with fifty-seven bales of cotton for St. Louir.

The Government of Peru has dispatched a circular to its diplomatic agents in Europe and the United States, in relation to the Spanish question. This circular has not yet been made public, but it is known that the Government declares it will use, as noon as possible, all the means at its disposal to recover the Chincha Islands; but will not open or initiate any negotiations with Spain to this end.

We have a mail or rather dates from Bogota, for the mail missed to the middle of last month. The whole Republic was quiet, and the Executive authority busy in expediting the projects for opening new communications between the various districts of country where they are so much needed.

The steamship Yazoo, from New Orleans, Oct. 6, and the Creole, same port Oct. 9, arrived at this port yesterday. They bring news of several successful expeditions in the Department of the Gulf. Gen. ASBOTH had advanced to Marianna, Western Florida, and captured quite a number of prisoners, including one Brigadier-General and one Colonel. Gen. ASBOTH himself was slightly wounded.

Our correspondent at Quebec, who has had special opportunity for studying the political situation in the Provinces, takes a less sanguine view of the progress of the federative scheme than the more ardent local sympathizers. The Conference has been a week in session. It has resolved by a formal vote, as everyone believed it would, that an union of the Provinces is desirable. Beyond this nothing.

His oratorical labors have been grandly faithful and effective. The splendid canvass he has made is a fitting climax to an administration distinguished above that of all other Governors for its success as well as for its arduousness.

The following is the text of the Franco-Italian Convention: ART. 1, Italy undertakes not to attack the present territory of the Pope, and even to prevent by force any attack proceeding from the exterior.
The following is an extract from a private letter dated Barrancas, Fla., Oct. 5, 1864:

An official explanation of the case of the Roya1 Sovereign has been offered, from which it appears that the Admiralty consider this cupola ship to be fit only for harbor defence. She is not a sea-going ship at all, and the officials say they have tried her as much as they need to do; although naval men condemn the withdrawal of the ship from public service as an unwarrantable proceeding.

The Gold-Room fell ten per cent, yesterday; the extremes were from 216 7/8 on Monday afternoon to 206 per cent. There was a subsequent recovery to 209 per cent. The Stock Market was much lower on the Railways in the forenoon: but a better feeling prevailed at the Second Board. Money easy at 7 per cent. Exchange on London 108 @ 109 for Gold.
The Royal mail steamship Scotia, Capt. JUDKINS, which left Liverpool at one o'clock on the af- ternoon of the 8th, and Queenstown on the 9th inst., arrived here this morning.

SHERIDAN reports to GRANT that, in moving down the Valley to Woodstock, he has burned over two housand barns filled with wheat, hay and farming implements, and over seventy mills filled with flour and wheat. This was done by order of GRANT, himself, commander of all the Yankee armies. It is only the execution in part of the order to destroy everything in the Valley that will sustain life.

A party of twenty-five armed men rode into St. Albans this afternoon, and robbed the three banks there of $150,000. It is supposed they were southern- ers from the border of Canada. Five citizens were shot, one it is thought fatally. Having accomplished their object the band left immediately for Canada.

THE FORREST RAID. The cavalry portion of the pursuers of FORREST have just arrived, and, as I speak from experience, having withessed the whole affair, from beginning to end, candor compels me to say that it was the most inglorious pursuit I have ever had to chronicle.

The latest news from SHERMAN'S army is embodied in a dispatch from Chattanooga, dated Oct. 18, which says SHERMAN has not yet come up with HOOD. Small bodies, supposed to have been detached from HOOD'S army, are hovering around our front. HOOD, with the main body of his army, is supposed to be retreating southward. One of our army corps was at Lafayette yesterday.

After long discussion the Canadian Federation has been decided on. Its main principles arranged, only details await settlement. The great difficulty was the proportionate representation of the Colonies in the Upper House.

GENTLEMEN; Sincerely grateful for the compliment you have paid me by tendering me your nomination for the office of County Clerk, I feel obliged to decline the honor of being your candidate, for the reason that, after careful examination and faithful effort, I can see no prospect of uniting the entire Democratic opposition upon my name.

Our correspondent at Quebec sends a special telegram, announcing the agreement of the Federal Convention assembled there, on the essential points of an inter-colonial Union. The great question of a representation basis, it appears to us is "settled" in a way which will prove neither permanent nor satisfactory.

Dispatches from Gen. ROSECRANS say that Gen. PRICE'S main force is still east of the Blackwater River. This is regarded as favorable to the disposition of our troops, and increases the chances of Gen. ROSECRANS getting a fight out of the enemy.

The Union gathering in New-Haven on Wednesday last was the largest political assembly ever convened in Connecticut. The entire day was given up to it. Early in the morning delegations from all the neighboring towns began to arrive, and at 11 o'clock a grand procession was formed.

LAUNCH OF THE NABUC. The light-draught monitor Nabuc was launched yesterday about noon from the yard of W. PERINE, Esq., at Williamsburgh. Quite a number of distinguished persons were present, among them Admiral: F.H. GREGORY, Capt. BOGGS and Chief-Engineer HALL.

Information of the St. Alban's outrage was communicated to the Government yesterday. A number of defectives and a body of troops were immediately dispatched to the frontier, with orders to arrest the parties at all hazards.

The Union citizens of the Sixth Congressional District held a mass meeting at the Bleecker Building last night to ratify the nomination of the Hon. HENRY J. RAYMOND for Representative in Congress from that district. The hall was densely crowded at an early hour, and the utmost enthusiasm prevalied.

Last evening the Academy of Music at Brooklyn was filled to its utmost, with a very enthusiastic audience, who had assembled at the call of the Central McClellan Association, to indorse the nomination of Gen. McCLELLAN for President of the United States.

Much excitement prevails throughout this county respecting a raid that is being made into Western Kentucky. It was our intention to reoccupy Mayfield this morning, but during last night information was received of the probable advance of a large force into this district.

Since the attack upon our rear while falling back from Harrisonsburgh to Strasburgh, there has been no regular fighting. The enemy's cavalry followed our rear closely, and fell into a trap, losing several hundred prisoners and artillery the exact number of each you will have received official notice probably long before this reaches you. Bushwhackers and some small regular organizations belonging to the rebel army are constantly hovering about our flanks and rear.

There are significant movements in the literary world of Salt Lake. The establishment of the Daily Telegraph seems to have stirred the other institutions to renewed life and energy, and the enlargement of that paper has helped still more to further the movement. The Vedette talks of enlarging, and the Deseret News proposes to issue two weekly papers one devoted to theology, the other to news and literature.

Dispatches from the front inform us that Gen. BUTLER has carried his point, and that the rebel authorities have dispensed with the services of the colored United States soldiers who were put at hard labor in their trenches. General BUTLER, it will be remembered, put an equal number of rebel prisoners at work in the Dutch Gap Canal.

We have news from Monte-Cristi up to the 5th of this month, but there is little additional intelligence expect that the five Commissioners sent by SALCEDO, the President of the insurgent Government, had arrived at Monte-Cristi on the 1st instant. A few other prisoners had been returned to the Spaniards. The yellow fever was still prevalent, and some officers had recently died of it, and others of dysentery.

The European journals have arrived at the most opposite conclusions touching the objects and probable effects of this new and remarkable treaty, and yet its terms do not afford much scope for doubt. I closed my letter to the TIMES last evening while the excitement here in regard to the rebel raid into Northern Vermont was but little past its highest point. A company composed of the citizens of Montpelier, and members of the Legislature, had marched to the railroad depot, and were about to take the cars, but the order for their departure had been countermanded on the reception of additional intelligence.

The celebrated Austrian statesman, METTERNICH father of the present Ambassador of FRANOIS JOSEPH at Paris, was, during one of his visits to his chateau of Johannisberg, called upon by several eminent French journalists to declare which was the most potent quarter for swaying publie opinion in Europe. "Frankfort," was the reply of the crafty diplomatist. "Frankfort," he added, "is the barometer of the public opinion of the world."

We have now official returns from every county in the State. The three counties not official in our list yesterday, have since been received. Forest gives 13 Union majority; Jefferson 202 Copperhead, and York, 2,808. Adams is 411 Copperhead instead of 365, Fulton 288 instead of 290, Clarion, 968 instead of 986, Cambria, 1,043 instead of 1,070, and Westmoreland 1,474 instead of 1,478. There is nothing new or startling in our local politics. Everything continues to look well, and to promise glorious results in future. I am inclined to raise my figures as regards the Union majority; but on the whole conclude to let the estimate remain at 25,000. Some of our friends are so sanguine as to expect 50,000. We may get it. It would reach 75,000, could our soldiers in the field vote.

General business was devoid of animation on Saturday. Flour, Grain, Whisky, and the principal kinds of provisions were quoted firmer, but were lightly dealt in. Cotton and Wool were in request and steady. The movements in most other articles were unimportant. Freights were very quiet, with 398 vessels of all classes in port.

Nankin, its capital, and the ancient capital of China, has been taken by the Imperialists, the rebel King has committed suicide, the bravest of the rebel chiefs have been slain or made prisoners, the remains of the rebel forces are no longer an army, but a fugitive, panic-stricken mob, without leaders capable of reorganizing them, and without spirit to renew the conflict.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I noticed a statement in the recently published letter of Mr. STEPHENS, which needs contradiction; and yet I meet with no contradiction of it in the various comments upon that letter which have fallen under my eye, although the statement touches a point of vital character in the history of our country.
The steamship Suwo Nada, from New-York, and Alliance from Brezos Santiago, arrived yesterday.

The Copperhead managers have labored more or less from the beginning to keep the real issue of peace or war with the rebels in the background, and to engross the public mind with bugbears of their own creation, or with personal defamation of President LINCOLN, or with questions of no vital account one way or the other.

Gen. BLUNT has been stubbornly resisting the advance of Gen. PRICE all day. BLUNT is falling back slowly, contesting every rod of ground as he retires. The force at PRICE is estimated at 28,000 men. Gen. CURTIS is concentrating his forces on the Little Blue River. Gov. CARNEY has telegraphed that the danger is very great, and to send every available man to the front. Troops are going forward rapidly.

For many years the Governments of the German States have looked with apprehension on the steadily increasing exodus of their laboring classes to America. They have long foreseen that a movement which, at first was felt as a relief to an over-populated country, would eventually become an exhausting drain upon their military resources. Yet they were powerless to check the movement.

The hall was crowded to its utmost capacity, and the Governor was received with the utmost enthusiasm. His speech, which was stenogrphicaly reported in our issue of yesterday morning, was worthy of his reputation clear, strong, and argumentative.

The Gold-Room was further advanced by the speculators for the rise yesterday to 218 cent., but after a dull demand through the day the price went down after 3 o'clock to 215 cent. Stocks dull on the Railway list at the close of the day. Governments steady, Money easy at 7 cent.
The steamer Mavero Cordatos arrived here last night, seven days from Bermuda, with the passengers of the captured steamer Roanoke.

If you want news of great particularity as to the relative positions of SHERMAN and HOOD, I have scruples against advising you to inquire within. As the chances of a grand battle with HOOD'S army, the same being nicely sandwiched between two of our armies, each larger than the lame Texan's whole host, recedes day by clap, we begin to lose Interest ...

Last evening a mass meeting of the different rades was held at Cooper Institute to indorse the principles of the Citizens' Association: At 8 o' clock the meeting was called to order, and Mr. THOMAS WHITEHEAD elected chairman. A list of VicePresidents and Secretaries was then read and approved, after which the President addressed the meeting as follows:

ACADEMY OF MUSIC The repetition of "Il Poliuto" last night fulfilled alt the expectations that had been formed of its excellence by the previous performance. The work was received with positive enthusiasm, due not merely to the popular merits of the music, but to the singular vigor with which it was interpreted. Mile. ZUCCHI's superb style is heard to the best advantage in the role of Pauline, ...
A grand mass meeting of the loyal people of the northeastern counties of New-Jersey will be held at Paterson on Thursday, the 27th inst.

Immediately after the fight at Allatoona, your correspondent left with the Twenty-third Corps for home, where SHERMAN'S army was concentrating and a fight expected. Upon reaching Kingston I ascertained that communication was open from Resaca, twenty-three miles above, and at once started for the place by rail, intending to send letters and rejoin SHERMAN'S army at Rome.

The Democral's Warrensburgh special says Gov. HALL has arrived here from Independence with a small escort, under Capt. FOSTEE. He thinks our cavalry are damaging PRICE"S rear considerably. PRICE is moving through Kansas, but is sprinkling the road with the blood of his best men.
The funeral obsequies of the late Col. THOBURN, commanding a division in the army of West Virginia, Capt. BEER, A.A.G. of Gen. CROOK'S Staff.
1864. GENERAL ORDERS No. 12. By Special Orders No. 248, Headquarters Army Northern Viginia, Lieut.-Gen. LONGSTREET resumes command of his army corps.

Yesterday morning it was rumored that the cannonding which occurred the previous evening along the whole length of GRANT'S lines, was nothing more than a "shotted salute" in honor of another victory of SHERIDAN over EARLY. The rumor grew as the day advanced, and by noon assumed startling proportions. It was stated that a well-known citizen, who happened to be in Fort Gilmor when the cannonading commenced, had reached the city with the following statement:
I have this day forwarded to the Governor of the state my resignation as a member of the Thirtyeight Congress, to which your vote elected me.

The St. Albans' Bank and the National Bank continue their business as usual. The former, according to last accounts, has recovered all its lost funds except $23,000, which is more than balanced by a reserved surplus on hand of $30,600. The Franklin County Bank redeems only at its counter bills in the hands of holders before the raid.

The rush for maturalization papers this season is unusually large, even fer a Presidential campaign. The Judges of the Superior Court and Court of Common Pleas have their hands full with the work of transforming aliens into full-grown citizens, at the rate of nearly five hundred per day. This unprecedented rush is partially owing to the fact that large num- ...
Late advices from Little Rock, Ark., state that Gen. MAGRUDER has left Camden and is rapidly marching toward the Red River.

The trial of the Vermont raiders at St. Johns was to have begun yesterday, but their counsel were absent, and the proceedings were postponed until to-day. The magistrates have taken the deposition of Mr. BISHOP, the teller of the St. Albans Bank.

By the steamer Mavrocordatos, we learn that the blockade-runner Little Hattie had arrived at Bermuda with six hundred bales of cotton; and that the Hope, with one thousand five hundred bales, and the Falcon, with seven hundred bales, had arrived at Nassau, all from Wilmington.

We have received full files of Charleston papers as late as Oct. 14, and Richmond papers to Oct. 22. They furnish us some interesting extracts, which throw additional light upon the state of affairs in the South.

Successive files of papers from different parts of the South bring us more and more of the remarkable speeches which the President of the Southern Confederacy delivered during his late tour into Georgia, and which have been first given to the country in the columns of the Times. Thus, on the 7th current, we were the first to give JEFF. DAVIS' astounding and desperate speech at Macon; which ...
The following address of BEAUREGARD, on assuming command of the Army of the West, has been received at the War Department:

An accidental collision of a passenger and a freight train near Shephardsville this morning, disturbed the Louisville and Nashville railroad so that the up train was two hours and a half behind time this afternoon.

BROOKLYN ACADEMY OF MUSIC. Our friends in Brooklyn have an unusual musical treat in store for to-night. Mr. MARETEEK'S company will perform in the Montague-street house the tragic opera of "Il Poliuto." This fine work has created a genuine sensation in New-York. It is admirably rendered by Mme. ZUCCHI, Signor MASSIMILIANI and Signor BELLINI. These artists indeed have never been heard to such advantage.

The Commercial's Nashville dispatch says: SHERMAN is at Gaylesville, near Cook River, pressing HOOD, who is retreating toward Gadsden. HOOD will be compelled either to move north to the Tennessee River, or south to Jacksonville. His army is reported to be destitute of shoes and food. The railroad from Chattanooga to Atlanta will be completed by Thursday.

The Stock Market was firm and on the advance yesterday, and money easy. The Gold Room speculation, after falling to 212 , recovered to 216 cent. Mr. ROBERT H. BERDELL, merchant of this city, has been made President of the Erie Railway Company, in place of the late NATHANIEL MARSH, the President ad interim, Mr. SAMUEL MARSH, declining further service.

An enthusiastic and spirited meeting was held on Monday evening last, at corner of Broadway and Forty-seventh-street, to ratify the nomination of WILLIAM A. DALLING, Esq., for Congress. The large hall was crowded to overflowing with an intelligent and attentive audience, among whom were many ladies. The meeting was called to order by Col. GEORGE D. VAN BRUNT, who nominated HENRY J. HADDEN, Esq. for President of the meeting. Mr. W.
Letters have been received here from prominent rebels in Richmond, stating that the archeves and other Government property were being secretly removed to Lynchburgh.
The latest intelligence from the Union armies indicates a most cheering and hopeful condition of affairs in every portion of the past theatre of war. We have no great movement to record;

The battle of Cedar Run, on Wednesday, Oct. 19, 1864, will be recorded in history as one of the most remarkable that has thus far taken place in this rebellion. My dispatch during the action, and letter forwarded just after nightfall, necessarily not only contained many inaccuracies as to facts, but were imperfect in other respects.
The following is a list of the places where the Boards of Registry in the different Wards meet. They sit next Tuesday and Wednesday. Every loyal citizen should see that his name is properly entered:
Six more of the Arctic whaling fleet have arrived.

S.P. Gilbert, Esq.: SIR As officers of the Fourth Union Congressional Convention it becomes our pleasing duty, under resolution of that body to inform you, that you were unanimously chosen as their nominee to represent this district in the National Councils.
Gen. CUSTER, the well-known cavalry leader, has written a letter upon the Peace party, which has the ring of the true metal. We make the following extract:

The party of the Copperheads, so far as it has been able, has precluded the soldiers who are devoting their lives to their country, from the elective franchise. In every State where it had the control of the Legislature, Indiana, Illinois, New-Jersey and Delaware, it has thwarted every attempt to secure to them the exercise of the first right of American freemen. This was sufficiently base.

The steamship Canada, Capt. HECKLEY, from Liverpool on the 15th, via Queenstown on the 16th inst., arrived here at 11:15 o'clock this morning. She has forty-two passengers for Halifax and seventy for Boston. Her dates are two days later than those already received.

The Democrat's dispatch from Leavenworth says: PRICE has been driven below Fort Scott, close ly pursued by our cavalry. We have captured a large number of prisoners, including Gens. MARMADUEE and CABELL, and several pieces of artillery.
The Toronto, Canada, papers publish some additional items of news respecting the progress of the trial of the border thieves at St. John. The Toronto Globe of Wednesday has the following dispatch:

There was a large business, yesterday, in Government Securities and Railway Shares, the general market being firm. Very heavy transactions occurred in Reading Shares. The market for Money is easy; the Gold Room 214 @ 216 and free from excitement.

The Lincoln and Johnson Campaign Club held another immense mass meeting at the Cooper Institute last night, Hon. CHARLES S. SPENCER, President of the club, presiding. The audience crowded every available space in the building, and it is no exaggeration to say that thousands went away unable to get in. Many ladies and veteran soldiers were present. Mr. SPENCER called the meeting to order, and said:

The steamship Canada arrived yesterday at Halifax, bringing two days' later news from Europe. The report that Capt. SEMMES had left England in the blockade-runner Laurel, is denied by the owner of that vessel, who ridicules the idea that the little steamer Ranger, of less than one hundred tons burden, is to be converted into a privateer. A report is current that JULES GERARD, the African explorer, has been drowned.

SIR: As a public man, observant of the interests which pervade all sections of our State, you have doubtless become aware of a strongly-developed senti-ment in this city in favor of municipal reform, although a conviction of the absolute necessity for such reform may not have been forced upon your attention.

The military situation presents to-day, over the whole field, the most satisfactory and encouraging aspect. In the West, the offensive movement designed to dislodge SHERMAN from Atlanta has ended by depriving the rebels of all foothold in Georgia. The closeness with which SHERMAN followed up the aggressive movement of the rebel force, completely trustrated their designs against his communications all the damage from which has now been repaired. But it did more than this.

DEATHS IN HOSPITAL. The following deaths of New-York soldiers are reported to-day: Francis Rawdeickl, Co. B, 7th infantry; George F. Tanner, Co. K, 1st Artillery; Orrin Mayo, Co. D, 6th Artillery; James Vanderwerken, Co. E, 46th Infantry; Hester Rusbeck, A, 10th Artillery.
The Special Committee on Retrenchment and Reform of the Board of Aldermen met this day, pursuant to the following published notice, and for the purpose therein stated:

The agreement between Gens. GRANT and LEE, reported exclusively in yesterday's issue of the TIMES, must be followed up by immediate and practical effort among us here at home. Our soldiers held as prisoners at Andersonville, and elsewhere throughout the South, may now be supplied with clothing, blankets, and such supplies of food as can properly be held to be necessaries for comfort and health.

There was no marked change from Thursday's market in the Gold Room yesterday. The Stock Market was higher on nearly all the railroads, and firm for Governments, with considerable activity in the former. Money easy, at 7 per cent.
One man says, "It's all right. McCLELLAN hasn't a chance. He won't make a show at all;" and so takes it easy. That is just the way to elect McClellan.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--DONIZETTI'S opera of "II Polluto" was repeated here last evening with the same success as heretofore. It has taken its place on the programme as one of the most popular operas in the repertoire.

The discovery of the conspiracy to falsify the suffrage of the soldiers puts the last brand of infamy on the brow of HORATIO SEYMOUR. His connivance with the mob that undertook to bully our Legislature from the election of a loyal United States Senator, dishonored him. He did so connive, for when the Assembly solicited him to protect it, he refused. His fomenting and countenancing the insurrection which for days went through ...

"I believe Mr. LINCOLN has done the best he could," says Maj.-Gen. SHERMAN, in his letter just published. Such is the conviction of an officer who, by his breadth of mind, his long residence in the South previous to the rebellion, and his military experience farther within the cordon of the rebellion than that of any other general officer, peculiarly qualify him to form a correct judgment.

It does not seem to have accomplished the business for which he called it together. Among other business which was not in accordance with the Governor's wishes, was the introduction of the following resolutions by a Mr. PARSONS: ...
The military commission to investigate the alleged frauds in taking the vote of the soldiers from New-York was resumed to-day.
Our mails from South America are not due till the 20th, and we have nothing of interest from the Capital of this Republic.

The steamship North Star, Capt. GRAY, Aspinwall, Oct. 17, with mails, passengers and treasure to D.B. ALLEN. She experienced very heavy weather north of the West India Islands; 20th instant passed the steamship Costa Rica hence for Aspinwall.
The steamship City of Manchester, from Liverpool on the 19th, via Queenstown 20th, passed this point last night.
NARVAEZ and the Moderadoes are again in power in Spain, and, it must be confessed, they have no ordinary difficulties to contend with.

The inquiries of the Shareholders' Investigation Committee have already led to some astounding disclosures respecting the manner in which the business of the Leeds Banking Company, which recently failed, has been conducted. It has been discovered, for instance, that MARSDEN, the Leeds Ironfounder, who has fled to New-York, had within the last few years passed forged bills to the amount of about 80,000 through the bank.
Our special correspondent at the headquarters of the Fifth Corps, transmits the following to this Bureau:

There is one quality in which the traitors are infinitely superior to their allies, the Copperheads. It is openness. While it is the very nature of the Copperhead to have a forked tongue and to creep stealthily, the traitor is straight in speech, and erect so that you see him just as he is. Essentially they differ not at all; but in manner altogether.

An army creates a little world of its own, one totally diferent from that which the members left behind them when they first came out to do and dare for the right, and in defense of the flag and institutions of our common country. Here one almost imagines himself in the midst of a strange and foreign country. The dress, customs, appearance, and general tone of the inhabitants are so different.

The particulars of the movement made on Thursday by Gen GRANT, show it to have been a reconnoissance in force to develop the real rebel line on the southwest front of Petersburgh. Our forces advanced some eight or ten miles, driving the enemy's skirmishers before them, and taking up a position on the Boynton plank road, over which the rebels have wagoned their supplies from Stony Creek, on the Weldon Railroad.

That the fate of Slavery is irrevocably sealed, nobody doubts. The idea of reestablishing slave labor is almost chimerical. Whatever system of labor is in future organized in the Southern States, must necessarily have a free labor basis. But Gen. BANKS' ideas of plantation labor have, confessedly, proved to be something of a failure.

Having heard that Dr. BRECKINRIDGE was to speak at Cincinnati, I took the cars and was carried there with the velocity of a locomotive. When you can get a new idea or hear a really great man, it is worth while to take a journey. Factitious great men?men made by blowing trumpets or puffing paragraphs?we have all round us.
General MEREDITH, at Paducah, Kentucky, received depatches from General SHERMAN on Wednesday that the rebel General FORREST intended to make an attack on that place yesterday.
A copy of the following telegram was received yesterday at the War Department from the Foreign Office:

The Dano-German question approaches a solution. The financial difficulty, at all events, has been set at rest, Denmark having consented to fix at the round sum of 9,000,000 rigsdalers the share which the Duchies are to have in the public property of the Kingdom. It is evident, however, that the Copenhagen Government yielded its assent to this proposition with the greatest reluctance.

Philadelphia is noted for its beautiful buildings. The Girard College has thus far held its rank as the finest specimen of architecture in this country, but the new cathedral which is rapidly approaching completion will hereafter present greater attractions to strangers visiting this city. This splendid edifice is located on Eighteenth street, facing Logan-square, which is already well known to those of your read-...

The rise in Gold on Saturday stimulated the demand for the principal kinds of domestic produce; prices of breadstuffs were decidedly firmer. General merchandise was held with more confidence, but was rather lightly dealt in Freights were dull, with 406 vessels, of all classes, in port.
Steamships City of Washington, (Br.,") Brooks, Liverpool, J. G. Dale : Morning Star, Nelson. New-Orleans, J. C. Raynor; Cotopaxi, Codman, Fortress Monroe, C. R. Poillon.

The Stock Exchange was decidedly buoyant on Saturday, the largest advance being made on the Western Railways. Gold was also higher, closing 220 per cent. The Government Securities firm and in demand. Money easy.
A special dispatch to the Gazette, from Knoxville, says:

The present week terminates Mr. MARETZEK'S first subscription season of eighteen nights, bringing it close up to the time of election. Fifteen performances have already been given, and consequently there will be but three representations this week instead of four. There may be a Matinee on Saturday. To-night "II Travatore" is to be repeated for the last time. On Wednesday "Don Giovanni" will be given with an unusually good cast, especially in the female department.
The following dispatch was published in the TIMES of yesterday:

The Inman steamship City of Manchester, from Liverpool on the l9th, via Queenstown on the 20th inst., passed this point at 12 o'clock last night, and was intercepted by the news yacht of the Associated Press, and a summary of the news obtained, which is four days later.

FRIENDS: The white refugees from the South have accumulated in our vicinity to such an extent that our local charity is no longer adequate to their relief. They are still arriving in constantly increasing numbers, mostly women and children, and all of them equally destitute, homeless, and almost hopeless.

Plymouth Church was last evening crowded to its utmost capacity to bear the fourth sermon of Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER, on the condition of the country and the coming election. The doors were opened at six o'clock, and before seven the building was completely filled. Before the services were commenced every aisle and passage-way was filled, and thousands were turned away unable to see, much less hear the speaker.

The succinct telegraphic dispatch from our correspondent, which we published yesterday, and the fuller details which are given to-day, present a view of the operations in GRANT'S army on Thursday which may be readily grasped.

PRICE left three hundred killed and tweve hundred wounded on the field, in the late battle. His army was composed of three divisions, of nine brigades. There were thirty-six regiments, averaging four hundred men to each, besides a large irregular force. He was in Jasper County on Friday, hard pressed by our forces. He had but two pieces of artillery, and one of them was disabled. The country is full of his stragglers.

The movement made on Thursday, by Gen. GRANT, has resulted in the extension of our line has far as Thatcher's Run, on the Duncan road, an advance of about three miles beyond our former position on the left, and in the discovery of the exact position of the enemy's lines, and the works erected for their defence, as well as a more complete knowledge of the country between us and the Southside Railroad.

A very large and enthusiastic meeting was held in the Sixteenth Ward on Friday evening, to ratify the nomination of HENRY J. RAYMOND for Congress. A speech was made by F.S. LAMBERT, ESQ., and he was followed by Mr. RAYMOND, who addressed the meeting in an extended and animated review of the questions at issue.

The letters of our special correspondents with the army of the Potomac and the army of the James, herewith transmitted, will give your readers a clear conception of the character and results of Gen. GRANT'S last operation. There is no disaster to record; no repulse to chronicle. Our losses are such as are incident to any encounter with a vigllant and vigorous antagonist.

The Memphis Bulletin, of the 27th says it is reported that the rebel leaders of West Tennessee are exceedingly active. They have established railroad and telegraph communication between Corinth and Jackson, and are conscripting every person able to bear arms, including old men and sending agents to every part of West Tennessee, outside our lines, for sheep, stock of all kinds, goods, money and everything that can be of service to them.

AN EXPEDITION DOWN THE RIVER. The United States steamer Don, flagship of the Potomac Flotilla, has just returned from an expedition down the river. A short time since, at a point on the eastern shore of the Chesapeake Bay, a short distance below the mouth of the Potomac, near Wycomoco Inlet, a guerrilla parts fired into Government transports, capturing and burning one of them.

The Union men of Brooklyn made an imposing display last night, not only as regards numbers and enthusiasm, but in all the details which add to the seenic effect of a demonstration of this kind, and which, taken all in all, was the finest exhibition and largest procession ever seen in this city.

The Journal says that a dispatch has been received at headquarters at Nashville, from Clarksville, which states that Lieut.-Col. BROTT, at Fort Donelson, reports a part of Gen. FORREST'S command, with three pieces of artillery, sunk a steamer and a barge loaded with army clothing, at Fort Herman, on the Tennessee River, on Saturday morning.
The Italia Militaire says: We believe we are able to state that a decree of amnesty on behalf of the prisoners taken at Aspromonte, has been signed by the King.

Union men from the South, and deserters, uniformly declare that the late rebel movements in Virginia, Georgia. Tennessee and Missouri, is a bold stroke of Southern leaders to defeat the Union party at the Presidential election. No doubt exists whatever as to the reliability of these statements.
The Stock Market was buoyant yesterday on the Railway speculation, and firm and higher on Government securities. Money easy at 7 per cent. The Gold Room advanced to 225@227 @226 per cent.

A meeting had been held at Bradford under the auspices of the Western Freedmen's Aid Commission. W.E. FORSTER, M.P., presided. LEVI COFFIN, delegate from the commission, made a speech. Resolutions were adopted in favor of the formation of an auxiliary society at Bradford.

Quite a lively fight occurred between a large force of MOSEBY's men and a portion of the Eighth Illinois Cavalry, last Sunday, in the neighborhood of Salem, Va. MOSEBY expected to surprise our troops, and sent three detachments of his men to make a simultaneous attack upon our forces.

The New-York State Commission have had today another interview with Secretary STANTON, on the subject of the late arrests for frauds perpetrated upon the soldiers' votes, but have not made much progress in the object of their mission.

This army has fully recovered from the shock of battle at Cedar Creek, on the 19th instant, and is again ready and anxious to thrash the rebel army of the Valley of Virginia, under EARLY, "or any other man," whenever attacked.

Vast as are the dimensions of the hall at Cooper Institute, it failed completely to accommodate the crowd of Union-loving, loyal Democrats that assembled last evening, and large numbers were unable to gain admittance.

The speculative excitement in the Gold-Room, and on the Stock Exchange, yesterday, was very great. The average rise on Gold was 10 cent., and the buoyancy and additional rise on the Railways quite general, resulting in a heavy day's business.
The schooner Hound, from Bermuda, has arrived with the officers and crew of the steamship Roanoke.

The New-York Union State Superintendent, Mr. C.H. Admiral PORTER reports that on the morning of the 28th Lieut. CUSHING, in command of Picketboat No. 1, blew up the celebrated rebel ram Albemarle, which was undergoing repairs in Albemarle Sound. Mr. MARETZEK'S season terminated on Saturday, when "Lucrezia Borgia" was sung at the matinee. There was a large and fashionable attendance, and the performance gave general satisfaction. The Academy will remain closed during the present week. On Monday, the 14th, the second season of eighteen nights commences. "Don Sebastian" will be one of the earliest novelties.

Last night the train which left Baltimore at 10:30 o'clock met with an accident about one mile this side of Perrymansville, which resulted in the death of two persons and the wounding of many more. Very fortunately the train was proceeding at a slow rate at the time of the accident, or the list of deaths and maimed would have been much larger.

Deacon JOHN PHILLIPS, of Sturbridge, Mass., who is 104 years, 4 months and 9 days old, appeared at the town hall and deposited his ballot for Presidential electors and State officers. The message of JEFF. DAVIS to the rebel Congress, which assembled on the 7th inst., has come to hand. He reviews the campaigns of the Federal Generals, and deduces the notable consolation, from his own statement of the facts, that the Federal successes have not been commensurate with the power put forth and the sacrifices incurred. In regard to rebel successes he is extremely reticent.

Having traveled from this city to Niagara Falls along with the delegates from the maritime Provinces, who have met in Canada to arrange the details of a plan of federation for British America, I am in a position to say that the feeling of this Province is entirely in favor of the scheme. The course of the delegates was one continued ovation.

The body of the opposition accept the decision in favor of President LINCOLN with a cheerful acquiescence. Some of their newspapers are full of spite; but, apparently, this has little effect. The great mass of those who voted for Gen. McCLELLAN both recognize and respect the will of the majority, and yield with thorough good sense and good nature.

The Gold speculation reached 10 cent, yesterday, against the advance attempted to be established on the result Of the Presidential election. Improvements in firearms are now attracting a great deal of attention, both in this country and Europe, in consequence of the great impetus given to the matter by the civil war between the Northern and Southern States. Up to the present time the armies of the United States have held their own in the matter of heavy ordnance; but so far as rifles and other small arms are concerned, the South has had the advantage.

One of the editors of the Philadelphia Bulletin, just arrived from the front, reports that on Monday morning, at daylight, the rebels attacked our pickets south of Atlanta, killed one, wounded two of the Third Indiana, but subsequently they fell back.

We publish this morning, at length, Judge SHIPMAN'S opinion in the suit brought by HAMILTON E. TOWLE against the steamship Great Eastern, to recover salvage for repairing her rudder, the shaft of which had been broken in a storm at sea. As will be seen, the Judge decrees that he recover $15,000 salvage.
The British press, it appears, is considerably excited over the capture of the Florida in Bahia Bay.

The latest intelligence from the Army of the Potomac shows that no material change has yet taken place in the situation around Richmond. There was much rejoicing in the Union army at the result of the elections.
The different articles of the treaty of peace were signed at Vienna on the 27th ult., and the final signature of the treaty itself took place on Sunday, the 30th.

In the brief remarks which follow, we shall attempt to indicate the grand moral aspect of the time, as developed by the politico-military situation to point out its natural suggestions, and to inquire how far these are disregarded and contravened by present practices and the propositions which emanate from politicians which are now being discussed in the public prints, and which threaten to assume the form of law in the approaching session of Congress.
We published, yesterday, a very brief telegraph- ic abstract of the news by the Nova Scotian. We have now fuller details by telegraph, and also mails to the 2d by the Peruvian.

We have additional telegraphic news from Europe this morning by the Nova Scotian at Cape Race, the dates being to the 4th inst. We have also mails by the Peruvian to the 2d inst. The news is not without interest. The death of JOHN LEECH, the famous illustrator of the London Punch, is announced. He died on Saturday, the 29th October, at the age of 47.
The Gold Room was comparatively quiet on Saturday. Stocks left off steady, and on two or three of the Western roads quite buoyant. Money easy.

The Emperor NAPOLEON, after his interview with the Czar, quitted Nice on the morning of the 29th for Toulon, at which place he received the squadron and witnessed a sham attack on the town. On the following day he started for Paris via Marseilles and Lyons.

When MULLER had finished the few sentences he addressed to the court on Saturday afternoon, he was conducted by a couple of jailers, and followed by Mr. JONAS, the Governor of Newgate, through a subterranean passage leading to the condemned cell. For the first few moments after he was taken out of the dock his demeanor was that of one who did not fully realize his awful position he seemed in a State of demi-stupor.

The whole army has been in motion to-day, and to-night a new line has been established, a temporary arrangement I presume. Army headquarters are a little north of Newtown. There is not an armed force of the enemy within twenty-five miles of our front.

The understanding that Mr. BEECHER was to preach on the result of the election, as a conclusion to his series of "political sermons," drew another immense audience to Plymouth Church, on Sabbath evening. Mr. BEECHER took for his text the 8th and 9th verses of the 46th Psalm: "Come, behold the works of the Lord, what desolations he hath made in the earth,"

Parliament was to assemble on the the 3d of November, when the committee on the transfer of the capital would present its report. It was said that a bill for compensation to the City of Turin, would be presented on the same day.
The rebel organs in London, it will be seen, are in desperate haste to denounce the capture of the Florida in Brazilian waters. They describe it as an act of piracy.

The perils which environ rebeldom are not producing unity of sentiment among its leaders. The message of JEFFERSON DAVIS, which he delivered to his Congress in Richmond a week ago to-day, is not the only evidence which has lately come to hand of the state of internal commotion in which the Southern Confederacy finds itself at present.

Another of those insane attempts to violate the sanctity of our picket trenches occurred last night. Fort Steadman, near the Jerusalem plank-road, was the scene of this new exploit. Our boys, however, have had their sharp wits additionally whetted, and the reception of the rebels was quite warm and enthusiastic, although the "Johnnies" did not seem to fancy it in the light of a welcome.

Gen. SHERMAN'S army may be considered the best representative of American veterans to be found in any of the armies of the Republic. The men have had an experience in fighting and marching, in camping and trenching, in pouring rains and burning suns, in the fierce heats of summer and the icy blasts of winter, sufficient to make a more perfect soldier than was led by either NAPOLEON or CESAR.
Herr VON BISMARK had returned to Berlin from his mission to Paris.

The Secretary of the Treasury has prepared his reply to the offer of a loan to the United States Government made by a German banker, a short time since, through the State Department for a thousand million dollars. He has fully examined the details of the proposal, and has come to the conclusion that there is no authority of law which would authorize him to entertain the proposition.
The fifth Annual Exhibition of the Artists' Fund Society opens at the Derby Gallery, No. 625 Broadway, on Wednesday next.

Suddenly, there is a great blank among us, and the shadow of great darkness. One of our dearest and most delightful companions, one whom not only we, but also all whose eyes will rest upon these columns must think of as in some sort a cherished companion, is taken from us.

Information has been received here that Gen. CANBY, while ascending the White River on the gunboat Cricket, was shot by a guerrilla from the shore, on the 6th inst., and was seriously if not fatally wounded in the groin, the bullet passing through his body.

The interview between the two Emperors, NAPOLEON and ALEXANDER, takes place at Nice to-day, and in France a good deal of importance is attributed to this interview. But since there are no questions up for discussion which implicates Russia in any way, it is difficult to see from what source this imperial interview is to derive its importance.

The telegraph, last afternoon, brought the intelligence from Montreal that the case for the prosecution against the St. Alban's robbers has closed. "Lieutenant" YOUNG afterward handed in a statement, to the effect that he is "a commissioned officer in the Confederate service."

Last evening the Veteran Union Club of this city, composed entirely of men who have served in the Union army and have been honorably discharged, and who, during the past political campaign, fought as hard for the success of the Union ticket as they did for their country's flag when in the field. Serenaded Messrs. DARLING, DODGE and RAIMOND, the three candidates the club supported, and worked to elect to Congress.
Now that the excitement and confusion of the election campaign are over, it becomes all good citizens of New-York, of whatever party, to begin-to look to matters near home.

The British mail steamer from Valparaiso and intermediate ports, arrived at this port yesterday. She brings dates from Valparaiso and Santiago de Chile to the 16th, and from Lima and Caliao to the 28th of October. The news is unimportant.

We have to announce the death of the Marquis of Bristol, which took place yesterday morning shortly after five o'clock, at Ickworth Park, near Bury St. Edmunds. For the last four weeks the respected Marquis had been considered in a very critical condition. On his arrival home from a tour in Germany, he was in such indifferent health that Dr. GARDINER saw him when he arrived at the family residence in St. James'-square.

The Berlingske Tidende, of Copenhagen, of the 26th ult., referring to the conclusion of Deace, Observes that the conditions are far more rigorous than those which were stipulated after the battle of Novara, when Austria found herself in a position to dictate peace to Piedmont.

The first annual term of the Columbia College School of Mines commenced yesterday, and the organization of classes was perfected. The building used by the schooi is the easterly wing of the college, situated on the corner of Fourth-avenue and Forty-ninth-street. Several these schools are in successful operation in Europe, but this is believed to be the first and only institution of the kind in the United States.

We are again enjoying the balmy atmosphere of Spring. The sun has been shining brightly all day, which, with a warm southerly breeze, has evaporated the water on the surface of the earth so rapidly that the roads are in good condition again.

The return of the fleet is daily expected at Fortress Monroe.

Our files of Southern papers furnish us the following additional extracts: In republics, all sorts of devices are resorted to, to cajole and beguile the people. Amongst the most prominent is that of party names. The original Yankee the New-Englander is notorious for his propensity to deception. If there is a direct and indirect way of accomplishing an object, he is sure to take the indirect.

It appears that a party in Canada are in favor of having the new scheme of Confederation adopted by the Parliaments of the var ious Colonies, without submitting it to the people, and the proposal to take a popular vote upon the question has been denounced by a leading provincial organ as "a dreadful American heresy."

The Thirty-Eighth Congress is soon to reappear. "Superflous lags the veteran on the stage." It has made some figure in its time, but has had its day. Its part during the winter will not be much else than pantomime.

A NEW CHEMICAL DISCOVERY. Petroleum from its great permeating quality, when shipped in ordinary barrels, loses on an average from five to fifteen per cent. in its transit between here and Oil Creek. Beside its disagreeable odor and filth in handling, it is, from its great inflammability, an exceedingly dangerous article of transportation.

The fluctuations in Gold yesterday were between 217 @221 per cent., with less excitement than on Saturday. The Stock Exchange firm on Government Securities. The Railways dull in the forenoon, but closed in better demand. The Money market very easy.

In pursuance to the call of the Union Central Committee, the several Union Ward Associations met last night, and elected the following delegates to the Aldermanic, Councilmanic, School and Ward Conventions, to be held during the present and ensuing week.

DANIEL WESTERVELT, of this city, is building for the Pacific Steam Navigation Company, of Liverpool, England, a beautiful side-wheel steamer, to be called the Favorita, and from present appearances she will be probably the fastest steamer of her length in the world; she is intended to be so at least.

The steamship Moravian, from Liverpool Nov. 10, via Londonderry Nov. 11, with five days later news, arrived at Portland yesterday. It has pleased Almighty God to prolong our national life another year, defending us with his guardian care against unfriendly designs from abroad, and vouchsafing to us in His mercy many and signal victories over the enemy who is of our own household. It has also pleased our Heavenly Father to favor as well our citizens in their homes as our soldiers in their camps and our sailors on the seas, with unusual health.

Thanksgiving Day was universally observed in this city, Brooklyn and other suburbs. All places of business were closed throughout the day, the churches very fully attended, and the people generally devoted the day to praise, festivity, feasting, amusement and rest. Reports from other cities prove the day to have been more generally observed than for years before. In our columns will be found reports of many of the sermons delivered yesterday.

The demoralization produced in the Democratic party by the recent victories at the polls is so great, that many of its members propose throwing down their arms and coming over to the Republican camp; or, at all events, desisting hereafter from all criticism of any kind upon the Government or its poilcy. We confess, much as we would value unanimity, we do not desire to see it brought about in this way.

About 5 o'clock yesterday morning flames were discovered issuing from the centre of the large lumber-yard of Messrs. OGDEN Co., situated on Hubert-street, and extending through from Washington to West street. The yard was closely stored with mahogany and other valuable lumber and owing to its highly combustible state, the flames spread rapidly.

Memphis papers of yesterday give detailed accounts of a plot by rebel agents to burn the Memphis and Charleston Railroad Depot and Government stores, worth two millions.

The flag-of-truce fleet of steamers, or at least a large part of them, are still at anchor in the Savannah River, above Fort Pulaski, receiving our released men as fast as the rebel authorities choose to deliver them. The aggregate number transferred to Lieut.-Col. MULFORD during the past ten days will not exceed 5,500, but it is believed that the end of this week will witness the completion of the work.
