Both boards of the Common Council met yes terday. The Aldermen concurred in the resolution to permit the "Masonic Mission " to erect a temporary building on the square at the Five Points, for the sale of coal and flour at cost prices. The Councilmen transacted nothing but routine business. Both boards adjourned to Monday, the Aldermen at 1, and the Councilmen at 2 P.M.
The investigation of the plot to burn the city is proceeding with the greatest vigor and secrecy. Gen. DIX is closeted daily with the detectives and others who are engaged in this business.

By the arrival of the bark Mirago, Capt. MERRILL, we have advices from Rio Janeiro to Oct. 13th. The ship Alexander, Capt. J. BROWN, arrived the night previous from Cardiff, and while off the port Capt. BROWN was washed overboard by a sea and drowned.
The first of a series of three lectures on Egypt and Egyptian Antiquities, was delivered before this society, last evening, by Prof. JOHN WILLIAM DRAPER, LL. D.

The one-legged rebel HOOD has again put in practice the system of quick, furious, persistent and desperate assault by which he and Stonewall JACKSON have been distinguished on the rebel side; and he has met with the same bloody luck which befell him when he tried the same thing at Atlanta.
Heavy skirmishing for the past few days, and still going on between our troops and FORREST.

The handsome victory won by our forces under Gen. THOMAS, in Tennessee, on Wednesday, was received and announced by the TIMES yesterday morning, several hours ahead of our cotemporaries. The details supplied by our special dispatch from Nashville are full of thrilling interest, and prove it to have been one of the most hotly contested battles of the war.

About noon on Wednesday our main army reached Franklin, when Gen. SCHOFIELD prepared to give the enemy battle. There was very little skirmishing, as HOOD'S object was to attack us before we had time to throw up defensive works.

Parties who have arrived from the front, and who witnessed the battle of yesterday, describe the attack of the rebel forces as desperate. Four charges were made upon the Federal masked batteries in columns four lines deep. Each time the rebels were repulsed with fearful loss.

Col. T. P. ANDREWE, Paymaster-General, has been placed on the retired list, after more than forty years active service. Major BRICE has been made Brevet Brigadier-General, and is still acting as PaymasterGeneral.

The general debate on the France-Italian Convention in the Chamber of Deputies was brought to a close on the 16th and the discussion of the articles of the Convention was progressing, and would be continued daily in order that it might be brought to an early termination.

STERN LOYALTY IN THE PULPIT. The Thanksgiving sermon preached by Rev. SAMUEL J. CORNEILLE Rector of All Saints' Church, has been published. We extract the following eloquent passage: "And yet there is something worse than war: national dishonor, cowardice, and selfishness: the decay of manly enthusiasm; the pusillanimity that shrinks from duty, because it is surrounded by peril. These are worse than war.
A great deal of artillery firing has prevailed to-day in the vicinity of the Jerusalem road, but without any result worth mentioning.

We published in last Sunday's TIMES the letter of a Southern lady, intended to give vent to the anguish she was compelled to smother in her domestic circle at witnessing the outrages committed upon her people in the prosecution of the war. We endeavored to show in as generous terms as possible wherein we thought our fair correspondent failed to appreciate the situation.

We believe it true that SHERMAN'S army has reached Millen, and separated into two columns, one moving toward Savannah River, and another turning back toward Augusta. The latter column and movement is without doubt intended as a feint to protect his rear from attack.

Gov. VANCE commences his message by calling upon the present Legislature to unite with him in a cooperation for the public good, as sincere, and tempered with as much forbearance, as existed between the Governor and the last Legislature. The crops of the past season, he says, were fair, and in some places excellent.

By the arrival of the steamship Fulton, from Port Royal, Nov. 30, we learn that the steamship North Star, from Aspinwall, about which so much anxiety has been felt, arrived at Port Royal, Nov. 28, short of coal, having in tow her convey the United States steam gunboat Augusta, which vessel broke her piston-rod four hundred miles to the eastward of Port Royal.

I have a paper now before me which shows to what extent the abuse of existing laws is carried by persons who desire to escape military service. It is the report of an inspecting officer who had first visited one of our Southern cities. Seeing a large number of men on the street, he made it his business to inquire who they were, and why they were not in the army.

The conduct of MULLER in the condemned cell is described by all who have visited him as being marked by perfect resignation. Whenever questioned, however, he as positively as ever declares his innocence. His friend HAFFA paid him his last visit yesterday, and thus describes the two interviews he had with MULLER yesterday and on Tuesday last;

Some of the Opposition prints are pretending that the late attempt to fire our city was no Southern work at all, but an Administration trick. This is carrying impudence into absolute senselessness. The abuse heaped upon Secretary SEWARD and Major-Gen. DIX, previous to the election, for their public notifications that rebel agents wore scheming such attacks upon our cities, had some sort of an excuse in the party excitement of the day.

The expedition of the combined Powers to open the passage to the Inland Sea, has proved successful. On the 5th of September the fleet appeared off Simonosaki, and immediately commenced an attack on the Prince of NAGATO's forts, two of which were destroyed before evening. Next day, at dawn, the attack was renewed, and a storming party having been landed from the ships, several of the other forts were quickly carried.

The latest official information from the army of Gen. THOMAS is that he has so concentrated his forces at the fortifications of Nashville as to be prepared for any movement which Gen. HOOD may venture to make.

The Charter Election takes place to-morrow, but so little interest is manifested in it by the public, that it is hardly mentioned outside of political circles, and nobody seems to care who is nominated, unless it be the nominees themselves.
ASHES Are dull and unsettled in price. Stock, 521 bbls.
Steamship Edinburgh, (Br.,) Roskell, Liverpool 16th and Queenstown 17th ult., with mdss, and 527 passengers to John G. Dale. Had strong westerly gales the entire passage.

In the First Aldermanic District SAMUEL HOTALING, the (Draper) Union candidate has withdrawn. THOMAS STEWART is the nominee of the Citizens' Association; he is the present Justice of the District Court.

The case of Bennett G. Burleigh came up before the Recorder in the Court-house yesterday morning, at ten o'clock. The examination was continued all day, the court room being filled all the time with an interested crowd of listeners.
There was a further large business in Government Stocks on Saturday. Gold fell to 228@227 per cent. The Railway dealings were light. Money easy.

We spoke on Saturday of the proposed plans for the reform of the City Government, and suggested, instead of delivering it over body and soul, to a Commission appointed by the State Legislature, that the powers of Commissions already in existence be enlarged.

Both Houses of Congress assembled to-day, and transacted such preliminary business as was necessary. A committee was appointed to wait upon the President, who informed them that he would communicate his message to Congress to-morrow. Both the Senate and House were quite full.

An anti-Slavery correspondent protests against our article which maintained that the real and only issue in this war is that between national authority and rebellion. He is greatly exercised by the fancy that we are turning our back on the Baltimore platform, and going to take slavy to our embrace. Perhaps if he will take a little more pains to discriminate, he will not think us so inconsistent.

The President's Message, the Reports of the Secretary of the Treasury, the Postmaster-General, and a comprehensive abstract of the Report of the Secretary of the Navy, are given in our columns this morning. The documents are all of much importance, and will command unusual attention. The pressure upon our columns defers the publication of Secretary WELLS' report in full until another day.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. DONIZETTI'S opera of "Don Sebastian" was repeated last evening, with complete success. The work gains in public favor, and is evidently destined to become a leading feature of Mr. MARETZEK'S repertoire. To-night, "Ill Poliuto."

The President's Message is brief, yet very comprehensive and explicit. It presents a satisfactory view of our foreign relations and of all the great departments of our internal administration. The exhibit thus officially authenticated, may well inspire the people with new confidence, though they were already prepared for its general outlines.
A flag of truce appeared yesterday, in front of the Second Division of the Second Corps, bearing a dispatch addressed to Gens. GREGG, HUMPHREY and FOSTER.

The Gold Room was stimulated yesterday, on false constructions among the speculators, many of whom are anything but friendly to the Government, of the President's Message and the Treasury Report. Chief Justice CHASE unexpectedly arrived in town last evening, and was unaware both of his appointment and confirmation as Chief Justice until an hour after his arrival, when a friend had called to congratulate him. He will not take his seat upon the bench until Monday next. In the meantime, however, there being a quorum present, the court will continue its daily session.

Up to the present time five thousand of our prisoners paroled at Savannah have arrived at Annapolis, all of whom have been mustered and are now receiving their back pay. The Union party, it seems, is to be treated to its annual display of "dirty linen." Now that the election is over, and votes are, therefore, not to be immediately affected by it, parties who deem themselves aggrieved come before the public in hot pursuit of "satisfaction." As a general thing, these performances are old friends with new faces, --old quarrels under new pretexts.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--"Il Trovatore"--the most permanently popular opera, with the single exception of "Don Giovanni," that has ever been produced in New-York--was repeated here last evening to more than an average house, ZUCCHI, MORENSI and BELLINI were excellent. The same--with the reservation of a solitary moment, when the weather had its way--may be said of Signor MASSIMILIANI, who, in the latter portion of the opera, was in fact admirable. The performance generally gave complete satisfaction.

MIDDLE MILITARY DIVISION, Tuesday, Dec. 6, 1864. There is no military news with which to bur den a letter to-day: all along the front quiet has prevailed for several days, and, as nearly all the guerrillas have left for parts unknown, it is difficult to realize--what is supposed to be truth--that we are liable to be attacked at any time by a smaller or larger force.

Information haing been received at these headquarters that the rebel marauders, who were guilty of murder and robbery at St. Alban's, have been discharged from arrest, and that other enterprises are actually in preparation in Canada, the Commanding General deems it due to the people of the frontier borders to adopt the most prompt and efficient measures for the security of their lives and property.

About 5 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in the block bounded by BOWERY, Canal, Chrystie and Hester streets, and in the course of two hours five buildings were entirely destroyed and six others were very badly damaged, beside several others that took fire and were materially injured.

The Post takes exception to a remark made by somebody that Gen. WARREN'S expedition, last week, was a "complete success." It says:

The Stock Exchange was more animated on the Railway Stocks yesterday. The Governments were dull and partially lower in the forenoon, but the demand was renewed on the Street and at the Second Board. The Gold Room ranged 233 @ 235 per cent. Money easy.

George Opdyke vs. Thurlow Weed. The trial of this noted cause was resumed yesterday morning, and the court-room was again crowded with spectators. The plaintiff having closed his case on the first day, Judge Pierpont opened for the defence, saying that he felt, like Hamlet, that there was a special providence even in the fall of a sparrow.

The steamship Arago, Capt. GADSDEN, arrived here lastevening, having in tow the United States gunboat Augusta, broken down from Port Royal with mails, passengers and important dispatches from Gen. FOSTER, commanding the Department of the South.
Richmond papers of the 12th, received here at the office of the Philadelphia Inquirer, contain the following items:

Passengers by the mail-boat to-day report that while on the James River yesterday morning, six or eight miles from Dutch Gap, they heard heavy firing in the latter direction. All of Gen. WARREN'S command are now safely back to their quarters from their late expedition.

Throughout this war I have had a high respect for the military spirit, conduct and knowledge of the rebels; but, I confess, this is exceedingly diminished by the recent plans and operations of Messrs. DAVIS and BEAUREGARD.

Gen. BANKS was before the Committee on the Conduct of the War, to-day, upward of two hours, He gave a detailed statement of the Red River expedition, and his connection with it. The committee have summoned a large number of witnesses, some of whom are in Arkansas and New-Orleans, and it is thought that most of the session will be consumed in this investigation.

Capt. BRIDGEWATER, with 125 men, went into Newcastle, Ky., and drove out the guerrilla JESSEE, with a loss to the latter of thirteen killed and wounded. BRIDGEWATER chased the guerrillas through Port Royal, and was only eight minutes behind at that place. It is thought the rebels would be captured by BRIDGEWATER'S forces.
The steamship Eagle, from Havana on the 10th inst., arrived at this port yesterday. We are indebted to her purser for the prompt delivery of our news packages and correspondence.

Joint resolutions of thanks to Capt. WINSLOW and Lieut. CUSHING were reported and passed. A petition from several line officers in the army, asking for additional compensation, was presented and referred to the Military Committee.

The discharge of the St. Alban's raiders surprised the members of the Government, and the ground of the discharge is pronounced ridiculous. The magistrate is likely to be severely dealt with. New warrants have been issued by a Superior Court Judge for the rearrest of the raiders, and constables are in pursuit. The Gold Room closed at 4 o'clock yesterday, 234 @235 per cent. Government Stocks steady. The 10-40 years, 5 per cents, in demand at par and interest since 1st of September. The Railways dull and lower than on Wednesday.

To Major-Gen. Dix: The department has just received unofficial dispatches from Nashville, announcing that Gen. THOMAS, with the forces under his command, attacked HOOD's army in front of Nashville at nine o'clock this morning, and although the battle is not yet decided, the whole action to-day is described as splendidly successful.

The steamer United States arrived this morning from Port Royal, with a large number of returned prisoners, estimated at between seven and eight hundred. The exchange of prisoners, under Col. MULFORD, was progressing favorably.

A large naval fleet, accompanied with land forces in transports, left Hampton Roads this morning, steering in a southerly direction.

We give to-day another letter from before Charleston from our special correspondent, who accompanied the fleet that went down to bring North the ten thousand Union prisoners for whom a special exchange has been effected. It appears that we have now succeeded in bringing back nearly the whole of the ten thousand.

To Maj. Gen. Dix, New-York: Official dispatches from Gen. CANBY have been received to-day, showing the complete success of an expedition sent by him from Vicksburgh to cooperate with Gen. SHERMAN'S operations, and cut HOOD'S communications with Mobile.

To Maj.-Gen. Dix: Richmoud papers of to-day state that on Wednedsay Gen. Sherman carried Fort McAllister, commanding the entrance to the Ogeechee River, by storm, and that the capture of this position puts Sherman in communication with the Yankee fleet, and necessitates the reinforcement of Savannah.

The Morning Star, Capt. HORATIO NELSON from New-Orleans Saturday Dec. 10, arrived at this port Thursday afternoon. Sailed in company with steamship Fung Shuey for New-York. The red banner was the symbol of triumph over a dangerous enemy; and the despatch announced the time, place and circumstances of the crowning victory.

The steamships Northern Light and Varuna arrived here from Charleston harbor, at a late hour last evening, with 800 released Federal prisoners each, and after landing the mails and dispatches, proceeded immediately to Annapolis.

Hon. James A. Seddon, Secretary of War: The expedition to Bellfield, under Gen. WARREN, returned within the enemy's lines yesterday. The two divisions of the Ninth Corps which went to WARREN'S relief, proceeded no further than Belcher's mill. On meeting the returning column, they turned back.
Nothing has been heard from Gen. THOMAS to-day. Unofficial dispatches state that the Provost-Mar shal at Nashville reports 5,000 prisoners and 40 pieces of artillery as being already secured.

The fall in Gold on Saturday checked business in Produce and Merchandise, and in most instances gave buyers any existing advantage. The excitement in Pork abated, and prices fell off materially. The Freight Market was inactive, with 452 vessels of all classes in port.

I have to record one of the most important battles of the campaign. Though the artillery has not yet ceased to throw its leaden hail into the retreating enemy. I believe it to be a crushing defeat of HOOD.
The presentation of medals to such members of regiments in the Second Corps as had particularly distinguished themselves in battle during the late campaign, took place yesterday.

In our supplement, this morning, we print another long list of Union soldiers who have perished miserably in the Southern prisons. The record is a dismal one, but thousands today will refer to it eagerly, yet timidly, in the hope of assuring themselves beyond a peradventure, of the fate of those dear to them, and as to whom their minds have been harassed by conflicting hopes and fears.

THOMAS is pursuing the enemy to Duck River. We have nearly all HOOD'S artillery, and his army is really fearfully demoralized. All the rivers are high, and all the bridges in HOOD'S front destroyed. Our pontoons are up. We captured three thousand of the enemy's wounded at Franklin, Tenn. Since Thursday, we have captured and brought in just six thousand prisoners, making nine thousand, counting the wounded taken at Franklin.

The new call for troops has made the business at the County Volunteer Office exceedingly brisk. The determination of Mr. BLUNT to avoid a draft in this city is being fully sustained by the people. The demand for substitutes, yesterday, was greater than on any former day since the last call. The supply was equal to the demand, and quite a number paid the necessary $650.

The President has issued a proclamation, calling for 300,000 men for the military and naval service, to serve for one, two, or three years. The quotas for the different States will be immediately assigned by the War Department. If they are not made up by volunteering by the 15th of February, 1865, a draft will be ordered to take place.

CIRCULATION OF NATIONAL BANKS. Judge McCULLOUGH, Controller of National Currency, has decided that no bank can be supplied with circulation to an amount exceeding 90 per cent, of its capital stock actually paid in, unless such bank shows a surplus which it may invest in bonds for a larger issue of notes.

The Senate Military Committee, after conference with the War Department, decided to report adversely upon the House bill dismissing all general officers not on duty within the last three months. The reelection of President LINCOLN was not simply a declaration of sentiment. It was a pledge. The people affirmed not merely that the rebellion ought to be put down, but that it should be put down; and they bound themselves to supply President LINCOLN with the money and the men necessary to that end. His new call for three hundred thousand more men must be met with promptitude and cheerfulness.

The United States vs. Abraham Harris. This was an action at common law, to recover duties from the defendant in an importation of merchandise which merchandise had been surrendered to the defendant as being worth only a fraction of the duties claimed. The Government chose rather to consider the duties as an indebtedness that had accrued to them, and decided to enforce their claim by a personal suit, rather than by a suit in rem.
A call for a State Convention appears in the Kentucky papers, to consider the policy that ought to be adopted by the State in respect to its own domestic interests and its loyal obligations.

The past two months' campaigning has taught the rebels a hard lesson. Each isolated event has an important lesson of its own, but taken together they open up startling revelations. It must be sufficiently distasteful to the rebels that an army of fifty thousand men can cut itself off from its base at Atlanta and at leisure establish another three hundred miles distant, on the Atlantic coast.

We publish in another column a correspondence of some interest to the public. The Citizens' Association has undertaken to protect the city, so far as possible, from the profligacy and extravagance by which the action of its public bodies of late years has been marked.

The bonded warehouse at No. 5 Whitehallstreet was entered by burglars about three weeks ago, and property consisting of silks and laces, to the amount of $1,000, was stolen. An entrance to the premises was effected from the roof through the scuttle.

The present exhibition of the Artists' Fund, though fairly attended, does not receive the attention which it deserves. We should be glad to see once more, in these splendid rooms, the crowds of delighted visitors that were wont to assemble at exhibitions far less worthy than this. A few years ago most any collection of pictures would attract fall attendance during a long season.

SCOTT'S Autobiography has been read by many of my young acquaintance, and there is a general complaint that he was so brief and scant in the part which is very interesting his reminiscences and accounts of public characters. The few portraits he does give us are remarkably accurate.

Special entertainments, suitable for the young folk and the festive season, are provided at nearly all our places of amusement, except where a change is undesirable, as at the Academy of Music and the Winter Garden. At these establishments "Fra Diavolo" and "Hamlet" are repeated to-night.

To Maj.-Gen, Dix, New-York: A dispatch has been received this evening by the President from Gen. SHERMAN. It is dated at Savannah, on Thursday, the 22d inst., and announces his occupation of the city of Savannah and the capture of one hundred and fifty guns, plenty of ammunition, and about 25,000 bales of cotton. No other particulars are given.

Those familiar with all the facts of the battle of Pittsburgh Landing, fought in Southern Tennessee, thirty-two months and two weeks ago, never could see any ground for the criticisms indulged in by certain parties' upon Gen. Ever since the action was fought, however, there have been great differences of opinion about it, especially in the West, both in the army and out of it, among officers and men.

On the 10th day of December, 1864, three men, Leopold Heidt, Adam Gubing and Ernst Koerbel, were sentenced by the United States Court to imprisonment for making, selling and using sewing machines in violation of an injunction, and besides Heidt was fined $250 and ordered to remain in prison till he should pay it.

The gold speculators endeavored yesterday to qualify our Savannah victory by bidding up the price on rumors from Washington of disaster to BUTLER and PORTER. The early sales of the day were 217 @216 cent.; but on the rumors referred to, the offers to-day were rushed up to 224, soon returning, however, to a point below 220 cent. The King of the Greeks has taken the oath prescribed by the new Constitution, and the National Assembly has been dissolved. Before taking the oath, his Majesty addressed some admirable words to the Assembly:

We have a half inch of snow this morning to the delight of the boys and the astonishment of the sparrows. All England is preparing for Christmas. The shop windows are full of prize beef, geese and poultry, and presents of all kinds.

Political affairs have settled down somewhat in this State. The very decided radical triumph is a quietus for us for some time to come. Col. CRAWFORD, the Governor elect, received a majority of about 3,000 on the home vote of 17,494. The home vote on Presidential electors was as follows:

Another governmental crisis has occurred in Spain. After a three-months' existence, the Narvaez Ministry has fallen fallen, not because of their perfidious treatment of the press, not because of administrative delinquencies, during their brief term of office, not because a popular tempest had burst forth, but simply because Queen ISABELLA and their chief had differed on matters of foreign policy.

The crisp, sharp weather of the last two weeks, which nearly rendered all military movements impracticable, has been moderating since the commencement of the holidays, until rain commenced falling twenty-four hours ago, and to-day the snow has almost entirely disappeared.

We begin the year with great strength and with most excellent prospects. Our veteran and triumphant army, our powerful and gallant navy, have operated on the great rebellion during the year with an effect which would assuredly prove mortal to it, even if they were henceforth to stand still in their career of conquest.

The profound sorrow experienced in this community at the death of the eminent jurist and honored citizen, WM. C. Produce and merchandise were generally quiet and depressed on Saturday, the main exceptions having been Pork and Linseed Oil, which were in speculative request and decidedly dearer. The freight market was dull.

The recent announcement of the transfer of the North American Review to the house of Messrs. TICKNOR FIELDS, of Boston, is hailed with pleasure by all who take an interest in American literature and in the prosperous condition of its oldest and most respected periodical organ.

Wednesday being the third anniversary of the death of the late Prince Consort, the day was marked with much solemnity at Windsor. About 11:30 o'clock in the morning. Her Majesty the Queen, accompanied by the younger members of the Royal family, attired in deep mourning, repaired to the mausoleum, which is now in the course of erection in the grounds of Frogmore House, and where are interred the remains of the late Prince ALBERT.

The gala event of our New-Year's celebration was the annual reception of Mr. and Mrs. LINCOLN. The White House was thrown open at 12 o'clock, and the Cabinet Ministers, the Diplomatic Corps, the Judges of the Supreme Court and the Court of Claims, and the army and navy officers, paid, in the order of precedence, the compliments of the season to the President and his wife. At 1 o'clock the citizens at large were presented.

Alike gratified and grateful at the evidences of the material prosperity of the State, as well as with the increasing manhood, self-reliance and patriotism of the people, as shown in the progress of our country, in its great struggle for nationality, I enter upon the discharge of the duties of the high station with which I have been clothed.

It is refreshing to read the appeals of Gov. FENTON to the patriotism of the Empire State. For two dreary years we have heard no such language. Nothing has been heard from the Executive Chamber at Albany in support of the war but cold, measured, perfunctory words. The only earnestness has been reserved for efforts to destroy the confidence of the people in the administration of the Government.

Quiet reigns in Savannah. With a good sense and judgment that contrasts favorably with the conduct of the New-Orleans Secessionists, when that city was first occupied by Gen. BUTLER, the citizens here submit gracefully to the rule of the successful invaders, and from the first hour of the occupation by our troops till now, have wisely abstained from every kind of aggressive demonstration.

The steamship Fulton, from Port Royal Jan. 1, arrived at this port yesterday morning, bringing news from Savannah to Dec. 31. The city was perfectly quiet and the best feeling prevailed. Gen. SAFRMAN had reviewed his entire army by corps, and was vigorously preparing for another offensive movement.
The markets are all closed to-day for the Christmas holidayS. They will reopen again on the 27th. The news to-day is quite unimportant.

From the Richmond Dispatch, Jan. 2. Nothing of moment has occurred on the lines in front of Richmond and Petersburgh. Winter is upon the armies, and active operations for the present are out of the question.
Mr. SHAFER submitted a minority report relative to the claim of HENRY R. Low to the seat of the Ninth Senatorial District.

The steamship Asia, Capt. MOODIE, from Liverpool at 3:30 o'clock on the afternoon of the 24th, via Queenstown on the 25th of December, arrived here this morning. Her dates are three days later than those already received.

George Opdyke vs. Thurlow Weed. The trial of this cause was resumed yesterday, by calling George Opdyke for cross examination by Mr. Evarts. I came to this city in 1824; have resided in NewOrleans six years; Cleveland, Ohio, two years; and for some years had my residence in New-Jersey, while engaged in business here; returned here in 1853 or 1854; have resided here since that time; have had business here since a about 1841.
The attempt upon Wilmington has failed and everybody is disappointed. Disappointed, because, like ripe fruit, the works were expected to fall into our hands with the first shake of the tree.

The Gold Room advanced yesterday to 233 cent., and then fell back to 231 cent. Government Stocks in demand and firm at the close. The Railway Shares, following a fresh decline in Eile, left off dull and lower.

Mr. BLAIR'S olive branch, it seems, was a private affair altogether. He went to Gen. GRANT'S lines without authority from Washington, at his own instance solely; and Gen. GRANT declined to pass him through, simply because he did not deem it meet to facilitate any such irresponsible errand.

On Tuesday, afternoon, Officer DWYER, of the Twenty-third Precinet, assisted by Officers PORCHER and MOLD, of the Twelfth, found, in a lager-bier saloon, in Third-avenue, near One Hundred and Seventeenth-street, BARNEY FRIERY, the murderer of HENRY LAZARUS, and JAMES McDONALD and JAMES CLARK, the persons who were with him at the time of the murder.
The demand for passports keeps the Governor and Provincial Secretary busily employed.

The steamship Asia, from Liverpool, via Queenstown, Dec. 25, arrived at Halifax yesterday morning, bringing three days later news from Europe. The Shipping Gazette says that advices from Nantes confirm the report that JUAREZ had issued letters-of-marque to Americans against French ships.

The Evening Post, a few days since, in an article entitled, "A Phenomenon Explained," attributes the rise in the price of gold, in face of the late brilliant victories of SHERMAN in Georgia and THOMAS in Tennessee, to the action of the Secretary of the Treasury in placing on the market an additional ONE HUNDRED MILLIONS Of Ten-Forty gold interest-bearing bonds.
We cannot help directing attention to the following passage in a letter from our correspondent at City Point, published on Monday last:

A serious accident occurred in the Bergen Tunnel at noon yesterday, in consequence of a Morris and Essex train of cars being run into by a NewYork and Erie Railway train, by which one person was killed and several more seriously injured.
The Judiciary Committee reported favorably on the bill for a uniform state bounty, and prohibiting local bounties.
A regular meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was held yesterday afternoon, at 1 o'clock, President Law in the Chair. HARVEY FARRINGTON and JAMES KELLY were elected members of the Chamber.
George Opdyke vs. Thurlow Weed. There was a large attendance in court yesterday, to hear the argument of counsel. Judge Pierrepont, on opening his remarks, paid a tribute to the court and jury.
The Speaker presented the annual report of the Superintendent of the Banking Department; also the report of the State Treasurer; also the report of the Canal Commissioners.

A dispatch from Decatur, Ala., dated Jan. 4, says that Gen. STEEDMAN'S cavalry has overtaken HOOD'S pontoon train south of the Tennessee, at Russellville, and had captured it, together with 600 mules, 100 horses and 200 hogs. It was reported that HOOD has been ordered to fall back upon Tuscaloosa to to reorganize his army.

It becomes us coolly and calmly to look into the circumstances of our conditions, and adopt with firmness and energy such a policy as wisdom may point out and our necessity constrain. It is childish to whine under misfortune. It is cowardly to sink under it. It is absurd to be enfeebled by it. A brave man struggling with adversity is worthy of special admiration a spectacle for gods and men.
The Senate reassembled at 12 o'clock, VicePresident HAMLIN in the chair.

In the Senate yesterday petitions were offered from citizens of Ohio, asking for the passage of Mr. CHANDLER'S resolution to orangize a corps for the protection of the northern frontier, and from officers of the army and navy, asking for increased compensation.
We are not ready for the yoke, and that our enemies will find to their cost. We have still within us, to a greater extent than we ever had before, the elements of war and victory.

We published, a few mornings since, a report of the Punishment of several persons by the United States Circuit Court in this city, for violation of the injunction of the court against infringements upon the sewing-machine patents.

Gov. CURTIN'S message was read in the Legislature to-day. He says that the year closes with a train of brilliant successes, inspiring the hope that the rebellion will soon be crushed and peace restored.

Contrary to general expectation, a quorum of Members were present at noon in the House. Mr. ASHLY, of Ohio, announced his intention to call up to-morrow the motion to reconsider the vote by which the Constitutional amendment for the abolition of slavery was defeated last session.
The movement to relieve the suffering people of Savannah deserves the support of every patriotic and every humane man.

The Gold Room was 5 per cent, weaker yesterday than on Wednesday. Government Stocks firm and in demand. The Railways better. Money in active demand from the Brokers. The Erie Railway Company have declared the customary half-yearly Dividend of 4 per cent, on the Common Stock.
Gov. CONY was inaugurated to-day. His message is a lengthy and comprehensive document.

The Richmond papers of Wednesday contain the following items:
Mr. WILSON, of Iowa, (Union, introduced a bill to increase the commutation value of rations at general and post hospitals. This was referred to the Committee on Military Affairs.

Capt. S.J. GILMAN, of the Schooner Charter Oak, of and bound to San Francisco, from Boston, called at our office yesterday, and gives us information respecting the capture of his vessel by the rebel pirate Shenandoah, in lat. 7 north, lon. 27 30' west.

The Michigan Legislature convened at Lansing yesterday. GILBERT E. REED, of Kalamazoo County, was elected Speaker, Gov. BLAIR'S message shows an encouraging condition in the State finances.
Several persons have employed themselves lately in preparing statistical tables of the wealth, food, and fighting men, remaining in the Confederacy subject to the command of the Government.

In the Senate, yesterday, bills were introduced to confirm the ordinance of the New-York Supervisors in relation to bounties. Requiring mortgage liens on lands sold for taxes to be revoked.
The Gold Room was dull yesterday, and Railway Stocks lower on a continued sharp Money market. Government Stocks steady.

Mr. STEVENS introduced a bill in amendment of the Revenue Law, which requires all persons having tobacco on hand to make immediate return of quality and kinds to the district assessor, and forbids removal without permit of the assessor.
The message of Gov. ANDREW was delivered to the Legislature to-day. It is a lengthy and comprehensive document.
The mails by the Asia, covering dates to Dec. 25, reached this city yesterday.

NIBLO'S GARDEN. A new Irish drama called the "Shamrock," is the present attraction at this establishment and the latest novelty offered to the public by the popular favorites, Mr. and Mrs. BARNEY WILLIAMS. The work has been in preparation for some time, and has been produced with all the scenic splendor and liberal stage appointments that characterize Mr. WHEATLEY'S management.
George Opdyke vs. Thurlow Weed. At the opening of the court, Mr. Emott resumed his argument in relation to the alleged fraud in the omission of the $28,000 received from the Government.

The steamer California, from Hilton Head, arrived at Fortress Monroe yesterday, with Col. EWING, bearer of dispatches from Gen. SHERMAN. The army was resting and preparing for another great campaign. KILPATRICK was actively watching HARDEE'S movements.

Major ANDREWS, who commands the guard picketing the Potomac River, from the Great Falls to the mouth of the Monocacy, says that the guerrillas who infest the banks of the river there have become very troublesome of late, and that hardly a night passes without their firing upon our pickets, or making an attempt to cross the river at some point or other.

The House passed the Senate bill repealing so much of the act incorporating the Smithsonian Institute as requires two of the Regents to be appointed from members of the National Institute, the latter having ceased to exist.
The Senate assembled at the usual hour, VicePresident HAMLIN in the chair.

For the first time during the last four years, or since the great Southern rebellion began, we now begin to see some indications of that for which we have always looked so anxiously and so vainly some indications that the imperious, defiant, rebellious spirit of the Southern people is beginning to break.
Our special correspondent, writing from Huntsville on the 2d inst., says HOOD made his final escape across the Tennessee, at Bainbridge, on the 24th ult.

The inquest on the body of PETER SCHENCK, of No. 323 Fifth-avenue, New-York, who lost his life by the collision in the Bergen Tunnel on Thursday noon, was held yesterday afternoon by Coroner HANLEY, at Hudson City. The body was identified by JOHN F. SCHENCK, brother of deceased, who was in the train at the time of the accident.

The Tennessee campaign is at an end. The last of HOOD'S army crossed the Tennessee River, near Brown's Ferry, on the 29th ult., with eight pieces of artillery and about eighteen thousand men. He left Macon with 35,000 men, and was reinforced with FORREST'S cavalry and a portion of DICK TAYLOR'S corps, swelling his force to fully 40,000 men and 110 pieces of artillery.

The statistics of crime in this city, as exhibited in the annual report of the Police Commissioners, are well worthy of general consideration; while the vast discrepancy between the number of arrests for high crimes, and the number of convictions for such offences in the courts, is truly alarming.

In the Senate, yesterday, several petitions were presented from army officers, asking for an increase of pay. The petition of the Sisters of Charity, asking for the remission of the duties paid on the material used in the manufacture of their uniforms, was reported back from the Committee on Finance, who were discharged from further consideration of the subject.

Yesterday morning at 11 o'clock, the Executive Committee, appointed at the last meeting of the Chamber of Commerce, met, to make arrangements for receiving subscriptions for the purchase of supplies to be forwarded to the destitute of Savannah. Mr. R.H. McCURDY presided, and JOHN AUSTIN STEVENS was chosen Secretary.
Under the auspices of the New-York Sigma Phi Club, the Fraternity held their annual reunion Thursday evening.
We regret that we do not hear as yet of the appointment of any special committee by Congress for the sole purpose of discovering means of reducing expenditures.

The full text of His Holiness the Pope's response to the manifesto of the "Confederate Commissioners," is a most inadequate fulfillment of the promise given of its significance in the telegraphic abstract. Cardinal ANTONELLI, so far from indulging in political disquisition, confines himself to a sober, sarcerdotal invocation of peace.

We left Beaufort Harbor, N.C., at 2 P.M. on the 16th inst., with a view of taking a short cruise in search of blockade-runners. We were prevented extending the time at sea beyond three days, in consequence of the anticipated attack on the Cape Fear defences, and the desire manifested by Admiral PORTER that our vessel should be present in the engagement.

Mr. CHARLES O'NEILL, of Pennsylvania, (Union,) introduced a bill to extend the boundaries of the port of Philadelphia, so as to include Richmond on the north and Greenwich on the south. The bill was referred to the Committee on Commerce.
To appropriate $200,000 for the relief of sick and wounded soldiers from this State in the service of the United States.

Gen. REYNOLDS arrived last evening, and this morning formally assumed command of the Department of Arkansas and Seventh Army Corps. Gen. Q.A. GILMORE, of Charleston fame, accompanied Gen. REYNOLDS as inspector of the fortifications of this place, which, after visiting to-day, he pronounced very good and highly creditable to Gen. STEELE. One fort, named after the latter General, is quite equal to the finest forts built south of the Potomac for the defence of Washington.
The situation of affairs in New-Zealand is altogether unsatisfactory. The anticipations of the colonial press touching the close of the rebellion have not been realized.

Brig.-Gen. CHAS. K. GRAHAM is at present in town on a furlough of twenty days, having just returned from the Wilmington expedition, where the army gunboats, commonly known as the "Naval Brigade," did efficient service under his command in landing and embarking troops before Fort Fisher.
The most eventful year in the current history of the State has closed, and she enters upon a new career of industry and progress under the fostering influences of freedom and the rights of man.

The United States vs. Wm. Graham and Jas. French. The defendants in this case were arrested yesterday morning and brought before the Commissioner charged with creating a revolt on board the American bark Sunshine, upon which they were employed as seamen. Mr. R.N. Watle appeared for the accused, and the examination was set down for Monday, until which the men were committed to the Tombs.
A trial has recently come off in the English Court of Exchequer, the decision of which will have a peculiar interest for the whole fraternity of blockade-runners.
Gen. BURBRIDGE has removed his restrictions upon trade in Kentucky.

The great movement of Gen. LEE, which is to "astonish the world," has, I am happy to say, not developed itself enough yet to astonish anybody in this neighborhood, nor could I meet a single soul who seems to feel any apprehension on the subject.

To-morrow will be New-Year's Day, and great preparations are going on to celebrate the natal day of what the soldiers generally believe will be the last year of the war. On Christmas Day, jollity and mirth was the order of the day, and right royally was it obeyed. Evergreen wreaths, emblematic arches and trophies, could be seen everywhere, and whole camps decorated with planted shrubs, and many similar modes and typical signs were observable.

A factious jour nal of this city is indignant because Mr. Minister ADAMS chose to return a civil answer to the address of a number of Englishmen of high social and intellectual standing, who have been from the beginning ardent sympathizers with the Government of the United States in its efforts to restore the National supremacy.

Since the announcement that the quota of NewYork was only about 3,500 on the last call, the people seem to have folded their hands in content and dismissed from their minds all fear of conscription. If this apathy continues until the 15th of February, the deficiency will be but little reduced by enlistments.

The tenant-right question in Ireland has entered on another stage. The existing state of the law has been treated by Judge LONG, of the Encumbered Estates' Court one of the most accomplished jurists in the kingdom- ...
Charles Meigs was put on trial, charged with embezzling a letter, he being employed in the Post office, in February last. Mr. Andrews, the Assistant District-Attorney, opened the case to the jury.

The great question which now excites equal interest with the experiments of free labor, and promises to involve the military and civil authorities of the West Mississippi Department in equal difficulties, is that which has grown out of the new regulations for the cotton trade with the rebels.

STONEMAN, with the assistance of Gens. GILLEM and BURBRIDGE, has certainly established his authority and standing as the great raider. The expedition through East Tennessee and into the heart of Southwestern Virginia has been one of the most, if not the most, successful of the war.
The third annual report of LUCIUS ROBINSON, Comptroller of the State of New-York, was laid before the Legislature to-day.

The question of the jurisdiction of the court in the rebel raiders rearrested, which has been under deliberation for some days past, was to-day decided. The decision was that the court had jurisdiction. The case will, therefore, proceed.

Coroner COLLIN held an inquest, yesterday, at Bellevue Hospital, upon the body of WILLIAM BEEBE, (or FITZGERALD) a soldier, who, after fifteen months' service in the army, was recently furloughed, and who, accompanied by several convivial companions, went to HENRY EICHHORN'S lager-bier saloon, on Tuesday evening last, and there received a mortal wound, from which he died on Saturday. BEEBE was a native of Philadelphia, aged 23 years.

Gen. DANA has received information from his cavalry force sent out from here on the 21st or December. They struck the Mobile and Ohio Railroad five miles below Corinth, and had, on the 27th, utterly destroyed it to below Oakalona. Twenty-nine bridges, a great deal of trestle work, thirty-two railroad cars, three hundred army wagons and four thousand carbines were destroyed.

Mr. BLAIR, Senr., left for City Point yesterday. It is said that a pass from the rebel Secretary of War is in waiting for him, allowing him a safe conduct to the rebel capital. It is understood now that he goes without any official authority.

I beg to inclose herewith a notice just issued under the direction of the Collector. We publish in another column, to-day, a communication from an authoritative source, drawn out by our recent article on Customhouse abuses. In that article we pointed out two alleged grievances suffered by importers; one the abstraction of merchandise from packages in the bonded warehouse, and the other, unnecessary delay in the delivery of goods from Custom-house store, as the penalty of refusal by merchants to pay illegal fees to Custom-house employes.

The new literary en terprise in this city, the New-York Weekly Review, is an exceedingly elegant, valuable, sprightly and attractive journal. Its first issue came out on Saturday last, and its success in every respent was proved at once. The lighter topics in literature, in art, especially in music, and in theatrical gossip and general affairs, are treated with ability and vivacity.

Gen. HAYS has received instructions from Washington not to fix the quotas of sub-districts in accordance with the order issued by Provost-Marshal General FRY, already published, and has been directed to report to the Department all the enlistments up to the 31st day of December.

The Bankrupt Bill is still before the Judiciary Committe of the Senate. There are but little more than seven weeks remaining to the present Congress, to finish up the business it has on hand. It would be too much to expect that in all the details of the Bankrupt Bill passed by the House, the Senate should entirely agree.

The recent proposal in the columns of the Richmond Sentinel, for a European Protectorate or defensive alliance, was evidently semi-official. That is, it was a "feeler" by the Confederate Government to sound the public opinion of the South on this desperate measure. As such, it is believed to be regarded by our own Department of State.

The Richmond Examiner, of Friday last, says it is confirmed that SHERMAN'S troops have crossed the Savannah River and are believed to be marching toward Grahamsville, in the direction of Charleston. The rebels are now as much puzzled in regard to the nature and direction of the next campaign of SHERMAN as they were about his last campaign at the time of its inauguration and during its progress.

Mr. BLAIR, Senior, left Washington for City Point, on Saturday. It is reported that a pass from the rebel Secretary of War is in waiting for him, allowing him a safe conduct to Richmond. It is understood now that he goes without any official authority.
Bark Magdalena, Day, Aspins all 21 ds., with mdse., wool, etc., to J. F. Joy. Has had heavy westerly gales the entire passage.

During the fiscal year ending Sept. 30, 1864, three incorporated banks, whose charters expired on the 1st of January last, have reorganized as associations, under the General Banking Law, with an aggregate capital of $1,150,000. One new association, with a capital of $100,000, and one individual banker, have also commenced business within the same period.

Mr. Mayor GUNTHER has doubtless surprised his friends and disappointed the public generally, by inditing a message characterized by a very fair share of common sense. The document is pertinent as to the subjects it embraces, and contains sundry recommendations which, in the absence of any radical reform in the charter, would be found of no slight value.

We trust there is no truth in the renewed rumor that Mr. F.P. BLAIR has gone to Richmond for the purpose of talking with the rebel authorities about peace. No good can possibly come of such a mission, and it may interfere more or less injuriously with the natural progress of events toward a substantial and a lasting peace.

Secretary STANTON and Gen. MEIGS arrived at Fortress Monroe at a late hour Friday evening, from Washington, D.C., on the revenue cutter Northerner, Mr. SIMEON DRAPER, Mr. HENRY MINTURN, and several attaches of the Custom-house in New-York, arrived on Friday forenoon, and sailed for Savannah, Ga., at noon Saturday, on the steamer Grenada.

The Board met at 1 P.M., yesterday, the President, Mr. JONES, in the chair.
The Money Market worked smoothly in Wallstreet yesterday. A large business done in Government Stocks, and the Railway Shares better than on Saturday. The Gold Room tame, 226 @ 227.
The following message from the Mayor was presented to the Common Council yesterday afternoon:
Present John T. Henry, Esq., President, Aldermen Fox, McCool, Shannon, Chipp, McKnight, Ryers, Jeremiah, Hardy, Kelly, Ottiwell, Farley, Long.

The Money market worked easy yesterday. Business was generally dull on Wall-street owing to the rain-storm. At the Stock Exchange, the Railways were irregular through the forenoon, and, with few exceptions, weaker than on Monday. There was a steadier feeling in the after noon. Government stocks steady or partially better. The general market, later in the day, closed firm. Gold down two or three per cent.

CITY AND COUNTY OF NEW-YORK. In accordance with the programme of Messrs. WM. R. STEWART and RUFUS F. ANDREWS, the Special Committee appointed by the Union State Central Committee to reorganize the Union party of the City and County of New-York, the Union delegates elected to the General Committee, assembled at the corner of Broadway and Twenty-third-street, on Thursday evening, Jan. 5, for the purpose of organization.

The number of homicides committed in this city, during the past year, is officially reported as one hundred. The number of unsuccessful attempts to kill we have not ascertained, but we are satisfied that if we set them down at four hundred, we shall be under the mark. So that it may be safely said that, since the 1st of January, 1864, five hundred attempts to kill, successful or unsuccessful, have been made.

The band of the First Brigade, Third Division, Fifteenth Army Corps, which has been home to Wisconsin on a short furlough granted its members by Gen. SHERMAN, is now stopping at the New-England Rooms, en route to rejoin SHERMAN'S army.

The People vs. Ira Garadier. The prisoner in this case was one of the gang recently arrested, charged with forging the name of Mr. Richard D. Lathrop to a check for $25,000, upon which they obtained $25,000 in Seven-Thirty Bonds from the Bank of Commerce. Mr. Hall, the District-Attorney, appeared for the People, and ex-Judge Stuart, with Mr. Spencer, for the defence.

The City Point correspondent of the Herald states that General Order No. 1,, for 1865, issued by the President, relieves Major-Gen. BUTLER of his command, and orders him to report at Lowell, Mass. Gen. ORD has been deaignated by Gen. GRANT as Gen. BUTLER'S Successor.

Gen. SHERMAN'S Christmas gift to the nation, of the City of Savannah, not only brought great joy to the people at large, but filled with elation a limited class, who saw at once, in the capture, a splendid chance for filling their pockets, by supplying the needy inhabitants with the good things of life, to which, for weary months, rebellion has made them comparative strangers.
The rebels made another attack on our picket line this morning, just before daylight, and captured a few vedettes on the right of the Second Division of the Sixth Corps.

Notice was given of a bill to aid the National Government in providing defences on the lakes, and to repeal the fare restriction clause in the railroad consolidation act of 1853.

The Senate spent last evening in trying to express an opinion upon the bounty question. Supervisors and others especially interested, in various sections of the State, are urging upon Senators and members the importance of speedily defining the policy that the Legislature will pursue upon this subject, and the legislators have an adequate sense of the responsibility resting upon them in this matter.

In the Senate yesterday, Mr. COLLAMER introduced a bill relating to postal laws, which was referred to the Committee on Post-offices and Post Roads. Mr. COLLAMER also introducd a bill relating to clerkships in the Post-office, which was referred to Postal Committee. Various petitions for increase of the pay of army officers were presented by Messrs. WILSON, TRUMBULL and HARRIS, and were referred to the Military Committee.
THE CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENT. It is to-day feared that there is no hope of the passage in the House of the Constitutional Amendment abolishing slavery.

At the opening of court this morning, there was a dense crowd, to learn to what decision the jury had come; and on hearing that they had been locked up all night, without agreeing, the expression was general : "I thought so; I was sure they would not agree."

The House met this morning when a resolution requiring a majority of all the members to elect officers was adopted. The House then adjourned without taking any other vote. Efforts are still being made to effect a compromise.

The Vicksburgh Herald, of the 5th inst., has a full account of GRIERSON'S recent raid in Mississippi. The expedition left Memphis on the 21st ultimo, 3,000 strong, consisting of the Second New-Jersey, Fourth Missouri, and Seventh Indiana Cavalry, First Mississippi Mounted Rifles, and Third and Fourth Iowa, Tenth Missouri; Second Wisconsin and Fourth and Eleventh Illinois Infantry, and Third U.S. Colored Regiment.
The steamship Moravian, Capt. ARTON, from Liverpool at 11 o'clock on the morning of the 29th, via Londonderry on the evening of the 30th of December, arrived here at 12 o'clock noon to-day.
It was reported in Washington, last evening that FRANCIS P. BLAIR, Sr., had returned from Richmond.

The Legislature of Wisconsin organized yesterday, the Senate electing F.M. STEWART, Clerk, and WILLIAMS, Sergeant at Arms, and the Assembly electing W.W. FIELD, Speaker; JOHN E. DEAN, Clerk; and A. WILCOX, Sergeant at Arms, all Unionists.

I don't know whether or not it is a studied scheme of the Richmond autocrat to send all his useless people out of his lines to be fed by us, but certainly the large number of helpless women and children who have, for a long time past, been leaving Petersburgh and Richmond, and who continue still to pour in upon us, tend to give a strong coloring to the suspicion.

The Chair laid before the Senate a message from the President, giving information as to an agreement between the United States and Great Britain, concerning the naval force on the lakes, which was ordered to be printed.
The Augusta Chronicle and Sentinel of the 4th inst. publishes a number of news items, derived from a gentleman who left Savannah on the 1st inst.
The mails by the Moravian, comprising files to Dec. 29, five days later than previously received, same to hand yesterday morning.

Bark Rechabite, of New-Glasgow, Capt. LEEMAN, from Ragged Island, Dec. 27, with salt to BRETT, SON Co., arrived yesterday morning. On the 4th Inst., in lat. 32 long. 73 , she picked up one bale of cotton. No date, lat. 30 42', long, 72 55', she spoke schooner J. Smith, ORLANDO, from Fortress Monroe for Wilmington, with sails split and loss of foreboom; supplied her with twine.
REPORTED RETURN OF FRANCIS P. BLAIR, SEN. It is reported in town this evening that FRANCIS P. BLAIR, Sr., has arrived in town from Richmond.
A gentleman in Washington, who has seen the Richmond Enquirer of Tuesday last, says that paper mentions the following:

Business with this Department is quite lively just now. Three months since the planters were requested to make returns of the amount of wages due the conscripts taken from their plantations, but the army-worm has made such havoc with the princely fortunes which all cotton-speculators had in prospect that a new phase has been developed in the character of many who have hitherto been considered...

To-morrow was the day assigned for the execution of GREEN, the Malden murderer; but it is understood that the Governor has with held his signature from the warrant, and that the execution of the sentence is deferred for action by the next Executive Council.

The following further particulars of GRIERSON'S recent raid are from a reliable source. They brought in 700 prisoners, including two Colonels and a number of other officers, 1,000 able-bodied negroes and 1,000 horses. They killed and wounded 150 men. Among the prisoners is Brig.-Gen. GHOLSON.

Several rebel deserters came in to-day, besides a large number of contrabands. All were in the most wretched condition imaginable. They had traveled a long distance in the rain, and were objects of pity to all who saw them.

We print this morning Major-Gen. BUTLER'S official report of the naval and military expedition to Wilmington, together with the instructions issued to Gen. WEITZEL, the correspondence between Lieut.-Gen. GRANT and Maj.-Gen. BUTLER. It will be seen, from this correspondence, that the Lieutenant-General intended that Gen. WEITZEL, and not Gen. BUTLER, should command the military forces of the expedition.
The Gold-room closed yesterday about the same as on Thursday P.M. The early sales of the day were at an advance of 2@3 cent. The Railways were better. Governments steady, Money easy.

The Cunard steamship China, with dates to the 1st inst., arrived here yesterday morning. The situation of SHERMAN in front of Savannah was the subject of most anxious expectation, as also the St. Albans robbery trials. The rebel loan had declined 6 per cent, under the pressure of the news received.

The heavy rains which have fallen for the past week have swollen the James River to several feet above the usual height, and the low grounds along the banks of the river are flooded, making travel in the vicinity anything but pleasant.

In the Senate, yesterday, a petition was presented in behalf of the soldiers captured in the Streight raid into Georgia. It was referred to the Military Committee. A resolution was offered, and referred to the Military Committee, instructing the Secretary of War to report to the Senate the number of men furnished by the loyal States ...

FOOTE, Member of the rebel Senate from the State of Tennessee, who recently declared his intention of leaving the Confederacy, and "going to some sequestered spot, where he could enjoy a little repose and be free from taxation," bas been endeavoring to carry out his purpose.

It was remarked two thousand years ago "how great a matter a little fire kindleth," and probably it was remarked long before that. There are illustrations of the saying often enough. We had one yesterday when the following startling dispatch from the Associated Press was published in all the journals of the city:
Mr. LAIMBEER presented a petition, numerously signed by wealthy citizens of New-York, asking for an immediate investigation into the affairs of the city departments.

GENERAL: In accordance with orders, I moved on the evening of the 7th inst., with about 7,000 men of Gen. AMES' Second Division. Twenty-fourth Corps, and Gen. PAINE'S First Division, Twenty-fifth Corps, to the rear of the left of our lines at Bermuda Hundred, and bivouacked for the night at the signaltower.

In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. LAIMBEER presented a petition numerously signed by wealthy citizens of New-York, asking for an immediate investigation into the affairs of the city departments. Bills were reported favorably to confirm the Bounty Act of the New-York Supervisors; to incorporate the Studio Building Association of New-York; to amend the law relative to the assessment of bank stock.

A meeting had been held at Dublin for the purpose of forming an association for the reform of the law of landlord and tenant, and for obtaining the abolition of the Church establishment. The Lord Mayor presided, and there was a large muster of Catholic clergy. A disturbance had been anticipated, but with some slight exceptions the proceedings were quiet and orderly.

Gen. KILPATRICK'S cavalry command will not be reviewed this week. The review is indefinitely postponed. This will prove a great disappointment to thousand of readers, especially the fair ones, who were anxious to witness a cavalry review.

CITY NOTES.?The steamship Arago, from Port Royal, S.C., brought up seventy-eight bags of letters, thirty of which were from the soldiers of Gen. SHERMAN'S army. DURYEA will deliver a discourse to-morrow evening at the Collegiate Church, Lafayette place, by invitation of the Young Men's Christian Association, on "Recreations of the Young."

The Richmond Dispatch, of the 12th inst., says:

The storm has passed and we are once more blessed by bright skies and warmer days. But the traces of the heavy fall of rain remain behind. Our roads are knee deep in mud, the creeks and streams are overflowed to a great extent, and large sheets and pools of water abound. Now that the rain has ceased busy crowds of soldiers can be seen hard at work making repairs and laying down new roads.

BLISS, of the Tenth New-York Cavalry, who was captured on WILSON'S raid, near Stony Creek, Va., on the 29th of June, 1864, furnishes us the following facts respecting his experiences while a prisoner, and his escape from Dixie. The regular British mail steamship from Valparaiso and intermediate ports arrived at this port on the morning of the 4th instant. She brings dates from Valparaiso and Santiago de Chill to the 17th, and from Callao and Lima to the 28th ultimo.

FORT BARRANCAS, Fla., Friday, Dec. 20, 1864. Since my last letter we have had many changes. Gen. BAILEY has been relieved, Col. ROBINSON, Ninety-seventh United States Colored, taking temporary command. He was relieved by Brig.-Gen. THOS. J. McKEAN.

A special meeting of the Board of Supervisors was held in the new Court-house on Friday, Gen. CROOKE presided. The most important business brought up was in relation to the county bonds and certificates of indebtedness issued to pay the money raised to give bounties to volunteers.

Mr. SEWARD, by recent accounts, was more likely to quarrel with France than with Great Britain, but events may prove too strong for his policy and disposition.

The board met, pursuant to adjournment, in their Chamber, No. 17 City Hall.

The contributions of our citizens for the relief of the destitute people of Savannah fully sustain the noble reputation of New-York for philanthropy. The committees appointed by the Chamber of Commerce and the Produce Exchange have been exceedingly successful in obtaining large subscriptions, most willingly made, from our merchants and business men generally.

There is no man associated with the Confederate cause in whom the Southern people have so great confidence, as Gen. LEE. Yet, of all the Southern leaders, he is the most taciturn. The attitude of silence which he has maintained has been a serious habit, and not a bare theatrical assumption, as in the case of weaker men.

Our Legislature has commenced its session, of which you have been, doubtless, informed by telegraph. Among its first business was the reenactment of the law which expired with the outgoing year, making Treasury notes receivable for taxes. An attempt was made to include the bills of National Banks, but it failed.

There is no legitimate military news at present in this department. The only demonstrations by the enemy are made by small scouting detachments, and these hardly appear often enough to keep the pickets awake.

The Senate took hold of the bounty question last evening in earnest. The interest generally felt in this subject was evinced by the fact that the Senate Chamber was densely packed with spectators who had learned that the question was to be taken up at that time. Every standing place was occupied until the hour of adjournment, 10 o'clock P.M.

By the United States transport Continentals which sailed from Key West on the 10th inst. and arrived at this port yesterday morning, we learn that the steam sloop-of-war San Jacinto, Capt. R.W. MEADE commanding, was lost on the morning of the 1st inst., on a reef off No-Name Key, on the Bahama Banks. The day previous to her wreck she had been chasing a blockade-runner, which escaped by reaching neutral waters.

Some of our cotemporaries deem it necessary, or find it agreeable, to contest the justice of Gen. BUTLER'S removal, and to treat that act as due to professional jealousy or personal hostility on the part of Gen. GRANT and Secretary STANTON.

Richmond papers of the 13th inst. chronicle the arrival of Hon. S.P. BLAIR in that city, but with hold the particulars of his visit. They profess to regard his mission as an attempt on the part of Mr. LINCOLN to set the rebel Government wrong before the world, by proposing terms of peace which he knows they cannot accept.

Mrs. HENRY S. FOOTE, wife of Ex-United States Senator and Ex-Confederate Senator FOOTE, whose advent among us has been before announced, is still in this city, awaiting news from her husband, who was arrested at Occoquon by the rebel authorities, and returned to Richmond.

The Rebecca Clyde left this harbor, and the Greyhound left Boston, on Saturday, laden with provisions and other necessaries for the suffering people of Savannah. The Daniel Webster will leave our docks to-morrow or next day on the same errand.

We are startled this morning by the announcement of the sudden death of EDWARD EVERETT. He died of apoplexy yesterday morning, at his residence in Boston. Mr. EVERETT has latterly held no public position, but his death will create as much deep and respectful regret as if he had held the highest office in the land.

The Ways and Means Committee yesterday resumed the consideration of the proposition of Secretary FESSENDEN in reference to the further issue of Seven-thirty Bonds, and authorized the Chairman of the committee to prepare a bill nearly in accordance with the views of the Secretary, which will be submitted to the committee for approval at their meeting to-morrow.

After all that has been written officially and non-officially on the subject of quotas in connection with the pending draft, we find that a large portion of our citizens are still in about as much doubt as ever how to read the law. And we question whether the multiplication of official circulars has done much more in many cases than to add to the bewilderment of the anxious inquirer.

A Military Commission, of which Col. M.S. Howa, United States Army, is President, and which has been some months in session at Gen. DIX'S headquarters, investigating cases arising under the laws of war, has recently been occupied with two interesting trials.

Since the 1st of January, 1864, there have been over twelve hundred cases of typhus fever in the most crowded and needy districts of this city. This dreadful disease has sometimes swept through whole blocks, scourging family after family of poor laborers.
The Commercial has a special dispatch from Nashville, which says:

Gen. DIX and his subordinates have had an object in view in striving, as they have done since the night of the incendiary attempt to lay our city in ashes, to create the impression that they were making no movements with a view to the apprehension of the incendiaries.
The Stock Market was better yesterday for the Railways, and steady for Governments. Money 7 cent., and in easy supply. Gold opened firm, but left off easier than on Saturday.

ALBERT D. RICHARDSON, of the New-York Tribune, with WM. E. DAVIS, correspondent of the Cincinnati Gazette and Clerk of the Ohio Senate, arrived here to-day. They escaped from the rebel penitentiary at Salisbury, N.C., on the night of Dec. 18, in company with JUNIUS H. BROWN, also of the New-York Tribune.

Mr. KNOEDLER reopens his gallery (No. 772 Broadway) to-day. It has been closed during the past few days for the purpose of hanging an entirely new collection of French and Belgian pictures. We have had a brief opportunity of examining some of these works.

The rebels THE REBELS ON WILMINGTON, The rebels have never concealed from us the supreme value of Wilmington to their cause. The great commerce in war materials, in general supplies and in cotton that they have carried on there, has been for nearly two years as their very lif-eblood.

There was at first some considerable doubt in this city as to the accuracy of the official report that at the capture of Savannah we had come into possession of thirty-three thousand bales of cotton. But since the matter has been looked into, at Savannah, there is reason to believe that the official estimate was much below instead of above the mark.

Prices are enormous, frightful. Everything is high with an upward tendency. To-day you decline purchasing on account of the price, to-morrow you have to pay several dollars more for the article. We cannot set a bound to the limit of prices. All the prime necessaries of life are much dearer than they were a month since.

Andrew J. Millspaugh vs. Seth Adams. This interesting case attracted an unusual crowd to the court-room yesterday. Great anxiety was evinced to see the parties to the suit, and particularly the lady whose character is at stake. She appeared perfectly composed, and consulted with her counsel quite frequently.

The Third Division of the Second Corps, commanded by Brevet Major-Gen. MOTT, was reviewed to-day by Gen. HUMPHREY. This is one of the largest divisions in the army, and there being no good ground in the vicinity on which to manoeuvre the entire division, each brigade was reviewed separately.

A week from hence the files of the London Times will hardly be recognizable. Those received by the City of Baltimore last evening contain the amplest assurance possible that the "leading journal" is about to lead in a direction precisely the opposite of that toward which it has lent itself, and led its dupes heretofore.

RESOLUTIONS OF THANKS. Mr. SCHENCK, of Ohio, (Union,) form the Military Committee, reported back the Senate joint resolution tendering the thanks of Congress to Brevet Maj.-Gen. TERRY and the officers and men under his command.

FRANCIS P. BLAIR, Sr. left this afternoon on the Government steamer boat for City Point. Thence he will go on the flag of-truce boat to Varina Landing, on the James River, where a permit is waiting him to return to the rebel capital.

In the excitement of our own affairs, the American public should not overlook the grand "Declaration of War" just made by the Pope of Rome against the ideas of the Nineteenth Century. We but repeat the voice of the liberal Roman Catholic party through Europe when we say that such a return to the spirit of the Middle Ages has not been made by any public official for more than a hundred years.

In the cose of BENNET G. BURLEY, the Lake Erie raider, judgment was given at 2 o'clock this afternoon, by Recorder DUGGAN. BURLEY is committed as subject to extradition under the treaty. It is only about a fortnight since that there began to be observed, and that we wrote an article in these columns upon, certain new manifestations in the spirit of the South. We began to see, what had not appeared before during the four years of the war, signs of the breaking-down of faith in their cause and its success indications of the departure of hope, the advance of despair.

NEW-YORKERS IN WASHINGTON. A large number of leading New-Yorkers have arrived here, among whom are WM. M. EVARTS, Judge PIERPONT and BENJAMIN FIELD. The object of their visit probably has reference to New-York appointments.

The Senate has adjourned until Monday evening without taking final action upon the Bounty Bill. The bounty question has, however, been brought to a definite point. The Senate has ordered the bill to a third reading; the Select Committee of the Assembly has reported precisely the same bill, and the Convention of Supervisors recommended the enactment of a law evidently copied from the main features of this bill.

There is not much prospect that M. PERSIGNY'S prediction touching the future freedom of the French press will be verified in our day, since, instead of relaxing its fetters, the French Government and French courts are incessantly laboring to strip it of the few privileges which yet remain to it.

Strange to say, for the past three days the weather has been pleasant balmy as April. No rain has fallen; the roads are becoming passable once more, and the sun has been shedding its benignant rays upon a previously damp army.

The Charleston Mercury says that in order to save the Confederacy more killing is necessary. "Men in command must not be afraid to die they must not be afraid to kill. Officers must be killed not mere privates. Reform must begin at the top, not at the bottom of the service. To reach the private, Captains must be shot. We want no child's play we want an army."

Bids for Central Park Improvement Fund Stock, paying 6 per cent, interest, were opened in the Comptroller's Office yesterday. The amount required was $234,000. Bids amounting to $289,500 were received, ranging from par to 4 per cent, premium, but, as the Comptroller decided to accept only those at and over 2 per cent premium, only $75,000 were taken.

SIR: My late experience with the monitor class of vessels under fire at sea and in riding out heavy gales, justifies me in making a special report in the matter. I feel the importance of the Government's receiving accurate information in relation to a class of vessels about which there has been a differencs of opinion, and of which we are building quite a number.

If there be any city in America, as muddy as Nashville, in this fourth winter of the rebellion, I should like to know where it is. I emphasize the period, for the rebellion has much to answer for, for the present frightful accumulations of filth, making side-walks, streets, lanes, alleys, yards, look some thing like a certain phase of the ocean as seen by the "ancient mariner" from the deck of his haunted ship.
The English mail steamer Solent from Vera Cruz, brings news from Mexico City up to the 27th ult., and from Vera Cruz to the 1st of January.
The current of college life moves on in uninterrupted tranquillity during the Winter term.

WM. D. SNOW was elected to the U.S. Senate by a two-third vote of both Houses of the Legislature on the 29th ult., in joint convention. Mr. SNOW was born in Webster, Worcester County, Mass., in 1830, and anti-slavery in his principles, he has always acted with the old Whig and Republican parties. The Legislature is composed mostly of men born in the slave States, numbering seven eights of the members.

Complaints continue to be received at this office that many persons liable to income tax fall to make full returns. Those complaints have become so general that I deem it a duty I owe to the public service to call the attention of assessors to the subject, that they may exert the necessary diligence to remove, if possible, the cause.

WALDO HUTCHINS and Ex-Tax-Commissioner WILLIAMSON were present to urge the claims of the bills. HENRY H. ANDERSON and Tax Commissioner ALLEN appeared in opposition.

THEODORE YATES, convicted of the murder of Policeman CHARLES CURRAN, was brought up before the Kings County Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday morning for sentence. His pale but self-possessed appearance attracted general attention. Soon after the opening of the court, Mr. JENKS, one of prisoner's counsel, renewed the motion made the previous evening for a stay of proceedings, with the view of procuring a new trial of the case.
