Five times he has asked to have charges preferred against him and has offered $50,000 bonds, but no notice has been taken of him.
Quiet still prevails along the lines of this army, the bad weather prevailing for the past few days making it impracticable to carry out any military movements even if one was contemplated.

The rapid dissolution of the Confederacy as a military power, forces into the foreground the great question of the return of the cotton trade to something like what may be called its normal condition. In spite of all the flying reports and predictions that have been uttered to the contrary, the people of the South have not made a general bonfire of their cotton accumulations.

The important station and grain depot of the overland mail contractors, at Julesburgh, on the Platte, has been abandoned by all except one of the men in charge in consequence of the Indian massacres in their neighborhood. At last accounts the savages had not attacked the station, and it is now hoped it will be saved, as Major-Gen. CURTIS, who commands the troops on the overland route, telegraphs from Fort Leavenworth as follows:

The committee recently appointed by the State Senate to investigate various departments of the city and county government, continued its labors yesterday. A large number of gentlemen holding official positions were present.
A special meeting of the Board of Supervisors was held at 8 o'clock last evening; the President, Mr. TWEED, in the Chair.

THE FRIARY CASE. The difficulties in the way of a speedy administration of justice in this city seem almost insurmountable, even where the officers of the law evince a determination to do their duty with vigorous promptness. The progress of the Friary trial is an instance in point, from which we can see how abuses have crept into the practice of our courts, and ...

The campaign which has already been opened by Gen. SHERMAN, and in which the armies operating before Petersburgh and Wilmington, will soon take part, will be the winding-up campaign of the rebellion. It is no secret that great bodies of troops have been coming from the West to take part in it; and whether they reinforce for the moment the army of MEADE, or of TERRY, or of SHERMAN, it is all the same.

In an abnormal state like that in which the country is now placed, we must expect to witness not only great diversity, but violent fluctuations in public opinion as to the influence of measures or events both upon the political and financial condition of the country.

The return of Mr. BLAIR from his second mission to Richmond was announced yesterday morning, and the result of his mission became known in this city yesterday afternoon. That result is fully set forth in our special Washington dispatches, and is, in brief, "failure" complete and entire. The only conditions on which DAVIS will negotiate for peace is on the basis of two independent nations, and an armistice.

The Gold Room advanced from 206 to 212 cent., yesterday, on the settlement of 3-day contracts made on Tuesday night, and on various rumors adverse to an early peace. The Railways active. Governments steady. Money easy.

The steamship Hibernian, Capt. DALTON, from Liverpool at 11:45 on the morning of the 12th, via Greencastle at 6:30 on the evening of the 13th inst., arrived at this port at 1 o'clock this afternoon. Her dates are a few days later than those already received.

The following is a summary of the news taken out by the Virginia: The news of the fall of Savannah caused much excitement, although fully expected. Additional compliments were heaped upon SHERMAN for his skill. The Confederate loan fell about four per cent., ...
Funds firm. Consols improving. Discount demand moderate. There was some expectation of a further reduction in the bank minimum soon. Gold was flowing to the bank.

Wm. Anderson was brought up for sentence yesterday morning, having pleaded guilty of an attempt at burglary. His Honor said there were no mitigating circumstances in the case, and he should sentence the prisoner to the State Prison for two years and six months.
Full files of Richmond papers to Wednesday, Jan. 25, have been received to-night at the Washington office of the Philadelphia Inquirer, from which the following intelligence is taken:

Whatever exaggerations there may be in the reports published yesterday of the cession by MAXIMILLIAN of Northern Mexico to the Emperor NAPOLEON, of the main fact we have no doubt. It is simply carrying out the original programme. That NAPOLEON entered on his Mexican campaign merely for glory, or in the interest of civilization merely, no one ever believed.

In the Senate, yesterday, a bill was introduced to amend the State militia law. Among the bills passed was one legalizing the acts relative to the bounty bonds of Brooklyn. A resolution was introduced providing that a Select Commit tee be appointed to ascertain, by correspondence with the authorities of Buffalo and all other municipalities in the State, on what terms grounds and buildings for a new capitol can be obtained.
The steamer Evening Star, from New-Orleans Jan. 21, arrived at this port yesterday. We are indebted to the Commercial Express Company, No.6 Broadway, for full files of New-Orleans papers.

Produce and Merchandise opened rather briskly on Saturday, at generally advancing prices, but closed tamely and irregularly, influenced by the fluctuations in gold. The freight engagements were less extensive, including 225 bales Cotton for Liverpool, making nearly 2,100 bales taken for that port within four days.

The Albany Investigating Committee continued its labors yesterday morning at No. 75 Duane-street. Judge WHITING said that Mr. WINANTS wished to correct a statement made by him during his examination on Friday. The privilege was granted by the committee.
The following resolutions, reported by the Exexecutive Committee, were unanimously passed at a special meeting of the Union League Club of this city, on Friday evening:

By the arrival of the steamship Arago, at this port yesterday, from Port Royal Jan. 25, we are in receipt of later intelligence from Gen. SHERMAN'S army and Savannah. No fighting had occurred, although Gen. SHERMAN'S forces were far from being idle. The last of Gen. SHERMAN'S army, under Gen. GEARY, left Savannah on the 20th, Gen. GROVER, with a strong body of reinforcements, had arrived and assumed command of the city.

The Bank of Prussia has reduced its rate of interest to 5 per cent, for commercial bills and advances on merchandise, and to 5 per cent, upon securities.

In the following necrological record we have not attempted to enter the names of all the officers of volunteers of the rank of Colonel and above, who have fallen to battle during the year, as it was manifestly impossible to do so; but have confined ourselves to those who have been, at the time of their death or wounding, in command of a brigade, or for some other reason had attained eminence:

SPECIAL FIELD ORDERS NO. 6. The General Commanding announces to the troops composing the Military Division of the Mississippi that he has received from the President of the United States and from Lieut.-Gen. GRANT letters conveying the high sense and appreciation of the campaign just closed, resulting in the capture of Savannah and the defeat of HOOD'S army in Tennessee.

The California journals are discussing the subject of the Emperor NAPOLEON'S colonization scheme in Northern Mexico, and generally take the view that it will relieve the State of Southern malcontents and rebel sympathizers, many of whom are already preparing to leave under the invitation of Dr. GWIN, and that eventually American settlers will revolutionize the country it the Monroe Doctrine is not sooner asserted by the United States Government.
To-day was specially set apart for speech-making on the proposed anti-slavery constitutional amendment. About thirty members only were present at the opening of the House.

The London Globe says, that this year no serious reduction in the cost of either the army or navy of England can reasonably be expected. In the last three years reductions have taken place to the extent of two and a half millions sterling, and by careful economy and reorganization the amount may be brought up to three millions in the ensuing financial year.

SPECIAL FIELD ORDERS, No. 15. 1. The islands from Charleston south, the abandoned rice fields along the rivers for thirty miles back from the sea and the county bordering the St. John River. Florida, are reserved and set apart for the settlement of the negroes now made free by the acts of war and the proclamation of the President of the Untied States.

THE REBEL LOSS IN THE IRON-CLAD RAID. The Richmond Whig, of yesterday, reports the loss, in the naval engagement of last Tuesday, at five killed and fourteen wounded. It says that the Drewry was blown up by one of the Yankee shells, and that a torpedo-boat was also lost.

This city, at the eleventh hour, proposes, with the Legislature's permission, to raise $100,000 bounty money to free herself from the draft; and she asks the Legislature to make substitute-brokerage a high misdemeanor, and conviction therof punishable by $500 fine and six months' imprisonment.

Mr. BLAIR has stated to an intimate friend, that by his first trip to Richmond be succeeded in obtaining from the rebel authorities many valuable papers, taken from his house by EARLY'S men last September. Among the documents recovered was his will.
A case is now pending in one of the subordinate English courts, the issue of which will go far toward showing whether British neutrality is a reality.

The Chair laid before the Senate a communication from the Secretary of the Navy, transmitting to the Senate, in compliance with a resolution of this body of June last, the proceedings of the Court of Inquiry in the case of C.W. SCHOFIELD, naval contractor, filling several hundred foolscap pages. The communication was laid on the table.
The Richmond Sentinel, of Jan. 27, has the following:
The English funds have been inactive. Consols closed at 89 @ 7/8.

A letter from the Army of the Potomac, dated Friday evening, says quiet still continues along the lines the only variation of the monotony being some occasional picket firing in front of the Ninth Corps, near the Appomattox.
The steamship America, from Southampton on Jan. 18, arrived at this port yesterday, with three days later from Europe.

Receipts of Produce since our last 42 bbls. Ashes, 2,825 bbls. Flour, 122 bbls., and 1,536 bags Corn Meal, 10,225 bushels Corn, 6,615 bushels Oats, 170 bushels Rye, 2,525 bushels Barley, 1,831 packages Provisions, and 370 bbls. Whisky.

our European news of yesterday that there was at least something of truth in the California reports we have lately been publishing as to the purposes of the French Emperor in Northern Mexico, and the complicity of Dr. GWIN. Our Paris letter, under date of the 13th inst., contained this paragraph:

Parties arriving from different points in the interior of Georgia state that a great reaction is taking place in the minds of the people, who now openly confess that the attempt to establish a Southern Confederacy is a failure, and that it is useless for Georgia to extend any more aid to this end.

The passport sys THE PASSPORT SYSTEM, The passport sys tem between the United States and Canadawas inaugurated and enforced by our Government immediately after the decision by Judge COURSOL, in December, releasing the rebel raiders. Since the date of my last letter announcing the departure of Gen. SHERMAN'S army from Savannah on its new campaign, a heavy rain has set in, which, in this country, and at this season of the year, is apt to render the roads useless for travel for several weeks.

The Thirty-sixth Annual Ball of the New-York Fire Department was held last evening at the Academy of Music, and never did this large hall present a more brilliant and beautiful appearance. The decorations were very neat and in excellent taste.

The House Commercial Committee were in session to-day, for the purpose of investigating the whole question of cotton permits. It has been referred to a sub-committee of five, who intend to hold daily sessions. They have already examined a number of persons, who are understood to have the necessary documents allowing them to trade in cotton. It is the intention of the committee to subpoena all persons who are in possession of these documents.

We published exclusively yesterday morning the full report of Gen. BUTLER'S speech, made at Lowell, on Saturday evening. Those who have read it will concur with us in saying that it is exceedingly able, defiant and mischievous. Its tone is not unpatriotic, because ...

There is no doubt that the passport system between Canada and the United States will be abrogated as soon as rendition is actually made of the rebel culprits. It is understood that the executive and legal action in the case of BURLEY will be taken as a test of the course of Canadian justice and the disposition of the Canadian authorities.
The annual report of the Trustees of the Astor Library was received and ordered to be printed.

A special meeting of the Board of Supervisors was held at noon yesterday. A resolution was adopted, after a protracted debate, earnestly requesting the Legislature to aid in filling the excessive quota now demanded of us, by speedily passing the bill legalizing the ordinance of June 14, appropriating $2,000,000 for the payment of bounties to volunteers, a part of which appropriation has been already expended.

The Clyde, laden with the contributions of New York for this city, arrived in the river below the obstructions yesterday about 12 o'clock. The rebels have been very industrious in the matter of these obstructions. All the channels, three, I believe, in number, have been filled from shore to shore with sunken vessels and cribs filled with stones, piles being driven below them to the surface of the water.

Mr. POMEROY, of Kansas, (Union,) presented a concurrent resolution of the Legislature of Kansas, setting forth that the military force on the frontier of that State is insufficient for the protection of the overland route against Indian depredations, and asking that it be increased. The resolution was referred to the Committee on Military Affairs.
The State Senate Committee yesterday morning continued its investigation of alleged abuses in the City Inspector's Department.

If any one wants to lose all faith in the details of history, he has only to come and be the army correspondent of a newspaper, to learn how difficult it is to disentangle truth from the web of conflicting statements surrounding even the nearest and most recent events which he may not have witnessed with his own eyes.

RAGES. The substitution of a national for a local currency will remedy more evils than one. The prime ends sought, of course, are first, uniformity of value, and next a reasonable security against counterfeits. The former of these objects, we have a fair assurance, will be secured; the latter will also be, in a measure, attained. At least, we shall not have one-tenth the number of spurious bills in circulation that we have now.

The Speaker presented the memorial of the Indiana Legislature, asking for a discharge of the recruits from that State, who volunteered in old regiments, in 1862, on the understanding and agreement of the mustering officer, that they were to be discharged with the regiment when its term of service expired. This was ordered to be printed, and was referred to the Military Committee.

An ingenious and philosophical writer in the last North American Review has accounted for many of the social defects in our civilization by the theory that they are the results, not of democracy, but of a frontier and pioneer life, reacting on the older communities near the coast.

The steamship Peruvian, Capt. BALLANTINE, left Liverpool at 2:30 P.M. on the 19th. Purser BROWN reports that she was detained off Lough Foyle by fog sixteen hours, and did not sail from Londonderry until the 21st, at 9 A.M. She arrived at Portland at 4 o'clock this afternoon. She brings no news of a later date than Friday.

In the Senante yesterday, an attempt was made by Mr. SAULSBURY to introduce a peace petition from Colorado JEWETT, but objection being made, the reading was suspended. A petition was presented, asking for the establishment of steam signals along the Atlantic coast. The House resolution reducing the duty on imported paper, with an amendment, striking out "three" and inserting "fifteen" per cent., was introduced and ordered to be printed.

Old Fort Nagley regaled us again on Thursday with another of its characteristic roars of joy, on account of a Union triumph. The guns at the Capitol, as usual, caught up and prolonged the sonorous jubilation, two or three suburban batterles uproariously coming in as chorus.

In the Confederate House of Representatives, at Richmond, on the 26th inst., it was decided to take up the bill to provide for the employment of free negroes and slaves to work upon fortifications and perform other labor connected with the defences of the country, and that it shall continue the special order for the morning hour until disposed of.
France is said to have proposed a European Conference, to meet at Paris on the 1st of March, in order to modify some existing telegraphic conventions.

It is always an ungracious task for a great Power to assert its rights against a weaker neighbor. The stronger party, whether the quarrel be of personal, social or national significance, is invariably expected to "yield," not on grounds of right, but on some ill-defined principle of chivalry. We Americans have been doing this sort of thing of late to an extent which barely comes within the bounddaries of prudence.

The vessels which have been sent by our people with food for the poor of Savannah are beginning to arrive, and naturally make some sensation there. They must remind the citizens of Savannah forcibly of the slanderous charges which have been as persistently made against the people of the North, of bloodthirstiness and barbarity.

It seems probable, from our advices this morning, that A.H. STEPHENS, of Georgia, R. M.T. HUNTER, of Virginia, and A.J. CAMPBELL, of Alabama, are on their way to Washington to confer with the President concerning Peace. We shall hail their appearance there as indicative at least of their conviction that the attempt to overthrow the authority of the National Government in the Southern States is a failure.

The House of Representatives is a queer institution. It seems to understand the art of looking one way and rowing another to perfection. Professing to support the Administration, it loses no opportunity of denouncing its action.
The Gold Room fell off 7 cent, yesterday. The Railway market weak. Governments in demand for Europe, for the 5-20s. Money easy, Exchange weak for the Boston steamer.
The Peoples Convention, opposed to any extension of the monopoly privileges of the Camden and Amboy Railroad Company, will meet here to-morrow.

The Inman steamer City of Cork, Capt. TIBBETS, which left Liverpool at noon on the 18th, and Queenstown on the 19th January, arrived here yesterday. Her news is mainly anticipated.
A bill was reported to incorporate the NewYork and Union Yacht Club. Bill were noticed to incorporate the State Temperance Society; and for the construction of a pier in the North River, New-York.

The State Senate Committee continued its investigation into the workings of the City Inspector's Department, yesterday morning. The attendance was larger and the proceedings more interesting than on former days.

By the English steamer Eider, from St. Thomas, we have dates from the Republic of San Salvador to the 19th ult. The Presidential election had taken place without any popular disturbance, and resulted in the re lection of Senor DUENAS.

The Port Royal New South, of the 23d inst., has been received. The occupation of Salkehatchie by our troops is confirmed. The rebels evacuated that position on the approach of the advance of our forces, and retreated to Ashepoo, where it is thought they will make a stand.

For many days the weather has been intensely cold, and many cases of frost-bitten feet, ears, cheeks, , on our picket lines are reported. Today the intense cold had moderated, and though the sun shone brightly and the air was calm, the roads were solid and travelers many.

Congress has decided to submit to the action of the several States an amendment of the Constitution prohibiting slavery forever within the limits or jurisdiction of the United States. The Senate adopted a resolution to this effect at its last session; and the House of Representatives concurred in its passage yesterday, by a vote of 119 ayes to 56 nays.

CONFIRMATION OF GEN. MEADE. The Senate went into executive session to-day, at an early hour, for the purpose of considering the confirmation of Maj.-Gen. MEADE. It is said that a very animated debate ensued, which lasted upward of two hours, in which several gentlemen animadverted very severely upon the military career of this gentleman.
The Senate is daily besieged with petitions from small mercantile bodies, asking that the Bankrupt Bill be made prospective in its operation.

BLAIR, on recently leaving Richmond, proceeded only as far as City Point, and there opened telegraphic communication with Washington, and in consequence of this communication, three eminent persons, after consultation with the President, have determined to proceed to the Yankee capital, their safe conduct being assured by the Washington authorities, for purposes which have been fully disclosed to the public.
After three days' spirited debate in Committee of the Whole, the convention amended and adopted the third section of the State Constitution, defining the qualifications of voters.

The Peace Commissioners, it seems, have not come to Washington at all. Our correspondent with the army gives intelligence of their movements down to the morning of day before yesterday, (Tuesday,) and at that time they had not even reached headquarters. We learn from Washington that Secretary SEWARD has gone to meet them, with what instructions or for what purpose is, of course, open to the Widest possible conjecture.
The Gold Room left off weak yesterday at 203 per cent. The Railways were also depressed in the early part of the day, and closed lower than on Tuesday. Governments steady. Money easy.

Throughout the entire day yesterday the excitement of this community concerning the killing of Mr. BURROUGHS was intense. Many rumors were circulated respecting the unfortunate, misguided woman who had perpetrated the fearful crime, of which we yesterday gave the particulars, as disclosed at the coroner's inquest on the evening of Monday, the fatal day.

In the Senate yesterday, after a number of miscellaneous petitions had been presented and referred to the appropriate committees, the House resolution of thanks to Gen. SHERIDAN was taken up and unanimously passad. The General Appropriation Bill for the year 1866 was reported.

The board met in their hall last evening, President McLEAN in the chair, and a quorum present. Among the communications that were received and referred was one from Mr. WILLIAM B. HUTCHINGS, proposing to teach his system of Arithmetic in the public schools.

On the 26th we received the news that the French frigate Entreprenaute, sixty guns, had got ashore on Cayo Blanco, about sixty miles west of Havana. The French transport Darien immediately left to assist in getting her off. Yesterday a report spread that the frigate had been saved, but I could trace it to no reliable source.

The People's Convention of those opposed to any further extension of the exclusive privileges of the Camden and Amboy Railroad Company, met in this city to-day. There were but few persons present. At 2 o'clock the convention was called to order.

To the People of the State of New-York: A call has been made by the General Government upon this State for an assigned quota of troops, in addition to those previously furnished, to recruit the ranks of the Federal armies. As the circumstances attendant upon this demand have been such as to excite much popular feeling, I deem it proper to address you officially upon the subject.

There is as great disappointment in London among the Tory writers at the settlement of the difficulties with Brazil, as there would be among a herd of Mackerelville rowdies at the breaking up of a prize fight.

In the Senate, yesterday, a petition was presented for public markets in Brooklyn. Notice was given of a bill for the completion of Harlem Bridge. A bill was introduced for the better prevention of fraudulent voting. A bill was passed to perfect the amendment of the Constitution, by providing for the appointment of five Commissioners of Appeals.

The country will be glad to learn that Mr. FERNANDO WOOD, of this city, has introduced a resolution into the House of Representatives to the effect, that it is the duty of the President, under no circumstances, to proffer or accept negotiations which shall admit, by the remotest implication, the existence of any other Federal or Confederate Government within the territory of the United States.
The steamer Hardy, from New-Orleans, the 25th ult., has arrived with a large number of passengers, most of whom left the Department of the Gulf in consequence of Gen. CANBY'S draft order.

Natchez letters state that Gen. DAVIDSON, since assuming command of that district, has extended his lines on the roads leading our of that city, so as to protect several plantations, and all troops are now encamped outside of the city.

The recent decision of the Supreme Court of the United States in the case of the Bank of the Commonwealth against the Tax Commissioners of NewYork, will have a most important bearing on the financial condition of the city.

Richard Casey pleaded guilty to forgery in the fourth degree, and was brought up yesterday for sentence. As the prisoner was only eighteen years old, and this was his first offence, the Court took compassion on him and suspended judgment.
The Gold Room ranged about the same yesterday as on Wednesday 205 @203 @205 . Gov ernment Stocks steady; the railway speculation dull, Money easy.

Deserters report HOOD as manoeuvring to get KIRBY SMITH's forces east of the Mississippi; but that is simply an impossibility, if anything like vigilance is displayed by our gunboats on that stream. Great vigilance. I feel confident, to continually exercised, so that any one who has been annoyed by apprehensions on that score, may sleep contented in the assurance that the rebels west of the Father of Waters will remain there.
A bill of more than local interest was passed to its second reading in the Canadian House of Assembly fon Tuesday.

ARCHIBALD BAXTER, C. H.P. BABCOCK and FRANK LATHROP.
The announcement that the rebel Peace Commissioners had arrived within our lines, and had gone to Washington, although premature, was not without foundation in fact.

The Army and Navy Journal for this week contains, in full, the elaborate report of the Naval Committee appointed to consider and report on the subject of rifle cannon for the navy. The report is dated Washington, Jan. 18, 1865. The committee find that 703 Parrot guns of all calibres, have been issued to the naval service, and that of these twentyone have burst or been otherwise injured by explosion.

The President and Secretary of State have gone to meet the emissaries from Richmond. If their only errand is to insist on independence, probably they will have leave to return at once to their own capital.

Mr. MARSHALL, of the New-York Chamber of Commerce, arrived here this morning with the testimonial to Vice-Admiral FABRAGUT, consisting of $50,000 in 7-30 United States bonds, contributed by the merchants and business men of New-York. Mr. MARSHALL presented the box containing the bonds in a neat and appropriate speech, and the Admiral made a most felicitous acknowledgment of the substantial token of regard for his eminent services.

A lively debate occurred in the Senate, this morning, on the question of adopting the resolution concurring in the action of Congress in relation to the proposed amendment of the Constitution of the United States. The resolution was adopted, after some able speeches had been made, both for and against its passage.

The Committee of Supervisors from New-York have been engaged all day with the War Department in regard to the draft. They have succeeded thus far in getting a reduction in the State of twenty-five per cent., but the Committee think that there ought to be a further reduction, and are earnestly endeavoring to bring it about.

For the first time since the war commenced we now have what may fairly be called a Peace Conference. Not a word has ever been directly exchanged between our Government and the rebel authorities concerning peace. The little communication which has taken place on the subject has all been the irresponsible work of private parties, officious not official, tolerated rather than sanctioned.

The Assembly passed to-day the resolution concurring in the proposed amendment of the Constitution of the United States. There was a brief discussion of the resolution before its adoption, not permitted to extend to any great length. The firing of cannon announces, as I am writing, that NewYork has spoken in favor of Freedom.

In another column we publish a letter from Provost-Marshal-Gen. FRY to Gen. HINCKS, of this city, in explanation of the draft. It is long and somewhat intricate, though this is due mainly to the nature of the subject; but it will be found to furnish a complete vindication of the Provost-Marshal-General from the sweeping charges of injustice and incompetency in which some of our own authorities have so freely indulged.

Congress, in passing the Constitutional Amendment for the abolition of slavery, has removed what has generally been regarded as a formidable obstacle to the termination of the war. Hitherto, the express abandonment of slavery by the South has always been deemed essential to peace. The country could never consent to leave the cause and root of the rebellion untouched.

family of the late CHARLES GOODYEAR have petitioned Congress for a further extension of the celebrated patent for vulcanizing india-rubber. MILITARY CONFIRMATIONS. The Senate Committee on Military Affairs, at their meeting to-day, reported a large number of military officers of various grades for confirmation. None of the Paymasters, Quartermasters or Commissaries have yet been acted upon. They are undergoing investigation before a sub-committee.

The following coal schooners arrived here today: Sarah J. Bright, C.E. Elmer, Maggie van Dusen ans Sophia Ann, all of Philadelphia. For some time past coal has been a very scarce article here, but as navigation is now open, the supply will be equal to the demand here.

The Senate Committee on Cities and Villages had the bill for the reorganization of the New-York and Brooklyn Fire Department, under the paid system, up for consideration, and large delegations from the city, for and against it, were in attendance.

A sudden and unexpected demonstration by the Army of the Potomac was begun on Sunday last. On the morning of that day the Fifth Corps, preceded by Gen. GREGG'S cavalry division, took up its line of march for Reams' Station and by noon. had reached Rowanty Creek, over which a bridge was construted.

The Senate yesterday took up a bill relating to postal laws. The bill contains seventeen sec tions, a full summary of which will be found in the proceedings of Congress. It is said to have the approval of the Postmaster-General. At 1 o'clock the Senate received a message from the House, that that body was really to proceed with the counting of the Presidential vote.

THE SUFFOCATION CASE. Coroner LYNCH held an inquest on the body of the infant. MYRON VAN BUREN, who died on the 3d inst., in consequence of inhaling gas at No. 228 Washington-street. The evidence showed that the room was without ventilation, and that the damper of the stove had been turned off, thus forcing the gas into the room. A verdict in accordance was rendered. The remainder of the family are getting well.

A large fire commenced about 3 o'clock this morning in the coal oil works on Ninth and Federal streets. About fifty dwellings have been consumed, occupying two squares on both sides of Ninthstreet, besides a few on Federal and Wharton streets. Several lives are reported lost.

A measure of far-reaching influence and importance to the colored race and to the country comes up before Congress to-day Mr. ELIOT'S bill for the establishment of a "Freedmen's Bureau," or, in other words, of a separate department of Government, controlling the interests of millions of human beings in the future.

The Committee on Cities have just been giving another hearing in the Senate Chamber to those interested in the Fire Department of New-York. Mr. HICKMAN, one of the trustees of the department, who spoke last night, continued his argument this morning, and replied to what had been said against the department. He spoke at some length of the firemen's fund for orphans and its benefits. Engineer DECKER and others made remarks.
The Committee on Cities and Villages again took up the Metropolitan Fire District Bill this afternoon.

Stocks were unsettled: Governments active and higher; the fancies less freely dealt in, and lower and irregular. Produce and Merchandise were less sought after, though prices favored buyers. Arabella Robinson was tried in this court yesterday, for grand larceny, in stealing $300, in Treassury notes. The exidence was found to be insufficient, and the prosecution was abandoned.

The news from the Army of the Potomac is not yet definite as to the object or results of the new movement. The Second and Fifth Corps obtained a well-advanced position on Sunday, and held it, despite the efforts of the enemy to dislodge them.
The recent annual address of Mr. MCLEAN, President of the Board of Education, presents some most important statements on the want of school accommodation in our city.

Luther A. Tibbetts vs. Horatio N. Twombley. The trial of this cause was concluded yesterday morning.

There appears, from the debates in Congress on the Enrollment Act, as well as from much of the discussion which takes place out of doors, to be a strong disposition prevalent to look upon a man who chances to be drafted, as something very like a criminal, and treat him accordingly.

The N.Y. State Agricultural Society held their annual meeting at noon to-day in the Assembly Chamber, the President, JAMES O. SHELDON, in the chair. The attendance is large and the report shows the Society to be in a flourishing condition, the balance in the Treasury amounting to over $7,000. The following were elected officers for the ensuing year: President, T.C. PETERS, of Geneses.

The result of yesterday's engagement appeared this morning in our advanced lines beyond Hatcher's Run, the capture of about two hundred prisoners, a train of wagons and mules, with their drivers, and considerable loss inflicted on the enemy in killed and wounded. The cavalry under Gen. GREGG captured the train at Dinwiddie Court-house, while on its way to North Carolina for supplies, the trip taking, as the drivers say, sixteen days for its accomplishment.

The declaration of the Richmond papers to the effect that the South is ready to become abolitionist, as well as the North, has been seized upon with eagerness by the French rebel press, as a pretext for urging recognition. Even the official journal prints prominently and menacingly in its columns, at least sufficiently so to give great courage to the Secessionists here, this declaration of the Richmond journals about abolition for recognition.

The United States double-ender Chenango, nine guns and 974 tons burden, sails to-day for Port Royal, to perform blockade duty. It will be remembered than her boilers burst in our harbor last year, since which time she has been undergoing extensive repairs in her machinery at the Morgan Iron Works.

The fight near Hatcher's Run, yesterday, was one of the most severe that has taken place in this army for some time, and taking into consideration the unfavorable condition of the country through which the troops had to move, and the large force opposing their advance, it is not strange that the enemy should gain a temporary advantage.
The Legislature yesterday rejected the proposed amendment to the Constitution, by a three-fourths vote in the Senate and a two-thirds vote in the House.

The message of President LINCOLN, giving the details of the peace conference, was not sent in to Congreess yesterday, as was generally expected. It will probably be sent in to-day. The Richmond papers of Tuesday contain a message from JEFF. DAVIS, communicating to the rebel Congress the report of the rebel commissioners, which we give elsewhere.

Yesterday Mr. CLARK, of New-Hampshire, was elected temporary Chairman of the Senate during the absence of the Vice-President. A bill was reported back from the Military Committee for the better organization of the Army Pay Department.

The question of removing the State Capital is coming to be discussed in right-down earnest, for present emergencies have so taken hold of the pockets and convenience of members as to force a consideration of the subject, with reference to determined and timely solution.

No news was received at the War Department last night from South Carolina. It was currently reported, however, that SHERMAN'S army had made a lodgment on the railroad between Branchville and Augusta. A project is now before the Assembly, and appears to be progressing favorably, which contemplates establishing a State foundry at the Clinton Prison. But it ought to have a closer scrutiny than it has yet received. If it does not meet with more attention, it will prove a Pandora box from which will come an innumerable flock of expensive experiments and experiences.

The latest Richmond papers, just received, contain an announcement of the capture of Branch- ville. The possession of this important point isolates both Augusta and Charleston, and will necessitate the immediate evacuation of the latter place, Richmond papers of the same date also admit the complete success of GRANT'S recent movement.

PHELAN, KAVANAGH and others assembled at Irving Hall last evening, to witness the return of the home-and-home match between these expert junior players, MELVIN FOSTER, of this city, and JOHN DEERY, of Washington.

Col. BAKER'S men discovered a large number of spurious certificate of enlistment, yesterday, on board the steamer North Carolina. These they seized, and took to the Astor House, and there they way be examined by any supervisor or other person who may had been cheated by the bounty-brokers.

The second annual ball of the Italian Benevolent Society, held at Irving Hall on last Friday evening, was one of the most brilliant and fashionable of the season. The decorations were beautiful, and in excellent taste. On the stage was an arch, bearing the name of the society, on the right of which hung in graceful folds the Stars and Stripes, and on the left the national colors of Italy green, white and red.

There is a strong feeling of opposition to federation in the maritime colonies.

The subject of last evening's address was " The influence of Climate." The lecturer introduced his subject by a comprehensive review of the steady advancement of civilization.

Two distinct things are to be learned from the language with which the rebel leaders follow up the failure of the Peace Conference. First, that their spirit of rebellion is as stubborn as ever; and, second, that they are conscious that popular support would fail them without grossest deception.

The Gold Room fell about 6.79 cent, on Saturday. Government Stocks were higher. The Railways opened firm, but fell off late in the day.

Senator HICKS, of Maryland, was stricken with paralysis of the left side on Friday last, and is now entirely prostrated by it. He has been confined at his hotel in Washington for some time, under the charge of Dr. WILLARD BLISS, the eminent surgeon in charge of Armory-square Hospital.

The past week was an exceedingly prosperous one at the Academy of Musle. We have rarely witnessed a succession of finer houses, or heard more general expressions of satisfaction. It was essentially a week of revivals. Beginning with "H. Trevatore" on Monday last, it ended with "La Traviata" on Friday.

The only excitement for the moment in France is the Encyclical letter of the Pope. But even this is rapidly passing from the stage of excitement into that of a bore, and the gamins in the street instead of saying, "Tu m'ennure!" now say, "Tu m'encycliques!" Such a phrase is enough to kill even a more vital question than this, and we may hope soon to hear no more of it.

The Gold Room partially recovered from the heavy fall of Saturday early on yesterday, but the speculation was without decided spirit. Government Stocks steady. The Railway shares decidedly better than at the close on Saturday.

The rebel authorities have lately made an unpleasant discovery. They have just found out that Mr. MEMMINGER, when going out of the Treasury Department, neglected to mention to his successor a little debt of four hundred millions which he happened to have on hand.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The indisposition of Milo. ZUCCHI compelled Mr. MARETZEK to change the opera last evening. Instead of "Ernani," which was announced, the acceptable substitute of "Faust" was given. The house was very good, and the pleasure of those who were in it seemed to be undisturbed. It is unnecessary to speak of the performance. To-night " Fra Diavolo" will be given for the last time.

From information received through a high official source, it may be safely announced that the draft, which was to have taken place to-morrow, will probably be postponed. The reasons for the change in the governmental programme are such as have been recently developed, and have no reference to the original plan for filling the ranks of depleted regiments, or the President's proclamation for a draft.

Everything indicates a general move of THOMAS' whole army. It is supposed he is going down the Mississippi.

O'BRIEN, FARLEY and McKNIGHT, met in the Chamber of the Board, yesterday, for the purpose of considering the advisability of framing an ordinance, forbidding, the storage of petroleum and other inflammable oils within the city limits, except in small quantities.
Mr. JOHNSON, of Maryland, (Dem.,) announced the death of Senator HICKS from that State, and concluded his remarks by offering the customary resolutions of respect.

The resolution providing for an adjournment from Friday, the 17th inst., to the 23d inst., has passed both houses of the Legislature, There is a pressure to push business forward as far as possible befor this vacation. The friends and advocates of many schemes are here from New-York City.

The subscriptions to the Popular 7.30 cent. Loan in this City yesterday were very large exceeding two and a half millions. The Gold Room was 3 cent, lower than on Tuesday. The Railways left off lower, and the speculation tame at the close of the day.
The steamship North American, Capt. KERR, which left Liverpool on the evening of the 2d inst., and Greencastle on the 3d, arrived at Portland at 6:45 this evening with 121 passengers.

Brig.-Gen. FESSENDEN, commander of this post since the 1st of January last, starts North to-morrow on a short leave of absence. During his stay the duties of Post-Commandant will be discharged by Col. CURRY, of the One Hundred and Thirty-third NewYork Volunteers.

The Board of Officers to investigate and report upon the cause of the explosion of the magazine in Fort Fisher, have made their report to Gen. TERRY. The opinion of the board is that the explosion was the result of carelessness on the part of persons to them unknown. It appears from the finding:...

CITY NOTES.--The Savannah cotton fleet has not arrived, though the steamers that should have convoyed the fleet are here....Miss SUSANNAH EVANS Will deliver a lecture on temperance, this evening, at the Free Will Baptist Church, in Twenty-eighth-street, near Broadway....The annual celebration of the birthday of WASHINGTON, by the pupils of the...

The proceedings of the board at the meeting last evening were unusually Interesting. The board was called to order by President McLEAN at 5 0'clock, and the following-named gentlemen answered as their names were called: Commissioners Adams, Brennan, Bogert, Dupignac, Farr, Fairchild, Horan, Heath, Hayes, Hitchman, Hastle, Maher, Murray, Miller, McSpedon, Neilson, O'Donnold, Pertey, Turner, Tuthill, Nance and West.
The steamship Europa, from Liverpool on the 4th, via Queenstown on the 5th inst., arrived at this port at 12 o'clock this (Thursday) noon. Her dates are one day later than those already received.

The steamship Europa arrived at Halifax, yesterday, from Liverpool on the 4th and Queenstown on the 5th, bringing one day's later news. GOLDWIN SMITH argues a peace in America through the separate action of the rebel States.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The complete recovery of Mme. ZUCCHI enable the managers to announce with certainty the performance of " Ernani" tonight. This favorite work has not been played here for many months. The distribution is unusually strong.
CANON, the rebel messenger from Richmond, arrived here yesterday, and was examined before the court.
The English mail-steamer Eider, which arrived from Vera Cruz a few days ago, brings news from Mexico up to the 31st ult.

Late news from KIRBY SMITH'S army says his troops are very much scattered, for the purpose of obtaining food and forage, and it would be impossible to concentrate them in any force during the present season, in consequence of insufficient transportation.

The Board of the City Fire Department held a meeting on Tuesday evening, to protest against the movement now in progress at Albany for the abolition of the existing organization, and the substitution of a small paid department. The speakers were very energetic in their defence of the present system, and declared it to be their intention to contest the passage of the bill now before the Legislature to the last.

The rebel raiders in Canada are endeavoring to prove to the satisfaction of the Canadian courts that they acted under regular Confederate authority in their demonstrations upon St. Albans and other towns in Vermont. They have produced their commissions, issued in due form by C. C. CLAY, who was in Canada ...

Professor GOLDWIN SMITH, in the London Daily News, controverts the opinions of a Manchester paper, and urges that although a compromise with the slave oligarchy is impossible, it is possible that at no distant time negotiations may be hopefully commenced with separate States over which the oligarchy of Richmond is losing its usurped power.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows a decrease of over three and a half millions of francs in cash.

Official dispatches from Gen. SHERMAN were received in Washington yesterday, and though announcing the successful inauguration of the South Carolina campaign, they do not contain news so late as that received through the Richmond papers, which report that on the 11th inst. a column of SHERMAN'S infantry and cavalry crossed the Edisto to the west of and above Branchville, and advanced on the Columbia Branch Railroad.

The "Confederate Commissioner" in London, Mr. MASON, of Virginia, has published in the English papers a very long letter about the barbarous treatment of Union prisoners in the South. The facts are too patent and too well authenticated to be directly denied by Mr. MASON; but he attempts to palliate some of the rebel atrocities, such as starving our prisoners, by asserting that our armies

Information from the Army of the Potomac states that the dispatch of the 10th instant announcing the execution of JAMES L. HICKS was a mistake, as his sentence until suspended by the President until further orders.
The Republican has a special dispatch from Cairo giving the following important intelligence:

In the senate, yesterday, the bill providing for a public parade-ground in this city was passed, among the bills introduced were the following Authorizing the consolidation of certain railroad companies in New-York; for a railroad in Broadway; for a railroad in Christopher and other

Our suburbs are again threatened by small bands of Confederate cavalry. This afternoon about four hundred men, supposed to be under the commend of Col. WITHERS, made their appearance at the Murfreesboro Pike, about six miles from the town, and captured several wood choppers and Government employee, among them Capt. STEVENS of the Quartermaster's Department.

For the benefit of the anxious sufferers of consumption. I make the following statement, and attach the testimonial of my physician and neighbors, so those who may read it may rely on the facts I am about to state:...

Mr. DAWES, of Massachusetts, (Union,) from the Committee on Elections, reported a resolution to admit Mr. A.P. FIELD to a seat from the Second, and Mr. MANN from the Third Congressional District of Louisiana.

Both Houses of Congress have passed the bill providing for the establishment of a steamship line across the North Pacific Ocean, from San Francisco to China. They have done well in so doing. The necessity of the line as a means of postal and commercial intercourse, is apparent; and the terms on which it has been established are eminently favorable at once to the enterprise and to the Government.

Mr. TOLMAN to-day introduced a bill providing for a more certain and speedy mode of cleaning the streets in the above cities, and also a more economical and certain plan whereby the expenditures for the same may be reduced.

The great military problem is hastening day by day to its solution. The toils are slowly, but inextricably tightening about the rebel General and his array in Virginia. Gen. SHERMAN is cutting his distant line of supplies, and, when Charleston is reduced, will be steadily advancing toward the grand concentration of the National armies in Virginia, and destroying as he marches the very sources of LEE's commissariat.
The American has a special dispatch from Annapolis, which is as follows:

Richmond papers of the 16th inst. have been received here. The Richmond Dispatch contains the following: There was a cannonade of several hours' duration on our left, near the Appomattox, on Wednesday evening. With this exception, nothing of moment occured. On the Petersburgh lines picket firing has, by tacit consent of both parties, very much slackened within the past few days.

It is now a little more than six years ago that I first saw Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS, then United States Senator from Mississippi, now the head and leader of this great rebellion. We were fellow-passengers on one of those magnificent packets that, in the palmy days of union and peace, plied a lucraitve trade between NewOrleans and the towns on the Mississippi River.

Mr. FARLEY offered a preamble and resolutions to the effect that whereas the Legislature has invited proposals from various cities for a site for a State Capital; and, whereas, New-York is eminently fitted for being the political as well as commercial capital of the State, and would be Greatly benefited by the location here of the State Government

A prospectus has been issued of the Telegraphic News Association, with a capital of 100,000, in shares of 10, of which one-half is already subscribed. The enterprise is understood to be promoted by parties of character and position, with the ability to render it efficient and trustworthy, and in any case it will be an advance to the commercial public to see competition introduced into this ...

The Inman new screw steamship City of Boston arrived in the Mersey from the Clyde yesterday, and will form a valuable addition to the numerous and handsome fleet of vessels belonging to the Liverpool, New-York and Philadelphia Steamship Company. For strength, speed, and beauty probably the City of boston cannot be excelled, although she may be ...

GRANT to Secretary STANTON containing extracts from the Richmond papers of yesterday give the cheering news that SHERMAN has captured Columbia, South Carolina, and is there with his whole army. S MACFARLANE, an agent of the London Missionary Society, the oppressive proceedings adopted under the authority of the French Governor of New Careconfa upon the Protestant missionaries and the native Protestant Christians in the Island of Lifu, South Pacific. Gen. J.a. McCLERNAND has written a letter ex- pressing his gratification at the passage of the Constitutional amendment through Congress. He says:

One of the Montreal papers, which boasts itself the organ of the Southern Confederacy, states that two gentlemen of the rebel "persuasion," now in Montreal, have on deposit in the banks of that place no less a sum than $2,300,000. It calls to mind the fact also that the money belonging to the refugees, which they have with them in Canada, amounts in the aggregate to a large amount.

The steamship Europa, from Liverpool on the 4th inst. and Queenstown on the 5th, arrived at Boston early yesterday morning. Her mails reached this city at midnight. From the London Times of Feb. 2 we copy the following:

The following resolutions were adopted by the Connecticut Union State Conversion at its recent session: Resolved, That we have undiminished confidence in the ability, integrity and patriotism of ABRAHAM LINCOLN, and rejoice in his reelection.

There are at present very excellent prospects o serious trouble with Mexico, which will be hailed with delight by our people generally, if we are capable of judging of the state of public feeling. Gen MEJIA, the Mexican commander at Matamoras, na issued an order directing his subordinates to return to the rebel authorities refugees found upon Mexican soil. MEJIA claims to be acting under authority from MAXIMILIAN.

GENERAL ORDERS, No.1. 1. The Major General, with the approbation of the Commander-in-Chief, hereby prescribes for this Division the System of Inantry Tactics of Brig.-Gen. WM.H. MORRIS, United States Volunteers.

The royal mail steamship Australasian, on her last arrival in Liverpool from New-YorK, brought the intelligence of the grounding of the ship herself, outside the channel, about twenty miles below NewYork, on the morning of Wednesday, the 11th of January, about 8 o'clock, but the bare fact only was stated.
A resolution introduced into the Louisiana Legislature, expressing regret for the assault of Mr. FIELD on Judge KELLY, in Washington, was tabled by a vote of 55 against 7.

The House of Representatives yesterday passed the amended Internal Revenue Act, embodying some very important changes in the tax laws. The amendment taxing sales one and a half per centum was stricken out by a vote of 65 in favor of the tax to 75 against it. The House refused to increase the tax on beer and ale from $1 to $1.50 per barrel. Among the amendments adopted were the following in

A public meeting was held at the Academy of Music last evening, in aid of the "Patriot-Orphan Home," located at Flushing, L.I. The capacious edifice was filled by a select and intellectual audience, which expressed its sympathy with the object in behalf of which the meeting was convened, by frequently applauding the speakers.

LETTER FROM THE PRESIDENT. Last summer, af- ter the public exhibition in this city of Mr. W.T. CARLTON'S very merritorious painting, entitled "Watchthe Hour of Emancipation under the President's Proclamation of Jan. l, 1865 It was deemed eminently fitting that it should be purchased by subscription, and presented to President LINCOLN, as a mark

Advices have been received from San Domingo to the 29th of December last. Up to that date the news of the action of the Spanish Government on the San Domingo question had not been received by the Dominicans, and fighting was still actively carried on.

Last evening, the two great cabinet and piano manufactories, Nos. 176 and 178 Wooster-street, were destroyed by fire, the upper portion of Public School building No. 10, at No. 180 Wooster-street, was considerably damaged, and the roof of Mrs. MONROE'S dwelling, at No. 174, was crushed in by falling walls.

The question of most interest on the subject of fashion for this month is the style in vogue for ball and evening dress. Among the novelties we remark robes of gauze embroidered in gold, or silver, or silk. Nothing is prettier than such flowers on a light, vapory material, and ladies of elegance can wear such a dress without appearing to be dressed in too simple or girlish a manner.

The Aldermanic Committee on Ordinances held an adjourned session Friday, to consider the subject of framing an ordinance forbidding the storage of petroleum within the city limits, except in small quantities. The trade was well represented, about twenty of the largest dealers being present.

On Saturday two young "women," apparently about 20 years old, were arrested by Commissioner KIRKPATRICK, at the instigatiion of the ladies of the Soldiers' Aid Society, to whom they had applied for transportation to Washington, on suspicion that one of them was a man, which on examination proved to be the case. They gave their names as CHARLOTTE ANDERSON AND EMMA.

Our Legislature has voted to adjourn on Thursday next, and the people say amen. The Republi- cans, although they have been enabled to carry through a few important public measures, have not gained much credit by having a majority in that "honorable body." The "Black Laws" have been erased from our statute books, and the Constitutional Amendment has been ratified; but upon other matters the Legislature has behaved shamefully.
Further details received by the last arrival from Vera Cruz show that fighting between the Juar sts and Imperialists is actively carried on in the interior of the country.

City passenger railroads are a kind of close corporations; very little is known about them except to the persons connected with them. The public see the immense number of cars which are employed on all the roads, and make their estimates accordingly of the business of the companies. These are more or less correct according to the means at command to base such calculations upon. But

This city has been shaken by a calamity unparalleled in its history. The explosion of nearly two tons of gunpowder, in the Retiro Barracks, on the morning of the 9th inst., threw a large building high in the air, and carried out the mutilated forms of near one hundred men, women and children. It was at 7 A.M., and a portion of the regiment had just come in from its early exercise.

The steamship George Cromwell, VATAL, from New-Orleans fifth, at 8 A.M., via Southwest Pass same day at 8 P.M., with mails, merchandise and passengers to H.B. CROMWELL Co., arrived at this port yesterday.

A gentleman who has just arrived here, directly from Shreveport, informs Gen. WASHBURN of affairs in the Trans-Mississippi Department. This informant left Memphis two months since for Huntsville, Texas, and has returned to our lines at this place, via Shreveport and Camden. I am permitted to send you some information which he brings.
Amherst. The freshmen class, which entered since the religious interests, has a smaller proportion of candidates for the ministry than any class in the history of college.

The Eighth Ward Pioneer Clay Club held its twenty-sixth annual ball Friday evening at the City Assembly Rooms. The hall was thronged by a brilliant assemblage, not less than one thousand people

The steamer Ariadne arrived here to-day from Fort Fisher. The Captain of the steamer reports that our forces had expected to make an attack upon Fort Anderson on the 13th instant, but failed for some cauee unknown to him. Before he left Fort Fisher he saw a bright light in the direction of Fort Anderson, and the supposition was that it had been abandoned and burnt by the rebels.
The French Government denies, no doubt with entire sincerity, all complicity in the affair of the Olinda.
The European mail last night brought us the conclusion of the trial of one RUMBLE, an officer in the British naval service, for a violation of the Foreign Enlistment act of the United Kingdom.
From late Denver papers we learn that considerable excitement prevails in Colorado, especiality at D-over, on account of the Indian hostilities.
The Senatorial Investigating Committee met on Saturday, when the Comptroller's Department was made the subject of investigation.

The authorities of Princeton, N.J., have voted to give every man drafted from that place, and who shall enter the service, a bond for $1,000; also levy a tax of $10 upon every person liable to conscription and $5 upon those not liable.
Capt. GRIST, Commissary on Gen. SHERIDAN'S Staff, went to Newtown, to-day, and distributed ten days' rations for five hundred persons.
Fire hundred and fifty bales and one hundred and fifty bags of cotton have arrived for St. Louis, and three hundred for Cincinnati.
From a gentleman who arrived on a special train last night, we gather the annexed news.

Dispatches from Gen. GRANT to Secretary STANTON, containing extracts from the Richmond papers of Saturday, give the cheering news that SHERMAN has captured Columbia, South Carolina, and is there with his whole army.

In the United States Senate on Saturday, Mr. MORGAN introduced a bill authorizing the giving of bounties to honorably discharged soldiers, who have already served two years, the same as are now allowed for three years' service, and entitles the heirs of such soldiers, if dead, to the same bounty.
Information has been received from the Army of the James, dated 17th.

CHARLES WINDSOR, late paying teller in the Mercantile Bank of this city, who absconded on the 28th of October last, and sailed for Europe the day following, was arrested last December by the Sheriff of Middlesex, England, and on the 3d last, was brought up at Bow-street, London, on a writ of habers corpus, directed to the governor of Whitecross Prison, to answer to a charge of forgery.
Advices from Chilli say that on and after May 1 the coasting trade of that country will be thrown open to vessels of every nation. This will have the effect to increase commerce with San Francisco.

Would it not be a good idea for all our managers to reverse the order of their performances; to begin, for instance, at 1 o'clock in the afternoon instead of 8 o'clock in the evening? The critics, who always place themselves first because every one else places them last, will not object; and the public, if we may judge by the experiment of Saturday, would be delighted. DIED IN THE CELLS.--Coroner FARREBL, of Jersey City, held an inquest yesterday on the body of a man named JAMES O'NEIL, who was found in the streets suffering from delirium tremens. He was taken to the Station-house and medical aid was procured: but he died soon after being admitted.

The court-room was thronged yesterday morning, in anticipation of the sentence of Friary, but the District Attorney stated that he should not move for judgement in that case unfit to-day, and he desired to notify prisoner's counsel to that effect. A large number of prisoners, against whom indictments have been found during the last week, were arraigned, and their pleas taken.

A brief but very satisfactory dispatch from Admiral DAHLGREN, dated Charleston Harbor, Feb. 18, announces that the enemy had abandoned Charleston, and that he was then on his way to take possession of the deserted and desolated city.

Information from the Army of the Potomac late as yesterday morning, reports all quiet. Deserters are constantly coming in, and are more numerous than for a long time. They have averaged over seventy a day for the past week. Among them several officers.

The telegraph operator at Weldon reported on yesterday that a raid from Washington or Newbern, N.C., was in progress, the supposed destination of the raiders being Rocky Mount Station, on the Wilmington Road, is Edgecomb County. The wires continued to work during yesterday evening through to Wilmington however, from which it would appear that they had not struck the road.

The march of Gen. SHERMAN through South Carolina is attended with none of the ravage predicted by all the rebels, and hoped for by many loyal men. So far as can be gathered from the few general facts that have reached us, our army is displaying no vindictive spirit whatever.

Measured by its effect upon the heart and temper of the loyal people of these States, there is probably no victory of the war that can be compared with that which was won by the stubborn valor of our troops on the 16th day of February, 1862.

we have used with such ability as we possessed the military and naval resources of the country in carrying this great war to the end, which we now appear to see shaping itself in no distant future, there have been many instances where the fate of the Republic has temporarily, at least, depended upon slight contingencies which could hardly have been foreseen much less prevented.

In compliance with the order of Assistant ProvostMarshal-General HINKS, the draft began yesterday morning in the Second and Third Congressional Districts. In the Second District Provost-Marshal WALDRON, at No. 29 Grand-street, E. D., set his wheel in motion at about 10 o'clock, in the presence of a large crowd who did not allow their fear of conscription to affect their good nature.

Three to four hundred Petroleum Bills (some days to 2400 a day) have passed, the Legislature reserving the power to amend or repeal the charters, limiting their existence to 30 years, and taxing each company $100 in advance. The corporations are no prohibited from running, after 30 years, railroads made by them under chartered grants; but nothing to prevent the Legislature's making railroads parallel with or crossing the corporations'.

pondent of the Goldsboro (N.C.,) Journal has been getting information about the "Yankees " at Newbern, in a way that carries us back to the earlier part of the war, when "reliable gentlemen" saw the New-York "Fire Zouaves" spring like wildcats on the backs of the Virginia "Black Horse Cavalry," when the latter were going full speed, and cut the throats of the riders in a horrible manner.
The City of Charleston is in the possession of the Union forces. The last of the rebel troops, consisting of about one brigade, left at 6 o'clock this morning.

An official dispatch from Gen. GILLMORE states that Charleston fell into our possession on the morning of the 18th inst., with over two hundred pieces of artillery, (another account says that all the guns were spiked), and a supply of ammunition. The surrounding defences having been evacuated during the previous night by the rebel forces, the Mayor surrendered the city to the troops of Gen. SCHIMELFENING, who at once took possession.
The steamship Nova Scotian, Capt. WYLIE, from Liverpool on the 9th, via Greencastle on the 10th inst., arrived at Portland at 10:15 o'clock yesterday morning.

The Times Paris correspondent says: "When the French Minister, Count MERCIER, was recalled from Washington, the Americans were led to understand that no new agent would be accredited until President LINCOLN should have recognized the Emperor of Mexico.
Some new facts have come to light in regard to the escape of the Confederate ram Olinda.

The announcement that Bernard Friary would be sentenced yesterday attracted an immense crowd to the Court of Sessions. Every one who had influence enough to pass the stern guardians of the outer door crowded into the room, and gratified a morbid curiosity by staring at the prisoner. Friary was brought to the bar about 11 o'clock, and took a scat between Mr. Sedgwick and Judge Stewart, his counsel.

PEACE MEMORIAL. Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, (Union,) from the Military Committee, reported back the memorial of ANDREW J. WILCOX, of Baltimore, asking that peace be made on the basis of the Crittenden Compromise. The Committee unanimously concurred in asking to be discharged from the further consideration of the subject, and it was so ordered.

The following official notice bas been promulgated, dated: DEPARTMENT OF STATE, Washington, Feb. 21, 1865. "The Department Building will be illuminated on the night of WASHINGTON'S Birthday in honor of the recent triumphs of the Union.
It is rumored that the British Admiralty contemplates the reduction of the Coast Guard service, owing to the policy of disarmament among the Continental Governments.

HATOH'S line on the coast, bringing, the pleasing report that the left wing had struck the Charleston and Augusta Railroad at midway. A salute of 100 guns was fired here to-day in honor of the occupation of Charleston by our forces.

This double-ender steamed out of the harbor yesterday at 11:15 A.M., having repaired her rudder chain, which broke down when she set out from the Philadelphia Navy-yard, about three weeks since, for the Gulf Squadron. She carries 10 guns, is 1,030 tons burden, and was built at New-York in 1864. She is under the command of Commander SHIRLEY.

Mr. O'NEIL, of Pennsylvania, (Union,) introduced a bill, accompanied by a petition, repealing so much of the act of May, 1864, which regulates the admeasurement of tonnage of ships and vessels, as applies to any canal-boat without masts or steam power, now by law required to be registered, licensed or enrolled and licensed. The bill was referred to the Committee on Commerce.

THE SECRETARYSHIP OF THE TREASURY. GOV. MORGAN positively refuses to accept the office of Secretary of the Treasury, although his personal and political friends have urged it upon him, as a matter alike of interest and of duty. The President has been especially anxious on the subject, and has had one or two long interviews with him in regard to it. Mr. MORGAN'S reasons for declining are wholly personal, but with him they are conclusive.

Twenty-five years after the death of the writer, appears the first authentic collection of his poetical remains. It seems to have been retarded by the illness and death of Mr. PRAED'S widow, as well as by the desire to make the edition as perfect as existing materials would admit.

We published, some days since, a British Order in Council in relation to rules of navigation on the inland waters of this continent. We desire to call attention to one subject which was embraced within those rules, viz.: that of the lights to be carried at night by vessels navigating those waters.

The Richmond papers announce that Virginia has determined to give its able-bodied slaves to the military service of the Confederacy. It has cost the public mind of the State tremendous throes to come to this. Desperation alone has made it possible. A very peculiar desperation, too.
The NEW-YORK WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office, in wrappers, ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS.

The condition of the streets is simply horrible. We have had four or five days of as fine February weather as the present generation has seen. Yesterday, as far as a genial sunshine, and a healthy breeze go to constitute a luxury for holiday-makers, was one of the most charming days that imagination could well paint.

The Senate Investigating Committee resumed the examination of the City Inspector's Department on Tuesday morning. Ex-Judge WHITING appeared for the Citizens' Association, and JOHN GRAHAM acted as council for Mr. BOOLE, City Inspector.
Yesterday morning the State Senate Committee continued its investigation of the workings of the City Inspector's Department.
It is rumored and believed that Gen. HURLBURT is preparing to establish the headquarters of the Department of the Gulf at Mobile.

In the Senate yesterday, an adverse report was made by the Committee on Naval Affairs on the petition for an increase in officers pay. A bill to extend to settlers on railroad ands the benefit of the Homestead Act, was reported on adversely.
There is no truth whatever in the sensation reports from Philadelphia regarding an engagement in front of Petersburgh yesterday.

The Richmond writers are of course casting their wits about, them to discover how to defeat the armies that are gathering round LEE. They are sadly puzzled. They never have had anything so difficult in hand.

Our special correspondent with the Army of the Potomac, who arrived yesterday morning at Washington, direct from that army, emphatically denies the truth of the startling report from Philadelphia, stating that Gen. LEE had attacked Gen. GRANT'S army, and that our troops had met with a reverse.
The Aldermanic Committee on Ordinances, who have under consideration the framing of an ordinance regulating the storage and sale of petroleum within the city, met again yesterday.

Spending last Saturday in Washington. I was called to undergo the terrors of that middle passage between Willard's and the Capitol, traversed now by street-cars, which generally are so full that an extra bedbug could scarcely find admission. During the trip I was the witness of a little episode, pleasant to remember and worthy of mention.

The feeling of patriotic rejoicing which has pervaded the North during the past week has no where found more full and fitting expression than here at the capital of this State. I mention this as in some degree in contrast with the tone of feeling manifested in this city, one, and more especially, two Winters ago. No locality of the State is now apparently more loyal than its capital.

In Produce and Merchandise, yesterday's business was quite light, without any remarkable changes in prices of Flour, Grain, Lard, Beef, Butter, Cheese, Cotton or Petroleum. Mess Pork declined 25c.@50c. bbl., and Whisky lc.@2c. gallon. Groceries tended downward. Freights dull.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC PRODUCTION OF "LA. FORZA DEL DESTINO," Mr. MARETZEK fulfilled the most important promise of his early programme last evening, when he offered to his patrons the latest novelty from the pen of Signor VERDI, "La Forza del Destino." In this work, as in " H. Trovatore." "La Traviata," and "Un Ballo in Maschera." we anticipate the verdict of London and Paris; a fact of no importance.

The following official report of the capture of Wilmington has been forwarded to this department by Gen. GRANT:

Many of our peo ple have very unreasonable expectations in regard to the loyalty of the inhabitants in Savan nah and other recaptured cities of the South. They complain that these people at heart do not love the Union a whit better than they did before their towns were taken. Why should they? The mere fact of conquest cannot be expected to change the hearts of those who have been defeated.

The State Assembly, at its yesterday morning's session, passed the direct tax Bounty Bill. The bill is auxiliary to the Bounty Act which originated with the Senate. And it is now understood that all the necessary legislation has been secured to enable the Governor, in concert with the Comptroller and the banks, to obtain at once the necessary funds. This is satisfactory as far as most counties are concerned.

The bounty-brokers have begun to comprehend Col. BAKER'S mission here, and to understand that he is in receipt of information which is deeply interesting to them; and some of the gang, taking their illluck; philosophically, have prepared themselves to receive the Colonel's subordinates, and comply with their demands at a moment's notice.
Honolulu advices represent that extensive preparations are making for cotton culture. The Colony of Mormons is preparing to plant a large quantity in the confident expectation of realizing profit.

The bill creating a new judicial district in this State, comprising the counties on Long Island and Staten Island, has passed both houses of Congress, and yesterday the President nominated CHARLES L. BENEDICT for Judge, B.D. SILLIMAN for District Attorney and A.F. CAMPBELL for Marshal.

It is not Charleston City, but the empty and ruined shell of a city, that the enemy have found lying with its door open, and entered without opposition. The Yankee nation is not particular about its title to boast and vaunt, else it would say very little about its reduction of Charleston.

GOODS IN GOVERNMENT WAREHOUSES. Mr. MORGAN, of New-York, (Union,) presented the petition of the merchants of New-York, asking for an extension of the time for withdrawing goods from Government warehouses, which was referred to the Committee on Finance.

In the Senate, yesterday, notice was given of bills for a Metropolitan Public Conveyance Company; authorizing the Ninth-avenue Railroad Company to extend its tracks; relative to the forclosure of mortgage by advertisement. The following were advanced to a third reading.

In the Senate Mr. SPRAGUE offered a resolution, which was passed, instructing the Committee on Finance to inquire into the expediency of enlarging the powers of the Bureau of Emigration, so as to afford relief to Southern refugees in the Northern States. The Minnesota Railroad Grant Bill was passed. The bill to give a $300 pension to the revolutionary survivors was passed.

Those who have least to say about the matter continue the business of Cabinet-making vigorously; but there is very little foundation for any of the numerous rumors in circulation. Only this much is positively known, viz.: that the President has not yet sent to the Senate the nomination of Mr. McCULLOOH as Secretary of the Treasury, that he will do so is believed by many persons well qualified to judge; including Mr. McCULLOCH himself.
The steamer Robert Burns, from Memphis, had 346 bales of cotton for Cincinnati, and 39 for Evansville.
The commencement exercises of Bellevue Hospital Medical College were held at the Academy of Music, last evening, in the presence of a large audience.

It is to be hoped that the claims of justice and humanity, in behalf of the Government clerks in this city, will not be much longer disregarded. If members of Congress will make a very brief calculation, they will be able to decide how far the present pay goes toward the support of a family.
On Friday, Mr. RUSSELL, from the Select Committee on that subject, reported a Revenue Bill in the House of Representatives.
The Legislative Committee continued its investigations into the City Inspector's Department, yesterday.

Financial embarrassment is probably the rock on which the Narvaez Ministry will suffer shipwreck. Senor BARZANALLANA has about 2,000 millions of floating debt, and an annual expenditure far exceeding the national revenue, to deal with, while there are only three modes by which he can even attempt to raise the needful a forced loan, a voluntary subscription on the part of the people, or a foreign loan.

The Providence Journal of Feb. 22, states that a young man named WALTER TUCKER, a resident of Scituate, about 17 years of age, has confessed that himself and one HENRY BATTEY, Jr., some time in August last killed a man named ELI BENNETT, robbed him of about five hundred dollars, and dragged his body into the woods some distance north of Ashland, and buried it.

The high price of Gold, under military successes that have given a thorough blow to the rebellion, is a matter of general surprise. A much more rapid and excessive decline was looked for, and not a little disappointment is expressed that it has not taken place.
