Within the limits of the City Washington and the District of Columbia, thousands of women and children, whose husbands, fathers and brothers are in their graves, or far away at unknown places with our armies, are at present suffering for the want of clothing, food and fuel.

We learn from Admiral PORTER'S official report to the Navy Department, that immediately after the evacuation of Fort Anderson, the fleet under his command pushed forward as rapidly as possible toward Wilmington.

All is quiet along our lines. There are no rebels within miles of us. The trade-stores outside of our lines, owned by merchants of this city, were recently closed by the military authorities, and the goods confiscated.

General business was inactive. Domestic Produce varied very slightly in prices, buyers having had any existing advantage. Foreign merchandise was held above the views of purchasers. The freight market was extremely quiet.

The House passed the bill appropriating fifteen thousand dollars as indemnity to AMBROSS MORRISON, for his real estate in Nashville, taken by the military authorities as necessary for the defence of that city. [A proviso was appended, that this relief is not to be considered a precedent for other similar claims.]

We remember of hearing, years before the present war, a distinguished statesman pre- dict that the time would come when "the Gulf States would become Africanized," or be entirely filled with black communities.

Cannot SHERMAN halt a while to let the rebels take breath and dig a little? He is taking the breath out of everybody; towns seem to fall into his possession as easily as ripe oranges are shaken from a tree.
The great Clarke Telescope is shortly to be set up in the Dearborn Tower at the University of Chicago.

Lieut.-Col. MAXWELL, of the First Michigan Cavalry, returned yesterday from up the valley, where he went the day before with a detachment of men on a reconnoissance. Only small bodies of the enemies cavalry were discovered, and these were dispersed after a little skirmishing, with the loss of one man seriously wounded.
Affairs are becoming interesting in the vicinity of Charlotte, N.C., on account of the near approach of the enemy.
We find in the North Carolina papers a proclamation of Gov. VANCE, issued on the 14th inst., relative to the recent "peace-negotiations." The following are some of the concluding paragraphs:

Financially and commercially the year that closes with this day may be numbered with the most eventful in the history of this Territory. The development of the mineral resources of Idaho and Montana, has left its mark also upon Utah, inasmuch as a large portion of the supplies for those two Territo- ries have been purchased and freighted from the vicinity of Salt Lake.

The Legislature of the Territory assembled today, in the "Council House" in this city. Most of the members presented themselves, and both Houses organized, with GEO. A. SMITH President of the Council, and JOHN TAYLOR Speaker of the House.

Till recently, a great deal of the best material has gone into the army, even in our large cities. We all know what large numbers of the best young men of the country men often of position, wealth, and education, and those representing our best trades and most intelligent pursuits have joined even the rank and file in this struggle.
FREDERICK DOUGLAS delivered a lecture, last evening, at the Odd Fellow's Hall, in Hoboken, before a large audience of ladies and gentlemen, who gave him a hearty reception.

All has been quiet on the picket line for the last twenty-four hours, and no more Generals, I am pleased to say, have been spirited away. The weather is quite moderate, and a rain storm that commenced about noon to-day is melting the snow rapidly.

In the Senate, yesterday, the bill to create the office of Solicitor and Judge-Advocate of the Navy Department, was passed. The House resolution to authorize Mr. POWELL to paint a picture for the Capitol, at a cost not exceeding $25,000, was strongly opposed by Mr. SUMNER, on the ground that our citizens were already taxed to the utmost to carry on the war. No action was taken.

The Yankees wasted much powder yesterday firing salutes on the anniversary of the birth of GEORGE WASHINGTON, whose native State has been devastated, and the soil of the noble old Commonwealth he loved so well, watered with the blood of the descendants of his relatives and friends.

One of the periodical battles the British Chancellor of the Exchequer has to fight is that over the maintenance of the malt tax, a tax from which the Chancellor derives no less than six millions sterling a year, and which he is therefore naturally disinclined to relinquish.

Another Prussian crisis is at hand. The King is as obstinate, and as averse to compromise as ever, and the deputies will concede nothing will sanction no ministerial measure, while he remains in this mood. Under these circumstances, a reconciliation between the Lower Chamber and the Government need not be looked for, and, after another brief struggle, the fiat of dissolution is sure to be again pronounced.

On Friday morning, as the Greenport and Hunter's Point train was approaching Lakeland, the first passenger car became detached from the engine, as it was passing over 3 creek, and fell down the embankment about twenty feet. Several of the passengers were injured, but none were killed.

In former letters I have referred to BRIGHAM YOUNG'S dislike of tragedy. The subject has now assumed a more definite shape. Mr. GEORGE PAUNCE FORT'S late engagement at the theatre terminated on Saturday night, with the play of " Macbeth" to a crowded house. "Othello," "Richard III," "Hamlet" and "Macbeth," having all been played here within a few weeks, the theatre-goers cannot be said to be entirely ignorant of that line of the drama.
To amend the Charter of the Manhattan Fire Insurance Company.

In the Senate, yesterday, notice was given of bills to incorporate the free Literary Association of New-York: legalizing certain resolutions of the Richmond County Supervisors; incorporating the Seventy-first Militia Regiment.
ROGER A. PRYOR TO BE EXCHANGED. President LINCOLN, to-day, ordered the rebel ex- Gen. ROGER A. PRYOR to report immediately to Gen. GRANT, at City Point, for exchange.
The annual meeting of the Children's Aid Society was held at the Metropolitan Bank, on Friday afternoon, the President, WILLIAM A. BOOTH, Esq., in the chair.
A new elemeat of trouble is likely to arise in brining the question of British American federation to a successful issue. It is that of the route along which the intercolonial railroad shall pass.

CONSPIRACY.--A German woman named TERESA BEISS was arrested on Saturday afternoon, by Constable WHITNEY, on a charge of having stolen a gold watch and chain, valued at $150, from GOTLEIB BREFUSS, a Swiss watchmaker, keeping a lager beer saloon in Washington-street, near the Post-office, Hoboken. It appears that Mrs. BEISS came to this country recently, bringing with her about $3,000,
The commencement exercises of Bellevue Hospital Medical College were held at the Academy of Music, on Saturday, in the presence of a large audience.

Early Saturday forenoon, the splendid side wheel steamship Montana, built bY WEBB BELL, for the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, was launched from the yard foot of G-street, Greenpoint. Her dimensions are: Length between perpendiculars, 330 feet; breadth of beam, 43 feet 6 inches; depth of hold, 27 feet; 4,100 tons burden. To the Hon. Henry J. Raymond: DEAR SIR: Before proceeding further in this discussion, it will be well to take a brief survey of the several reforms, opposed at first and granted at last, three-quarters of a century ago, in regard to the treatment and management of the insane.
The price of Gold closed on Saturday night 199 1/8 cent. Money easy. Some few of the Railways active and higher, Governments steady. The subscriptions to the 7.30 Popular Loan again large.

THE DRAFT IN THE THIRD DISTRICT.--The draft in the Third District, Brooklyn, was completed on Friday, and on Saturday many of those drawn appeared at the office of the Provost-Marshal, for the purpose of being exempted, or to report with the view of procuring substitutes. Most of those drafted are poor men, with families dependent upon them for support. Those able have mostly procured representative substitutes, and their names were, therefore, not drawn.
Testimony of City Inspector Boole. The Legislative Committee met again on Satur day, and continued its investigations into the affairs of the City Inspector's Department.

The steamer Swan, from New-Orleans 18th, has pushed up for St. Louis. The Constitutional Amendment abolishing slavery was ratified by the State of Louisiana on the 17th by both Houses of the Legislature.

We have reason to believe that a large portion of the rebel forces lately about Memphis have already gone. Their destination is said to be Mobile.

The absence of news from Gen. SHERMAN, and the reticence of the rebel press concerning the movements of their own troops, will naturally tend to breed apprehension in the minds of many in regard to the concentration of forces which the enemy is making in the hope of checking SHERMAN's march. SHERMAN. A glance at the figures given in our correspondents' dispatch, will show that SHERMAN'S army is far superior in point of numbers to any force that can be brought against him.

This board met at 2 P. M. yesterday, Mr. JAMES HAYES in the chair. A communication was received from MOSES TAYLOR, Esq., Chairman of the committee of citizens appointed to make arrangements for celebrating our recent victories, inviting the board to join in the celebration.

The Committee of Arrangements of the National Celebration of Union Victories, WILLIAM P. BLODGETT, Esq., Chairman, were in session the entire day yesterday at the Astor House, attending to the preliminaries for the great celebration on Saturday next. The committee is composed of the following citizens: Wm. P. Blodgett, Chairman; Thos. C. Acton, Elliott C. Cowdin, M. Cooper, Josiah Hadden, Hon. Chas. C. Cornell, Supervisor Wm. M. Tweed, and Hon. Douglass Taylor.

In House of Lords, Monday, Feb. 13, Lord HOUGHTON moved for returns relative to the working of the Metropolitan Casual Poor Act. Earl FORTESOUR thought the act was a failure. After some discussion, Lord HOUGHTON'S motion was agreed to, and the House adjourned.

The House went into Committee of the Whole on the Six Hundred Million Loan Bill.

If all that is transpiring in these regions, and has been for the past two weeks, could be set forth in print, it would certainly be made manifest to the people that, if the forces here have been hibernating they will hibernate no longer. The indications of a speedy and energetic renewal of activity are numerous, and cannot escape the attention of the most superficial looker-on.
Mr. COLLAMER, of Vermont, (Union,) moved to take up the resolution to contract with W.H. POWELL for a picture for the National Capitol to cost $25,000, which was carried.

The rebels still withhold from us all news about the progress of Gen. SHERMAN's army, and the only thing about SHERMAN that we feel sure of at present is that the rebels have had not even the slightest success over any part of his forces, else it would have been communicated to the Richmond press, to the rebel army and to us, very speedily.

A large and influential meeting of gentlemen composting the committee on the celebration on the 7th of March of our recent victories in Charleston, Savannah, Wilmington, , was held to-day at the Collector's office. MOSES TAYLOR, Esq., occupied the chair. Hon. SAMUEL SLOAN and S.P. CHITTENDEN acted as Secretaries.
The Canada's peace news caused a great sensation here. The cotton market is entirely unsettled. There is little or nothing doing this morning, and quotations are nominal.

The case of Francisco or Frank Ferris, indicted for the murder of his wife Mary Ferris, came up for trial yesterday morning. The District-Attorney stated in his opening that this case was what the books call an old-fashioned grudge-murder.

The Senate has devoted the entire day and evening to the consideration of the Tax Bill in Committee of the Whole. The proposition to tax savings banks was agreed to, after a long discussion, by the casting vote of the Vice-President. This action may be reversed when the bill is reported from the committee.

The Workingmen's Association of this city recently passed a resolution requesting DAVID S. CODDINGTON, Esq., to write in their behalf a congratulatory letter to President LINCOLN, upon his second inauguration as President. Among doubts, hesitation, delay and uncertainty about orders, the draft in the City of New-York was begun yesterday, and is, apparently, to be continued to-day and until completed. Major DODGE, the Provost-Marshal, had not returned from Washington up to last evening; but Capt. BROWNSON, commanding in his absence, has, in at least one case of doubt on the part of a District Provost-Marshal, peremptorily ordered the draft to proceed.
Count WYDENBRUKE was to-day presented to the President by Secretary SEWARD, as Minister Resident from Austria. The usual complimentary and friendly salutations were exchanged.
To amend the act establishing a quarantine for the port of New York.

BATES OF PASSAGE THE CURRRNCY. I take advantage of the sailing of two steamships, this morning, to send you a letter. It will go only in one of them. A great number of persons go in each of them more, I think, than ever left San Francisco on any one day before. "Their name is ...

The United States transport steamer Thorn was blown up by a torpedo planted in the river just below Fort Anderson on Saturday afternoon, and sunk in mid channel within two minutes afterward, the crew barely escaping with their lives.
The NEW-YORE WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office, in wrappers, ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS.

We still continue in the full and uninterrupted enjoyment of most delicious weather, and it will in all probability last for some days. The roads and camps are now in very good condition. A ride round the army yesterday evidenced the fact that a move may take place at any day, so far as regards the state of the ground, but it is extremely difficult to make any prophesy in the premises.

The Paid Fire Department Bill was favorably reported to the Assembly, this morning, by the Committee on Cities the vote in committee standing four for the bill, and three against it. The Firemen's Bill, providing for a reform of the fire organization of New-York, in accordance with the ordinance of the Common Council, was adversely reported by the same committee.
CITY POINT. Va., Monday Evening, March 13, 1865. You must excuse me if I again commence with that most convenient of all subjects for correspondents or conversationalists the weather; but, ...

A military commission for the trial of guerrillas, Gen. WHITAKER, President, assembled today. JEROME CLARK, alias "SUE MUNDAY," was found guilty, two witnesses swearing positively to different murders committed by him, and there were witnesses also to his throwing a train off the track and robbing the passengers and the mail. He was sentenced to death by hanging, at the time and place assigned by the Major-General commanding.

Information from the Army of the Potomac, speaking of SHERIDAN'S success in destroying the Lynchburgh Railroad at several points, and inflict- ing severe damage on the canal, etc., says he is on his way to White House, and that military of- ficers, high in authority, claim this to be the most important raid of the war.
The steamship Africa, which left Liverpool on the 4th inst. and Queenstown on the 5th, arrived at Halifax at 7 this morning. She has 39 passengers for Halifax and 25 for Boston.

Washington was a little exercised yesterday by rumors that LEE was getting out of Richmond. The report seems, however, to have been rather the foreshadowing of a probability than the record of a fact. There are signs of commotion in the rebel army, and correspondents judge that they are about making a demonstration upon GRANT'S lines. But everything is vague, most of it guesswork.

Officers just from the front state that an order was read to the troops Saturday evening last from Maj.-Gen. Cox, commanding, stating that they would be joined by SHERMAN'S army in three days, which created the greatest enthusiasm.
The steamer Rebecca Clyde, with 350 rebel prisoners, captured near Kinston, North Carolina, during the late battles, arrived here this morning from Newbern, North Carolina.

The occurrences of the past four years have made Fort Lafayette and its commandant, Col. MARTIN BURKE, historic and memorable. For obvious reasons it has not been deemed desirable hitherto that newspaper historians should have the run of the Fort, as their zeal might now and then get the better of a discretion which would suggest reticence rather than publicity.

If there is nothing so difficult to believe in as human consistency, there is nothing so easy of belief as the thorough inconsistency of that which takes the indefinite name of public opinion. Reading such a telegraphic abstract of the views of the London press as ...

George M., The Count Joannes vs. Stephen R. Fiske The Count brought this action to recover the sum of $25,000 damages, which he contended he had sustained by reason of an alleged false and malicious article published some time since in the Leader.

We have received a great many communications concerning the bills pending in Albany on the subject of railroad fares, as well as on that of railroad accidents and railroad management in general. Most of them utter the resentments of the writers rather than the convictions of their judgment, and would, if published, contribute very little to the general stock of information upon the subject.
This already somewhat noted case came up again yesterday afternoon before Judge McCUNN, of the Superior Court. We published in the TIMES, ...

The telegram dated Washington, March 16, from Provost-Marshal-General FRY, in regard to the draft, published in the evening papers, has just come to my notice. Gov. FENTON'S circular was based upon my telegram from Washington.

The news per Australasian of the fall of Charleston caused much sensation. Its immediate effect was the advance of two per cent. in United States bonds, and a decline of four per cent. in the Confederate loan.
Our forces have several times occupied Kinston, and it was once before the scene of an engagement as obstinate as that of last week.
Information from the Army of the Potomac says the Fifth Corps was reviewed on Tuesday by Gen. WARREN. This corps is one of the largest in the army, and in regard to discipline, stands second to none.

Hen. C. A. Dana, Assistant Secretary of War: I am just in a receipt of a letter from Gen. SHERMAN, 12th, from Fayetteville. He describes his army as in fine health and spirits, having met with no serious opposition. HARDEE keeps in his front at a respectful distance. At Columbia he destroyed immense arsenale and railroad establishments, and forty-three cannon. At Cheraw he found much ma-...

The offer of the French Mission to JAMES GORDON SENNETT excites some comment in political circles. It is said to have been made partly on the strength of a strong letter of recommendation from HORACE GREELEY. The statement that it has been declined is premature.

Drafting was continued yesterday in all the districts of the city, without any trouble, opposition or disturbance. Correspondence has taken place in various directions about the draft and its postponement, but the subject still remains somewhat obscure. The order under which the draft has been carried on thus far seems to be the following:
During the greater part of yesterday active operations on a most extensive scale could be discovered within the limits of the rebel army.

A majority of both branches of the Legislature is unquestionably in favor of removing the capital, but the discussion already had in the House has demonstrated clearly enough that no removal will take place. There is a general distrust of everybody on this question, and it is simply impossible to harmonize ...

The London Times says the fall of Charleston is a victory which will recompense the Federals for many labors, and encourage them to pursue, with renewed vigor, the conquest of the South. It believes that although the South is now virtually shut out from the world, it will continue to show unabated obstinacy in defence.

North Carolina bids fair, at length, to divide with Virginia the field of conflict during the grand, final campaign of 1865. In these two States, the great bulk of the military forces of the Union are now gathered.

The cavalry expedition sent from here by Maj.Gen. HERRON, has been heard from. They have had some heavy skirmishing, in which we lost ten or fifteen killed and wounded, and inflicting a loss on the rebels of thirty or forty, and some prisoners, including two officers. The roads over which our forces passed were horrible.
The Board of Education met on Tuesday evening, President McLEAN in the chair, and nearly all the commissioners present. Mr. MILLER, of the com-...
A special dispatch from Washington to the Bulletin, says:

A sober man thinks about the length of the way before him; a drunken man about its breadth; an oil man about its depth its depth in two senses; first, as respects wading through the miry ocean to his destination; second, as respects the distance to be bored before reaching the oleaginous deposit, or, to use a Scripture expression, "before he dips his foot in oil."
The only member of the committee present on Thursday was Senator MUNGER.
The President has appointed JOHN BIGELOW, our present Charge d'Affaires at Paris, to be Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary at that court.

The Confederacy no longer stirs apprehension; it only piques curiosity. We look at it much as sailors watch their hooked shark snapping, flapping and floundering. Fury and impotence always make an odd combination.
The English mail steamer Eider which arrived here yesterday from Vera Cruz, brings news from Mexico city up to the 28th of last month, and from Vera Cruz to the 3d of March.

Last evening the Knights of St. Patrick gave a grand banquet at the Metropolitan Hotel. The large hall was tastefully decorated; landscapes of Irish scenery graced the panels, and were displayed amid a labyrinth of festoons formed of the Stars and Stripes and Irish flags.

The light draught monitor Madoc will be launched on Monday, 2 P.M., at the foot of Greenpoint-avenue, Greenpoint, from the yard of her builder, Mr. J.S. UNDERHILL. Tickets of invitation have been issued, and the affair promises to be one of considerable interest to all who feel interested in naval movements.
ACADEMY OF MUSIC. BELLINI'S opera of "I Puritani" was given here last evening to a fashionable house. The performance was pleasant, but not great.

It seems to-day that the movements within the enemy's lines, which I noticed yesterday morning, as occasioning considerable excitement here, meant neither an intention to fight nor evacuate. They were simply changing the position of troops on their line, and this morning their tents were all up again, and their force in our front as usual.

Large quantities of ice have lodged on the flats below the city, and the river has swollen until the docks and piers are submerged to the depth of eight or ten feet. Many of the streets in the southern part of the city are under water two or three feet.

Thomas Thatcher vs. The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company. The plaintiff is a merchant in this city. In the spring of 1861, he received through the mail, a bill of lading from the firm of Messrs. G. C. Paoli Co., of Chicago, with whom he had been dealing for a few months: the bill being signed by one M.C. Hale, the only authorized freight agent of the defendants at Chicago.

The festivities of St. Patrick's Day passed off yesterday with entire success, and without any inauspicious circumstance. About 15,000 persons marched in procesaion, including the military, temperance societies and benevolent associations. The streets were very full of quiet and pleased spectators. The Mayor and Common Council reviewed the procession as it passed the City Hall.

The people in this city really evince a loyal feeling. If one was astonished to witness the cordial reception given to the Union troops on their entrance into the place, he would most assuredly clap his hands with delight to perceive how unanimous is the public expression in favor of reestablishing and maintaining the laws and orders of the United States Government. This change of sentiment has not been brought about by pretentious threats.
The thirty-fifth annual commencement of the College of Pharmacy, of New-York, was held on Thursday evening, at the Chapel of the New-York University, Washington-square.

The London Times, and other Anti-Liberal journals of England, have exhausted deception. They are beginning to give out that the rebellion will fail. They no longer call us stark mad for persisting in a war that had no chance of success. They are getting into quite a complimentary vein, and are commending both our wisdom and our courage.

The military companies and benevolent and temperance associations mustered early yesterday forenoon, and by 10 o'clock many of them were on their way to their posts. Tde procession of the day was intended to move from the corner of East Broadway and Grand-street before 12 o'clock, but it was about 1 o'clock before the start was actually made.

We published, on Thursday, one of the most shocking pieces of reading that has fallen under the eyes of any Christian community in our day, in the shape of an address recently delivered by Dr. STEPHEN SMITH, on the sanitary condition of New-York, before the joint committee of the Senate and Assembly at Albany.

NATIONAL BANKS. Gen. SPINNER reports that up to-day the whole number of National banks authorized and having procured the necessary papers, are nine hundred and nine. The conversions of State banks has just commenced, but they are coming in very rapidly.

Yesterday the pelting rain continued, and all through the night, but this afternoon the wind veered round to the north, bringing us cold bracing air, cloudless skies and a bright moonlight night. Let us hope that, for a while at any rate, we shall escape the watery visitation from which we have so long been suffering.

Yesterday forenoon I left the Queen City for Newport, directly across the Ohio, and separated from Covington by the Licking River. Newport is the more easterly of the two, and contains about 12,000 inhabitants; while Covington is rated at between 20,000 and 25,000, both growing steadily.

City Point is rapidly becoming the fashionable rendezvous of sight-seers. Scarcely one party leaves before another comes; and they in turn, after taking a ride round our fortifications, and seeing the grand preparations of war, give way to another batch of visitors. This morning a party of 60 distinguished ladies and gentlemen arrived here early.

We have news direct from SHERIDAN to the 15th inst. He writes from the railroad bridge across the South Anna, a few miles north of Richmond. He reports that he destroyed the James River Canal as far eastward as Goochland, then marched North to Tolersville, on the Virginia Central Railroad, then easterly along that road, destroying it for 15 miles.

The rebels, in the most judicious manner imaginable, keep themselves pretty much to themselves, and, therefore, all news purporting to come from Mobile is of the most straggling nature. Occasionally, however, the "reliable gentleman" turns up, and then we hear something, of course. Very few Mobile papers find their way to this city, none having been received at any of the newspaper offices for the last ten days.

The Friendly Sons were not untrue to their traditions though it must be allowed that many of those whose names are inseparably connected with the history of their organization, and who have, in latter times, been the faciles principes at the annual banquet, have taken to "fresh fields and pastures new." Yet the society was not by any means lacking in talent at their dinner at Delmonico's last night.

There has been very little activity in the American publishing trade during the present year, so far as the production of novelties is concerned. With a general state of business acknowledged to be highly satisfactory, there exists an apparent hesitation to venture upon new enterprises among the ...

Maj.-Gen. SHERIDAN reports, on the 15th inst., from the bridge of the Richmond and Fredericks- burgh Railroad, across the South Anna River, that having destroyed the James River Canal as far to the east as Goochland, he marched up the Virginia Central Railroad at Tollsville, and destroyed it down to Beaver Dam station, totally destroying fifteen miles of the road.

Notwithstanding the extensive movements and seemingly bellicose interims of Gen. LEE'S army during the greater part of Tuesday and the night succeed- ing, and of which full accounts were forwarded to the TIMES yesterday morning, the present state of the enemy's camps betoken anything but an attack upon our lines, and still less that they are preparing to evacuate their positions in front of Petersburgh.
Hon. FREDERICK A. CONKLING lectured before the American Geographical and Statistical Society on Thursday evening, at Clinton Hall, on the "Production and Consumption of Cotton."
Sundry remonstrances were presented against three cross-town railroads.

Official dispatches from City Point give us news from Richmond papers of yesterday (Friday) morning. The rebel Congress had adjourned sine die. Vice-President STEPHENS had been in Georgie for about ten days, and the Richmond editors are anxious to hear from him. The tone of their inquiries implies that they have a suspicion that he has quit the Concern.

At St. Thomas, March 10, ship Hemisphere, Pendle ton, leaking very badly, discharging her cargo of coal, and will probably have to be condemned; ship Holyhead, Davenport, from Cette for Boston, when within 100 miles of Boston, lost everything above her lower meets; brig Gilmore Meredith, Snow, with loss of spars and sails; brig Ida L. Ray, Ray, with loss of all her spare and sails.
The bill to improve Park-avenue, Brooklyn, was reported favorably.
Senator MUNGER was the only member of the committee present yesterday.
the numerous worthless articles called GOLD PENS, which have flooded the market for the last few years, when at lower prices you can get pens which are acknowledged to be the BEST IN THE WORLD.
The following brief synopsis gives a general idea of the doings of SHERMAN'S army from the time of leaving Savannah until their arrival at Fayeiteville, N.C.:

Quite a distinguished party, composed of about 16 ladies and gentlemen, arrived here an hour or two ago, by the Riser Queen, Capt. BRADFORD Commander. Among them I find Secretary Stanton, lady and son Surgeon-Gen. Barnes and lady, Hon. Mr. Hooper, of Massachusetts, with his lady and son, Maj. Mack, Lieut.-Col. Crosby, Col, Mack, Mr. and Mrs. Bell, Mr. and Mrs. Von Hoffman, Mr. Geoffroy, and others whose names may have escaped me.

The Spanish mail steamer Espana arrived at this port the day before yesterday from Europe bringing news from the Peninsula as well as from the different Spanish colonies at which she touched on her voyage out.

Immediately upon the occupation of Charleston by our forces, the American Union Commission sent an agent to inquire into the the necessities of the remaining population of the city, and of refugees arriving from the intorior. After careful investigation, acting under the advice of the military Commandant, the agent invited the cooperation of loyal residents in the work of supplying the wants of the poor in the city, and an auxiliary of the Union ...

ENTERTAINMENT BY THE SIXTEENTH BAPTIST SUNDAY SCHOOL. A very pleasing entertainment was given on Friday evening by the teachers and scholars of the Sixteenth Baptist Sunday School, at the rooms of the New-England Relief Association, No. 194 Broadway. The proceeds of the entertainment were devoted to the relief of the sick and wounded soldiers now under ...

One mile and a half of the Hudson River Railroad track in the vicinity of Schooback is washed away, and the company have issued an order suspending the running of all down trains. Up trains convey their passengers to Albany via the Hudson Berkshire road.
The United States steamer Narragansett, Commander SELINE E. WOODWORTH commanding, arrived at this port this morning. She left Rio Janeiro Feb. 1, via St. Thomas 10th inst.
The most marked feature of the week has been the fall in gold, which has declined since our last issue from 191 1/9 to 160 , the minimum of yesterday, recovered to 164 at the close.

An offcial statement of the result of blockaderunning at the port of Wilmington from January, 1863, to December, 1864, appears in the Manchester Guardian. The total ventures made by English capitalists and speculators, counting the values of ships and cargoes, amounted to more than sixty-six millions of dollars ( 13,241,000.) The returns are made in six different tables, covering various periods, the shortest being ten months.
The flood in the Susquehanna River is unprecedented. The river is thirty inches higher than in the destructive freshet of 1846.

A friend relates to us that the Summer before the war, at the house of a hospitable South Carolinian planter, he was up one morning with the sun and was about to venture forth on a morning walk, when he was checked by the planter at the door.

The draft in this city was not resumed yesterday, surprising the public as much as did the unexpected revolutions of the wheel on Wednesday. The surprise in this instance, however, was an agreeable one, eliciting warm commendations from everybody. Although no official order has been promulgated suspending the draft, it is understood that it will not be resumed until our citizens have had an opportunity to fill the quota by volunteering.
The flagship Metamora, having on board Brevet Brig.-Gen. ROBERTS, and a fleet of loaded army boats arrived here to-day on their return from a raid up the Little Ucomico River, Va.

The Austrian successor of MONTEZUMA is evidently ambitious of distinguishing himself as a ruler. But the policy which he is now pursuing in Mexico, though excellent in the abstract, may prove suicidal in his very peculiar circumstances. It is dangerous for even an old-established sovereign to bid defiance to public opinion, yet how much more ...

On the 7th instant, a boat belonging to the steamer Juniata, Commander JOHN J. ALMY, having in it Acting Master CHARLES H. HAMILTON, Acting Master's Mate ARTHUR F. TAAFE, and ten seamen, was capsized at Georgetown, S.C., while crossing the bar in a gale, and all were drowned except one seaman. The Juniata has been ordered to the Bra- sillan station.

In Produce and Merchandise, on Saturday, transactions were restricted, though, in most instances, the tendency of prices was decidedly downward. Medium and high grades of Flour declined 10c.@20c. bbl. New Mess Pork, which opened at $32 50@$32 62 , fell to $31 bbl., under reports of a panic in some of the Western markets, particularly in Chicago. Petroleum was firmer, but not active. The Freight engagements were on a limited scale.
This being the birthday of GEORGE WASHINGTON, the passengers resolved to pay the customary tribute of respect to his memory.

Our foreign critics still argue that even if the large armies of the Confederates be broken up, the country will still be filled with guerrilla bands, and that then our real difficulties will only begin, in the large spaces of the Southern States, and the impossibility of holding such vast tracts and such a scattered population, in subjection.

News has come by the last arrival from the mouth of the Rio Grande that the rebel authorities have ordered twenty six Union families to leave Corpus Christi and its vicinity, and cross the Rio Grande into Mexico. No doubt exists as to the fact.

In peace prepare for war; in a calm be ready for the storm. The latter of these precautions, especially in the present portentous conjuncture, is as sagely significant as the former. The Government, enlightened by a four years experience, and stimulated by successes, by hope and confidence, is sparing no pains to make the coming campaign the crowning success of the fearful struggle.
Hon. John P. Stockton and lady, New-Jersey; Hon. A.J. Alberger, Buffalo; and Hons. J.M. Ashley, Ohio; O.B. Madison. Utica; A.W. Randall, Washington, are guests at the Astor House.

After the storm of this Revolution has swept over the insurgent States, and the institution that struck so fierce a blow at the national life has been itself trampled under the hoel of victory, it will remain for some future BANCROFT to analyze and portray the features of that old plantation style of civilization which is already a thing of the past.

Every careful housekeeper in town ought to consult the brief comparative statements of wholesale prices in the breadstuff and provision markets, published among our "General Markets" yesterday. The dates brought into comparison are the last day of 1864, and Friday, March 17, 1865. And the articles comprised in the statements include those of the most ordinary honsehold consumption.
The great billiard tournament for the championship of this State has just finished. WM. A. TOBIN having beaten all his opponents, seven in number, is the champion elect.

Gen. SHERMAN is once more dazzling his countrymen with the brilliancy of his success. For a time, after it was known that his army had broken up from Savannah to advance into South Carolina, its progress was inexplicably delayed. The Richmond journalists said that SHERMAN would find campaigning in South Carolina a different thing from promenading through Georgia, and they were right.

Dr. GWIN arrived here on Tuesday evening last from Mexico, much to the surprise of his family, who were not looking for him. Nothing has transpired as yet as to the real cause of the ex-Senator's return, or as to what his future plans may be.

The se- cessionists of East Tennessee who, at the outset of the war, practiced every imaginable outrage on their neighbors, are beginning to suffer the just penalty of their action. The Union men, the courts having been reestablished, are prosecuting their former persecutors for damages sustained, and the juries, so far as cases have come to trial, indicate a disposition to see full justice done to all concerned.

Some eight or ten Union men "bolted" a caucus at Albany a few evenings since, because the party decided to support the Health Bill and the Paid Fire Department Bill for this city. Why these gentlemen do not support those bills we are not aware. It would be very difficult, in our judgment, for any man of any party to assign any good reason for not supporting them.

THE MONTAUK. The Monitor Montauk which was recently engaged at Fort Fisher and struck by over two hundred shot was towed up to the navy-yard yesterday, where her guns will be exchanged for 15-inch ones, and some slight repairs made to her turret and machinery.

WHITEHOUSE, Va., March 17, 1865. Isolated facts regarding the operations of the cavalry under Gen. SHERIDAN, have doubtless ere this been occasionally announced, and for want of time I now give only a brief resume of the whole ex- pedition, reserving a more detailed account for your next issue.

The occasion of moving the... Address in the Corps Legislatif, in answer to the Emperor's Speech, promises to be marked by a singular episode. It will be remembered that the Speech itself contained no allusion whatever to American affairs. By ordinary usage, therefore, the Address could only be made to include a reference of a supplementary character,

The river has fallen between four and five feet from its highest point, and as a boat has arrived here from Catskill, coming through the main channel, it is believed that navigation is fairly open between New-York and Albany. A passenger-boat is expected to-morrow morning.

The steamer Shubrick, sailed last week for Victoria with Capt. BULKLEY and party of the Russian International Telegraph. Arrangements will be made during the Winter for the exploration of the route and commencement of the work in the Spring.
Information from the Army of the Potomac shows that our troops are in the best possible condi- tion, and are ready to move at any time occasion may require.

We hope the question of relieving the State railroads from existing legal restrictions as to fares may be discussed, before it is decided, on some higher grounds than those thus far generally assumed. Whether the New-York Central Road is or is not a party machine-- whether its directors and managers get too much or too little for their services--whether...

val at the rebel headquarters in Europe seems to have been a doubtful sort of surprise to his friends. Its suddenness evidently was suggestive of misgivings. And these misgivings, by all appearances, were confirmed, rather than allayed, by the detailed report of his mission. The Paris news clubs have already given GWIN'S statement shape.

WHO PERPE- TRATE THEM.--A singular commentary upon one portion of Gen. WADE HAMPTON'S letter to Gen. SHERMAN was furnished by the description which we copied from the Richmond Whig on Friday last, of the scenes attending the evacuation of Columbia.

Sermons were delivered, yesterday, upon the sanitary condition of New-York City, by Rev. Dr. T.D. ANDERSON, of the First Baptist Church, in Broome-street; Rev. Dr. W.F. MORGAN, of St. Thomas' Church, corner of Broadway and Houston-street, and Rev. Dr.S. OSGOOD, of the Church of the Messiah, corner of Madison-avenue and Twenty-eighth-street. They were plain and distinct expositions of the moral side of the sanitary question, and of the duties of citizens in the matter.

From the Congressional Globe. The Vice-President elect, (Hon. ANDREW JOHN SON, of Tennessee, in reply to the question as to whether he was ready to take the ostn.) I am, (Then turning to the Senate he said:) Senators: I am here to-day as the chosen Vice-President of the United States, and as such, by constitutional provision, I am made the presiding officer of this body.

Recruiting in Illinois, Indiana, Iowa and Wis consin is very brisk, and the men received from those States are of an excellent description, many of them having already seen considerable service. Very little volunteering is going on in Michigan. Some sections of New-York and Pennsylvania are also very negligent.

The Underground Railroad Bill is again before the Legislature, and there is no conceivable reason why it should not pass. The only persons to whose interests it can prove in the slightest degree prejudicial are the street railroad companies, and omnibus proprietors. To all complaints made against these worthies for the shameful and indecent overcrowding of their vehicles, their reply is that it would.

The military pressure within and without the rebel capital has sadly spoiled the fine variety and pungency of Richmond newspaper literature. But there is some compensation in getting what is still left to us fresh. There is now but one daily to record what it formerly needed half a score to get up with the proper inflections.
Much trouble seems to make... WADE HAMPTON talk like a Radical of the most advanced type. The following, from his letter to Gen. SHERMAN, is worthy of GARRISON or WENDELL PHILLIPS:...
There is great uneasiness here in business circles relative to decline in prices of all articles owing to the fall in gold.

Included In the interesting budget of news from Paris, which we publish to-day, is a report which promises a sensation equal to the famous fight of the Kearsarge and Alabama. At a rebel Council, composed of the chief emissaries of the Confederacy, and which closed its sittings at Paris, on the 2d inst., it is understood that a decision was come to, author-...

from the Congressional Globe a report of the remarks made by Vice-President ANDREW JOHNSON, on taking his place as President of the Senate, on the day of the Inauguration. There may be differences of opinion as to the timeliness and good taste of some of the topics which he introduced on that occasion, --but few will venture, we presume, to question publicly the justice of the sentiments.

It is probable that the news of prospective shipments of gold from London to New-York has induced the Philadelphia agent of the Government to send part of the last seventhirty issue to San Francisco. There is quite as great a plethora of gold on the Pacific coast as there is in Lombard-street.
The steamer George Cromwell, from New Orleans 12th, arrived at, this port last evening.

We publish this morning a graphic and interesting sketch of Gen. PHIL. SHERIDAN'S magnificent and destructive raid on LEE'S communications. It will be seen that previous accounts have understated rather than exaggerated the importance of the work accomplished by the gallant General. Miles and miles of railroad were destroyed.

JAY COOKE, the Subscription Agent, reports the sales of Seven-Thirties to-day at over $2,500,000, the largest Eastern subscription being $200,000, from Boston, and including 1,700 individual subscription of $50 and $100 each.

The draft in the city, though its continuance had been announced for Saturday, was not resumed on that day, but the different District Provost-Marshals stated that it would not be continued for the present.
The citizens of the Twentieth Ward held a meeting last evening at the corner of Eighthavenue and Thirty-third-street, for the purpose of taking measures to fill the quota of the ward with volunteers.

The steamer James S. Green arrived last evening from Wilmington. She brings no new intelligence from Gen. SHERMAN'S army, which by the last accounts received here yesterday, had crossed Cape Fear River, and was marching on Goldsboro.

Before a Military Commission, which convened at Fort Lafayette, New-York Harbor, and at New-York City, by virtue of Special Orders No. 14, current series from these headquarters, of Jan. 17, 1865, and of which Brig.-Gen FITZ HENRY WARREN, United States Volunteers is President, was arraigned and tried, ROBERT C. KENNEDY.

Among the deserters who arrived from City Point this morning, were two who were on detached duty in Richmond last week, but, being put in the trenches, took the first opportunity to leave the rebel service.

The Richmond Sentinel of the 18th publishes the correspondence referred to in JEFF. DAVIS' message. It is as follows:
I reached this point at an early hour this morning, after having traveled over thirteen counties of the State, with the cavalry expedition commanded by Maj.-Gen. PHILIP H. SHERIDAN.

The excitement about the relations between France and the United States is on the increase, and causes infinitely more uneasiness here than it appears to do at home. All sorts of possible and impossible rumors are flying about on the subject, and on all sides a demand is made for a word of explanation from the Government.
The Inman steamer City of London, Capt. PE- TRIE, which left Liverpool at 3 o'clock on the after- noon of the 8th, and Queenstown on the 9th of March, arrived here yesterday morning.

Parties who have arrived here from Gen. SHERMAN'S army say that we shall be able to join hands with him to-morrow or next day. One of them says SHERMAN walks over the course as fearlessly and unconcerned as a giant among pigmies, and the enemy are so demoralized and panic-stricken that it is doubtful whether they will make a stand or not.

I rode yesterday along the entire front line of this army, extending from the Appomattox to Hatcher's Run. From several localities I had excellent views of the rebel encampment, and, with the help of a good field-glass, could plainly discern their movements.

A large meeting of the citizens of the Twenti- eth Ward was held on Monday evening, at the corner of Eighth-avenue and Thirty-third-street, for the pur- pose of taking measures to fill the quota of that Ward with volunteers.

COTTON--The market on Monday opened at a recovery from the serious depression which prevailed on Saturday, and there was more steadiness in prices. Nevertheless quotations were 1 d. lower for American and Surats than on the previous Friday, and d. @1d. lower on other descriptions. On Tuesday the market was quiet but steady. Sales of the two days, 13,000 bales, including 4,500 for speculation and export.

Passengers from City Point who arrived in Washington yesterday, say that SHERMAN had been joined by SCHOFIELD, and had occupied Goldsboro without opposition. This news came through SHERMAN'S scouts, who left him some time last week.

A large and enthusiastic meeting of citizens of the Twenty-first Ward was held last evening at Ebbit's Hall, No. 55 West Thirty-third street, for the purpose of filling the quota of the ward by stimulating enlistments in the army.

We endured a great deal of dust and a rather severe gale of wind yesterday. Clouds of flying sand filled the air and blinded all with the dusty particles. What rain we have had of late has all dried up, and the roads are all in good condition.

Richmond papers of Monday are as reticent in regard to war news as usual. The Sentinel says, a report was current that a fight had occurred a short distance north of Fayetteville, N.C., between HARDEE and four divisions of SHERMAN'S army, in which our troops were repulsed with heavy loss. It does not vouch for the truth of the report, but assures its readers that they will hear good news very soon.

From all accounts the grand old Fifth United States Cavalry has covered itself with fresh laurels in the recent splendid campaign of SHERIDAN. They were ordered to take and destroy a very important bridge across the South Anna. On arriving there, they dismounted, charged, put the rebels to flight, seized three pieces of artillery, with a number of prisoners, and then totally destroyed the bridge.

The report of Fire Marshal BAKER for the six months ending Nov. 30, 1864, was presented to the Common Council on Monday. From the document it appears that the total number of fires during the six months has been 183, being 6 less than occurred in the corresponding six months of 1863, and 12 less than the previous half year.

The Pacific Mail Steamship Company's new steamship Colorado, lying at the foot of Canal-street, North River, was thrown open to the public yesterday, and is to be on exhibition to-day and to-morrow, and on Friday and Saturday, from 10 o'clock in the morning until 4 o'clock in the afternoon.

The Australasian has made a fine passage, and has brought great news. Charleston has fallen. The most mischievous city in the Union that which provoked the old difficulties between the United States and Great Britain, and that which initiated the present great civil war has met with a just fate.

Yesterday (Sabbath) was a delightful day, and after the usual hours devoted to worship, the Sixth and Ninth Corps were reviewed, partially by brigades, preparatory to a general review to take place some time this week. The reviews were conducted by Division and Brigade Commanders, and all appeared well satisfied with the appearance of their respective commands.

The bulletin of Gen. LEE announcing a check to Gen. SHERMAN'S army, creates not the slighest uneasiness here. It is plainly discernable that it was written simply to shed a ray of hope over the fast sinking fortunes of the enemy.
Subscriptions to the 7-30 loan are freely offered here. There have been taken $600,000 since the receipts of the bonds in February.

The news by the Etna of the fall of Wilmington was not unexpected, and the effect, therefore, was not so great as it otherwise would have been. Federal securities improved under the news, but the Confederate loan was only a shade lower, having declined in anticipation.
The steamer Parthenia arrived here to-day from Newbern, N.C., with mails and dispatches.

We have news from New-Orleans to the 17th inst., from which we learn that Gen. CANBY was then near Mobile, and the grand attack on that city would be made within five days. The mines of California are yielding heavily since the rains. The receipts of treasure here for ten days are over $2,100,000. The deposits at the mint to-day are 1,200 ounces. Money is more in demand on account of the speculative movements in Legal Tenders, which are now selling at 56 and 57, and there is an increased demand for the best mining stocks.

LAUNCH OF THE STEAMSHIP MANHATTAN. The Manhattan is fitted up expressly for passengers, and is intended to run between New-York and Vera Cruz.

The chartered steamer Wenonah, Capt. DAWES. arrived here yesterday afternoon from the White House, to which point she had been dispatched several days ago with supplies for Gen. SHERIDAN'S troops.

At a late hour last night we received official news of a bold attack yesterday morning upon a portion of GRANT'S lines, which resulted in a decided, defeat of the rebels, whose losses are about 3,000 in killed and wounded, and nearly, as many prisoners. Our losses are under 1,000.
Dr. GWIN, Ex-Senator from California is, we near, once more on his way to Paris from Mexico perhaps we should rather say from the Court of Mexico to the Court of the Tulleries.

The official report by Gen. THOMAS of operations to the Southwest from the date of the occupation of Atlanta covers seven pages of the official gazette, and is dated Eastport, Jan. 20. The first important event alluded to is the capture of Athens, Ala., by FORREST. Of this he says:
The rebels have repented of their former design of evacuating Mobile at a military post. Selma is now being fortified and strengthened, but not at the expense of their principal seaport town.

Major-Gen. PALMER, now in command of the millitary district of Kentucky, has recently taken, as his headquarters, the fine building on Walnut-street, long used as the headquarters of the Department of the Ohio.

The grand military movement against Mobile commenced yesterday by Gen. BENTON'S Third Division, Thirteenth Corps; Col. BERTRAM's First Brigade, Twenty-second Corps; Gen. VIECH'S and STOKES' brigades are also moving in the direction of Bonsecour.
Senator J.W. Grimes and wife, Iowa; Senator F.A. Pike, Maine; A. Getty, Philadelphia; Gen. W.M. Babbitt. New-Jersey, and J. Whiting, Michigan, are stopping at the Astor House.

In a dispatch, admirable for its brevity and clearness, Gen. SCHOFIELD has resolved whatever doubts of a serious character may have been entertained regarding the safety of SHERMAN'S position up to Tuesday, the 21st.

The rebel General-in-Chief seems to have been seriously deceived as to the scope and bent of certain movements ordered early last week by Gen. GRANT, on the left of our lines. These movements were made the subject of comment in the Richmond papers on Wednesday; and the Whig of that date, while doubtful whether Gen. GRANT'S apparent activity...

Recruiting is at dead low water. There are plenty of men, and so far as that part of the business is concerned the city quota would be filled just as soon as the surgeons could examine the requisite number of men. But the money has failed, no more can be had for a day or two yet, and if the drafting is not resumed the reason will be a further indulgence by the authorities.
Is our war with the rebellion now soon to close to be followed by another against MAXIMILIAN in Mexico? The time is not distant when this will be forced upon us as a practical question.

ROBERT COBB KENNEDY was hanged on Friday last at Fort Lafayette. He was a Captain in the rebel army, found guilty of being a spy and of setting fire to hotels in New-York on Nov. 25, 1864, and condemned by court-martial. Full accounts of these crimes and proceedings have already appeared in the TIMES.

Considerable excitement was created here this morning, the cause of which will be told you by one of our correspondents from the front just come in haste with his despatches. His Excellency President LINCOLN arrived here last night, in the steamer River Queen, with Mrs. LINCOLN, it was intended to have a grand review to-day, that of the cavalry corps having been again postponed yesterday, but from present appearances our men are likely, during the...

The wretched criminal, KENNEDY, who suffered the extreme penalty of military law at Fort Lafayette on Saturday, belonged, too clearly, to the vulgar class of malefactors to make his story note-worthy in any particular save his confession of being one of the principals...
The following advices from Newbern have jus reached here via the Albermarie Canal:

BURNED TO DEATH. At about 6 o'clock yesterday morning, fire was discovered in PATRICK CARR'S room, on the third floor of Mrs. CATHARINE KEARNES' boarding-house, at No. 13 Monroe-street, and the servant who made the discovery, on bursting in the door, found CARR'S body on the floor, horribly disfigured from burning.

A fight occurred between twenty of our troops and seventy guerrillas, thirty miles from Paducah, on Wednesday night. Twenty of the guerrillas were killed, including the notorious leader, Capt. McDOUGAL. Capt. McGREGORY was killed on our side.

The decisive repulse of LEE'S attack on our lines before Petersburgh, yesterday, is the cause of much congratulation among loyal people here to-day. As usual, however, rumor has enlarged upon the report thus far received, and extravagant statements of still greater successes are in circulation, but there is nothing to warrant them, and the very acceptable bulletins of Secretary STANTON do not need further embellishment to produce rejoicing everywhere.

Maj.-Gen. Div: This morning at 4:30 o'clock, the enemy, by a strong and sudden assault captured Fort Steadman, but after a vigorous contest the fort was recaptured with 1,600 prisoners, two flags, and all the guns uninjured.
Steamship America, from Southampton on the 15th of March, with three days' later intelligence from Europe, arrived at this port last evening.

Lady FULLERTON is well known as one of the most accomplished women of the day. Her works of fiction have not been numerous, but they live individually in the minds of all who have read them, and to that large class of the community her name is a sufficient recommendation of any new book.

I suppose we may take it for granted, that in this section of the country the fighting is almost ended. From this remark I do not wish it to be inferred that we are unprepared for further fighting. Should events require the troops to act on the defensive, or to take up the offensive, they are ready for such an emergency.
The following dispatch from Gen. SCHOFIELD reports his arrival at, and occupation of Goldsboro, on Tuesday, March 21, with but slight opposition.

Before daylight last Saturday morning, three divisions of the enemy made a sudden and determined attack on Fort Steadman, in front of Petersburgh, overpowering the garrison and capturing the fort, where they temporarily established themselves, and turned the guns upon our lines. Our troops on either flank maintained their ground. A determined attack on Fort Haskell was gallantly repulsed with great loss to the enemy.

SIS: I have the honor to request that you will in form me positively and immediately what prospect there is of your obtaining and keeping on hand sufficient funds to pay the bounty to two hundred volunteers daily. The arrangements for recruiting in the several wards had just been completed, and recruits were beginning to come in, when the whole thing is brought to a dead stop by the failure in the supply of funds.

The mail steamer Daniel Webster, which left City Point at 10 o'clock A.M. yesterday, and arrived here thia morning, bronght up one hundred and ten rebel officers, one hundred and one of whom were captured in the engagements of Saturday, ranging in rank from Colonel down to Third Lieutenant.

This board met at 2 P.M. yesterday, Mr. JONES in the chair. A preamble and resolution by Mr. GEDNEY were adopted, pledging the Common Council to assist, by every means in their power, is procuring volunteers and filling the quota, and calling on out wealthy citizens to subscribe liberally to the Bounty Fund Loan.

We print this morning from our owns correspondents a very full account of the daring rebel attack upon the Ninth Corps of the Army of the Potomac on Saturday morning, accompanied by further official dispatches from Gen. GRANT. The main features of the battle have already been given in our columns. Early in the morning four divisions of rebels made a rush upon Fort Steadman, and took it after several smart repulses.
By arrival at this port yesterday morning, from Port-au-Prince, of the bark Angler, we have details of a fearful conflagration in that city.
The Baltimore American's special Annapolis correspondent says:

The official reports from GRANT and SHERMAN to-day do not essentially change the military aspect either in Virginia or North Carolina. But these reports show that both Generals have had more work on hand than the earlier dispatches made apparent.
The following official report of Gen. SHERMAN'S operations since he left Fayetteville have been received this morning.
The United States mail steamer Evening Star, from New-Orleans March 19, via Havana March 23, arrived at this port yesterday. She brings NewOrleans papers to the 19th inst. inclusive.

During yesterday only a few scattering recruits were picked up in the city, nearly all substitutes. In the Fifth Ward three substitutes were enlisted, and six recruits for the regular army, making nine on the quota; in the Ninth, nine substitutes, and so on. Considerable numbers of volunteers were offered at various recruting stations, but not received for want of bounty money.

To-day has indeed been a busy day for the Army of the Potomac what with the rebel attack on our right and our counter attack upon our left, and the various movements of the reserves within our interior lines, scarcely any one can say that the day has passed easily.

Several prisoners, convicted during the past term, were brought up for sentence yesterday morning. Margaret Riley, convicted of petit larceny in stealing a picture-frame, was sent to the Pentitentiary for six months.
To secure to creditors a just division of estates of debtors.

The ball-playing season is near its commencement, and the Summer campaign of the base ball and cricket fraternity bids fair to be one of the most interesting of and since 1860, in which year the furor for base ball was at its height.

The long anticipated and carefully prepared rebel movement, which was to "astonish the world," took place to-day, and I have no doubt, did astonish that part of the world within the limited precincts of rebeldom. A few more such rsuprises will, one would think, be sufficient to bring the leaders of secession to their senses, and convince them of the hopelessness of their struggle to divide and ruin our common country.

The recent debate in the English House of Commons on the probability of an attack on Canada by the United States, after the close of the struggle with the South, reveals the fact that English statesmen have at last found out that the real power of government in this country lies in the agricultural population.

The result of the engagement this morning was more important that at first reported.

On Sunday last the Twentieth Corps of Gen. SHERMAN's army met the enemy at Bentonville, instead of Mount Olive, as at first reported, twenty-six miles southwest of Goldsboro, where our advance was checked until the arrival of the Fourteenth Corps, which held the enemy at bay, when the Seventeenth Corps arrived and flanked the enemy, who left in confusion for Raleigh, SHERMAN'S forces entering Smithfield, which is half way between Raleigh and Goldsboro.

George W. Blunt, a contraband of the deepest dye, pleaded guilty yesterday to an attempt at grand larceny in stealing a silver watch. The prisoner stated that he found the watch and did not know to whom it belonged. He was sent to the Penitentiary for one year.

In spite of the desperate struggle of LEE to regain the fading prestige of his Virginia veterans, by that frantic assault of Saturday upon GRANT'S lines, the opinion begins to pre- vail, among careful thinkers, that the last great battle of the war is already recorded.

The late engagement along the front of the left wing of this army resolves itself, on due examination, into a movement of the most perfect success, and we hold in our hands the substantial fruits of the victory.
Sundry remonstrances were presented against the Broadway Railroad Bill.

The engagement here yesterday was, without doubt, the most important and successful for the Union arms that has taken place since our arrival in front of Petersburgh. Not only was the enemy met and defeated at every point, but the result demonstrated the fact that they have lost heart in their cause, and that large numbers are ready and anxious to lay down their arms and give up the struggle.

I forward a more detailed account of the two battles fought by SHERMAN'S troops in their progress to a junction with SCHOFIELD and TERRY. The first fight is called the battle of Moore's Cross Roads. Gen. SHERMAN, after leaving Fayetteville, decided to form a junction near Goldsboro.

The correspondent of the London Star writes from Rome, under date of March 10: "I wrote you last week that Gen. McCLELLAN had arrived here; he had not come then, though invitations had been given out for a party for Sunday a week ago to meet him. He arrived last Sunday.

Advices from Arizona to Feb. 15, announce that the expedition under Lieut. BARR had attacked a camp of hostile Indians, and killed nineteen warriors. The Apaches continue to steal and kill horses, mules, and cattle.
The draft begins again to-day. The pending amendment to the Thirty Million Bounty Bill was passed yesterday, and in the afternoon Mr. BLUNT received a telegram from State Paymaster-General ...

A lady named MARY TEXIDO, residing in the upper part of the city, recovered a verdict yesterday in the Supreme Court, circuit, of $2,500, against the Second-avenue Railroad Company, for injuries sustained in March last while she was attempting to alight from one of the cars of the company.

The National Steam Navigation Company's steamer Virginia, Capt. GRACE, which left Liverpool at 10 o'clock on the morning of the 15th, and Queenstown on the 16th March, arrived here last evening. The news is chiefly anticipated.

We have, in the Richmond Enquirer of the 25th, the complete report of Gen. HOOD during the time he commanded in the Southwest. We copy the more interesting portions, omitting that which is merely a narrative of the movements of his forces:
Steamers Octorora, McLaughlin, Baltimore, Wm. Dalzell; Zodiac, Bulkley, Beaufort, Murray Nephew.

The rebel raiders, who robbed the St. Albans (Vermont) Banks and committed other depredations, and who have been on trial here for so long a time, have been discharged from custody. They are now at liberty. Their acts are fully sustained.

Another Canadian Justice has decided that the St. Albans burglars were guiltless of the crime laid to their charge. More strictly speaking, Justice SMITH, of Montreal, decides that the accused were Confederate soldiers, and that as such, they did not come within the Extradition Treaty. To better clinch the matter, in his own Dogberry way, Justice SMITH further, holds that the Extradition Treaty is no longer binding on the contracting parties.
Sundry petitions for, and remonstrances against the Broadway and Crosstown Railroad Bill were presented.
The NEW-YORK WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office, is wrappers, ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS.
Our Charleston correspondent states that "the work of administering the oath of allegiance is progressing with an astonishing cegree of rapidity."

The inauguration meeting of the New-York Association for the Advancement of Science and Art, was held at Cooper Institute last evening. The hall was about half filled with spectators, while the stage was occupied by many prominent citizens, including Mayor GUNTHER, Judge DALY, PETER COOPER, W.C. BRYANT, S.J. PRIME and LORENZO SHERWOOD.
COMMON PLEAS Equity causes. Part I. Nos. 143, 150, 127, 128, 141, 146. Part II. Nos. 104, 108, 117, 113, 126, 103, 482, 96, 28. All the other courts have adjourned for the term.

There are indications that Gen. GRANT has put the entire Army of the Potomac in motion. Our Washington correspondent says it is so understood at the Capitol, and we may hear of great events very soon.
Yesterday morning, very early, the famous English steamer Denbigh arrived from Galveston. She brought papers from Houston to the 18th.
The steamship Asia, from Liverpool at 11 o'olock on the morning of the 18th, via Queenstown on the l9th instant, arrived at Halifax at 6 o'clock yesterday morning.

Lieut. ROBERT J. WARD, Acting Assistant Provost-Marshal, under instructions from Maj. DODGE, resumed the draft in the Fifth District yesterday morning. The quota of the ward is 712, and with the additional one hundred per cent, 1,424; number of ballots in the wheel, 7,099.
Funds firmer and advancing. There is a moderate demand for Discount.
WASHINGTON, Wednesday, March 29. The following is LEE'S official report of Saturday's engagement:

The world does move. It moved in GALILEO'S day, though inquisitorial heresy-hunters clamorously denied it, and forced its keen-sighted asserter to retract the astounding and dangerous dogma. It moves more swiftly in this day than that. Its motion is marked and illustrated constantly by grand and wondrous changes, radically affecting the condition of society.

The forces under command of Maj.-Gen. STONEMAN have, in their rapid advance, recovered one hundred miles of railroad, and are driving the scattered troops of the enemy in confusion before them, Gen. STONEMAN will soon strike the enemy where they least expect it. Probably when this dispatch reaches New-York, the Richmond papers will have chronicled the advance.

Both Houses have been deligently passing bills during the day. Chief Engineer DICKER and EDWD. BUNNELL, Fire Commissioners, and other NewYorkers here, actively lobbying against the Paid Fire Department bill, which, however, was not reached at the time of adjournment.

Information received here to-night from the army of the Potomac, states that the entire army was in motion yesterday, and that Gen. GRANT and staff were to move from City Point during the afternoon. It is not improbable, therefore, that we may hear important news to-morrow.

The course of Gen. LEE in remaining at Richmond surprises many persons who have been looking for some sudden plunge, some great achievement, by which a great General should exhibit extraordinary resources. It was supposed that the close of the Confederacy would be signalized by some startling and brilliant exploits. This seems to me a mistaken theory.

In the Senate yesterday a report was made against removing the capital, for the present at least, but recommended that if moved at all it should be to New-York. The committee report in favor of putting up a new capitol building in Albany. A number of bills concerning private corporations were reported, one to incorporate the New-York Pier and Warehousing Company.

There is an end to the Volunteer Fire Department system of New-York. The Senate bill, substituting for that system a paid department, passed the Assembly yesterday by a vote which lacks but one of a two-thirds majority, and which thus relieves the measure effectually of any partizan or even party character.
The House has been convulsed with prodigious excitement to-night, consequent upon the passage of the Paid Fire Department Bill.
This Board met at 2 P.M., yesterday, Mr. HAYES in the chair.

Wm. Bush, of James-street, a cabinetmaker's apprentice; Anna Farmer, of No. 50 Park-street, a female of the town, and Bridget Sheridan, of Washington-street, a servant, were arrested for larcenies from the person.

THE GOTTSCHALK CONCERTS. The farewell concerts of Mr. GOTTSCHALK and Miss LUCY SIMONS have been unusually attractive and successful. In the course of the third reading of bills, the Metropolitan Paid Fire Department Bill was reach- ed in the Assembly, to-day, at about 1 o'clock P. M. The situation in North Carolina becomes more and more interesting. With his army scarcely organized, Gen. JOHNSTON has been able to resist the advance of the enemy from the time he left the Cape Fear. On three occasions he had given SHERMAN a severe lesson in the art of war, while at Kinston he was no less severely punished by Gen. BRAGG.

SPECIAL FIELD ORDERS No. 35. The General commanding announces to the army that yesterday it beat, on its chosen ground, the concentrated armies of our enemy, who has fled in disorder, leaving his dead, wounded and prisoners in our hands, and burning his bridges on his retreat.

The battle of Saturday morning, on the lines near Petersburgh, is the opening of the Spring campaign. Gen. LEE has taken the initiative, and no longer waits for Gen. GRANT to attack. That the Army of Northern Virginia should take the offensive just when the enemy are confessing to be daily expecting the evacuetion of Richmond, will very materially confound the plans of Gen. GRANT, as well as astonish the too confident Yankee public.

WILLIAM FELIX LIONEL TOLLEMAGHE, commonly known as Lord HUNTINGTOWER, ro recover 15, one quarter's annuity, "granted to her by the detendant in consideration of past cohabitation."

The Junior Exhibition of the New-York Universtiy took place on Friday in the large chapel of the institution, in the presence of a large and select audience. Chancellor FERRIS presided. The platform was occupied by Professors JOHNSON, COPELY, MARTIN and BAIRD. HELMSMULLER'S orchestra band was in attendance and performed several beautiful selections.
At the Police Trial-room last week a majority of both complainants and defendants were from Brooklyn.

The armies in North Carolina are taking a brief repose. SHERMAN'S forces were marching in need of shoes, clothing and other necessaries prior to striking the finishing blow to the rebel Confederacy.

The execution of WILLIAM J. HARRIS, of Boone County, Missouri took place at one o'clock yesterday afternoon on the scaffold in Gratiot Prison yard. HARRIS had been convicted by a military commission of being a guerrilla and highway robber, white he protested his innocence of the charge and claimed that he was a regular soldier of the Confederate army.

Gen. SHERMAN arrived with the leading corps of his army, the Fourteenth, yesterday noon. Gen. SCHOFIELD, who arrived with the Twenty-third Corps on Tuesday last, had just prepared a column to march in the direction of the enemy's rear to create a diversion, when Gen. SHERMAN'S courier arrived with the information that JOHNSTON had retreated across the Neuse River on the morning of the 22d.

The revised Internal Revenue Law went into operation yesterday. It imposes a large increase of taxation on every taxable interest, in response to the wants and claims of the National Treasury.
