Maj. FRANK POPE, Assistant Engineer of the Bulkley Overland Telegraph expedition to Rrussia, leaves this port on Monday next for Sitka, New Archangel, where he will join Col. BULKLEY.
THE REBEL RAMS.

The week has been marked by another heavy decline in railway shares. Prices have now reached a point far below values, unless the public have been previously greatly mistaken as to their actual worth. There is, however, a general feeling of uncertainty as to the condition of our roads, and till this is dispelled we cannot expect to see any very decided recovery.
Amongst other intelligence conveyed to the Yankee papers by their Washington correspondents, we find this:
AMERICAN FINANCES.
The effects of the late storm in this State have been very severe.

The great contest between the Russian Emperor and the aristocracy still continues. We called attention, in a recent issue, to the address put forth by the Moscow Diet, urging a representation of the nobility in a new Imperial Parliament for all Russia.

COUNTRYMAN SWINDLED.?Mr. KENDALL NORRIS, from one of the interior counties of New-York State, was yesterday swindled out of $200 by means of the patent safe game. Three snarpers induced him to accompany them from Lovejoy's Hotel, and proceeding to Litchfield's Woods, near the Flatbush line, succeeded in their purpose and escaped. NORRIS was about emigrating to California.

A letter from the Army of the Potomac, dated Friday evening, says there has been severe fighting on some parts of the line from morning till night, the result of which has been the extension of our lines still further westward, although at a considerable loss in killed and wounded.

The entire interest of Washington seems centered to-day and this evening at the front and upon War Department bulletins. The news of yesterday's victory was generally known at an early hour this morning, and special thanks for it were rendered in several of the churches.

Petitions are being signed by many persons here praying that the President declare Tennessee no- longer an insurrectionary State, and that the Secre- tary of the Treasury will remit the present tax on goods from the Northern States.

The hot fury of battle has raged all but continuously, for three full days, along as inflected line which is now occupied by the main body of Gen. GRANT's forces, and which has stretched from the Appomattox to the South Side Railroad.

Supervisor BLUNT was actively engaged on Saturday in enlisting Volunteers at the Park Barracks. Thirty men were secured, which is a large number for a Saturday's work. The subscriptions to the Bounty Fund Loan amounted to $75,000, and a much larger sum is expected to-day.

The grand movement of the Army of the Potomac, introduced as it is with gratifying tidings of success, naturally absorbs public attention to the exclusion of all other topics. The presence of Mr. LINCOLN with the army; his brief and modest telegrams; the knowledge that GRANT himself is at the front, supervising in person; ...

The formal re-hoisting of the old flag at- Sumter, by Major-Gen. ANDERSON, on the anniversary of the day when it was there lowered, is calculated to give a new prestige to that emblem of our national unity and glory, and is in every way an excellent design.

Preparations are in progress by the government to celebrate in a becoming spirit the restoration of Fort Sumter to the national authority. The day appropriately decided upon for the interesting event is the 14th inst., that being the fourth anniversary of the sorrowful time when the flag of the Union was lowered by the gallant ANDERSON and his brave band after a stout resistance to the overwhelming assaults of the misguided men of South Carolina.

The steamer Gen. Sedgwick, which arrived at this port at noon yesterday, brought as passengers twenty-nine persons saved from the wreck of the transport steamer Gen. Lyon, which took fire off Cape Hatteras on the morning of Friday last, and was totally destroyed. The Gen. Lyon had on board from five hundred and fifty to six hundred souls. The twenty-nine who arrived here yesterday are believed to be all that was saved.
A special meeting of this board was held at 2 o'clock yesterday, Mr. TWEED in the chair.
The United States steam transport Gen. Sedgwick, Capt STARKEY, arrived at this port at noon yesterday, with twenty-nine persons saved from the wreck of the transport steamer Gen. Lyon.

After closing my dispatch yesterday morning and indulging in a brief sleep, I was again startled by the sound of cannon, and ascertained that the postponement of operations was not effective, except in regard to certain especial movements on the left. The fighting was resumed, and was apparently very severe.

Gov. FENTON says there is money sufficient to pay drafted men and probably something more, and there is fair prospects of additional subscriptions to the State loan. The bonds are now ready for payment to towns, cities and counties upon proper proofs being furnished to the Paymaster-General of the muster in and credit of men. He will forward circulars with instructions to-morrow by mail to supervisors and representative agents of localities.

Receipts of the principal kinds of Produce since our last, 18 pkgs. Ashes, 12,173 bbls. Flour, 407 bbls. and 577 bags Corn Meal, 300 bushels Wheat, 6,722 bushels Corn, 623 bushels Barley, 1,215 bushels Malt, 3,645 pkgs. Provisions, and 82 bbls. Whisky.

NARROW ESCAPE OF A FAMILY FROM BEING POISONED OXALIC ACID PUT INTO THEIR TEA BY A COLORED SERVANT. The family of Mr. GEORGE F. MAIN, residing No. 33 Bond-street. Brooklyn, had a narrow escape from being poisoned at the breakfast table yesterday morning.

As the mild weather becomes seasonable and navigation possible, our beautiful harbor and the confluent rivers are made the theatre of great activity and wonderful enterprise. Scores of mammoth steamers thunder through the waters, hundreds of well-modeled palaces glide swiftly on the wave, and thousands of smaller craft betoken by their presence the power and wealth and commerce of this great city.

The County Committee on Volunteering commenced operations yesterday with $60,000 in hand. The announcement of the fall of Richmond gave an impetus to recruiting, and volunteers and substitutes presented themselves freely.

Mr. PRESIDENT Inasmuch as dispatches have been received here announcing the fail of the rebel capital, I move that this board do now adjourn to 1 P.M. on Friday, with three cheers for the success of the Union arms.

NUMONT'S dry goods store, on Market-street, was burned this morning. EVERMAN'S bakery and HELBURNE Co.'s dry goods store, adjoining, were also injured by falling walls and water. The aggregate loss is $80,000, upon which there is very little insurance.

The illuminations last evening were not by any means so general as might have been expected, considering the enthusiasm displayed in the early part of the day: This probably arose from the fact that our citizens had not had time to weigh the full import of the glad tidings.
The advance of Gen. SHERIDAN'S command crossed Hatcher's Run yesterday, meeting only slight opposition and annoyance at that place from the en- emy's cavalry.

A very important arrangement has just been effected for the purpose of facilitating the exchange of prisoners. Brig.-Gen. MORGAN L. SMITH, commanding the post, has the honor of bringing about the first conference in regard to the matter, in which he has been strongly supported by his superior, Maj. Gen. DANA. The arrangement or agreement referred to has an important bearing and must greatly facilitate the objects proposed.

Tuesday, the 21st inst., was a great and joyous day in Charleston. I have already intimated in a previous letter the leading events that happened on the occasion referred to, but the early closing of the mail prevented my giving so many of the particulars as I otherwise should have done. The occasion was a grand celebration by the freed people of Charleston in honor of their release from bondage.

The following was promulgated by the Secretary of State to-day:

The capture of Richmond plucks out the very heart of the rebellion. It is not enough to say that the rebel capital has been taken. Richmond bore a much more important relation to the rebellion than that term would express. It was not merely the locality where rested the rebel government as Washington is the seat of the Federal Government; it was the great generator of the vital force of the Confederacy.

In our financial column we give an official statement of the indebtedness of the nation on last Friday, the 3lst of March, as compared with the figures of Oct. 31, 1864. The grand total of the debt on the 31st ult. was $2,366,955,077, showing an increase of $574,088,037 since July 5, 1864, when Secretary FESSENDEN succeeded Secretary CHASE. This increase has been at a comparatively moderate rate of $2,134,156 per day.
The board met at 1 P.M. yesterday, Mr. JONES in the chair.

Our citizens are still jubilant over the fall of Richmond and Peterburgh. The only military display during to-day was a parade of the Third and Fourth regiments of Gen. HANCOCKS new Veteran Army Corps. They mere commanded by Col. MORGAN and Lieut, Cols. CYRUS and DOBBS. The troops, all honorable veterans, presented a fine appearance.

STATED SESSION TUESDAY, April 4, 1865. Present Morgan Jones, Esq., President, in the chair. Aldermen Moore, Norton, Flynn, Shannon, Gedney, McKnight, Ryan, Jeremiah, Brice, Kelly, Masterson, O'Brien, Farley, Van Voorhis.

Assistant District-Attorney Robert C. Hutchings appeared for the people, yesterday, and called the case of Mary Reedy for trial.

The aspect of the drafting question, yesterday, was far less unpromising than on any previous day. The victories in Virginia induce a notion, by no means without reason, that enlistment now is much more like an engagement to take promenade in blue at a very fair rate of wages, and much less like a covenent with death than heretofore.

In the Senate yesterday a bill was passed authorizing the Manhattan Gas Company, of this city, to charge $3.50 per thousand feet for their gas. Bills were passed for the relief of the Bath and Coney Island Bridge Company; amending the Brooklyn Water Act; incorporating the Soldiers' Messenger Corps; incorporating the Atlantic. Base Ball Club. The remainder of the session was spent in discussing the Registry law.

I find I was correct in stating, not only that each Corps was to attack the enemy's lines at certain points at 4 o'clock yesterday morning, but that each attack was successful, and the entire line carried by them as quickly and surely as it was attempted, thus proving that mud walls are never impregnable when attacked with determination by an equal force, well supplied with artillery and other proper appliances for their assault.

A large number of our most influential and wealthy citizens met at the office of Collector DRAPER yesterday, for the purpose of making arrangements for a grand celebration in honor of the capture of Richmond and Petersburgh, in accordance with the resolutions framed at the great Wall-street meeting of Monday. The meeting was characterized by much enthusiasm and the greatest unanimity. SIMEON DRAPER, Esq., was appointed Chairman, and SAMUEL SLOAN, Secretary.

A meeting of the Board of Engineers and Firemen of the Volunteer Fire Department took place on Tuesday at Firemen's Hall, to act upon communications from the Common Council respecting the Paid Fire Department Law.

ACCIDENT TO SECRETARY SEWERD. At about four o'clock this afternoon, Secretary SEWARD left the State Department in his carriage, and passed up Pennsylvania to Fifteen-and-Half street to his residence, where his son, F.W. SEWARD, and wife, and Miss TITUS got in. While the driver was in the act of closing the door with his right hand, holding the reins with his left, the horses started.

The draft was yesterday in abeyance, the number of recruits being sufficient to keep the District Provost-Marshals busy. We cannot, as has been already observed, furnish on each day the exact figures of enlistments the day before, as the returns are not consolidated in season.

Extensive frauds by Illinois whisky distillers have been discovered, amounting to half a million, by evading the revenue. Some 1,500 barrels cosigned to merchants here have been seized by the authorities.
Mr. J. STUART MILL having been requested to become a candidate for Westminster at the next election, has returned the following reply:

The Cunard mail steamer China, Capt. ANDERSON, which left Liverpool at 8 o'clock on the morning of the 25th and Queenstown on the evening of the 26th March, arrived here yesterday morning.
Sir FREDERICK BRUCE arrived yesterday by the China. The time of his arrival is, in a certain sense, auspicious. Much of the labor that fell to the lot of his predecessor, will probably be spared him.
Advices from Japan, sixty days on the way, announce further reports of murders by the natives of foreigners, and more complications with foreign Powers.

Gen. SHERIDAN attacked and routed LEE'S army, capturing Gens. EWELL, KERSHAW, BUTTON, CORSE and many other general officers, several thousand prisoners and a large number of cannon, and expects to force LEE to surrender all that is left of his army.

Tha latest reliable intelligence of the whereabouts of LEE's fugitive army is that it is at or near Amelia Court-house on the Danville Railroad, without ammunition, and, of course, no means of resupplying.
The funds were without material change. Consols on the 24th closed at 89 @ .

The city was greatly excited yesterday over a report that LEE's army had surrendered, but the joy wss premature; it was FITZ HUGH LEE, and not the General-in-Chief, who had succumbed; at least such was the ultimate story from Philadelphia.

Down the Cumberland, from Nashville to its mouth, the distance is about 200 miles. About thirty miles below Nashville, we enter a range of hills, known as the Highland Rim., inclosing the blue limestone region of Tennesses and following the course of the river for probably thirty miles.

Late Western Louisiana accounts, represent great scarcity of breadstuffs about Alexandria, and much suffering in consequence. The scarcity of forage had compelled the rebel cavalry to depart for Texas, and the infantry has also been withdrawn from Alexandria and had encamped at Natchillo. The Confederate troops at Brownsville have been removed to Galveston to awail attack from the Federals.

The steamers Ajax and United States have arrived from Morehead City with a large number of rebel prisoners and refugees. Steamers are constantly arriving from Newbern with prisoners captured by Gen. SHERMAN.

A dispatch from Geneva this afternoon announces the death of WILLIAM HEATHCOTX DE LANCEY, D.D., D.C.L., Episcopal Bishop of the Diocese of Western New-York. The Bishop was a native of Westchester County in this State, born October 8, 1797, and he had consequently nearly attained his 68th year.
A notice is posted at the War Department that no passes to Richmond are granted under any circumstances.

Collector DRAPER presided, and SAMUEL SLOAN, Esq., acted as Secretary. A large number of prominent citizens were present and took part in the proceedings. The Melbourne Argus, of Jan. 15, relates a singular incident at sea. On the 21st of November, while a heavy sea was running, one of the crew of the steamer London, from London to Melbourne, fell overboard. A boat was at once lowered, and Mr. HARRIS, the sailing master, and five men, pulled off in search of the man, who, however, perished.

The capture of Richmond, which all have looked forward to as the coup de grace of the rebellion, was immediately followed by a very large advance in the share market. The realization of an event had an effect precisely opposite to that produced by its anticipation.

The London Law Times had recently an attack upon this country, which, for a paper that does not claim to be a political sheet, might well have been spared, bus which was as full of blunders as any English attack upon the United States is apt to be.
The steamer John L. Stephens, from Mazatlan, brings $93,000 in treasure and a thousand bags of silver ore.

On my way up the bay last night I fell in with a very intelligent officer from SHERMAN'S army. He left that army on Tuesday evening at Goldsboro, N.C., where it has been encamped for several days. It had done no fighting since the occupation of that town, but was preparing to move at the time he left.

The speech of Lord PALMERSTON on the international situation, which we published yesterday, is a singular compound of shrewd party drilling, and absurd reasoning. In both these characteristics it merits some notice.

Another anniversary of the pleasant college entertainment of Junior Exhibition has come and gone. Such an exhibition as this is far more gratifying to the mind of a son of Alma Mater Yale than that exhibition of "educated rowdyism" which the newspapers, a short time since, chronicled as the last report from these classic grounds.

From officers who have just arrived from the front I learn that on Monday night our men intrenched themselves behind earthworks. On Tuesday siege guns went up from Fort Gaines, and are probably by this time in position and at work.

New-Orleans dates of the 2d inst. are received. The Times says that the monitors Osage and Mil waukee were sunk by torpedoes in Mobile Bay, while attempting to get in range of the Spanish fort. They were not materially damaged, and can be easily raised and repaired.

By the annexed abstract of the log of the Cunard mail steamer China. It will be seen that she has accomplished the voyage from New-York to Queenstown in 8 days, 14 hours and 8 minutes deducting the difference in time a feat quite unparalleled in the annals of screw steam navigation.

The year of jubilee is come. "Glory to God!" The glorious news reached the hospital to-day at 11:30 A.M., and soon spread like wildfire throughout the wards. The convalescents hastened in great crowds to headquarters to hear the enchanting and soul-stirring music of our two expert bands.
The command operating from Pensacola, under Maj. Gen. STEELE, left that point on the afternoon of Sunday, March 20, upon the road leading to Pollard, Alabama.

It is beginning to be hinted in various quarters that a proposal on our part to assume the Confederate debt as a condition of peace would do much to reconcile the masses of the Southern people to the reconstruction of the Union.

The great struggle is over. Gen. ROBERT E. LEE and the Army of Northern Virginia surrendered yesterday to Lieut. Gen. U.S. GRANT and the Army of the Potomac.

The steamship Matanzas, Capt. LIESEGANG, arrived yesterday morning, from City Point, bring900 rebel prisoners, part of those captured by Gen. SHERMAN, at Bentonville, Goldsboro and Columbia. They are in charge of Capt. N.W. PERKINS, Thirteenth Connecticut Battalion, with a squad of 100 U. S. Veterans.

The committee appointed on the 3d inst. to make arrangements for the celebration of our recent victories, held a meeting at the Custom-house, on Saturday. U.S. steam transport Ellen S. Terry, Chapin. Newbern. N.C., April 4, Via Fortress Monroe April 7, with passengers to U.S. Assistant Quartermaster.

The U.S. steamer Vicksburgh arrived at this port to-day from Hampton Roads, and proceeded to the navy-yard. She has been nearly eighteen months in commission, was actively engaged in blockade duty off Wilmington, N.C., and in cruising for runners and privateers, also occupying a prominent part in the engagements, resulting in the capture of Wilmington. Her last duty was up the Pamunkey River.

This very interesting ceremony of the Catholic Church took place yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral, the investor being the Right Rev. the Bishop (LAUGHLIN,) of Brooklyn. The pallum is the badge of authority of an Archbishop of the Catholic Church, and its investiture is as old as the church itself.

The British nation is undergoing one of its semi-occasional spasms about railroad accidents. The great problem how to establish communication between the passenger-cars and the engine-driver is again puzzling the brain of our thick-headed old grandmother.

At noon on Saturday, the government transport Arago sailed from the foot of Beach-street, bound for Fort Sumter, the object of her mission being to convey a large party of ladies and gentlemen to witness the restoration of the old flag to the ramparts of the fort.
Lieut.-Gen. Grant: Thanks be to Almighty God for the great victory with which he has this day crowned you and the gallant armies under your command.
A grand celebration will be held in this city on the 18th of April, in commemoration of the abolition of slavery in the District of Columbia, April 16, 1862 and the subsequent triumphs of freedom.

We find the following paragraph in a recent number of the Frankfort (Germany) Journal. What it says of the service rendered to the American cause in Europe, especially in Germany, by Mr. MURPHY, our Consul at Frankfort, is well deserved.

Among those who delivered speeches to-day was Maj.-Gen. BUTLER. His remarks were principally directed to the subject of the future disposition by the government of the participants in the rebellion. He recommended that all the leaders should be disfranchised and disqualified for holding any office under the government, but that the masses, including the negroes, should have the rights of citizenship. The address was loudly applauded, and at its conclusion the crowd dispersed.

The Goldsboro correspondent of the Associated Press, under date of the 6th inst., states that rebel deserters and refugees report the evacuation of Raleigh by the enemy, and that there is no rebel force of any account between Goldsboro and Raleigh.
The U.S. steam transport Fulton, WOTTON Commander, from Port Royal, S.C., April 7, with mails and passengers to U.S. Quartermaster, arrived here yesterday morning.

The Assembly was occupied to-night with a discussion on the Senate Bill to pay the members of the Common Council of New-York two thousand dollars each per year. The House went into committee, and Mr. VAN BUREN denounced the bill as an outrage on the people of New-York. The proposition was to tax the people without a single petition for it, when money was yearly taken from the treasury by fraud the bill called for.

A letter dated Headquarters Army of the Potomac, Jetersville, Amelia County, April 7, says that on Monday the cavalry under SHERIDAN made as important capture of prisoners, guns and wagons. It appears that LEE'S army was moving as rapidly west as his limited transportion and the demoralized condition of his troops would permit, on the road between Amelia Court-house and Jetersville.

This continent quivered yesterday as never since its upheaval from chaos. The lightning flashed peace, and from ocean to ocean, all minds thrilled with the sense of a new order of things. No more deluge of blood. No more whirls of ruin. No more brooding darkness. The republic rested again, and upon foundations as eternal as the hills. The whole heavens were spanned with the rainbow of promise, and every eye saw it.

War news was very scarce yesterday; no battles nor rumors of battles burdened the wires; they were devoted to the more agreeable task of recording the heartfelt thankgivings for the great victory and the prospect of an early, honorable and permanent peace. It seems quite strange to make up a TIMES without some news of conflict, but the change is happy and welcome, relief not only to the makers but to the readers of newspapers.

The suit of JOSEPH SMITH against CHARLES O. ROGERS, publisher of the Boston Journal, for slander, claming damarges in $10,000, which has been on trial before the Supreme Court, resulted to-day in one cent damages for the plaintiff.
The report of the Conference Committee on the bill authorizing plank-road and turnpike companies to charge additional fare, was concurred in and the bill passed.

VOLUNTEERS AND SUBSTITUTES.--At a meeting of the Kings County Board of Supervisors, yesterday afternoon, a resolution was adopted to pay $50 hand money to every recruit or substitute, and $300 bounty for one year; but that no additional bounty would be paid for men who entered for two or three years.

Vice-Admiral DAVID G. FARRAGUT, United States Navy, arrived here 6 o'clock this morning from Fortress Monroe, in the steamer Louisiana, Capt. PORTER, and was received at the wharf by a large detachment of military, ordered out by Gen. W.W. MORRIS, the Mayor and committee, and many citizens.

Maj.-Gen. Dix, New-York: The capture of Selma is reported by Maj.-Gen.
The afairs of Messrs. SPOONER ATWOOD'S Bank were discussed in the Birmingham Court of Bankruptcy, and it was detetmined to wind up the estate by private arrangement.
The steamer Sierra Nevada, from Portland, Oregon, on Saturday night, brought $110,000 in gold.

In the Assembly this evening, after a lengthy speech from Mr. VEEDER, in favor of the sitting member, a vote was taken on the resolutions of the Committee on Privileges and Elections, throwing out the the vote of the Ninth Election District, Albany City, on the ground that the freedom of the election was violated by mob, and awarding the seat to JOSEPH SHOOK, the contestant. Resolutions were adopted, 59 to 38.

At the charter election held in Jersey City, on Tuesday, Mayor ORESTES CLEVELAND (Dem.) was reelected by a majority of about 500 votes. The largest part of the city and ward democratic ticket was elected; though the Citizens' candidate for Chief of Police, Mr. McMANUS, had a majority of nearly 700.
The steamers Pensacola and Calypso have anchored in Quarantine, and will proceed South the first suitable opportunity. The former will be towed to Baltimore by the latter to receive her machinery.
The second volume of the Diplomatic Correspondence is, like the first, confined to our affairs with Great Britain, ana treats of a variety of subjects.
The steamship New-York, from Southampton on the 30th ult., arrived at this port yesterday afternoon.
Advices from the army about Mobile are to the 4th inst. They state that water communication between the Spanish fort and Mobile has been cut, and a battery established above the fort.

Dispatches from the War Department announce the occupation of Lynchburgh by a scouting party from GRANT'S army. No resistance was made. A brigade of cavalry has been sent there to hold the place and protect property.

The Tribune again sues for JEFF. DAVIS. It submits that to punish him will be "virtually degrading a great conflict of ideas and principles into a paltry matter of detected felony and legal retribution." This is extraordinary language for a loyal journal.

Frequent references have been made to a decision of the Supreme Court by Chief-Justice CHASE some time since, as defining the status of the rebel States and their inhabitants in consequence of the rebellion. As the subject is one of marked and permanent importance, we copy the decision in full from the Washington Republican.

In the case of Wilson vs. The City of New York, tried in the Court of Common Pleas, on Wednesday, the jury, after being out several hours, were discharged yesterday morning without being able to agree upon a verdict. Ths principles involved are regarded as important, not only to individuals, but to New-York in its corporate capacity. The trial was quite fully reported in the TIMES of Thursday.

We have news from Panama to April 5. Matters on the Isthmus have remained quiet since the sailing of the last steamer, though the natives are in constant dread of further revolution. The government keeps a strong night guard around the city, and a couple of old cannon are planted at the entrance of the town, in case the negroes should attempt to make an assault. But there is at present little cause for alarm.

Odell, Hon. Samuel Sloan, Senator Ira Harris, Col. Frank E. Howe, Capt. Worden, U.S.N.; Hon. Abram Hyatt, Hon. Mr. Larkin, of Sing Sing; R.H. McCurdy, L.W. Winchester, Josiah Hedden and others.

A stroke from Heaven laying the whole of the city in instant ruins could not have startled us as did the word that broke from Ford's Theatre a half hour ago that the President had been shot. It flew everywhere in five minutes, and set five thousand people in swift and excited motion on the instant.

Probably no act of the Government of the United States was ever received by its people with profounder satisfaction than the general order, just issued, stopping all drafting and recruiting, and announcing the speedy reduction of all branches of the military establishment. It was the first practical earnest that this dreadful war had indeed ended.

Recent explorations have demonstrated that the Colorado River is navigable for small steamers and sailing vessels for six hundred miles above its mouth, to a point within four hundred miles of Salt Lake, and it is quite certain to be the highway of a great trade between Utah, Arizonia, and California.

The steamship Europa, from Liverpool on the 1st, via Queenstown on the 2nd inst., arrived here at 2 o'clock this morning. She has 43 passengers for this port, and 30 for Boston. Her dates are two days later than those already received.

After a two hours' contest in the Assembly this evening, the final vote on the Metropolitan Health Bill was reached, and the bill was killed beyond resuscitation by a vote of 51 for it to 61 against it.

Some very important action has been had here to-day affecting the reconstruction movement in Richmond; and particularly that portion of it pro- posing a session of the rebel Legislature in Richmond, in the very face of the thousands of real Union men over whom they so long held evil sway.

The organization of two large expeditions against the Indians one to start from Leavenworth, making their base of supplies at Fort Kearney,under command of Gen. MITCHELL, and the other to rendezvous at this post are progressing rapidly. The energy and direction of the whole campaign are under the immediate supervision and command of Maj.-Gen. DODGE, who is working incessantly in order to supply them both with the necessaries for an active and successful campaign.

With an area of about 45,000 square miles, Tennessee is naturally divided into three grand divisions, East, Middle and West Tennessee. The first comprises the mountain section between the border of North Carolina and the Cumberland Mountains; the second stretches thence to the Tennessee River below the Muscle Shoals; the third comprises that, part of "Messopotamia" between the lower Tennessee and the Mississippi, the residue being in Kentucky.

The news of the capture of Mobile is confirmed by official dispatches printed in New-Orleans. Spanish Fort was captured on the 9th, and 700 prisoners were taken. The last sad rites are to begin to-day. Not they alone in the nation's capital will celebrate them, but the loyal millions from the Atlantic to the Pacific. The coffin in which was deposited the dead body of our deceased President was kept open from 12 o'clock Monday noon, until 12 o'clock Tuesday noon. From the earliest moment to the latest, every facility compatible with the narrow arrangements of the committees, was offorded the public for viewing the remains.

At an adjourned meeting of the Board of Education, last evening, an appropriation of $28,000 was made for repairing Grammar School-house, No. 15, in the Eleventh Ward; $7,000 was appropriated for altering and repairing Grammar School-house, No. 45, in the Sixteenth Ward, and other routine business was transacted.

The Legislature has reached that stage of the session when important matters are acted upon hastily, when members receiving no compensation from the State for their services loss something of the feeling of responsibility that governs their action earlier in the session; when many things are done, for which they are afterward accused, and some things are done which have to be repented of.

BURGLARY. The clothing establishment of Mr. A. AYRES, No. 363 Fulton-street, was feloniously entered on Tuesday night, by prying off the shutters of the rear window. Goods to the value of $150 were stolen, consisting of ready-made clothing mainly. The Lafayette Insurance Company, in the same block, was robbed a few evenings previously.
JOHN O'CONNELL, a youth of 17, was detected in the act of passing to a confederate a gold watch he had stolen while riding on the platform of a Sixth- avenue Railway car on Tuesday afternoon.

The Right Rev. Dr. COXE delivered an interesting lecture last evening on the subject of the Russo- Greek Church, at the Church of the Incarnation, corner of Madison-avenue and Thirty-fifth-street. The pillars, pulpit, chancel, and desk were heavily draped with crape, relieved with white rosettes. The audience was large and highly intellectual.

Our correspondent at Havana writes that the news of the assassination of President LINCOLN created intense horror and indignation among the people of that city, and that the open exultation of the Confederates over the atrocious crime excited general disgust and reprobation.

The steamer Olive Branch, from New-Orleans 21st, has passed up for St. Louis, with 35 bales of cotton and 619 paroled prisoners from Vicksburgh.

The English schooner Joseph Reed, which arrived a few days ago from Matamoras, brings the important news that Gen. CORTHINAS had declared against the empire, and had taken up a position on the highroad from Monterey to Matamoras, having seized the horses belonging to the stages and carts that were carrying merchandise between the two places.

THE JAMES-STREET MURDER. Corner GOVER held an inquest, yesterday, at the Fourth Ward Police Station, over the remains of THOMAS CASEY, who was shot by FREDERICK HISLEY, a young Canadian, in JAMES CASEY'S liquor-store, at No. 40 James-street, on Tuesday afternoon.

Yesterday morning, at 12:30 o'clock, the steamer Massachusetts, with a load of soldiers, the greater part of whom were exchanged and paroled prisoners collided with a steamer named the Black Diamond, a small barge propeller in the Potomac River, one mile from Blackstone Island, which was acting there as a packet boat, and had on board a guard of some twenty men.
We had a rumor in town yesterday that Gen. GRANT had been assassinated. The only noteworthy feature of the case was that nobody deemed it impossible, or even unlike- ly.

The United State steam transport Fulton WOTTON, from Port Royal, S.C., April 23, to United States Quartermaster, arrived here yesterday noon. The painful intelligence of the assassination of President LINCOLN and Secretary SEWARD caused a deep and profound impression among all classes of our citizens.
The NEW-YORK WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office, in wrappers, ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS.

The steamship Africa, Capt. ANDERSON, from Liverpool, at 11 o'clock on the morning of the 15th, via Queenstown, on the 16th inst., arrived here at 5 o'clock this evening. She has 57 passengers for this port, and 52 for Boston. Her dates are three days later than those already received.
In common, as is presumed, with the whole of the northern portion of the Union, on the 4th inst., the reinauguration of Mr. LINCOLN, was celebrated here in grand style.

The arrival yesterday afternoon of the steamer Liberty, and the awful and unexpected intelligence of the assassination of President LINCOLN, and the attempted assassination of Secretary SEWARD and his son, caused a great deal of excitement.

Two blockade-running steamers, the Wren and the Badger, bearing the English flag and laden with cotton, entered this port yesterday from Galveston, the former consigned to HELM, the Confederate agent, and the latter to the Spanish firm of HERRTRA Co. The Wren had thirteen passengers and the Badger four.

Notwithstanding the regular arrival of steamers from St. Domingo, little or nothing is known here of the state of things in that island, were it not that the subject of the abandoning St. Domingo, which is to be debated in the Spanish Cortes at Madrid, gives one an inkling as to affairs in that island.

The statement that President JOHNSON declines all precautions for his personal safety is erroneous. True, he has not given any special directions for guards to be placed about his person, but he ap- proves the precautions taken by the authorities which embrace the continuance upon duty of the late President's body-guard, commanded by Lieut. J.B. JAMIESON, of Ohio.
The Historical Society held a very interesting meeting last evening, at the hall corner of Secondavenue and Eleventh-street. The President, FREDERIC DE PEYSTER, Esq., presided.

"Peace, from the Potomac to the Rio Grande, and a hope soon to lead you to your homes," were the cheering words in which Gen. SHERMAN announced to his proud army the result of his two days' conference with Gen. JOHNSTON. The terms, as they were understood in the army, unconditional submission to the laws as they will be interpreted by the civil courts of the Federal Government, were read with perfect satisfaction.

SIR: In my last dispatch, of the 12th inst., I had the honor to inform the department that Gen. GRANGER and myself hed demanded the immediate and unconditional surrender of the City of Mobile, and that it would undoubtedly be accorded, as the city was at our mercy and we were in possession of the outside forts.

New-York has lost one of her most illustrious sons. The eminent surgeon, the honored, kind, and philanthropic citizen. VALENTINE MOTT, M.D., L.L. D., died last night at his residence, No. 1 Gramercy Park. Dr. MOTT was born in Glencove, L.I, Aug. 20, 1785. His father, Dr. HENRY MOTT, was for many years a practicing physician in this city.

BROADWAY THEATRE. Mr. and Mrs. CHARLES KEAN old favorites of our public reappeared here last evening. They have been honored by the generation that has gone, they come merely to take farewell of that which is going.

Slavery has written its guilt and its folly on the record of history, as no other human crime has ever done. It has insanely sought to overthrow the best structure of government which mankind ever erected; it has deluged this continent with the blood of our noblest and best; it has piled on us mountains of debt, and thrown civil discord into a happy people.

Some of the Democratic journals justify and applaud Gen. SHERMAN'S stipulations with the rebel JOHNSTON. Others, more chary, do not venture to approve these stipulations outright, yet complain that Gen. SHERMAN is too harshly judged.
ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--Mr. GROVER announces "Faust" for this evening, with the admirable cast which won the success of the work last season.

The members of the Berean Baptist church, (Rev. Dr. DOWLING) held a memorial meeting last evening, for the purpose of adopting appropriate resolutions and listening to addresses on the death of President LINCOLN.

About 8 o'clock last evening we received the intelligence of the capture of J. WILKES BOOTH, the assassin of ABRAHAM LINCOLN, and one of his accomplices in the murder, DAVID C. HARROLD. The following are such of the particulars as we were enabled to gather, which, with the exception of the precise locality where the occurrence took place, we give as being reliable and correct.
We were rejoiced, on the 14th inst., to publish the first orders from government for retrenching expenses. They were of a nature to produce a vast effect on the country.

On Monday, April 24, the Sixteenth New-York Cavalry detachment started out on the south side of the Potomac in chase of BOOTH. They crossed the Rappahannock River at Fredericksburgh, and moved down on the west fork of that stream to the vicinity of Port Royal, a distance of some twenty-five miles. They had with them a photograph of BOOTH and an accurate personal description.

Scouts from Fredericksburgh report that that city and vicinity need the protection of the Government against rebel officers and soldiers, disbanded from LEE'S army, who are now marauding upon the provisions and property of the inhabitants. Young men belonging to respectable families, who have been in the army, swear they will not work for a living, and devote themselves to plunder.

A well-known citizen of Baltimore committed suicide last Monday, a short distance from this city, by shooting himself with a pistol. No cause could be assigned for the rash act, except that he had recently seemed depressed and melancholy.

Within twelve hours after the death of Mr. LINCOLN, certain "friends" of Mr. JOHNSON, to the number of about twenty, met in an upper chamber in Washington for the purpose of reconstructing the Cabinet. That there was wine and good cheer around the board need not be said, for these are always present at political meetings in Washington.

DOUBLE TRACK. The work of laying a double track on the Camden and Amboy route is progressing steadily, the portions of the road where it is most necessary having already been provided with additional rails.

The excitement which prevailed in this city yesterday has considerably subsided. While all regret that the assassin, owing to the rashness of the soldiers engaged in the capture, was not taken alive, they at the same time felt grateful that the murderer had paid the penalty of his crime. Had he been brought to the Washington Navy-yard alive nothing could have withstood the fury of the excited congregated thousands.
The remains of ABRAHAM LINCOLN arrived here at 1 o'clock this morning. The bells were tolled and minute guns fired.

Late on Thursday night, ANDREW WILLIAMS, an English seaman, and JAMES BARR, of No. 127 Cedar-street, fought in Broadway, near the Astor House, and WILLIAMS slabbed BARR in the left side with a sharp pocket-knife, inflicting a serious wound. WILLIAMS was arrested by policeman O'CONNOR, of the Third Ward, and, after examination, committed for trial.

JOHNSTON'S surrender of his entire army leaves no rebel force this side of the Mississippi. KIRBY SMITH has a few thousand on the other side; but they have long been in a very disorganized condition, and will now disperse at once. We very safely assume that the last gun of this war has been fired.
A private dispatch from St. Louis reports the explosion and sinking of the steamer Sultana on the Mississippi place and date not given and adds that a great many soldiers lost their lives.

The full history of the transactions between the pirates of the Shenandoah and the British authorities at Melbourne is now before us. We venture to say it supplies an illustration of "neutral" malice, imbecility and cowardice combined such as has not been witnessed during the whole of this war.

THE STEAMER RISING STAR. In our account of this vessel published yesterday, were some errors which are corrected in the description given below: The side-wheel steamer Rising Star, when completed, will be put on the route between New-York, New-Orleans and Havana, in connection with the Morning Star and Evening Star. She is built of white oak, hacmetac, , and is securely fastened. Her length is 318 feet: beam, 44 feet: depth, 31 feet 6 inches.

The Veteran Temperance Corps, organized April 16, 1865, and composed of persons who have not used intoxicating liquors as a beverage for a third of a century, held a meeting last evening in the Forty-eighth-street Methodist Episcopal Church.

WILLIAM LAWRENCE McDONALD, arrested on suspicion of violating the neutrality laws, was brought up yesterday morning, at the Police Court, before Alderman J. VANCE. The court-room was well filled with Southern sympathizers, among whom was the St. Albans raider Bennett H. Young, and the public generally. The court was delayed for some time, through Godfrey J. Hyams being before the Grand Jury in the case of Bennett H. Young.

RUFFIANLY OUTRAGE. Mr. ALEXANDER McDONALD, residing in South Fifth-street, near Second, Eastern District, reports that he was attacked by two or three ruffians near his residence, late on Wednesday night, after his return from New-York, and robbed of what money he had in his pockets. His assailants treated him so roughly that he has been confined to his room ever since.

The dilemma in reference to the rebel army of Gen. JOHNSTON is satisfactorily solved. The Lieutenant-General has sent official information to the War Department from North Carolina that JOHNSTON has surrendered the forces of his command on the basis agreed upon, on the 9th instant, for the surrender of the army of Gen. LEE. We need not say that this will be perfectly satisfactory to the country, as it assuredly is to the government.

There is no one member of the Cabinet about whom public opinion has been so surely, though gradually changing, as in regard to the Secretary of War. The faults which appeared in the beginning of his administration his impulsiveness in public action, and his sometimes harsh treatment of individuals are being forgotten in the splendor of his successes and the integrity of his administration.

The present is the last session of the existing British Parliament. And although there are no important measures put upon the ministerial programme, to tickle the liberal electors and the great unenfranchised multitude, there is a greater amount of party engineering in progress, than has been witnessed for many years. Everybody seems to take it for granted --we know not why--that Lord PALMERSTON must, perforce, retire at the end of the present Parliamentary term.

The death of our late noble and illustrious President continues here, as elsewhere, and will, at least till the grave covers his honored remains, the topic that absorbs all others, that seems indeed to render people impatient of bestowing a transient attention upon matters which at other times would be regarded as full of interest and moment.

The Parlimentary recess still continued. The usual Easter banquet was given by the Lord Mayor of London at the Mansion House, on the 17th, but it was devoid of political interest, no Cabinet Minister being present. Mr. and Mrs. FERNANDO WOOD and Miss WOOD were among the guests.

The matinee at the German opera on Saturday failed to excite the usual degree of interest. It was to speak plainly, badly attended. Although we may partly account for this by the fact that the National Academy is now the popular lounging place, and the sterner fact that Saturday was set aside for the domestic convulsion called moving, there is still another reason.

The extraordinary story of the escape of a rebel ram from the upper waters of the Red River comes to us in such a shape, that it is difficult to know whether to treat it as a needless exaggeration or a warning of danger.

The ball-playing season of 1865 was duly inaugurated during the latter part of last week, and henceforth, until the cold winds of November stop field sports, the invigorating exercises and manly recreations of our Metropolitan ball clubs will be the feature of the out-door sports of the season.

Major-Gen. HALLECK's recent order, opening up the ports of Virginia and unloosing the reins from commerce, has acted already on this community like a beneficent Summer shower upon parched vegetation. What gave that order more joyful significance was the fact that it wes distinctly announced as given by command of the President himself.

We hear nothing definite as to the Probable whereabouts of JEFF. DAVIS or the route he has taken. It is believed he is travelling incog., en route for Texas, and that he will be captured before he gets there. DAVIS to include himself in the capitulation.

The first act of the American war has closed with a tremendous finale. BROADWAY THEATRE.--SHAKESPEARE'S comedy --kindly called "brilliant" in the programme--of "Much Ado About Nothing," was played here last evening. The fifty-ninth anniversary of the Orphan Asylum Society of New-York, was celebrated at Irving Hall yesterday afternoon. A large and fashionable audience was present. The express train on the Erie Railroad, which left Buffalo at 6 o'clock on Thursday evening, the 4th inst., met with a most frightful accident while crossing the bridge over the Conestoga River, near the village of Painted Post, about two miles west of Corning. The train, it appears, broke bodily through the bridge, precipitating the first passenger-car, the baggage-car, and the locomotive into the stream below.

THE STREET-CLEANING COMMISSION.--The newly-appointed Street-Cleaning Commission, comprising the Mayor, Comptroller, City Inspector, Corporation Counsel and Recorder, met on Saturday afternoon in the Mayor's office. His Honor was elected Chairman and the Recorder appointed Secretary. Tne Corporation Counsel was directed to draw up specifications for the work of cleaning the streets, and submit them to the commission at its next meeting. The commission then adjourned to Monday next, at 4 P.M.

Two of our paroled prisoners have arrived at Raleigh, hanging news that JEFF. DAVIS was at Charlote, N.C., on the 25th of April, but that be left on that day bound for the West. He had a train of twenty wagons, escorted by 3,000 cavalry under Gen. ECHOLS and BASIL DUKE.

The following circular from Gen. FRY has been forwarded to the Commissioners of the Boards of Enrollment in the Southern District of New-York, by Col. DODGE. The dismissal of commissioners will extend throughout the United States, and will prove a great reduction of the expenses of the government.
ART, 1. The government concedes to the company the entire and perpetual ownership of the railroad and all its appurtenances.

Nothing new occurred yesterday of interest in the disputed legality of the new Fire Law, except that the commissioners of a Paid Department have engaged WALDO HUTCHINGS as their counsel, with instructions to defend the board before the courts, and authority to engage such legal assistance as he may deem necessary. The entire matter, therefore, will rest wholly with the courts, and until their action is known no new features will arise.

The war excitement in America being now at an end, the finance question becomes the grand one. During the next three months the most extensive speculative operations of the two hemispheres will depend upon it, and a correct resume of its present position in therefore a critical requirement. On the 31st ult. the United States debt was 473,000,000, of which 290,000,000 bears interest payable in coin, and 105,000,000 consists of currency.

It is announced, somewhat abruptly as it seems to us, that the season of German Opera will end with this evening's performance. We have of course seen, and with constant regret, that the attendance was not of a remunerative character, but the Academy has not been worse off in this respect than any other place of amusement.

In the English House of Lords on Thursday might, Earl RUSSELL, and in the House of Commons, Mr GEORGE GREY, (on behalf of Lord PALMERSTON.) gave notice that they would on the 1st of May, move an address to the Queen, expressing sorrow and insignation at the assassination of President LINCOLN, and praying her to convey that expression of feeling to the American Government.

FIRE IN A FIREWORKS MANUFACTORY.--Between 1 and 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon a fire was discovered in the basement of Messrs. EDGES' fireworks establishment, at North Point, Jersey City. The firemen were promptly at work and succeeded in confining the fire to the room in which it originated. Loss by fire and water about $500.

No one acquainted with the history of those leading rebel spies who have been playing the alternate roles of peace commissioners and cut-throat conspirators in the neighboring provinces can be at all surprised to learn that SANDERS and TUCKER have tied from Montreal. Had there been nothing else to point to their complicity with the assassins, they have merited suspicion, ever since the murder was committed, by protesting too much.

HENRY WARD BEECHER, the Secretary of the Union read the annual report, showing that about $14,000 had been subscribed during the year, and that a balance of about $2,000 still remained unexpended.

The members of the New-York Club opened play for the season at Bedford yesterday, and, though the uncertain appearance of the weather and occasional showers which fell prevented as full an attendance as was expected, quite a number of players were on the ground, and in the afternoon sides were chosen, and an interesting game of one innings was played.

It is imagined generally in England that the United States, now that the rebellion is overthrown, will soon attempt to get possession of Canada, either by violence or by negotiation. Parliament debates solemnly how best to fortity and defend it; and a great deal is said in the press about the expediency of letting it go rather than fight for it.

Yesterday, on the morning train from Big Black, the rebel Gen. HODGE, and Cols. HENDERSON and WATTS, came into the city on an official visit to the military authorities here. They stopped at the Washington Hotel, and were well received by our military officers as well as citizens. They left on the afternoon train for Big Black, after an interview of several hours with Gens. DANA and SMITH.

BROOKLYN BOARD OF ALDERMEN.--The board met last evening, Alderman WHITNEY, the President in the chair. A communication from the Mayor was received, calling the attention of the board to the neglected and disgraceful condition of Washington Park, stating that the walks should be graded, trees planted, shrubbery arranged, and that the whole required to be inclosed with a substantial iron railing.

The absolute surrender of DICK TAYLOR, the only rebel commander east of the Mississippi, is positively announced by a telegram from Gen. WILSON, at Macon, to the War Department. There are now no organized rebel forces east of the Mississippi, and guerrillas become outlaws, to be hunted without mercy.
Intelligence has been received here giving further particulars of the flight of DAVIS.

Yesterday the offices lately occupied by the County Volunteer Committee, in the City Hall Park, were sold at public auction, together with their contents, consisting of a number of chairs, tables, stools, safes and stoves.
Five hundred and fifty bales of cotton passed here to-day for Cincinnati, and 40 for St. Louis.
It has been vaguely reported heretofore, that President JUAREZ, of the Mexican Republic, had issued letters of marque for reprisals against French commerce. This is now an established fact.

The light draft monitor Waxsaw wes successfully launched last Thursday afternoon, after a second attempt, from the yard of Mr. DENMEAD, a Canton, Maryland. She has 1 turret, is 225 feet long 45 feet wide, and 11 feet deep, with a wood backing of 4 feet, and an iron coating of 4 inches thick, and water-tight compartments. She will not be ready for service for at least one month.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--There was an exceedingly fine house last evening to witness the final representation of "Les Huguenots," and the regret was general that it should, indeed, be the only remaining opportunity of hearing MEYERBEER'S grand work. Mr. GROVER'S season terminated with the evening, and for the present, at least, we shall have no more of German singers or German music.

DANIEL O'CONNELL and FRANCIS KINNEY fought in Vandewater-street, near Pearl, at about 9 o'clock on Sunday night, and O'CONNELL received a severe stab in the abdomen. He was taken to Bellevue Hospital, and Patrolman HORBELT, of the Fourth Ward, apprehended KINNEY and took him to the Tombs. The prisoner was committed to await the result of O'CONNELL'S wound.

The advance of Gen, HOWARD'S army reached Blacks and Whites Station on the Southside Railroad on Saturday, having marched nearly one hundred and fifty miles in five days and a half. The brave boys are returning from the wars, and march with light hearts and elastic step.

CHARLES REED, a Swedish seaman, took laudanum late on Sunday night, at No. 98 Mott-street, while suffering under temporary derangement. Patrolman TUCKER, of the Fourteenth Ward, took him to the New-York Hospital, and he died shortly after his admission to that institution. He was about 30 years of age.

The Mercantile Library Association held its forty-fourth annual meeting at their hall in Astorplace last evening. Several interesting reports were read, showing the prosperity of the Organization. The society now has over 73,000 volumes of books, and the list shows that there are over 6,000 paying members. Interesting speeches were made by Hon. Judge DALY and Messrs. LATHERS, PRIME, DODGE and HUNT. The proceedings were enlivened by excellent music, furnished by DODWORTH'S Band.

The eleventh annual meeting of the Brooklyn Young Men's Christian Association was held in their Rooms at the Washington Institute last evening, and in view of the unfavorable state of the weather, was well attended. The President, Mr. WM. EDSALL, occupied the chair, and after the usual preliminary exercises the business of the meeting was proceeded with.

The first session of the thirty-second anniversary of the American Anti-Slavery Society was held yesterday morning, at 10:30 o'clock, in the Church of the Puritans, (Rev. Dr. CHEEVER'S.) The heavy fall of rain in no way interfered with the entire numerical success of the occassion, as at 9:30 the spacious edifice was crowded to its fullest capacity.

The twenty-ninth anniversary of the American Temperance Union was celebrated at Irving Hall last evening. About one hundred persons were present, one-half of whom were ladies, Hon. WILLIAM A. BUCKINGHAM, Governor of Connecticut, presided.

JAY COOKE reports the subscriptions to-day to the Seven-thirty Loan at $15,165,300. The largest single Western subscriptions were $380,700, from the Second National Bank of Chicago, and $200,000 from the Fourth National Bank of Cincinnati.

The steamer Corsica, Capt. LE MESSURIER, arrived, yesterday morning, at this port, with advices from Havana to the 6th, and from Nassau to the 8th inst. The news from Havana is not later than previously received.

A meeting in behalf of the Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions was held yesterday morning at Irving Hall. Interesting addresses were made by missionaries from China and the Nestorian Missions, and others. The statement of the society, as read by one of the Secretaries, was full of interest, and gave a good report of progress in the past, and an augury of good for the future.
The court-martial for the trial of BENJAMIN G. HARRIS, Member of Congress from Maryland, charged with violating the Fifty-sixth Article of War in harboring rebel soldiers, resumed proceedings to-day.

AID FOR SOLDIERS AND SAILORS.--A "committee " of gentlemen of this city was organized some time since, for the propose of aiding in the work of caring for our sick and wounded soldiers, by opening reading-rooms, and furnishing to the soldiers libraries of entertaining and instructive books, such as history, travels and voyages, poetry, and the standard romances.

Morris Schlessinger was tried yesterday, for the crime of receiving stolen goods. The case was, therefore, abandoned by the District Attorney.

The country is devastated and its immediate resources ruined.

Next to the murder of the Emperor, none other could have produced the same perturbation in the public mind. With one general accord it is admitted that the Confederate cause, which was already dead materially, is now dead morally.

They have pretended that they did this not for any selfish objects of their own, but from a sincere conviction that the rebel cause was just. FREE EXHIBITION. A pair of stallions driven to carriage without bridles, reins or traces, by A.H. Rockwell, on Duboise Association Track, 8th-av. between 144th and 148th sts., New-York, FRIDAY and SATURDAY, May 19 and 20, at 4 o'clock P.M. This is a feat of horsemanship that is truly wonderful, and has never been equaled in this or any other country.

Mrs. PERRINE, charged with assisting the rebel cavalry in plundering the train between Baltimore and Philadelphia, during the rebel invasion last Summer, set up a plea to-day through her counsel, Mr. CORWIN, that the Military Commission has no right to try, nor jurisdiction over, her case. Now that peace is proclaimed, such cases as the one before the court are to be tried by the judicial courts of the United States.

The proceedings which were commenced before the courts of England to procure the extradition of CHARLES WINDSOR, the defaulting teller of the Mercantile Bank, that he might be brought to this country for trial and punishment, have resulted in a failure, the Court of Queen's Bench, before whom he was brought on a writ of habeas corpus, having discharged him from arrest.

The Chattanooga Gazette of May 9 states that in the early part of the week preceding, Maj. Gen. JAS. B. STEEDMAN, commanding the District of the Etowah, proceeded to Resacca, where he was met by Brig.-Gen. W. T. WOFFORD, commanding the Confederate forces in North Georgia, and the terms of the surrender of the rebel forces were agreed upon.

John Kruschinsky vs. Frederick Dinkel. The plaintiff in this case sued the defendant to recover the sum of $5,000 damages in an action of slander, for words spoken in the German language. The parties and their witnesses are all Germans, and, with one or two exceptions, they are unable to speak English so is to be understood in court without the aid of an interpreter.

JOE BROWN, late rebel Governor of Georgia, was brought to this city last night as a prisoner, and eft for Louisville this evening. He has been a violent rebel, but, on account of his opposition to JEFF. DAVIS, he has found some favor with the Union people of his State.

The London Times A SENSIBLE CONCLUSION.--The London Times has come to the conclusion that much mischief has been caused by the utterance in England of "loose ideas" respecting the United States. It seeks, therefore, to make some amends for its own delinquencies, by devoting a leader to unqualified praise of the statesmanlike qualities of which President JOHNSON, in its judgment, shows himself possessed.

INDIANAPOLIS, Tuesday, May 16. A dispatch from Washington to Gen. HARVEY announces a suspension of the execution of BOWLES and MILLIGAN, and a commutation of HORSYES' sentence to imprisonment for life.

LIVERPOOL, Saturday, May 6--P.M. COTTON.--The market has been rather than and irregu lar to-day. American and Egyptian are generally about d. below the official quotations of yesterday. Sales of the day 6,000 bales, including 1,500 for export and speculation.

On the 5th instant, in the House of Lords, the Earl of AIRLIE asked whether negotiations were still pending with respect to the defences of Canada. He complained of the reluctance of Canada to assume those duties of defence which went incumbent on every free State, although the mother country had fully recognized her obligation of assisting it against any aggression.

WASHINGTON, Tuesday, May 16. The cavalry corps under command of Maj. Gen. CROOK, which left Petersburgh and Richmond on the 10th inst., arrived at their camp, on the road from Washington to Alexandria, this afternoon. Your veteran correspondent, Capt. PAUL, came through with them. The march was made in easy stages, and the men and horses are in fine condition.
LOUISVILLE, Tuesday, May 16. Major-Gen. THOMAS arrived this evening en route for Washington.
ST. LOUIS, Tuesday, May 16. Cairo dispatches say that Gen. NEGRETE, with 4,500 Liberal troops, appeared before Matamoras on the 29th ult. and demanded its surrender, which was refused.

PHILADELPHIA, Tuesday, May 16. JAY COOKE reports subscriptions to the Seven thirty Loan to-day to the amount of $1,743,800. The largest subscriptions were: $200,000 from the First National Bank of Cincinnati: $50,000 from the First ...

The latest news from Italy gives a less hopeful sign of an early reconciliation between the Pope and VICTOR EMMANUEL then we had anticipated. The Ultramontane party evidently give tokens of backing out of the proposal to concede to the King of Italy the patronage of the bishopries, even with the reservation of a certain veto power to the Pontiff.
LIVERPOOL, Saturday, May 6--Evening. COTTON--Easier, and slightly declined; sales 6,000 bales, including 1,500 to speculators and exporters.

VETERANS OF THE NATIONAL GUARD.--The association under this name, organized six years ago, now comprises 210 members. The objects of the association are to institute a bond of union between former and present companions in arms, and to create a fund to afford pecuniary relief to indigent members, or their widows and children.

The executive order of President JOHNSON respecting Virginia, makes thorough work. It is a complete wiping out of four years of the civil history of the State, as far as rebels had to do with it in any way. It makes null and void every legislative act, every judicial act, every executive act, of whatever character. Of course, thousands of these acts had no bearing whatever upon the rebellion.

The two Senators from the new State of Nevada, Messrs. STEWART and NYE, spoke at a public meeting last night concerning the mineral resources of the young State of which they are the first representatives in the United States Senate.
We learn from Fortress Monroe that the farmers are returning to their plantations, now that the war is over, and are making strenuous efforts to produce good harvests.

The funds on the 6th were firmer, and Consols fractionall improved, closing at 90 @90 for both money and accounts. The assassination of Mr. LINCOLN called forth an able letter from "Historicus" to the London Times, which we copy to-day, and in which, as our readers may see, there was no lack of just appreciation and kindly expression.

JAY COOKE reports the subscriptions to-day to the seven-thirty loan at $1,561,400. The largest single Western subscriptions were: $200,000 from the First National Bank of Pittsburgh: $50,000 from the Second National Bank of Cleveland.

To the Editor of the London Times: SIR: The American civil war is beyond doubt the greatest event in the histroy of mankind which has occurred since the French Revolution. Dr. J. FOSTER JENKINS has resigned his position as General Secretary of the United States Sanitary Commission, and Mr. JOHN S. BLATCHFORD has been appointed to that office.

We learn from Havana that the rebel ram Stoneman reached that port on the morning of the 11th inst. Her arrival caused considerable excitement. At a meeting of the Board of Education, last evening, was shown that the compensation of teachers of music, German and French, in the Ward Schools, is, in many instances, greater than that of the principals of the schools. The scarcity and high price of flour at Boise City, Ideho, culminated on the 1st of April in a popular outbreak and raid upon the flour stores. The distubance was quelled, and the prices of flour reduced. There is a considerable supply now on the way.

THE "MOURNING DRAPEBY" USED FOR DRESSES FOR SOLDIERS' WIDOWS. Much of the "mourning drapery" used for decoration at the funeral of our late President, in this city, has been collected by the NewYork State Agent, No. 50 Howard-street, for the widows and orphans of our soldiers.

THE WALPOLE BANK ROBBERY. In November last, a party of burglars broke into the dwelling of the cashier of the Walpole Bank, at Walpole, N.H., and stole from that officer's pantaloons pocket the key to the safe, and with this entered the vault, stealing $45,000 worth of bank-notes, Treasury notes and United States bonds.

A review of the teachings of the London Times on the subject of the rebellion, is being prepared in England, and will, we believe, be issued very shortly. It will be a singular and rather amusing pamphlet. In what manner it will be arranged, we do not know, but it ought to contain three divisions devoted to the letters of the New-York correspondents, the articles of the money editor, and the regular editorials respectively.

We have long since learned to get along without the benefit of European critical appreciation of our military efforts, just as we wore forced, also, to get along, to a great extent, without European sympathy in our struggle with the rebellion.

Occupying an ordinary and commonplace position in one of the show-cases in the large hall of the Patent Office, is one little model which in ages to come will be prized as at once one of the most curious and one of the most sacred relies in that vast museum of unique and priceless things. This is a plain and simple model of a steamboat roughly fashioned in wood by the hand of ABRAHAM LINCOLN.

The commissioners appointed by the Legislature to make a contract for cleaning the streets have prepared specifications of the work to be done, and the bids are to be opened at noon on Monday next.

Mr. DENNIS McFEELY, a workman in the Eagle Coffee-Mills, at No. 200 Fulton-street, was missing from noon on Wednesday until the time of closing the mills, when his mutilated corpse was found in the cellar under the hatchway, through which it is supposed that he accidentally fell from one of the upper stories of the building. The jury rendered a verdict of "accidental death."

The formidable iron-clad ram Dunderberg is now about approaching completion. Her keel being laid Oct. 4, 1862, it was expected that long since she would have participated in the splendid naval engagements that have marked the history of our navy during the rebellion; but owing to various causes, the delay in her machinery and the contemplated change by the government in her original design, the bright anticipations respecting her have not been realized.

The Army of the Potomac has passed in review. The first day's pageant is over, and to the correspondent falls the duty of depicting a scene almost devoid of incident, save in its grand aspiration.

Gen. McDOWELL has convened a Military Commission to try the rebel pirates under the command of HOGG, alias ENSON, arrested in November last off Panama, while attempting to seize the steamer Salvador. They were brought hither by the steam frigate Lancaster several months ago and have been confined at Fort Alcatraz, in this harbor. The proofs of their guilt are believed to be irrefragable.

The weather to-day was everything that could be desired for the unprecedentedly grand review of the Army of the Potomac. The atmosphere was pleasant, the sun shone with unclouded splendor, and the recent rains had laid the dust, putting the streets in good marching condition.

Gold has advanced 6 and 8 per cent. in the New-York market since the close of last week. The market has been influenced by an active export demand, which is now taking specie out of the country at an average rate of three millions a week.

The United States vs. One Bale Containing Human Hair.--This was an action to forfeit the goods for alleged fraudulent undervaluation. KIRBY SMITH'S forces have surrendered, in accordance with arrangements made with Gen. CANBY. This ends the rebellion, as SMITH'S command was the only organized force yet holding out. The surrender includes the rebel naval forces, such as they are, and all material of war, whether on land or water.

I have received several letters from the North asking for information respecting the graves of relatives and friends who have died in the hospitals at Richmond. All Union soldiers who died in Richmond during the war have been buried in Oakwood Cemetery, and from the Summer of 1863 up to the time of our occupation in April last, there have been buried them two thousand six hundred and thirty-six.

In three or four days we shall have for publication a full report of that part of the testimony taken during the trial of the assassins with closed doors. The reasons for withholding this evidence from the public no longer exist, and the Judge-Advocate is now desirous that the greatest publicity be given to it.

The new trade regulation, removing the restrictions on the import and export of nearly all kinds of goods, has had a decidedly favorable effect in business circles here. Parties who have invested in rice are specially pleased at the privilege extended them of shipping that article to the North.

Messrs. MASON Co.'s extensive chair manufactory, at Nos. 186, 188 and 190 Avenue C. was totally consumed, and several tenement dwellings and other buildings in the immediate neighborhood were very seriously damaged by fire and water, at about noon on Saturday.

The State of Ohio Billiard Tournament, which is now being played at Mozart Hall, in this city, has attracted much notice from the billiard public generally, although the attendance thus far has not been so great as that at the late Massachusetts tournament.

Gen. SHERMAN is in greater peril at the present moment than he has been at any time since the war began. He is in danger of seriously impairing the profound respect which his noble devotion to duly throughout the war, has inspired in the breasts of the American people.

Yesterday, in Goldsboro, the place where the first secession flag was raised in the State of North Carolina, and on the fourth anniversary of the passage of the ordinance of secession, by which it was attempted to take the State out of the Union, a Union meeting was held, at which, beside the residents of the town, about three hundred of the inhabitants of the county were present.

Major-Gen. WILSON has ordered that all the Confederate States mules, horses, barness, wagons, and leather, not required for the use of his Cavalry corps, be turned over to Colonel FOSTER, Quartermaster-General, to be distributed amongst the poorpeople as a loan from the United States but returnable to the United States whenever called for by the proper authority.

The following circular was issued to-day by Gen. HOWARD, chief of the Freedmen's Bureau, and approved by the Secretary of War, who orders all military authorities to sustain and to aid the several State Commissioners in the execution of its provisions.

There are but few changes to note at the theatres. The season, indeed, is almost over. After a time we shall, of course, have fresh ventures, but for the present the regular managers are expiring with singular meekness. The hardy raiders from the country will have no difficulty in infusing new life and spirit into the various places of amusement all of which will remain open during the hot weather.

The Assembly resumed proceedings on Saturday morning, pursuant to adjournment, at the Lafayette-avenue Church, Brooklyn. After the customary religious exercises, the Assembly came to order at half-past eight o'clock. The minutes of the previous meeting having been read and adopted, several reports from Committees on Synodical Records of New-York, Iowa, New-Jersey and Western Reserves were received and adopted.

An official dispatch from Secretary STANTON conveys the welcome intelligence that the land and naval forces under command of Gen. KIRBY SMITH have been surrendered to Gen. CANBY. The belligerent power of the rebellion has thus passed away forever, the army of Gen. SMITH having been the only organized force that held out after the surrender of JOHNSTON.

The room of the north and eke of the cast contain several pictures of satisfactory merit. As a rule, too, they are better hung than in the coridor. Human vanity, for which FRANKLIN says we should be thankful, inasmuch as it is the source of much comfort in life, is the same all the world over. He who holds the power of seizing the best place, is generally content to occupy it.

The great two-mile race between Norfolk and Lodi came off yesterday afternoon on the Ocean House Course. A furious wind was blowing at the time, raising clouds of sand. In the first heat the horses kept close together, swung into the homestretch side by side, and crossed the score together, making a dead heat. Time 3:45 .
Steamship Baltimore, Lewis, James Hand. Steamers Artisan, Young, Baltimore, Wm. Dalzell Elizabeth, Fowler, Baltimore, Wm. Dalzell; Burdel Hart, Denton, Mobile, I.B. Gager.

On the 24th instant, the main Ordnance Department, at Mobile, blew up with a terrible explosion. About three hundred persons were instantly killed, and many more wounded, while large numbers were buried in the ruins. Eight entire squares of the city were demolished, and about eight thousand bales of cotton destroyed. The whole city was more or less injured by the explosion, the cause of which was not ascertained.

All those who had the fortune to see the review of the Army of the Potomac and the army of SHERMAN in Washington last week, were greatly struck with the superb physical development of the two hundred thousand young men who then marched past the President.

Yesterday afternoon the Washington Club of Williamsburgh gave their first annual regatta, for double and single scull races, the course being from the foot of Broadway around a stake boat, about one mile and return. There was quite a large gathering of the boating fraternity present to witness the several contests, and great enthusiasm was exhibited by the parties interested. Mr. H. EGGERS furnished...

The Tribune has a special dispatch from NewOrleans, dated the 26th inst., which says:
Gen. SHERIDAN arrived here at noon to-day. The Mississippi and Tennessee Railroad will soon be opened. Two hundred bales of cotton passed for Evansvile to-day.

The steamer Belgian, which left Liverpool at 2:30 P.M. of the 18th, and Londonderry the 19th inst., passed Father Point late this afternoon.

The progress of events has made it necessary for the President to revive, enlarge and amend the amnesty proclamations of Dec. 8, 1863, and of March 26, 1864.

Now that the war is absolutely at an end, we begin to think of the rapidity of its conclusion. Six months ago the Confederacy held half of Virginia, both Carolinas, half of Georgia, Florida, Alabama, Mississsippi, and the greater part of the Trans-Mississippi territory in its grasp. It had a seacoast line, and cruisers ran the blockade with European products.

Mr. JEROME B. LATOUR, of No. 51 East Twentyeighth-street, conductor on the Harlem Railroad, made oath that on Monday afternoon, while he was riding on the rear platform of a Fourth-avenue car, JOHN PRICE stole a gold watch from his waistcoat pocket. The accused, who describes himself as a machinist, 25 years of age, was arrested by Officer DAVIS, of the Twentyninth Precinct, and, after a hearing, denied bail.

The police of the forty-eighth Precinct of Brooklyn and the Fourth Precinct of New-York have thus far arrested three persons on suspicion of being implicated in the murder of ANTONIO DIODATI, and have also discovered that they belong to a gang of counterfeitters whose manufactory was broken up in Sixteenth-street, South Brooklyn, about one week ago.
Steamships California, Bayley, Acapulco, Wakeman, Gookin Dickinson; Cuba, (Br.,) Stone, Liverpool, E. Cunard.

The Board of Supervisors yesterday adopted a resolution tendering the hospitalities of the city to Gen. SHERMAN. A Vote of thanks to Gov. FENTON, was passed, for vetoing certain bills affecting the rights and franchises of the city. A resolution was adopted authorizing the Surrogate to retain for his own use, as compensation for extra services, the fees in certain will cases. Adjourned to Tuesday next.
