The gunboat Hunchback, JOSEPH P. FYERE, Lientenant commanding, from Shorn River, N.C., arrived at this port yesterday. She left New-York in 1861 on her first service; was in the Burnside expedition on Roanoke Island, in which fight she was struk by eight 32-pound shots, which passed completely through her, and also by one 100-pounder, which disabled her engine.

The examination made into the circumstances attending the conspiracy to seize the Panama steamer Collon at this port reveal these facts: Parties on board the Bronles, some 400 in number, onlisted ostensibly to proceed to Arizona, but really to land on the Mexican coast, in the Gulf of California.

Robert M. Martin vs. John C. Fremont. Sammel Hallett Co., of this city, to buy five hundred shares of the Southern Michigan Railroad stock, which was then selling at 80.

It is almost impossible to conceive the number of devices resorted to here by a set of unprincipled sharpers to relieve officers and soldiers of their money. Among the most open and flagrant operators may to numbered a class of men who have recently sprung up and call themselves authorised navy and army claim agents, who advertise to promptly adjust officers accounts and procure their final settement with the government.

Judge NELSON, sitting in the United States Circuit Court, has reversed the decision ren dered in the District Court, in the case of the stock of the Great Western Railroad Company decreed to be forfeited under the Confiscation Acts as the property of LEROY M. WILLY. We publish his decision, in full, in another column.
This day's session of the assassination trial has been more than usually interesting in the matter of incident and pertinency of testimony.

The New York Conference of the African M.E. Church, which commenecd its sessions in Zion Church, met again yesterday morning. The conference embraces upward of 180 churches, principally in New-York and New-Jersey. Superintendent BISHOP presided, and was assisted by Rev. Mr. BROOKS.
The board met, pursuant to adjournment, in their Chamber, number sixteen City Hall.
The People vs. John A. Kennedy.?His Honor Judge CARDOZO was compelled to issue an attachment for contempt yesterday, against John A. Kennedy, Superintendent of the Metropolitan Police Force.

Visitors of both sexes continue to crowd the court-room almost to suffocation. John B. Hubbard, John E. Roberts, and Charles E. Fellows, of Col. Baker's detective force, are in attendance, enforcing order and courteously attending to their appropriate duties.

The Prince of WALES has been to Dublin toopen the great Irish exhibition, and the papers, lacking matter of more importance, are filled with accounts of his visit, the enthusiasm of his reception, and of all that is now and interesting to the English Journalist in the cepital of Ireland, of which most Englishmen know less than they do of Paris, or Rome or New-York.

The Inman steamer City of Baltimore, Capt. MIREHOUSE, which left Liverpool at 2 o'clock on the afternoon of the 17th, and Queenstown on the 18th of May, arrived here yesterday. SHERMAN'S own reputation, if it had shown less of the inspiration which comes of excited feelings.

SUSPENSION OF BUSINESS. To-day having been designated by President JOHNSON as a day of national humiliation and mourning on account of President LINCOLN. Special services will be held in all the churches in this city, and there will be a general suspensions of business.

The formal delivery of the Stonewall to the Spanish authorities was made in the following manner: On the 19th, the Captain presented a memorial to the Captain-General, stating that the repairs to the engine would require more time than he had expected, and for that, and other reasons, he was resolved to give up the vessel, so that the government of Her Majesty the Queen of Spain might dispose of it.

The President's proclamation calling for the devotion of this day to national humiliation, in view of the great national affiction, will be everywhere responded to with heartfelt solemnity. It is true that the people have already mourned, as no people ever mourned before for the loss of a leader. It is true that the hand of Providence, in permitting the dreadful blow, has everywhere been recognized.

GRIFFITH asked the First Lord of the Tressury whether his attention had been drawn to the proclamation of the President of the United States, offering $100,000 for the arrest of Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS; and, whether her Majesty's ministers were prepared to make any representations to the Government of the United States in reference to the treatment of the Southern leaders.

The public commemoration of the death of President LINCOLN to-day, was one of the most imposing demonstrations that has ever taken place in Boston. The military and civic procession was nearly two hours in passing a given point. The buildings were draped with emblems of mourning, and thousands upon thousands thronged the sidewalks by which the procession passed.

At a Union meeting of all the M.E. Churches of the Eastern District of Brooklyn, Rev. C.H. PAYNE, of South Fifth-street M.E. Church, delivered the following discourse in the South Second-street M.E. Church:

A spontaneous and hearty compliance was shown by all the people of New-York and the neighboring cities in the appointment of yesterday, by President JOHNSON, as a day of national humiliation and mourning for the cruel murder of our late President. Not alone was business utterly suspended in the government and municipal offices, but also, by the banks and insurance companies, and by private individuals generally. An all-pervasive Sabbath...

The day of humiliation and prayer was very generally observed here. Business was entirely suspended, the departments all closed, and the city presented the appearance of a very hot Sunday. Appropriate ...

The Fast Day has been kept closed to all business down town. The Banks, Treasury Office, Custom-House and Stock Exchange were not opened at all. The Post-Office opened until noon for the distribution of the foreign mails by the Persia, and the morning mails from the interior.

Troops are being rapidly started homeward from Washington. A number of Western regiments left yesterday morning. The Sanitary Commission is doing excellent work in distributing fresh vegetables among the men in camp, and a still better work inassisting soldiers in settling their accounts and saving them from the wiles of sharpers.

Now that the entire Southern country is actually and completely pacified, and the whole of the vast planting region, from the Roanoke to the Rio Grande, is free for business and open to the commerce from which it has been shut out for four years, the cotton question, suddenly looms up in new and practical importance.

No place at present more than Nashville present stronger proofs of the discontinuance of the war. Time was when at all hours of the day the streets were crowded with Federal soldiers. Now very few blue uniforms are to be seen; but in their place are the men clad in gray. Thousands of rebel soldiers have arrived at and passed through this city during the past two weeks, and the cry is still they come.

Gen. W.T. SHERMAN arrived in this city yesterday morning, at 7 o'clock, and immediately proceeded to the residence of his entertainer, JAMES SCOTT, Esq., No. 64 East Twenty-third-street. The General kept himself quite secluded and quiet the better part of the day, but rode in a carriage to the Central Park during the afternoon, and his presence created considerable excitement among the thousands congregated there. Gen. SHERMAN was accompanied by members of Mr. SCOTT'S family.

OUTRAGE.--The chief officer of the ship Belle Wood recently arrived from Liverpool, was set upon yesterday, and dreadfully beaten by a number of sailor runners. After he became insensible they continued their brutality by jumping on and kicking him until they thought they had killed him.

The master out and depature of troops increases with every day, and the army is rapidly, though almost imporceptibly dissloving. One train containing fifty-five car-loads of troops, left this afternoon for Harrisburgh, by the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad.

Mr. BENJAMIN NOYES of New Haven writes us a letter which we publish in another column, in favor of paying off the National Debt by subscription Mr. NOYES misapprehends our position on the subject. He thinks we are opposed to it;--on the contrary, quite the reverse. We are decidedly in favor of it.

Judge BOND, of the Criminal Court in Baltimore, has just announced his decision on the negro apprenticeship case reported a few days ago. The decision sustains the new constitution of Maryland, and the children are remanded to the custody of their parents.

The temporary residence of Gen. SHERMAN at the house of JAMES SCOTT, Esq., No. 64 East Twentythird-street, was again besieged yesterday morning by our citizens, who took complete possession of the sidewalks at an early hour. Hour after hour the large concourse of eager citizens stood, patiently awaiting the General's appearance, but he did not vouchsafe even a glimpse of himself to his humble but enthusiastic admirers.
At noon, yesterday, the Street Cleaning Commission met in the Mayor's office, for the purpose of opening proposals for cleaning the streets of the city for a term of ten years.

The main ordnance depot of the United States forces stationed here was blown up about fifteen minutes post two o'clock this P.M., making a tremendous report and spreading the wildest consternation throughout the city. The magazine was located in Marshall's warehouse, situated on the corner of Lipscomb and Commerce streets, and the present appearance of the city in that city beggars description.

We learn on good authority that the Mobile and Ohio Railroad is now in operation from Mobile to Corinth. Three trains weekly now run to the latter place from Mobile. Daily trains run from mobile to Okolona.

Among the inscriptions on the banners which were displayed on the occasion of the late great Military Review in Washington, was one in these words: "A debt the country can never pay the debt of gratitude it owes to its heroic soldiers." We may add that if this debt is one which can never be paid, it is one which should never be repudiated.

A case of unusual interest, showing extraordinary tenacity of life, has recently come under our notice. It is that of a man living for six weeks, with a minie ball, weighing one and a quarter ounces in his brain, and after the ball was removed being fully restored to consciousness, with his intellect unimpaired and his physical powers perfect.

The inauguration of the statue of DANTE took place at Florence on Sunday, the 14th ult., in the midst of a display of patriotic feeling and enthusiasm such as have been rarely withnessed in the city of the Medicis. There are many books that obtain a large share of notice on account of the circumstances of their origin and the sources whence they spring. There are a few that command attention from their intrinsic merit. And there are a still smaller number that legitimately combine both classes of attraction. Among them, Lord DERBY'S Homer undoubtedly takes rank.

The innumerable bearings of the social revolution that is in progress in the South, consequent upon the abolition of slavery, will not be fully revealed for ages. Both races are being permanently influenced. Society, in all its relations, is being profoundly affected. Measures are being put in operation whose development will require centuries, and whose transforming effects upon the individual and national character no man can compute.

By Mr. Doester Q. State whether, on the evening of the 14th of April last, you went from Ford's Theatre to the room of Vice-President Johnson. A. Between ten and half-past ten o'clock on that evening I went directly from the theatre to the Vice-President room.
The French Oaks was run on Sunday last at Chantilly: Deliane, 1; Lalla Rooh, 2; La Fortune, 3. Deliane won easily by two lengths.
This court opened for the June term yesterday morning. His Honor the Recorder occupying the bench, and Assistant District-Attorney Robert C. Hutchines appearing as prosecutor for the people.

Last week another of those tragedies which are of such frequent occurrence in our midst, but which are so often hidden from the public gaze, was enacted in the abode of one Mrs. ELLARS, in the rear of No. 85 Columbia-street.
The Inman steamer City of Washington, Capt. BROOKS, which left Liverpool at 2:30 on the afternoon of the 24th, and Queenstown on the 25th May, arrived here yesterday.

A mutilated copy of the " suppressed testimony," surreptitiously obtained, has been permitted to circulate for several days, in some Western country newspapers naturally without the cognizance of the military authorities, who seem to have only been apprised of the facts, when the spurious report was copied into some of the New-York papers. The imposition is rectified in the official report of the "suppressed testimony" which we publish to-day.

The opinion has recently been expressed by Maj.-Gen. JOSEPH JOHNSTON, one of the foremost of the Southern leaders, that a social war between the whites and blacks of the South is probable. There is reason to fear that this expectation widely prevails throughout the South. It was an universally accepted axiom there, long before the rebellion, that emancipation would result in one of two things either amalgamation or extermination.

Since the order issued by the Navy Department reducing the navy to the actual wants of the government, a large number of vessels have been sent home form blockading and other squadrons. These vessels immediately go out of commission, and their officers and crews not being required further are discharged.

The final session of the Osbon Court-martial was held, yesterday morning, at the headquarters of the Department of the East; present, Brig.-Gen. Fitz Henry Warren, Brig.-Gen. Morris, Col. Howe, Col. Day, Lieut.-Col. O'Beirne, and Major Wallis, members of the court; also Major Bolles and Hon. Grenville T. Jenks.

HACK INSPECTION. Capt. BRACKETT'S men, at the City Hall, are inspecting hacks, hotel omnibuses, and other vehicles, with a view of ascertaining whether they are fit to run, and whether licenses ought to be granted their owners. The carriages are driven into the east gate of the Park, and near the Police Station, which is in the southwest corner of the basement of the City Hall.

The trial of the assassins to-day was not remarkable for the development of important facts nor interesting incidents. The weather being intensely hot, the crowd in attendance was not as crushing as it has been for several days past.

The Patterson Races commenced yesterday, under the most brilliant auspices in attendance, and the admirable arrangement of the Passaic Agricultural Association. Although the weather was lowering, the attendance was unprecedentedly great, the grand stand being filled by elegantly-costumed ladies. The first race, a premium of $250, for all ages, mile heats, was won by Arcota in two straight heats; Luertine Second in each, Monmouth third, and Nightlock fourth.

The opening day of the Passaic County's Spring racing meeting was, yesterday, (Tuesday,) under the same management as last season, and with the same unquestionable admirable managerial results. Mr. COLT, the President, Mr. CHISWELL, the Secretary, and the members of the executive department, were indefatigable in their exertions to promote the comfort of all present, and thoroughly conservative in all their arrangements, regarding the racing department of the meeting under their control.

The United States steamer Susquehanna, 16 guns, arrived at Havana, May 29, with the monitors Monticello, Chippewa, Fakee and Wando. The rain Stonewall was in the harbor. Notwithstanding the flaming reports circulated as to her formidable character, the officers of the Susquehanna and our correspondent considered her a miserable failure, and that six broadsides could have finished her.

Lord PALMERSTON, under the pressure of parliamentary questioning, has made a sort of official confession on the subject of United States claims for the depredations of the Alabama. And if his statement of the facts is not marked by peculiar ingenuousness, it is probably as honest and straightforward as might be expected from a First Minister of the Crown under the circumstances.

The steamship Africa, Capt. ANDERSON, from Liverpool at 10 o'clock on the morning of the 27th, via Queenstown on the 28th ult., arrived at this port at 6:30 o'clock this morning. Her dates are two days later than those already received.

THE RECORD OF OATHS. In view of the suppression of the rebellion and the amnesty accorded to the mass of the Southern people, it becomes interesting to know what record is kept by the government of the oaths taken by all who desire to purge themselves of treason. The government requires every oath, subscribed to under the amnesty proclamations, to be forwarded to the State Department.

MRS. LINCOLN'S MEANS.--It is not true, says the Tribune--far from it--that "the late President left an ample fortune." On the countrary, we happen to know that Mr. LINCOLN'S executor and nearest friend, United States Judge DANIEL DAVIS, of Illinois, after taking an account of the estate, has notified Mrs. LINCOLN that she cannot afford to keep house on her means, but must board.--Express.

Assistant District Attorney Hutchings appeared for the people yesterday, and called as the first case that of Paul Valner, a dishonest Tenton, who was indicted for stealing a watch and chain from the person of Henry Strauss, while the said Henry was enjoying his lager at Jones' wood on a warm day in May last. Complainant testified that the value of the watch was $20.

Naturally, the result was a singular failure.

The U.S. steamer Commodore Morris, Acting Master H. BINGHAM, commanding, arrived here on Friday from Hampton Roads, where she left on the 7th. She was put in commission in 1862, at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, and proceeded to Hampton Roads to join the North Atlantic Squadron.

Citizens of the Sixteenth Ward having recently made bitter complaint against a gang of young thieves who were bounty-jumpers as long as the war lasted, and who are now the terror of the West Side above Eighteenth-street, Capt. HEDDEN, of the Sixteenth Police Precinct, instructed his men to watch the fellows vigilantly, at their nest and elsewhere, and lose no opportunity to take them into custody.

GENERAL ORDERS, No. 44. Complaints have been made to these headquarters of the manner in which certain enlisted men of the One Hundred and Twenty-seventh New-York Volunteers, have treated the colored citizens of this city, insulting and, in some cases, beating them.

The Pacific Steam Navigation Company's steamer Bogota arrived at Taboga on the 20th inst. She brings $333,575 in specie, principally for Southampton. Her cargo consisted of the following: For Southampton 6 packages merchandise. For Central America 250 sacks flour, 2 cases. For Liverpool 473 bales cotton, 18 bales wool, 34 sacks mineral, 14 ceroons bark, 8 packages merchandise. For New-York 18 casks oil, 7 cases. For Panama 510 sacks flour, 176 packages merchandise.

The Supreme Court, at General Term, have just rendered an important decision in regard to the title of a rich guano island, known as Howland's Island, situated in the South Pacific Ocean. The amount of money involved is estimated at several million dollars. Presiding Justice INGRAHAM, who delivered the opinion of the court, gave what he regarded as the true construction of the Act of Congress of August, 1856, as to the right of discoverers.

The President has under consideration and will shortly issue a proclamation, intended to put an end to the purchase, by government agents, of products of the late insurrectionary districts, The law of July 2, 1864, provides for the sale to the government of products of States declared in insurrection, and requires in effect that one-fourth of such products shall be given to the government.

We have never intimated a wish or hope that any one charged with assassination, or arson, or poisoning, or willfully disseminating pestilence, or "robbery and murder," should not be tried therefor, and, if found guilty, sentenced and punished. Trying and hanging for treason simply those defeated in our late contest, we do not believe in.

The Duchess County Regiment (One Hundredth and Fiftieth New-York Volunteers) numbering 545 muskets, arrived at 11:30 P.M., on Friday, and took quarters at the Battery Barracks, leaving at noon on Saturday by boat for Poughkeepsie, where a grand reception awaits them. The Paymaster, who has not seen them for seventeen months, will then make his welcome and final visit.

A disastrous fire occurred at Nashville on Saturday last, by which the Quartermaster's depot was destroyed, and with it property valued at ten millions of dollars. The depot contained stores sufficient, to supply an army of 80,000 men for two years. The quantity of rope alone consumed was valued at upward of one million of dollars. The building was the largest in the country, being 800 feet front, and 200 feet deep.

Several regiments returned yesterday, passing rapidly through the city on their way to their respective State rendezvous for final payment and mustering out. MEXICO, Wednesday, May 10, 1865. The death of President LINCOLN and the re ported death of his Secretary of State have been, for the last few days the most preminent topic of conversation, and are still furnishing material for the editorials of the Mexcian press. Every one predicts consequences in keeping with his own interested sympathies.

THE REGATTA OF THE HOBOKEN YACHT CLUB. The eighth annual regatta of the Hoboken Yacht Club will take place on Monday next. The course to be sailed will be from the club-house, Elysian Fields, to a stake-boat moored one mile east of buoy No. 15, off the West Bank. The start will take place at 11 A.M. A number of new yachts are entered, and, with a fair wind, an exciting race may be expected.

A letter to the New-Orleans Times dated Jackson, Miss., June 1, says: Heavy calamities have fallen on Jackson. Numberous columns, shattered and charred, have suggested for the name of the place "Chimneyville."

For some days past Brownsville has been in process of evacuation by the Confederate forces under Gen. SLAUGHTER.

The history of witchcraft illustrates many interesting historical and psychological problems. It is one of those universal supersitions which must evidenity correspond to some of the most deeply-seated tendencies of the human intellect. Every savage tribe in the world appears to have developed in one form or other. Some, indeed, of the beliefs which are incladed under the generic name of witchcraft appear to be still extant amongst us.

The council convened in the city on Wednesday, and was welcomed by Rev. A.L. STONE, D.D., in a brief address in the Old South Church. He referred to the historical associations connected with the building, where many assembled to oppose the stamp act, and to encourage the revolution.

The dedication of the monument erected to the memory of LUTHER C. LADD and ADDISON O. WHITNEY, who fell in Baltimore the 19th April, 1861, which was postponed from the 19th of April last, took place here to-day, with imposing military, masonic and civic ceremonies. The famous Sixth and Thirtythird Regiments performed escort duty, aided by several other military organizations.

We are enabled, through the courtesy of Mrs. W.T. SHERMAN, to publish the following letter from the Lieutenant-General. We are authorized to state that the autograph letter will be given to the fortunate winner of the horse a fact which will materially enhance the value of the prize:

EMPIRE VS. MYSTIC. The contest between these clubs, which took place on the ball-grounds on Sixty-third-street and Third-avenue, on Saturday afternoon, proved to be a signal victory for the Empire Club, and a very good practice game preliminary to the grand match which comes off at Hoboken on Wednesday between the Empire and the champion Atlantics.

REOPENING SOUTHERN POST ROUTES. Postmaster-General DENISON has ordered the post offices at Winchester and Danville, Va., to be reopened. GEORGE W. TAYLOR is appointed Postmaster at the former place, and J.B. LOWRY at the latter. The offices at Smyrna, Fountain Hill, Carthage and Bristol, Tenn., are also ordered to be reopened, and Postmasters have been appointed.

On Saturday evening, Capt. THORNE and a squad of policemen made a raid upon street-walkers and other abandoned femaies whom they found soliciting from the street; from doorways, and from windows in Water, Cherry, Roosevelt and other delightful promenades in the Fourth Ward, and the reconnoissance resulted in the capture of thirty-six persons.

A QUIET SABBATH. Complaint from various quarters having recently been made against the many lager-bier gardens on the upper part of the island, Superintendent KENNEDY instructed the captains of police to enforce an old order forbidding music or dancing at these places of popular resort on the Sabbath.

DROWNED. On Saturday evening FREDERICK FOSTER, a deaf mute from the Deaf and Dumb Asylum at Bloomingdale, was drowned while bathing in the Hudson off One Hundred and Sixty-third-street. His companion, GIFFORD AUDUBON, dove and strove to save him, but the body disappeared before the brave youth could reach it. Young FOSTER, whose body has not yet been recovered, was 11 years of age.
DROUYN DE LHUYS had issued instructions similar to those contained in Earl RUSSELL'S letter, of June 2d, relative to withdrawal of protection to Confederate vessels of war.

This institution held its fourth anniversary meeting last evening, at the Fourternth-street Presbyterian Chured. There was a rather slim attendance, of which the ladies formed the majority. There seemed to exist a pronounced disinclination to be present on the part of the gentlemen whose names appeared on the programme.

We have received a very long letter from the Count JOANNES, nie JONES, concerning a brief notice made recently of his argument before the New-York Literary Society, in defence of JEFF. DAVIS against the charge of treason. A large part of the letter has nothing to do with what purports to be its main object the correction of errors in the report and therefore we do not print it, but notice its leading points.

The warm weather has not interfered materially with the prosperity of the Summer Season. To New-Yorkers it seems strange that our principal places of amusement should still continue to flourish, but those who frequent them are not of the city, and know nothing of its fastidiousness.

The directors of the East Broadway and Dry Dock Railway, having, on Saturday evening, extended their track through Thiry-fourth-street, to connect with the Hunter's Point Ferry, President RICHARDSON, of the Fourth-avenue line, sent a force of about one thousand men to the spot last night, tore up the East Broadway and Dry Dock track, and put down rails belonging to the Fourth-avenue Company.
This morning, at 18 minutes past 1 o'clock, her Royal Highness the Princess of Wales was happily delivered of a Prince.

Troops continue to arrive in the city in large numbers on their homeward march. Many of them merely pass through without stopping, while others make a temporary sojourn at the New-York State Depot, in Howard-street, and the Battery Barracks. It cannot be said that the regular and legitimate industries of the country were prostrated during the war. The crops were duly sown and gathered, and beside supplying our own necessities, there was an abundance to supply the heavy demand for export.

The President has appointed ANDREW J. HAMILTON, of Texas, to be Provisional Governor of that State, and also JAMES JOHNSON, of Georgia, to be Provisional Governor of Georgia. The form of the proclamation is precisely similar to those heretofore appointing Provisional Governors for North Carolina and Mississippi, and the duties prescribed the same.

I had the pleasure of meeting JOHN MINOR BOTTS, to-day. He has changed but little during the past four years, though he shows marks of increased age. But his manner is as prompt and peremptory as ever, and his views of public affairs are marked by the same clearness and boldness which always characterized his political opinions.

At the collation which followed the monument dedication ceremonies in Lowell, yesterday, Gen. BUTLER responded to the toast complimentary to the army and navy. He urged that the confiscated lands forfeited by treason should be given to the soldiers who had put the rebellion down.

PENSIONERS DROPPED FROM THE ROLLS. Under the act of February 4, 1862, the names of all pensioners on the rolls of the States lately in rebellion have been dropped. Those who are prepared to prove their continued loyalty during the whole period of the rebellion, can make application to the Commissioner of Pensions for restoration to the rolls, proving their place or places of residence and means of subsistence since January 1, 1861.

PROBABLE SUICIDE BY DROWNING. The body of Mr. GEORGE MANN, residing at No. 130 Willow-street, was found floating in the water near Fulton Ferry yesterday morning. The Coroner was notified and on being hauled on shore it was at once identified by several persons who had been familiar with him.

As I stated in my letter of last evening, this post is entirely covered with crinoline. It is doubtful if Fifth-avenue, on the brightest and balmiest Tuesday in pleasant May, before the fashion flies have flown to their several resting places, could display such gorgeous toilettes, such magnificent sacrifices on the altar of habit, as the parade-ground of West Point exhibited this afternoon.
Parliament remained adjourned for Whitsun recess, and English politics are consequently unimportant.

President JOHNSON is entitled to great liberality of judgment in his most arduous work of reconstruction more so even than was President LINCOLN in his prosecution of the war. The latter had only to push on steadfastly in a very plain way marked before him.

During the past two days we have reached that extreme of heat to which, in the course of the year, the human pendulum oscillates from the opposite extreme of cold in this pleasant climate. The dog-days are upon us, and, consequently, we cannot too earnestly enjoin upon our readers the necessity of keeping cool. "Keep cool, with the thermometer as 90 degrees?" Most assuredly, you must do so, or your life will be forfeit.

To the People of Ohio: I accepted the nomination of the Union party for Governor of Ohio two years ago, with unfeigned reluctance. I did not seek of desire it, and only accepted from considerations of public duty, which, its view of the state of the country, it clearly imposed upon me.

Almost simultaneously with Mr. SEWARD'S announcement of the withdrawal of rebel belligerent rights by France, comes the news by the European steamer that England has followed the lead of her neighbor, and is "to refuse any longer," as the London Daily News puts it, "to recognize Confederate men-of-war in British ports." Lord RUSSELL'S official announcement of the fact we republish in other columns.

About 4:30 o'clock this afternoon a fire was discovered in the north wing of the United States Hotel. A short time after a second fire broke out in another and distant part of the building. The flames spread with a fearful violence, and in a few moments the north wing was a sheet of fire; and soon after the whole edifice was a mass of flames.

PATRIC CAVANAGH, of No. 227 Tenth-avenue, whom JOHN DRAKE, of No. 296 West Twenty-eighthstreet, stabbed in the breast on Monday night, the 12th inst., having died, Coronor GOVER impanneled a jury at the Twentieth Ward police station, yesterday morning, and heard conflicting testimony concerning the occurrence; but enough evidence was brought against DRAKE to convince the jury that he inflicted the mortal stab, and they so rendered their verdict.

DEATH OF DETECTIVE POLICEMAN KING Mr. ROBERT KING, a well-known and highly esteemed member of the New-York Detective Police Force, died at his dwelling, No. 112 Sullivan-street, at 10 o'clock yesterday morning. Mr. KING was a veteran Policeman, having been a member of the old Municipal Police twenty-five years ago.
The steamer Henry Burden, from New-York, arrived this morning and anchored in Hampton Roads. JOHN MITCHEL, is said to be on board.
At meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday, a resolution was adopted granting to the City Gas Company of New-York the right to lay mains and pipes for conducting gas through the city.

The Thirty-fourth Massachusetts Regiment, numbering 386 men, under command of Col. W.S. LINCOLN, and the Twenty-ninth and Thirtieth Massachusetts Light Batteries, 283 men, in charge of Capt. BINGHAM, arrived in this city during Sunday afternoon, remaining at the Battery Barracks until yesterday.

Yesterday the eighth annual regatta of the Hoboken Yatch Club came off under auspicious circumstances. The weather was fine, but the wind was rather too light to show the dashing sailing quailities of the respective boats, entered for the contest, to advantage; nevertheless, there was no favor to either in this respect.

Our municipal government at the same time illegally paid to the same print more than that sum for city advertising.

A meeting to consider the subject of the reorganization of the rebel States, called by Gov. ANDREW and others, was held in Faneuil Hall to-day. THEOPHILUS PARSONS, Law Professor in Harvard Univiversity, presided. Resolutions were presented declaring that the work of reorganizing government and society in the rebel States requires of the legislative and executive departments of the government the most deliberate exercise of their powers of statesman.

The opponents of reform in the City Fire Department have had all the opportunity they desired to test the validity of the new act. The decision rendered in their favor in the lower Court has been reversed by the Court of Appeals. The Metropolitan Fire Commission is pronounced a legally constituted body, and it assumes henceforth the organization and control of a Fire Police for the city.

An important meeting of the Board of Education was held last evening. The report of the committee recommending that the male department of Grammrr School No. 30 be discontinued, was adopted. The trustees of primary schools are authorized to close them at 2 P.M., throughout the month of July. An increase of 25 per cent. was made to the salaries of certain officers of the Free Academy.

This action is brought to recover the sum of $5,000 damages, which it is claimed were sustained under the following circumstances. In July last the defendant was the owner of premises known as Nos. 103 and 105 Mercer-street, and was at that time engaged in building thereon.

The One Hundred and Thirty-ninth Regiment (Veterans) arrived in this city yesterday afternoon, from Richmond, on the steamer John Brooks. They landed at the foot of Bridge-street and marched to Joralemon-street, rear of the City Hall, where they were dismissed until 2 o'clock this afternoon, when they are to proceed to Hart's Island for the purpose of being paid off.

Despite the threatening appearance of the sky and the heat, the usual crowds of citizens and strangers are thronging this city, giving it that holiday appearance it usually wears upon these festive occasions.

The tenth commencement of this institute was celebrated last evening at No. 126 East Twenty-fourthstreet. The spacious schoolroom was tastefully decorated with flags and bouquets. The majority of the pupils were present, as well as many of their relatives. Rev. Dr. CROSBY presided.

The accounts by the survivors of the late steamboat disaster on Red River, agree in their reflections on the officers of the lost transport for the carelessness and criminal indifference manifested on the occasion. The accounts say the Kentucky, which appears to have been an old weakly craft, had, shortly after leaving Shreveport, been run into the river bank ...

During yesterday the Metropolitan Fire Commissioners filed numerous applications for appointments, and met the Mayor and Comptroller as a Board of Estimates, agreed to ask (it is said) $600,000 for the rest of 1865, and $700,000 for 1866. They also requested Chief DECKER to continue in office, and he agrees to do so. The commissioners are perfectly undisturbed in office, and their administration is not opposed nor likely to be.

WALLACK'S THEATRE. We notice, with some surprise, that the very successful drama of the "Iron Mask" will be withdrawn after to-night's performance. Few plays have been given with more marked success. The press has been uniformly flattering in its notices, and the audiences except when kept back by the extreme heat have been large and thoroughly appreciative.

Admiral DUPONT, the hero of one of the earliest and most brilliant naval victories of the war, died suddenly yesterday morning, at the La pierro House, in Philadelphia. He was a native of New-Jersey, but received his appointment in the navy from the State of Delaware, of which he was a citizen, in December, 1815, nearly half a century ago.

The greatest trotting match that has been witnessed for a very long period will take place at the Fashion Course on Monday next, the stakes being $5,000, heats of three miles each, the contestants being HIRAM WOODRUFF'S famous Long Island horse Dexter, and the justly celebrated Stonewall Jackson, of Hartford. (The latter must not be confounded with his namesake who has trotted repeatedly on the Island.)

TRADE WITH THE SOUTH. To meet the necessities of trade with the port of New-Orleans, the New-York Mail Steamship Company have put on that line the steamship Mississippi, of 2,009 tons burden. She is fast filling up, and will sail from Pier No. 46 North River on Tuesday next. The Mississippi is an A No. 1 ship, very fast, and has magnificent accommodations for first-class passengers.

N.M. ELLIOTT was the only person pardoned by the President to-day. There were nine petitions filed, among them one from Gen. D.M. DU BOSE, of Georgia. The others are persons unknown to the public. The Cabinet being in session to-day, under the rule visitors were excluded from the Executive mansion, and consequently the numerous seekers for pardon failed to get an audience with the President.

A terrific explosion occurred in Chicago June 19, when the boiler of the tug Fanny Stafford exploded. The engineer was instantly killed. His body was blown out of sight, and has not been seen since. The Captain was blown from the storn of the tug to the vessel in tow, a distance of forty feet. Two wheelsmen and a deckhand were also blown into the headgear of the vessel, where they clung fast.

In a few days more, at every popular gathering in honor of the National Anniversary, we shall hear the stately utterances of our Declaration of independence. Again we shall listen to those simple but noble words which, while they record the high and solemn resolutions in which the nation had its being, avow "a decent respect to the opinions of mankind."

THE ONE HUNDRED AND THIRTY-NINTH REGIMENT. The flags of the City Hall and Court-house were displayed, yesterday, in honor of the One Hundred and Thirty-ninth Regiment, which arrived the day previous, and were dismissed to meet again at 2 o'clock P.M.

Boston has led off in an imperative demand upon President JOHNSON, that he shall exact negro suffrage at the hands of the Southern States, as a condition of their being permitted to belong to the Union. Hon. RICHARD H. DANA made the ablest and most careful argument on this subject on that occasion. We reprint it in another part of this morning's paper.

DANA at the reconstruction meeting in Faneuil Hall yesterday afternoon: Mr. PRESIDENT: It was hoped by those who have summoned us together this morning, that a voice might go out from Faneuil Hall to which the people of the United States could listen as in times past.

All who are in any way conversant with the soldiers in camp and field, will remember the oft-repeated expression of "wait till we get home, and see how we'll straighten matters." During the continuance of the war, now practically closed, this feeling has reigned paramount, and no one knowing the force of the soldiers' character will be surprised that the movement so often foreshadowed, has at length found utterance and a definite shape.

The Thirteenth New-Hampshire, Third Massachusetts Heavy Artillery, One Hundred and Sixth New-York and Tenth Vermont Regiments, arrived in the city yesterday. The Vermont boys remain at the Battery barracks until to-days, when they will depart for home. The Thirteenth NewHampshire, sailed for Boston in the State of Maine; the Third Massachusetts took steamer for Boston, and the One Hundred and Sixth NewYork, left by special steamer for Albany, yesterday.

CUSTER on the first day of the review, directing that the horse be delivered immediately to the claimant. We are authorized to say that no such order has been issued.

The congenial work of receiving and welcoming regiments at the fair still goes on. The weather on Saturday morning was oppressively warm, but more fans were called into requisition, and no halt in the proceedings was made. About 11 o'clock the Eightysixth Regiment, which arrived in Chicago last Sunday and went into barracks at Camp Fry, was drawn up in line along Washington-street.

In the eleven divorce suits below entitled, Justice INGRAHAM yesterday confirmed the reports of the referees, and granted the judgments of divorce prayed for by the plintiffs. In five of the suits the wives are plaintiffs, and in six the husbands appear as such:

The great fair continues to be a noun object of interest. It closes to-morrow evening. It is regarded as a success the receipts being about $300,000. It will probably yield more than this sum when everything on hand is disposed of. The proceeds are to be divided between the Soldier's Home and the Christian and Sanitary Commissions.

There will be several changes at the theatres to-night, which we proceed to note. At Wallack's the "Iron Mask" has been withdrawn, and "Oliver Twist" takes its place. GENERAL ORDERS No. 8. 1. Until the civil authority is fully restores no more public meetings of citizens will be held within the limits of this command to establish a fixed price for negro labor, or make distinetions prejudicial to the interests, and limiting the freedom of the blacks. Such meetings are combinations which will result in injury to both parties. The proceedings in this report of those already held are disapproved.

MICHAEL CORNER was tried yesterday for robbery in the first degree. The indictment charged him with taking $35 by force and violence from the person of PATRICK BARRET, at a drinking saloon in Washington-street, on the 8th day of June inst. The evidence, however, only showed that the prisonor had committed an assault on the complainant. He was convicted of this clience, and sentenced to pay a fine of $50, to stand committed until paid.

The Buenos Ayres Standard says the project started to connect Valparaiso, along the west coast of South America, to Panama, thence to the United States, meets with much favor in the countries interested. R.E. GOLDSBOROUGH is the civil engineer.

Despite the rain of last night, the advocates of this measure assembled in large numbers at Clinton Hall, the main object of it being the closing of the stores on Broadway and Canal-street at 3 o'clock on Saturdays, during the months of July and August. MR.M.W. MURPHY presided, and briefly stated the purposes of the meeting.

The sixth anniversary of the Antioch Baptist Church, of this city, was celebrated on Sunday evening last. The annual sermon was preached at 10 A.M., by Rev. HALSEY W. KNAPP, from Luke viii.: 25. "where is your faith?" "Faith its basis, effects and the importance of its possession," was ably and elequently presented by the preacher.

Maj.-Gen. HARTSUFF, commanding the District of Nottoway, Virginia, has prohibited meetings of planters and other combinations to regulate the wages of freedmen. There have been several meeting in that part of the State, at which the planters agreed to pay only $5 per month for first-class field hands, and only $2.50 a month for second class the men to find their own clothing, and all time lost by sickness to be deducted from their pay.

CITY RAILROAD CASUALTIES. On Sunday evening PETER RYAN, who was riding up town on a car attached to dummy engine No. 3 of the Second-avenue Railroad line, endeavored to jump from the rear platform when at the corner of Seventy-seventh-street. RYAN stumbled and fell, one of the wheels of the car passing over one of his feet and crushing it fearfully.

We have before us, as we write, a package of letters which furnish a truly terrible picture of the condition of the people of Northern Georgia. These letters come from the post and district commanders at Chattanooga, Atlanta and Macon, and represent a state of affairs which is appalling, while the representations possess an authority which allow no room for doubt as to the reality of the scenes they describe.

The British official mind, as we learn from the London Daily News, received last night, is still manfully struggling with the question of enabling passengers in railway carriages to communicate with the guards. Nothing, however, like a solution of this perplexing problem has yet been reached; and, judging from the tone of our London cotemporary, the case shows less hopeful progress than could be wished. The editor says:

Within a week or ten days, there has been a decided improvement in the financial position and prospects of the nation. Europe has again renewed its demand for our government goldbearing bonds, as well as for our flour, grain, provisions, cotton, tobacco and petroleum, thus giving foreign exchange a most desirable turn in our favor, and relieving us of any urgent necessity of making any further considerable shipments of specie.

The speech Of REVERDY JOHNSON against, and that of Judge BINGHAM in defence of the jurisdiction of the military tribunal now trying the assassins of the President, were both very able; but so far as they related to the general question, whether this government possesses, during war, unrestricted war powers, they were out of time. That question belongs to the past. It has been settled.

The visitor to Saratoga, this year, will find, on stepping from the cars at the depot, his first view startling as well as saddening. A mass of blackened and unsightly ruins covers the spot on which the grand old pile of the world-renowned United States Hotel stood, its spacious open portal, a few feet from where the cars stop, inviting the newly-come to enter, through shaded and picturesque avenues, and enjoy its unstinted hospitalities.

It does not seem at all wonderful to us when we see the aristocracy, the Tories of Europe, urging strenuously that JEFF. DAVIS has done nothing calling for punishment. But we must admit to some surprise at the tone with which the Liberals of Europe speak on the subject, and we cannot but think that they do not rightly consider the just bearings of the case.

The President's health was such to-day that he was unable to receive visitors at 9:30 o'clock this evening. He is somewhat better, but it is doubtful whether he will be able to attend to any business this week, though he expects to be present at the Cabinet meeting tomorrow.

Advices from Matamoras to the 15th inst. confirm the report of the defeat of NEGRETE after his unsuccessful attempt on Matamoras. NEGRETE is reported to have lost 700 killed, and 2,000 men taken prisoners. The Matamoras Commerce asserts that JUAREZ is buying up old arms in the United States. There were plenty of goods at Matamoras waiting a market.

The usual routine of commencement week is broken at Trinity this year by the ceremonies connected with the inauguration of a new president of the college. The order of this commonly known at other institutions as "Alumni day" are varied to meet the requirements of the occasion.

Henceforth when we speak of the army of the Potomac, it will be as of a thing of the past. Its immediate commander, Gen. MEADE, has issued a farewell order, in which he announces that by command of the president, that army has ceased to exist. Its work is done, its record is closed, and now only its traditions and its history remain.

The popular demand for the new series of the National 7-30 Loan has been quite active through the week, especially in the line of the orders for the smaller denominations of the notes, which have reached a much higher daily average than in any week since the 7-30 Loan was first opened to the public.

BLAKE, of California, read a very interesting paper before the Travelers' Club of this city, at their splendid suite of Club-rooms, No.1 West Fourteenthstreet. Prof. W. P. BLAKE, of California, lectured last evening before the members of the Traveler's Club, at their rooms, corner of Fourteenthstreet and Fifth-avenue. The subject of the lecture was an account of the explorations of the Professor in Russian America, and was found to be of interest and value by the select audience present. Prof. BLAKE leaves to-day for his home in California.

C.C. CLAY has been taken sick; his imprisonment is evidently telling on his health. Dr. BANCROFT attends him. The doctor is doing all he can to restore the prisoner's health. He is suffering from no particular disease, but is laboring under general physical prosrtation or debility.

The citizens of Georgia are coming together in public meeting at prominent points all over the State, and giving expression to their desires and wishes to reorganize civil government, and restore the State to it old-time peace and prosperity. We have no prevailing sickness in Charleston at the present time, and the indications are that we shall escape the yellow fever and other epidemic diseases this season. GENERAL ORDER No. 45. I. In obedience to order from the Headquarters Department of the South, General Order Nos. 29 and 34, current series from these headquarters, which establish a system of free public schools for white children alone are hereby revoked. These school have been organized by the military authority, and supported by a military fund, while the education of the colored children has been left to private effort and sustained by charitable contributions.

The Paris journals publish the following: "Letters received here from Washington state that the enrollments for Mexico has proved a complete failure, and that President JOHNSON had decided to maintain friendly relations with European and neighboring Powers. In yesterday's sitting of the Lower House of the Reichsrath, Herr VON SCHMERLING gave some reassuring explanations relative to Art. 13 of the Constitution, which empowers the Ministry at the time the Reichsrath may not be sitting to take certain urgent measures, for which they are, however, bound to render an account to the House upon its reassembling.

Our latest advices from Santo Domingo state that the Spanish troops have almost entirely abandoned the island. They are continually arriving at Puerto Principe, Sagua and other points. Before evacuating Monte Christi, the Spaniards blew up the forts of San Pedro and San Francisco, and other defensive works which they themselves had built.

MANN and DANIEL STRATTON, Jr., founders, managers, stockholders, President, Directors Co. of the United Service Petroleum and Mining Company, which was to have taken place before Justice DODGE, yesterday afternoon, has been postponed to to-morrow morning, at 10 o'clock. The case of the United Service Petroleum and Mining Company, the officers of which are charged with defrauding the public by means of false representations, was resumed before Justice DODGE yesterday. A splendid banquet was given to Major-Gen. SHERMAN, at the Masonic Temple, on Monday evening. The General addressed the guests in one of his happiest efforts, and distinguished military and civil orators contributed their efforts to the occasion.

The Fourth in Brooklyn was celebrated by sa lutes in the morning, ringing of bells, a military parade, and fireworks in the evening; in addition to which there was a meeting at the Academy of Music, and a happy time among the sick and wounded sailors at the Marine Hospital.

The Ninety-first Veteran New-York Regiment numbering 676 men and officers, under the command of Brevet Brig.-Gen. J. TARBELL, arrived yesterday noon, from Washington by the New-Jersey route. Landing at the foot of Cortlandt-street, they proceeded up town to the rooms of the State Agency corner of Centre and Grand-streets, where all needful accommodations and refreshments were afforded them. The regiment subsequently left by chartered steamer for Albany, where they will be mustered out.

Some of our cotemporaries, both Republican and Democratic, assume that President JOHNSON is opposed to extending the right of voting to negroes. Upon this assumption he is sharply assailed by the former, and as loudly praised (which is much more damaging) by the latter. It seems to us that both are some- what hasty in forming their opinions.

Police trials were simply sepulchral. The usual multitude of officers were in attendance, but without counsel; for they have ascertained that in this rattlebrained tribunal this court wherein perplexing precedents and the musty tomes of the jurists are not recognized the gentlemen of the green satchel can render them no service, and that their money ex- pended upon counsel is, briefly, money thrown away.

The Emperor is still at Puebla, where the climate, as well as the people, seem to be better adapted to his health and taste. Indeed, there has been considerable talk as to removing the Imperial residence and making Puebla the capital. Mexico is not as loyal as it might be; it is not as clean as it might be, and its people are really backward as far as improvements are concerned.

Mrs. MARY SMITH, of No. 533 Fifth-street, while looking at gold-fish in the Bowery, near Rivington-street, felt a hand in her pocket. She seized it, and the pickpocket, dropping her wallet, begged her pardon; but Mrs. SMITH, a unable to perceive the neuter pronoun, turned the fellow over to Policeman LONG, of the Tenth Ward, and the prisoner, who rendered his name as WILLIAM RILLEY, was committed for examination.
The new steamship Manhattan, Capt. TURNER, from Vera Cruz 28th June, and Havana July 3, arrived yesterday afternoon thus making the trip from Havana in three days and twenty-four hours.

The latest news from Hayti, by way of Santiaago de Cuba, represent the insurrection as progressing, and GEFFRARDS had suffered some reverses. He, however, boldly faces his enemies and heads his army. Among the insurgents are said to be some Dominicans.

Trade in Charleston has assumed wonderful proportions for this season of the year. The railroads are being rapidly opened, and in a short time we shall doubtless see the streets filled with drays ladon with cotton, rice and other products, and the wharves completely barricaded with merchandise. We are all looking forward to a busy season next Fall.

The frequent complaints of planters that they are burdened with helpless women and children whose natural protectors are upon the plantations of their neighbors, are useless, it having already been announced in General Orders, No. 19, from these headquarters, that families should be brought together on the same farm, or satisfactory arrangements made for their support by persons employing the husband and father.

THE WHITE MOUNTAINS AND LAKE MEMPHREMAGOG. A trip to the mountains and lake is as delightful an excursion as can be taken at this season. Passengers can leave the city by the New-Haven steamboat at 3:15 P.M., lodge at Springfield and arrive at the mountains the following evening; or, by rail, they can leave the New-Haven depot at Twenty-seventh-street at 12:15 P.M., sleeping at White River Junction and arriving at their destination the following afternoon.

The Fourth of July was celebrated in true Northern style in Newbern, which excited the amazement of the natives and delight of the colored population both of whom were present in thousands to witness the wonderful scenes. CHARLES E. FITCH, of the Newbern bar, was the orator of the day, and delivered an eloquent address.

Without being alarmists, and with no disposition toward fault-finding, we heartily concur with the Common Council in solemnly adjuring the Street Cleaning Commission to delay no longer such effective measures as shall remove at once the pestilence-breeding offal which now clogs most of our streets. The danger of further neglect is imminent and appallingly real.

GARROTING BY THE EIGHTH WARD GANG. Lieut. GEORGE H. GREEN, of the Thirty-fifth Regiment United States Infantry, left LOVEJOY'S Hotel on Sunday afternoon, and shortly thereafter accepted WILLIAM WIGGIN'S invitation to explore the dens of Greene and Mercer streets. The couple drank copiously in every house that they visited, and Lieut. A Shreveport letter to the New-Orleans Times, dated the 4th inst., reports a heavy storm in Louisiana and Texas. The Red River was rising rapidly, and there was a prospect of navigation lasting till August. The stands of Gen. BANKS are working against the Wells' party. The former wish a provisional government the latter object to it. Mr. COVODE, who was recently here, will report against WELLS.
A meeting of the engineers and firemen of the old department was held last evening at Firemen's Hall, Chief Engineer DECKER presiding. About one hundred members were present.
The Isthmus is almost barren of news, the only item being an attempt to get up another revolution, which is still pending, but likely to end in smoke.

A few days since we spoke in these columns of the dreadfull crowded condition of the City of New York, of the great want existing for houses in which respectable working people of limited incomes could reside; of the enormous height of rents; of the unhealthfulness, inconvenience and general wretchedness of the tenement houses in which half a million of our inhabitants live, and of our dismal prospects for the future in these regards.
It is astonishing what a difference it makes wheather we discuss a question as a matter of theory or a matter of fact: In the light of "cold reason," or from the stand-point of experience.

The annual examination of the pupils of the De la Salle Institute, under the direction of the "Brothers of the Christian Schools," is now progressing each evening, and the proceedings are very gratifying. The examinations are held in the open air, in the court or yard of the school, beneath a spacious canopy, and by these means the audience do not suffer from heat.

Much excitement was created at East Albany this afternoon by the shooting of a prisoner in the Police Court-room. Last Friday afternoon two girls, named ANN and BRIDGET BURNS, went to the woods a short distance from their home to pick berries. While thus engaged they were seized by four men, who repeatedly violated their persons. BRIDGET, who is but fifteen years old, cannot live, it is said.
We give the following interesting extracts from late foreign exchanges. The speculations on the condition of our country, from a tory point of view are amusing from their very absurdity.

There are few of us who have forgotten that famous, or rather that infamous address of JOHN C. BRECKINRIDGE, when, having safely skedaddled into the Confederate lines, he denounced President LINCOLN in bitter and almost beastly language, and detailed what things were not to be done while the gallant sons of Kentucky could "make that State sing to the music of their rifles."
The races are postponed until to-morrow on account of the rain.

The Commissioners met yesterday, and expelled from the department THOS. C. KENNEDY, foreman of Engine No. 49, who was charged with assaulting JOHN O'DONNELL, of No. 48 Hose Company, and JAMES OWENS and JOHN SHELLEY, of No. 45 Engine Company, charged with insubordination.
The U.S. gunboat Ashuelot, Capt. DAVIS, arrived here last evening from Eastport, bringing Hon. FREDERICK A. PIKE.

A special dispatch from Nashville to the Commercial, of this city, announces the arrest of Hon. EMERSON ETHERIDGE, at Columbus, Ky., by the commandant of the military post in that city, on the charge of delivering incendiary speeches in Tennessee.

The convention now in session at Detroit will be best judged of by the result of its deliberations. But it is not anticipating these deliberations, nor the issues which may arise out of these deliberations, if we say that this Commercial Convention is, in some respects, the most remarkable extra-constitutional assembly of our time.

THE PRESIDENT VISITS ADMIRAL DAHLGREN. The President accompanied by the members of the Cabinet, Hon. PRESTON KING, Gen. MUZZY and Mrs. PATTERSON, and other members of the President's family, made a trip this afternoon upon the Pawnee, Commodore DAHLGREN'S flagship. The party left at 5 o' clock and returned at 8 o'clock this evening, highly pleased with the trip and the hospitality of the officers of the vessel.
The ship Wheeler, with a cargo of tobacco, which was aground for some days in James River, has been lightened, and arrived here to-day.

Hon. HIRAM WALBRIDGE of New-York, was chosen President of the Trade Convention. Hon. HANNIBAL HAMLIN and Mr. WALKER, of Chicago, were chosen Vice-Presidents at large, and a Vice-President was appointed for each State and the British Provinces.

The people of South Carolina are rejoiced that at length they were favored with a Provisional Governor. The impression prevailed to a considerable extent that the government had decided to let this State remain out in the cold, but now all will admit that President JOHNSON is by no means disposed to withhold civil government from this State any longer than such a course would be for the best interests of the people.

Yesterday morning the fine exhibition room of Grammar School No. 11, in West l7th-st., was well filled by the visitors desirous of witnessing the exercises of the graduating class of 1865. The Hall itself was beautifully adorned by a profusion of evergreen wreaths and festoons, and a large number of bouquets, cages of canaries and globes of gold fish.
The Government of San Salvador has withdrawn the exequator of Dr. BERNEARD, Consul of Prussia, at San Miguel, and forbidden him to return to the Republic.

Acting Rear-Admiral S. P. LEE has reduced the Mississippi Squadron to the peace basis. Fifteen vessels are retained in the inland service of the government. The Tempest is to be the flagship, and the transport Gen. Lyon, towboats Samson and Brown, and tug Thistle are attached to her. The First Division of the squadron has been placed under command of Lieut.-Com. E. Y. McCAULEY, and consists of the Hastings, Abena and Kale.
